title: BRIDGES IS TERMED ARROGANT BY BUTZ
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 29 (AP))Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz described Harry Bridges today as a selfish, arrogant, publicbedamned labor leader and said that the recent West. Coast dock strike had cost farmers a net income of $1million.

title: L.I.R.R.10Trip Tickets Ruled Valid
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 29The Long Island Rail Road was ordered in State Supreme Court here today to honor its 10day trip tickets for a year from the purchase date stamped on the back.

title: House Votes Federal Authority To Set Noise Level Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The House, voted today to give the Federal Government the power partly to curb noise pollution in the nation. The rollcall vote was 356. to 32.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ANT ART More than 2 million ants, surely the most grandiose cast in town, are the stars of Army Ants Patterns and Structures, Alan Sonfist's exhibition now running, actually running, around a large rectangular enclosure that fills a first floor room at Automation House, 49 East 68th Street. Mr. Sonfist realizing that ants are not too unlike humans, places food, apple cores mostly, in various parts of the sandcovered enclosure and gets them to shape up in different geometric patterns. The ants are rather better behaved than Man at buffet dining and the effect is possibly esthetic depending upon the beholder, and they are absolutely hypnotic, even when they were visited during an uncreative midday. One watches the sinuous stream of traffic, with almost never a tieup and wonders what makes the insects so orderly. The exhibition ends March 17, by which time the artist says the ants will have selected and stabilized their own patterns rather than the ones designed (and shown in a wall display) by Mr. Sonfist. The viewing is done over a high wall surrounding the enclosure, which is lined with an unscalable plastic to prevent ant leakage The ants, who use their own bodies as building modules, were brought here from Panama and are bigger than our usual picnic ants. The hours for visiting are 9:30 A.M. to 7 P.M., Monday through Friday. Admission is free.

title: Senate Foreign Relations Unit Approves $3 Rise in Gold Price
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The Senate Foreign Relations Committee added its approval today to the legislation, already unanimously approved by the Banking Committee, formally devaluing the dollar by raising the price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce.

title: FILMS ON CASSETTES DUE IN HOTEL ROOMS
description: A movie in an individual cassette projector will be available through room service for patrons of the Commodore Hotel starting next week.

title: ANGELA DAVIS JUDGE RULES ON RED ISSUE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 29 (UPI)Judge Richard Arnason ruled today that a prospective juror in the Angela Davis murderkidnapping trial could not be removed solely because he did not like Communism.

title: Achievement Scholarships Won By Negro Students Over Nation
description: The names of the winners in the Eighth National Achievement Scholarship Program for Outstanding Negro Students were announced yesterday by Edward C. Smith, president of the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: CONFEREES ADOPT JOB RIGHTS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 A HouseSenate conference committee approved legislation today that would give the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission the power to seek court enforcement of its findings of job discrimination and place employes of state and local governments within the commission's jurisdiction.

title: Liberty to See
description: In a valuable report on public broadcasting, the American Civil Liberties Union declares that the more than 200 stations making up the aspiring fourth network are faced with A Question of Survival. That is exaggerationbut useful in pointing up the dilemma how these stations are ping to resist pressure against public affairs and political programs while at the same time obtaining Federal funds.

title: Books of The Times
description: So many of us have lost our religion, our feeling of ethnic or national identity, our instinctive moral orientation, that the coordinates of our spirit are becoming increasingly rootless and vagueperhaps even precarious. One moreand perhaps finalroot we seem in danger of losing is our sense of place, and we can ill afford it. For the places we have roots in, as David Brower sees it, and the flavor of their light and sound and feel when things are right in those places, are the wellsprings of our serenity. A place, says the poet Richard Wilbur in his Introduction, is a fusion of human and natural order. We need that fusion. We need it because it is as close as many of us can come to a religion. To be continuous with nature, intimate with it, is immensely reassuring in a world of abstractions and inconceivable distances. As Spengler said, religion is tension between man and the universe that man can love. Our placeS are the bases of that tension, and we need to love them just as much as we need to love each other. Otherwise, we are intellectual nomads who walk the earth like ghosts, who have lost the landscape inside themselves and will never find it outside.

title: Memorial to a Radical Leader Written by Fugitive
description: A profile of Samuel Melville, who was sent to Attica prison for his role in a series of 1969 bombings in New York City and killed during last September's uprising at the prison, has been written from underground by Jane Alpert, herself a fugitive from justice for her role in the bombings.

title: Volunteer Ulster Soldier Killed in Home
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 29 (UPI)  The British Army said that two gunmen shot to death a member of the volunteer Ulster Defense Regiment in his home tonight and wounded his 11yearold daughter in a leg.

title: Executive Chages
description: Edwin C. Fox has been elected president of James Talcott Factors and executive vice president, a member of the board and of the. executive committee of James Talcott, Inc., the parent company. He succeeds Thomas J. McGann, who as executive vice president of James Talcott, Inc., will head internenational factoring operations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yield Falls at Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said to day it, issued $11.5million in fourmonth commitments at an average yield of 7.638 per cent at its auction for conventional mortgages, down from 7.741 per cent at the last such auction two weeks ago.

title: VINCENT T. MULLIGAN
description: JAMESBURG, N. J., Feb. 29 Vincent T. Mulligan, officer in charge of Marshall Plan funds for the French American Banking Corporation in New York at his retirement in 1952, died Saturday in Princeton Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: FREGOSI'S DEBUT: LIKE OLD TIMES
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29  Jim Fregosi, who has 1,405 games at shortstop, made his debut at third base today in a New York Mets camp game. He made two errors, batted in two runs and was immediately, labeled the man for the job in the classical Met mold.

title: Sabin Has Heart Surgery
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 29 (Reuters)Dr. Albert. E. Sabin was reported in satisfactory condition today in the Cleveland Clinic Hospital after heart surgery Dr. Sabin who developed the oral polio vaccine is 65 years old. It was believed that the gelation involved removing veins from. his legs and using them to bypass a blocked coronary artery.

title: Proposed Sales Tax Killed
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 29 (AP)The New Hampshire House killed today a proposal for a 2 per cent sales tax. The measure would have imposed the tax on retail sales and provided a local option for cities and towns to levy additional sales taxes of up to 1 per cent.

title: Hamilton Says City Won't Use Layoff Scare to Push Albany
description: Deputy. Mayor Edward Hamilton said yesterday that the Lindsay administration had no, plans this. year to paint a horror picture of massive layoffs and cuts. City services to push the State Legislature into voting funds to balance the city budget.

title: Swift Net Declines For First Quarter Despite Sales Rise
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 29 Although Swift & Co. earnings for the first quarter of the fiscal year were down 10 per cent from the record of year earlier, sales and profits should increase in the full year, Robert W. Reneker, president, said at the annual meeting today.

title: 2 Cubans Refused Asylum By Canadians in Havana
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 29 (UPI)Two armed Cubans invaded the Canadian Embassy. in Havana today and held two employes hostage in an effort to gain political asylum, the External, Affairs Department reported. They were finally convinced to put their weapons down and leave the embassy grounds.

title: BILL WOULD BAR VOTE ON SABBATH
description: Plans to hold antipoverty elections on, the Jewish sabbath would be forestalled by legislation introduced in the City Council yesterday at the request of the Lindsay administration.

title: Injured Foot Sidelines Liguori for 6 Weeks
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (AP)Marty Liguori said tonight that his left foot was so badly injured that he has been instructed not to run forat least six weeks.

title: I.B.M. Building Bombed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP)An explosion of a small pipe bomb today damaged a Harvardowned building used under lease by the International Business Machines Corporation. Two hours later a man telephoned The Associated Press to say the bomb had been planted by the Black Underground Military. Later, however a man identifying himself as James Smith of Boston, who said he was the area coordinator of the Black Underground Military denied his organization had any connection with the bombing.

title: Reagan Calls on California To Reinstate Death Penalty
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 29 (Reuters)  Gov. Ronald Reagan demanded today reinstatement of capital punishment, which was recently declared unconstitutional by the California Supreme Court.

title: Last DoubleDecker on L.I.R.R. Joins Others in the Scrap Heap
description: The last of the Long Island Rail Road's 63 doubledecker commuter cars was sent to the scrap heap yesterday after it had completed its trip to Penn Station. On the return route, the cars were made up of the first group of 150 new Metropolitan cars, of which the railroad already had 620.

title: MISSILE SITE HIT ON RAID IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 1 (AP) An American fighterbomber attacked a North Vietnamese missile site yesterday 40 miles north of the demilitarized zone along the line between the two Vietnams.

title: Hudson Pension Unit Put In Receivership Under Court Order
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 29 Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Lamer today ordered the Hudson County employes pension fund into temporary receivership on the application of Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr, who contends the fund is being grossly and fraudulently mismanaged.

title: 2D SUSPECT SEIZED IN POLICE SHOOTING
description: A second man was arrested last night and charged with attempted murder in the shooting Feb. 19 of Patrolman Richard A. Gamble at the Brooklyn Terminal Market, the police said.

title: I.L.O., in Crisis, Urges Meany To Press Congress on Funding
description: GENEVA, Feb. 29  NonCommunist trade unionists on the governing body of the International Labor Organization have appealed to George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, to urge Congress to appropriate funds for the dues that the United States owes the agency, an affiliate of the United Nations.

title: FRANCIS X. KENNY
description: Francis X. Kenny, business representative of the Bartenders Union of New York City, died apparently of a heart attack on Monday at his home, 768 Nightingale Road, West Hempstead, L.I He was 55 years old.

title: Adelphi Dismisses Bedell, Its Director of Athletics
description: Adelphi University, which has a track team the equal of almost any and the envy of many, yesterday lost its athletic director. James L. Bedell was suddenly dismissed by Randall P. McIntyre, the acting president, effective at the end of the current academic year.

title: PRICES OF FUEL OIL PARED BY HUMBLE
description: The Humble Oil and Refining Company, the largest United States supplier of heavy industrial fuel oil, announced yesterday price cuts of 20 to 30 cents a barrel. The company, subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reduced prices by 30 cents a barrel on No. 6 oil with 1 per cent or less sulphur. by 30 a barrel and by 20 cents a barrel on other higher sulphur fuels.

title: MANIADAKIS IS DEAD; GREEK SECURITY AIDE
description: ATHENS, Feb. 29Constantine Maniadakis, chief of security under Greece's prewar Metaxas dictatorship who dubbed his country's present leaders a bunch of amateurs, died in hospital yesterday after a brief illness.. He was 78 years old.

title: Views Given to Congress By Radical Economists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The relatively new school radical economists had its first fullfledged, hearing Congress today. Three members of the schoolwhich believes basically that most of the nation's problems are inherent in the capitalist system itselftestified before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, which wound up its annual hearings on the President's economic report.

title: Text of 1954 U.S. Treaty With Taiwan
description: The Parties to this Treaty, Reaffirming their faith in the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations and their desire to live in peace with all peoples and all Governments, and desiring to strengthen the fabric of peace in the West Pacific Area,

title: EUROPEANS RAN STOCK UNIT IN U.S.
description: Four major European banks announced yesterday, plans to set up a new, jointly owned securities company in the United States.

title: Maudling Dismisses Proposal
description: LONDON, Feb. 29, (Reuters)  Home Secretary Reginald Maudling today rejected Senator Kennedy's call for the withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland.

title: Decline Shown In Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Feb. 29 (Reuters)The dollar closed lower today at 303,30 yen after rising to 304.20 yen on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today, compared with 303.95 yen at yesterday's close.

title: JUMEZ, A GUITARIST, PLAYS VILLA LOBOS
description: JeanPierre Jumez, a young (28 years old) and welltraveled guitarist from France, presented an interesting program Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Although Villa Lobos was the featured composer (Preludes, Etudes, Choros 1 and Legende d'Amazonie), Mr. Jumez included a number of unusual contemporary French items by Sauguet Jolivet and Poulenc.

title: Homecoming
description: President Nixon deserves great credit for his initiative in reversing this country's sterile and unrealistic policy toward China. While there will long be argument over the relative merits of summitry versus less spectacular diplomatic approaches, disagreements over the method cannot obscure the potential benefits to be derived from the President's journey to Peking.

title: Red Smith
description: The most potent single scoring weapon in the National Football League in 1971 was the left foot of an undersized necktie salesman who can say charge it to the Dolphins in Greek, Turkish, Armenian and English, but cannot run, pass, tackle or block. Garo Yepremian, the AllAmerican Boy from Cyprus, won preeminence in the great American game by kicking 28 field goals and converting 33 points after touchdown for a total of 117 points. That's, almost twice as many as. the. Miami Dolphins got from their next best scorer, Paul Warfield, the Presidential favorite who caught 11 touchdown passes for 66 points.

title: New Pakistani Envoy to U.S.
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 29 (Reuters)  Sultan Mohammed Khan, permanent head of the Foreign Office, has been appointed Pakistan's Ambassador to the United States. He has been ambassador to China twice.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay directed the Department of Correction yesterday to step up the final inspection of the new Adolescent Remand Shelter by three months.

title: CHINA TRIP DERIDED IN A SOVIET PAPER
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 29The first direct Soviet press commentary on President Nixon's visit to China characterized it today as a propaganda show designed to impress the American electorate but achieving minimal concrete results.

title: Wide Deficiencies In Car Safety Code Charged by Nader
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, sent the Government a 28page compendium today of what he called flagrant deficiencies in Federal auto safety standards. He urged drastic improvements.

title: Department Store Sales Slumped During February
description: Despite strong business on Washington's Birthday last week, departmentstore sales in New York slumped in February for the second consecutive month and were the lowest of the last 14 months.

title: Reconciliation in Sudan
description: The secessionist war that has raged for 16 years in the southern area of Sudan has never become such an international cause clbre as similar struggles in Katanga, Biafra, Bangladesh or Ulster. But it has rivaled and perhaps outdone them all in bitterness, brutality and bigotry.

title: BorgWarner Closing Unit
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP)The BorgWarner Corporation announced today that it is discontinuing its cold rolled stainless steel sheet operation at its Ingersoll Steel division in New Castle, Ind. A spokesman said the 50 employes in the operation would be dismissed.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: I.L.A. Told to Bar Scotch In OneDay Irish Protest
description: No Scotch whisky will be unloaded today on East and Gulf Coast and Great Lakes docks, if a directive sent out yesterday by Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, is carried out.

title: Hughes Losing Hangar
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb.29 (AP)The Harbor Commission said today that it would not renew Howard R. Hughes's $36,000ayear lease on the hangar where the huge, allplywood Spruce Goose plane has been stored since 1947.

title: Advertising:
description: Batten, Barton Durstine & Osborn, the nation's foul largest ad agency, made up yesterday for a serious executive vice president deficiency by adding its second and third. They are Bruce E. Crawford, president of the international division and E. E. Norris, management supervisor and chairman of the, strategy review board.

title: Senate Bus Votes Sharpen Issue in Florida's Primary
Linda Sue Spaet Is Married Upstate
description: WAPPINGERS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 29Miss Linda Sue Spaet, daughter of Dr. Theodore H. Spaet of Scarsdale and the late Mrs. Amy Abrams Spaet, was married here at noon today to William Tetzlaff. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tetzlaff of Skokie, Ill. Town. Justice Vincent S. Francese performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Birch Society Denunciation
description: BELMONT, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP)  The John Birch Society issued a statement today saying President Nixon's visit to China humiliated the American people and betrayed our antiCommunist allies.

title: Merger Hearings Reset
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The Senate Judiciary Committee's subcommittee hearings into the proposed merger of the National and American Basketball Associations, scheduled to resume yesterday, were reset today for next Monday and Tuesday.

title: Cote to Coach Panhandle
description: GOODWELL, Okla., Feb. 29 (AP)  Ron Cote was named head football coach today at Panhandle State College.

title: Racing at Aqueduct Will Start Today
description: A strike threatened for today by, the Independent Association of Mutuel Employes at Aqueduct was averted late last night when the clerks agreed to continue negotiations with the New York Racing Association.

title: Lakera Outlast Knicks, Clinch Divison Crown
Palestinians Freed on Bail In Cairo Assassination Case
description: CAIRO, Feb. 29Four Palestinians who have confessed to assassinating Jordan's Premier, Wasfi Tal, in Cairo Nov. 28 were released today by state security court on bail of 1,000 Egyptian pounds each, the equivalent of $2,300.

title: A Peking Opera Will Highlight Capital's College Stage Festival
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29A prerevolutionary Peking opera in English is coming to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts as one of 10 winners in the fourth annual American College Theater Festival.

title: Music Critic Translates Bhagavad Gita for Layman
description: Back in 1957 Winthrop Sargeant the New Yorker's celebrated music critic and profilist was interviewing Daisetz Teitaro Suzuki, the renowned authority on Zen Buddhism. To illustrate point, Mr. Suzuki chalked Sanskrit phrase on a blackboard.

title: DIDN'T AID IRVING, MAHEU SAYS HERE
description: Robert A. Maheu, the deposed director of the Nevada investment empire of Howard R. Hughes, appeared before a Federal grand jury here yesterday to deny that he had supplied, the Information for Clifford Irving's disputed autobiography of the elusive billionaire.

title: Fountains of Life
description: On March 1, 1872, President Ulysses S. Grant signed into law a bill which provided that the tract of land the territories of Montana and Wyoming, lying near the headwaters to the Yellowstone River... is hereby reserved and withdrawn from settlement, occupancy, sale under the laws of the United States, and dedicated and set apart as a public park or pleasuring ground for the benefit and enjoyment of the people.

title: Plastic Plants Banned
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (UPI) An outcry over the use of plastic plants to landscape street resulted today in a ban against future use of arificial greenery to beautify county roads. Henceforth, living grass and plants will be used in all instances where beautification is deemed desirable, the County Board of Superivsors ordered.

title: Michael Accepts Yankee Terms
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 29After two winters of discontent, Gene Michael has concluded he prefers his summers of satisfaction.

title: Bay State Races Canceled
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP)Unsafe track conditions forced the By State Raceway to cancel races today for the second straight day. A spokesman said, however, racing at the oval would resume tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Syed Qutb Weds Elizabeth Bean
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 29Miss Elizabeth Ann Bean, a former Foreign Service officer, was married here tonight to Syed Nazim Qutb, who has been in Washington since 1966 as press attach of the Embassy of Pakistan. The. Rev. James H. Curtis performed the ceremony in the River Road Unitarian. Church.

title: Date of Soviet Trip Not Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) The White House said today that no definite date had been set for Presidefit Nixon's'scheduled visit to the Soviet Union late in May. Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House presS secretary, denied reports from diplomatic sources published in The New York Times on Feb. 26 that the Nixon trip would start on May 22.

title: Goldsworthy of North Stars Signs ThreeYear Contract
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 29 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League signed a star wing, Bill Goldsworthy, to a threeyear contract today, dealing the fledgling Minnesota Fighting Saints of the rival league another setback.

title: At Canton Fair, China Displays Her Wares for Sales Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29Administration sources confirmed here today that Chinese leaders had indicated in Peking last week that American businessmen would be welcome at the Canton trade fair this spring. Such a development was predicted today in Japan by Marshall Green, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: GINLEY's THE NAME GUMSIIOE'S THE GAMEADVT

title: Racers Debate Guard Rail Issue
description: Racing people have a trade joke about Jackie Stewart's advocacy of steel guard rails on road courses: To find his home in Switzerland, fly to Geneva Airport and then follow the Armco fence. The subject of guard rails (usually called by the trade name Armco) is a touchy one these days. The pressure for them comes from the Grand Prix Drivers Association and the safety committee of the Commission Sportive Internationale. For internationally sanctioned races run on this continent, they recommend guard rails, two tiers high, be built the full length of a course, on both sides of the road and within about six feet of the pavement.

title: U.S. LIFTS ITS BAN ON COLUMBIA AID
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday provisionally lifted its freeze on more than $13million in Federal contracts earmarked for, Columbia UniVersity after approving an interim report from the university on its prdIgress toward meeting Federal equaljobopportunity rules.

title: H.D.A. Disbanding Urged In Council Panel's Report
description: Legislation to dismantle they City Housing and Development Administration and curb) Mayor Lindsay's power to authorize funds for municipal loans for the rehabilitation of slum housing was introduced in the City Council yesterday.

title: SEX EQUALITY BILE BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today, in the form supported by, the feminist movement, a constitutional, amendment barring discrimination based, on sex.

title: U.S. Official Sees Harm In Any Ulster Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29A senior State Department official argued today that any unsolicited American intervention in Northern Ireland would worsen the volatile crisis rather than help ease it.

title: 8 MEN ROB BANK OF $89,000 HERE
description: Eight fastworking bandits stole a canvas sack containing $89,000 in small bills from Brooklyn bank yesterday while the guard was away on jury duty.

title: Some Economists Note Underlying Vigor in LongTerm Outlook for Currency
description: In the domestic United States economy, the issue of dollar convertibility does not arise; a dollar is convertible into nothing but another dollar. As Miroslav A. Kriz, the scholarly vice president of the First National City Bank of New York, notes, American paper money now carries the humble imprint, In God We Trust, where 15 years ago it carried the much more mysterious imprint that the dollar was redeemable in lawful money, which presumably meant that it was convertible not merely into another dollar but into 100 cents or four quarters.

title: WHEAT FUTORES DROP IN CHICAGO
description: Prices of wheat futures Closed  cent to 2 cents lower a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. They reflected, liquidation with the ginning of deliveries agianst the March contract and speculative profit taking, following the gains of 1 cent to 2 cents a bushel Monday with the news of the sale by Canada. of 185 million tons of wheat ValUed at $330million, to the Soviet Union...

title: A Quake in Japan Causes Damage but No Deaths
description: TOKYO, Feb. 29 (UPI)A strong earthquake rolled through central Japan today, causing landslides and small fires and making buildings sway. No deaths were reported.

title: Agents Woo Legislators
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29Dozens of smiling, chatty legislators, invited. personally by their local insurance agents, attended a free lunchandlobby gathering this, afternoon as guests of the State Association of Insur, ante Agents.

title: Tarrytown G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29The Defense Department announced today that Ronald J. Manca, an Army private first class from Tarrytown, N. Y., had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: U.S. Telephone Official Hails China's Operators
description: Telephone operators in China were cited by an American telephone official yesterday for tremendous cooperation in expediting the more than 1,000 calls placed between the two countries during President Nixon's visit.

title: Financial Concerns On Coast Explore Merger Prospects
description: The Southern California First National Corporation and the Palomar Financial Corporation announced yesterdy that they were holding preliminary merger negotiations. Both companies stressed that no accord had been. reached, Informed sources said that under the merger plan, Southern California First would acquire Palomar for more than $10million.

title: BICENTENNIAL SITE SET IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (AP)  The Board of Directors of the 1976 Philadelphia Bicentennial Commission announced today that it had reached an agreement on a site for the exposition.

title: U.S. Warned West Virginia in 1967 That 30 CoalWaste Piles Were Unstable
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 Almost five years before the breaching of a West Virginia coalmine refuse bank, which lobsed 5 million cubic feet of dammedup water on the narrow densely populated valley of Buffalo Creek last Saturday with a loss of at least 70 lives nearly a score of state and local officials were officially warned by the Interior Department that the waste pile and 29 others in the state were unstable or could be topped by high water.

title: Schoonmaker in 4th Place
description: PUERTO AZUL, Venezuela, Feb. 29 (AP)John Schoonmaker of the United States at the helm of Dingo, was in fourth place today with 50 points after the second day of the South American Starboat sailing championship. John Albrechtson of Sweden, aboard Contact, held a 1minute 15second advantage over Joerg Bruder of Brazil for the lead. Albrechtson had 53 points and Bruder 52.

title: Policy Is Outlined
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) The Federal Power Commission (F.P.C.) today outlined a threepoint United States gasimport policy, including a control system to safeguard national security if the United States should be faced with excessive gas imports.

title: Poetry, Politics and Mao
description: BOSTONThe quotation from Mao Tsetung in President Nixon's opening toast in Peking comes from the second part of a poem, Reply. to Comrade Kuo Mojo:

title: NEW DAILY MIRROR HALTS PUBLICATION
description: The New York Daily Mirror halted publication last night after a 13month, threeweek effort to sustain a third morning daily newspaper in the city, publishers of the paper announced.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Busing Compromise
SENATE APPROVES MILD BUSING CURB; STRONG BILL FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb: 29In a session filled with tension and emotion, the Senate narrowly defeated today strong proposals against school busing to achieve desegregation and approved instead the mild compromise measure offered by the top Senate leaders.

title: 2 CHILE COMPANIES ATTACHED IN SUIT
description: An order of attachment against assets held here by two Chilean corporations was obtained in Manhattan's Supreme Court yesterday by three American corporations.

title: NORTHERN NATURAL SHOWS HIGHER NET
description: The Northern Natural Gas Company reported yesterday 1971 operating revenues of $581,846,000 against $516,210,000 a year earlier.

title: PAYMENTS BALANCE A SURPLUS IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Feb. 29 (Reuters)Japan's balance of payments in January produced a surplus of $196million, the Finance Ministry announced today. The revised figure was in contrast to a deficit of $309million a year before.

title: Amtrak Names Official
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) The president, of Amtrak, Roger Lewis, today named Frank S. King vice president for operations of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation. Mr. King joined the operating department of the Pennsylvania Railroad in 1942.

title: Reapportionment Suit Filed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (AP) A suit has been filed in Federal District Court to enjoin the statee from holding elections under a legislative reapportionment plan recently upheld by the State Supreme Court, The action filed yesterday by District Attorney Arlen Specter, contends that the reapportionment commission failed to abide by the Federal and state constitutional requirements of compactness and contiguity.

title: Democrats Rule Out Primary in Arkansas
Korean Marines Back Home
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Feb. 29 The first phase of the withdrawal of South Korean forces from Vietnam was  completed today when the last contingent of the Blue Dragon marine brigade landed at the port here. Their departure reduced the South Korean strength in Vietnam to about 38,000, most of them serving in two infantry divisions.

title: Danang Boys, Beggars, Live by Wits
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 24He is 9 years old and he hobbles around this bedraggled port on two wooden stubs and a tiny crutch. His name is Bay.

title: SPITZ CAPTURES SULLIVAN AWARD
description: Mark Spitz, who shattered seven world swimming records last year, has been named the 1971 Sullivan Award winner as the outstanding amateur athlete in the United States.

title: Court Rebuffs Peabody On Pennsylvania Ballot
MRS. E. K. ANGSTADT SR.
description: Mrs. Irene Valente Angstadt, a daughter of the late State Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, died last Wednesday of a heart ailment In Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 50 years old and resided in Reading, Pa., with her husband, Earle K. Angstadt Sr., a funeral director.

title: 2 SENATE LEADERS WILL GO TO CHINA; INVITED BY CHOU
description: The White House announced today that Mike Mansfield of Montana and Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate, would visit China at the invitation of Premier Chou Enlai.

title: New Facsimile System
description: Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a new facsimile system, designed to reduce the cost of transmitting newspaper pages to distant printing plants as much as 80 per cent. It compresses words and pictures into digital pulse groups and transmits them over ordinary telephone lines.

title: Retail Food Prices Rose in January; Up 5.6% in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 Spurred by record high beef prices, average retail food prices rose 0.6 per cent in January, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: WarnerLambert Net Up 20.7% In Quarter on a 15% Sales Gain
description: The WarnerLambert Company posted record sales and earnings for 1971, supported by the finalquarter resultsthe highest for any quarter if the company's 115year historythe big pharmaceutical consumer products and medical instruments maker reported yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 29 (UPI)  Light earthquake shocks rocked a wide area of central and southern Italy tonight, touching off a panicky exodus in the Adriatic port city of Pescara.

title: BUS STRIKE PUT OFF AS TALKS CONTINUE
description: A threatened strike by eight union locals against the largest bus company in New Jersey was postponed early this morning as negotiators for both sides agreed to bargain past the 12:01 A.M. deadline.

title: Taiwan Seeks Defense Pledge
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 29 Mr. Green will come under strong pressure when he visits here Thursday and Friday to have the United States Government publicly reaffirm its commitment to the defense of Taiwan, highly placed Government sources said today.

title: GRAEBER LOSES, HAYES TOURNEY
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 29 (AP) Clark Graebner of New York and Gerald Battrick of England were upset today in opening play of the United States National indoor tennis tournament,

title: LowKey, LowProfile Councilinan
description: On the tennis court, Edward Louis Sadowsky never blasts away recklessly. His serves never sizzle across the net; they come with just a modicum of force, but they come with invariable accuracy.

title: North Carolina Upset
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 29 (AP) Paul Coder hit a free throw with seven seconds left as North Carolina State upset thirdranked North Carolina, 8584, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Advertising:
description: Robert LEdens Jr., who joined Foote, Cone & Belding in July as executive vice. president and general manage of the Chicago office has, in the, words of the official pronouncement, left the employment of the company."

title: PEKING GIVES CHOU ROUSING GREETING
description: PEKING, Feb. 29  Premier Chou Enlai received a triumphant welcome at the Peking airport this afternoon on his return from Shanghai, the last stop on his brief tour of China with President Nixon.

title: Former Serviceman Testifies
description: BELFAST 29  A former. British serviceman said today that he was sickened by the way British soldiers went into action against demonstrators in Londonderry. last month when 13 persons were killed.

title: Kissinger. Under Attack By House Foreign Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's assistant, for national security, came under severe criticism today from members of Congress who accused him of preempting the State Department's traditional role in formulating United States foreign policy.

title: Debt Ceiling Rise Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) The Senate Finance Committee approved today legislation to increase the temporary national debt ceiling to $450billion $30biilion less than the Administration requested The $20billion rise over the present $430billion ceiling is the same as that recently approved by the House.

title: 10 Bar Groups Assail Bill
description: Ten city bar associations charged yesterday that the no fault automobile accident insurance bill now under consideration by the State Legislature would discriminate against minority groups, women, children, the elderly and the poor.

title: PENTAGON USING DRUGABUSE CODE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29A highranking Pentagon official disclosed today that the code SPN384 is stamped on the discharge papers and the perpermanent records of soldiers, sailors and airmen who are discharged for drug abuse.

title: Robert J. Landry Dies at 58; Dun &
description: Robert J. Landry, a general economist with Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., creditreporting concern, for the last 26 years, died on Friday at French Hospital after a long illness. He was 58 yars old and lived at 19 West 31st Street.

title: Lesser U.S.Soviet Role Is Urged at Geneva Talks
description: GENEVA, Feb. 29Mexico proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union give up their cochairmanship of the Geneva disarmament conference as a means of encouraging China and France to participate.

title: Lindsay Aided in Florida by City Employes
Loan Company Agrees To Terms of Bias Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI)The nation's largest consumer finance company has agreed to a court order requiring it to provide equal borrowing opportunities to members of minority groups and to hire more women and nonwhites, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.

title: Policeman Wounded By a Shotgun Blast At Carmel Station
description: A desk sergeant with the Carmel town police in Putnam County was gunned down at police headquarters last night by a shotgun blast firsed from an automobile.

title: Warriors Triumph, 128120
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 29 (UPI)The Golden State Warriors jumped to an early 20point lead and coasted to 128120 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight. The triumph kept the Warriors tied with Seattle in the battle for a Pacific Division playoff spot.

title: Opposition Wins Control Of Jamaica Parliament
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Wednesday, March 1 (AP)The People's National party, led by Michael Norman Manley, won the general election last night, ending 10 years of rule by the Jamaica Labor party.

title: Muskie Vows to End Surveillance by Army
Two Days of Talks on Gibraltar End Without Narrowing Dispute
description: MADRID, Feb. 29Two days of talks between the Foreign Ministers of Spain and Britain haVe produced no appreciable narrowing of the dispute between the two countries over Gibraltar.

title: U.S. Foresees Americans At Next China Trade Fair
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, March 1Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green predicted to Japanese officials yesterday that United States corporations would be represented at the Canton trade fair for the first time this April.

title: Con Ed APlant Shut as Menace to Fish
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29  The State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, Henry L. Diamond, ordered Consolidated Edison today to cease testing its pump and waterintake equipment at its new nuclear plant at Indian Point.

title: Henry Woods Jr., 71, Dies; Public Relations Counselor
description: LYNCROFT, N. J., Feb. 29Henry F. Woods Jr., a retired public relations counselor, died yesterday in the Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch, at the age of 71. He had moved here from Port Washington, L.L. in 1965 on his retirement as vice president in charge of public relations for the Young & Rubicam advertising agency.

title: Scaasi to Do ReadytoWear Abroad
description: Arnold Scaasi is practically the last of the oldtime couturiers practicing their art in New York. Of course, other people make madetoorder clothes, but few go through the business of regular fashion shows, photographers in the frontrow seats, fresh flowers and all that.

title: Sheik Mujib Off to Soviet For 5Day Good will Visit
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 29 (UPI)  Sheik Mujibur Rahman; Prime Minister of Bangladesh, flew to Moscow today for a fiveday visit of goodwill and gratitude for Russian support in the struggle for independence from Pakistan.

title: BANK GUARD KILLED; 2D HELD IN RICHMOND
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 29 (UPI)A bank guard was killed and three others were wounded today In a shooting that arose during a meeting of security officers in the Fifth Federal Reserve Bank.

title: Chavez Signs Florida's First Farm Pact
description: MIAMI, Feb. 29The first labor contract for migrant agricultural workers in Florida was signed today between Cesar Chavez's United Farmworkers of California and the CocaCola Company's Foods Division.

title: Atlanta Bus Fare Cut to 15c
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 29 (AP)Beginning tomorrow, Atlantani will be able to ride city buses for 15 cents instead of 40 cents. The Atlanta Transit System was purchased by the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, which will be subsidized by $600,000 a month from sales tax revenue.

title: Banker: Use Stocks to Solve Problem
description: PARIS, Feb. 29A Chicago banker is drumming up support for a novel way to deal with the problem of inconvertibility of the dollar. He would have the United States Treasury buy up packages of American corporate securities and offer them at a discount to foreign central banks.

title: A Rare Day Is a Matter Of Degrees
description: What is so rare as..a day in February that is numbered 29 and sees a high temperature of 62 degrees?

title: ARGENTINES STAGE A GENERAL STRIKE
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 29A 48hour general strike by Argentina's labor unions crippled industrial and commercial activity today in this automotive center and in most. of Argentina.

title: Aaron of Braves To Get $600,000 Over Three Years
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 29 (UPI)The Atlanta Braves superstar, Hank Aaron, the man most likely to break Babe Ruth's home run record, became the highest paid player in baseball history today when he signed a contract that reportedly will pay hini $600,000 during the next three years.

title: Prosecution Rests Its Case In Yablonski Murder Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 29 (AP)The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of Paul Gilly in the Yablonski murders after a witness testified that Mr. Gilly had unjammed a carbine to help carry out the slayings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidney Foundation Plans Drive to Get Funds and Organs
description: Knowing that thousands of lives could be saved by kidney transplantation and dialysis, the National Kidney Foundation described a bold new advertising campaign here yesterday to raise money and organs for the mote than 10,000 potentially treatable kidney patients who die each year.

title: Alleged Memo Ties I.T.T. Trust Action To G.O.P. Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29  A memorandum purportedly written last June by the chief lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and disclosed here today linked the settlement of an antitrust action against the company with a subsidiary's pledge to help finance the Republican National Convention this year.

title: Excerpts From Committee Report on Housing Unit
description: Many persons associated with the program were either charlatans, thieves, or incom petents.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29When the history of the Nixon Administration is finally written, the chances are that his China policy will stand out as a model of common sense and good diplomacy.

title: Genesco Susan Thomas Unit Realigned Into 2 Divisions
description: The Susan Thomas, division of Genesco, Inc., has been divided into two divisions and presidents have been appointed for each,.Edward F. Carney, corporate vice president of Genesco, announced yesterday. Last weekend, the fourmember top management team of Susan Thomas said it would resign effective today.

title: Alonzo Wilkins, a Star Player In Wheelchair Sports, Is Dead
description: Alonzo Wilkins, a disabled Korean war veteran who had been a leader in wheelchair sports since 1957, died in Metropolitan Hospital yesterday after suffering a stroke Sunday at his home, 315 East 108th Street. He was 43 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Arctic Ice Floes to Be Tracked
description: A base camp is being established on a lonely ice floe as prelude to the most ambitious effort yet undertaken by the United States and its allies to understand what forces control ice movement in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Lebanese Troops and Tanks Enter Commandos'
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 29Lebanese troops and tanks have moved into the Palestinian commando area of southeastern Lebanon that was evacuated by Israeli forces yesterday.

title: E. GORDON WALLS
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 29 E. Gordon Walls, retired vice president and manager of the Philadelphia office of the Blair Television division of John Blair & Co., died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 55 years old.

title: LTV Narrows Its Loss;
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., reduced its consolidated net loss last year to $57,367,000 from $69,619,000 in 1970, the company reported last night. In the fourth quarter the net loss of $22,363,000 compared with a restated deficit of $27,092,000 in the yearearlier quarter.

title: Table Thrown From Hotel Kills a Man on Bleecker St.
description: A 78yearold man was killed yesterday when a table, apparently thrown from an upper floor of a Greenwich Village hotel, landed on his head, the police of the West 10th Street station reported.

title: Miners Cling to Homes That Are Left After Flood
description: LORADO, W. Va., Feb. 29As far as Oscar McComas Sr. could see the Buffalo Creek hollow was one big tangle of mud and upturned cars and timber today. But the retired miner talked like a civic booster in any small town as he pointed his finger at the coalladen hills and said: We'll come back. Miners always do.

title: Offer Confirmed at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 29  A reliable diplomatic source confirmed here tonight that Mrs. Sipila had been offered a post with the rank of Assistant Secretary General.

title: Ford Car Name Stirs Fight in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 29A British television and publishing empire and the Ford Motor Company were locked in a bitter legal dispute today over the use of the name. Granada.

title: Pennsy Renovates Yard
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 29 (UPI)The Penn Central railroad said today it had completed a. $1.8million renovation of its Bayview yard here.

title: Gustave E. von Grunebaum, Medieval Scholar, Is Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 (UPI)  Dr. Gustave E. von Grunebaum, an authority on medieval Islam,died on Sunday night at the University of California Medical Center after long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Farm Income Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP)Prices that farmers received for raw products rose 2 per cent in February the fifth consecutive monthly increase and averaged 9 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Ailing Coach Is Removed
description: FARGO, N.D., Feb. 29 (AP) Lyle Belk, basketball coach at North Dakota State University, was relieved of his duties today, Ron Erhardt athletic director announced. Erhardt cited Belk's state of health as the reason for the change.

title: New Soviet Rules Tighten Border Controls
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 29The Soviet Union has acted to tighten control over its border zone by giving frontier guards, an elite military force, additional powers to detain anyone found there without permission.

title: Music: Lieder in Depth
description: Evelyn Lear staged a small Goethe festival in the midst of her song recital at Town Hall on Monday night, a rare study in depth of his poem Kennst du das Land, as set by three masters of the German lied: Schumann, Beethoven and Wolf. Then, when.an encore seemed indicated, the soprano added, not the anticipated Schubert version, but the Goethe lyric as translated by Ambroise Thomas into operatic terms: Connaistu le pays? from Mignon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Home Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced today amendments designed to raise nursing home standards set under the Administration's welfare reform plan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE EXPECTED FOR 2 RENT BILLS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29The Senate Housing Committee advanced two bills today to repeal the eightmonthold state law that permits apartments in New York City to be decontrolled as they become vacant.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DILINMING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, MONK DEWAR'S. 86.8 Proof, 100% Blended Scotch Whlekles, William Lasveon'e Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., Syosset, N. Y.Advt.

title: Shanghai Radio Offers Instruction in English
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 29A Shanghai radio broadcast made available here today appeared to indicate a longrange interest on the part of Chinese officials in opening China to English speaking visitors.

title: Finnish Wornan Lawyer Is Offered a Top U.N. Position
description: GENEVA, Feb. 29A Helsinki lawyer Mrs. Helvi Sipila, has been, offered an appointment as the first topranking woman member of the United Nations Secretariat.

title: OHIO STATE WINS TO TIE FOR LEAD
GARFIELD D. MERNER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29 (AP) Garfield David Merner, industrialist, philanthropist and past president of the Pfeiffer Medical Research Foundation in New York, died on Sunday. He was 89 years old.

title: Market Place: U.S. Acquisition By Europeans?
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 29An American banker operating in the Common Market might want to make something out of the fact that the American economy is beginning to snap, crackle and pop at the very moment European economies are starting to fizzle.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President gave separate briefings to Congressional leaders and his Cabinet on his trip to China. The President also announced that Senators Mike Mansfield and Hugh Scott were invited to visit China by Premier Chou Enlai. The President participated in the swearing ire of Peter G. Peterson as Secretary of Commerce.

title: Volkswagen Plans to Float $93.7Million Bond Issue
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany (AP)Volkswagen, the West German auto producer, plans to float a $93.7million bond issue with a banking consortium headed by Deutsche Bank AG, a company spokesman said today.

title: Red Cross Month
description: Today marks the opening of Red Cross Month, the time of the year when the Red Cross seeks the contrib utions that support Its many community services. In a proclairiation issued to mark. March as Red Cross Month in the City of New York, Mayor Lindsay declared.

title: Chased Car Hits Another In Yonkers, Killing a Man
description: YONKERS, Feb. 29 (AP)A speeding car with four men, being chased by the state police ran a red light today and smashed broadside into a second auto, killing its 45yearold driver.

title: ALASKAN PIPELINE PUT AT $5BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29It would cost $5billion to build a gas pipeline from Alaska across Canada to the United States, a group of three, pipeline and three gasproducing companies reported today.

title: Socialist's Defection Cuts Brandt's Majority to 4
description: BONN, Feb. 29Dr. Herbert Hupka, a Social Democratic member of parliament who opposes Chancellor Willy Brandt's foreign policy, quit his party today, thereby cutting the margin of the Government's majority to four votes.

title: $2.5 MILLION IS BET AT WESTBURY OVAL
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 29The first of three harness racing meetings at Rciosevelt Raceway this season was concluded tonight with 19,554 fans wagering $2,300,000 on the 50th program of the 1972 campaign. The second part of the threeply schedule at the Nassau County course will be held from May 25 through July. 22, covering 51 nights.

title: NYQUIST'S RULING PROTESTED HERE
description: Leaders of the organizations representing most of the city's principals and other school supervisors took issue yesterday with a state ruling that parents have a right to see all school records concerning their children, including confidential data.

title: Galella Rests $1.3Million Case; Mrs. Onassis'
description: Counsel for Ronald E. Galella rested their case yesterday afternoon in the photographer's suit against Mrs. Aristotle Onassis for $1.3million for alleged interference with his livelihood.

title: PRISONS'
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald said today that despite the problems at the Attica Correctional Facility and the resultant call for reform of the state's penal system, about $22million had been pared from his department's original budget request.

title: Dollar Down in Frankfurt; Decline Shown in Tokyo
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 29 (UPI)Reports of the nearrecord American trade deficit in January sent the United States dollar reeling today in irregular trading on the Frankfurt foreignexchange market.

title: Murphy Defies P.B.A. on Patrol Cars
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy suggested yesteiday that the use of oneman patrol cars was a prerogative of management that could be instituted without the approval of the Patrolmen'ti Benevolent Association.

title: Bridge: An Abnormal Game Contract Can Provide Testa in Defense
description: A very rare feat seemed in prospect last weekend at the New ,Jersey Bridge League's sectional tournament when a team headed by David. Mason of Maplewood, N. J., was unbeaten with two rounds of play remaining.

title: AMEX ISSUES UP; OTC ENDS MIXED
Notes on People
description: Edward R. Egan, the former New York City detective whose exploits were recounted in the hit movie The French Connection, was depicted as the target of a, campaign of smear and harassment in State Supreme Court. The occasion was the opening of his lawsuit for reinstatement with the rank of detective first grade and retirement with a commensurate pension.

title: William Buckley Critical
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 29  William F. Buckley Jr. charged today that President Nixon's desire for political publicity at home had forced him into concessions in Peking that undermined the whole moral basis of United States treaty commitments in Asia.

title: GONORRHEA TEST BY BLOOD SOUGHT
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 29  Venereal disease specialists at the Center for Disease Control here expressed Confidence today that within a year they would have a reasonably helpful blood test to detect gonorrhea, the most commonly, reported communicable disease in the country.

title: Cranbrook to Sell Art in Fund Drive
description: Beset by a pressing need for endowment funds Cranbrook Academy, one of the country's leading art schools will auction off a major part of its art collection at ParkeBernet Galleries, beginning tonight. The star offering, among the more than 1,000 items to be sold, is a monumental elmwood carving by Henry Moore, said to be the most important modern sculpure put on the auction block in many years.

title: Letter Discloses That Berrigan Informer Sought $50 000 From U.S.
description: HARRISBURG; Pa., Feb. 29The defense revealed today that Boyd F. Douglas Jr., an informer for the F.B.I., expected the United States to pay him $50,000 taxfree for exposing the alleged bombing and kidnapping conspiracy by priests and nuns.

title: BENEFIT FOR ATTICA SPARKS MUSICIANS
description: Benefit concerts often bring out the best in musicians. Monday night's program at the Gaslight Au Go Go to raise funds for the Attica Defense Committee was a good example.

title: Kips Bay Gets Public Library After Seekiiig It for 17 Years
description: After doing without a public library for 17 years, the Kips Bay area on Manhattan's East Side marked the opening of a new branch of the New York Public Library yesterday at Third Avenue and 31st Street.

title: BANGLADESH STORY PROMPTS LIBEL SUIT
description: A $150million libel suit has been filed in State Supreme Court against New York Magazine and one of its contributors over an article alleging that part of the proceeds from benefit record album for Bangladesh was unaccounted for.

title: City U. Accused of Bias Against Women
description: When Ruth Weintraub, now the dean of social sciences of Hunter Coljege, found that she was pregnant, she recalled yesterday, she was delighted and would have liked to cherish lit for a while. Instead, she had to notify the college president of her pregnancy forthwith.

title: St. Peter's Downs Siena
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 29St. Peter's College, rallying in the last five minutes, defeated Siena College, 8572, tonight for its sixth straight triumph.

title: RENT ACCORD SET IN GRAMERCY PARK
description: Disgruntled tenants and their landlord agreed yesterday to a courtproposed settlement of a fourmonthold rent strike at 36 Gramercy. Park East.

title: WEST GULF DOCKERS IN CONTRACT ACCORD
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 29 (AP) West Gulf longshoremen and shipper's announced a tentative threeyear contract today that would give deepsea dockworkers a $2.27anhour pay and benefits increase.

title: Cowboys Hire Gillman
description: DALLAS, Feb. 29 (AP)Sid Gillman, former head coach of the San Diego Chargers, has been hired by the Dallas Cowboys as an executive assistant to Coach Tom Landry, the team announced today. Gillman will have no field duties but will aid Landry in the same manner as another special assistant, Ermal Allen.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN BRISK TRADING
Article 2  No Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29 (UPI)Harry Bridges, leader of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, said yesterday that it the: Pay Board struck down either agreement reached recently by, dock workers on both coasts, we both join forces and pull out in every port in the United States.

title: Saigon's Chinese Feel Nixon Trip Spurs Hostility Toward Them
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb 29  For Saigon's large Chinese community, which controls some threequarters of South Vietnam's major business and industry, President Nixon's trip, to Peking brought deep anxiety and a feeling that the time may have come to begin shifting its political loyalties from Nationalist to.Communist China.

title: American Zoos Vying for 2 Gift Pandas
description: The two giant pandas promised to. the United States by China in exchange for two mtisk oxen, as a token of goodwill, have stirred up polite warfare among the nation's zoos.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rochester Plans Layoffs
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 29 (AP)City Manager Kermit Hill announced today that 150 to 200 city employes would be laid off April 1 and that 170 vacant positions would not be filled, to help overcome the city's, expected $8million budget deficit.

title: NEEDIEST CASES WINDS UP APPEAL
description: The 60th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with contributions totaling $1,020,763.85 from 13,155 donors.

title: In Much of the Nation Winter Is Acting Younger Than Springtime
description: In Omaha, the first and second graders wore cotton dresses and Tshirts to school. In Chicago, businessmen doffed their jackets and carried tp.em in the crooks of their arms. In New York,.a Central Park.benchsitter stripped to his waist and tilted a silverfoiled reflector toward the winter sun.

title: Meany's Comment Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29Mr. Meany was not available to comment on the appeal. An A.F.L.C.I.O. spokesman noted, however, that Mr. Meany said last year that the United States owed the money and should pay it.

title: Yorty Sees Rivals as Fulbright Faction
Special Tax Bills Blocked By Reform Drive in House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 The House of Representatives, in a fresh demonstration of reform spirit, refused today even to consider a series of tax bills that would ordinarily have passed with little opposition or debate.

title: U.S.Unit Concludes Study Here Of Mentally Retarded Centers
description: Many of the mentally retard ed residents now vegetating in giant institutions like Willowbrook could be gainfully employed if trained in smaller; well staffed facilities, the leader of a Federal investigating team said yesterday.

title: Church. Role Indicated in Italy's Election
description: ROME, Feb. 29Italy's Roman Catholic hierarchy indicated today that it would strongly back the Christian Democratic party in the campaign for the general elections in May.

title: 1913 Scout Guide: On Catching Thieves, Mice and Colds
description: She wore a midi skirt and boots and was into ecology and natural foods. She was encouraged to fly a plane (not during hurricanes, however), but was warned against trying to be an imitation man. She teetered on the brink of Women's Liberation, but was hauled back before she got too far, back on the safe grounds of a territory known as housewifery.

title: SCOTT PANEL ENDS BOROUGH SESSIONS
description: The Scott Commission ended its borough public hearings yesterday with a meeting in Manhattan and added a dozen more suggestions, complaints and warnings to its long list of decentralization plans, for New York City.

title: STEVEN DAVIDOW, CLOTHIER, WAS 33
description: Steven A. Davidow, president of Davidow, Inc., makers of women's suits, dresses, coats and sportswear, was killed in an automobile accident Monday evening on the Hutchinson River Parkway. Mr. Davidow, who was 33 years old, was driving to his home, 15 Oak Crest, Darien, Conn.

title: Bulls Top Blazers, 11692
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 29 (AP)Chet Walker, Bob Love and Norm aVn Lier combined for 71 points tonight to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 11692 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: NEW ISSUES TOP ACTIVITY IN BONDS
description: The bond market, dawdling along yesterday without getting anywhere, nevertheless handled a big volume of newissue financing with a fair amount of dispatch.

title: Advertising:
description: Life is funny Take if you will the who of Norman Grulich who spent years becoming a topnotch advertisman and then took over a company that doesn'tad vertise.

title: MICHAEL EAGLE
description: Michael Eagle, former vice president and director of Publix Shirt Corporation, 350 Fifth Avenue, died on Monday in Miami, where he had lived since his retirement in 1956. He was 71 years old.

title: STATE DISTRICTING WOULD ELIMINATE BELLA ABZUG SEAT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 29Republican sources reported today that agreement had been reached on the basic outline of the state's Congressional redistricting plan, including the elimination of two New York City seats.

title: TV: Pictures From China Were Clearer Than the Commentary
description: Thoughts of an eyeweary viewer on the television extravaganza scrutably dubbed The China Caper or The Peking Primary.

title: City Budget Warnings
description: The early announcement of New York City's proposed expense budget for the next fiscal year comes as a grim storm warning. Details are to be revealed in their full tabular form later this week, but the public has already been told that this budget will total about $10 billion, a rise from $8.6 billion for the current fiscal year.

title: '71 Saleg at New York Life Climbed to a Record High
description: The nation's fourthlargest life insurer, the New York Life (Insurance Company, reported yesterday that total sales reached $7.1billion during 1971, a new high, up $74million from a year earlier.

title: Contaminated Chickens Held In Maine by U.S. Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) The United States Department of Agriculture reported today that it had found additional broiler and roaster chickens in Maine contaminated with polychlorianted biphenyls.

title: Jersey Districting Held Invalid
description: NEWARK, Feb. 29A three judge Federal District Court panel today declared existing Congressional district finds in New Jersey unconstitutional and ordered a court hearing April 3 to consider redistricting proposals.

title: U. S. Lofts Satellite to Monitor Soviet Launchings
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 1 (AP)  An American spy satellite soared into space early today, reportedly the third in a series intended to monitor rocket tests of the Soviet Union and Communist China and to provide almost instant alert of a missile attack on the United States.

title: Some Shipping Loss Here In Strike Called Permanent
description: The East Coast dock strike will result in a permanent loss of perhaps as much as 20 per cent of shipping traffic diverted through Canada, Mrs. Helen Delich Bentley, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, said here yesterday.The strike began on Oct. 1, 1971, and ended when long shoremen returned to their jobs in late February after a Federal injunction.

title: ...Homogenizing by the Senate
description: The most effective way to fight discrimination against women in higher education is to eliminate it at the graduate levelthe source of future scholars, teachers, researchers and administrators. This is precisely where the universities past record is most dismal, both in outright discrimination and in refusal to respond to women's needs for parttime study opportunities.

title: 41 ARE INDICTED IN RAHWAY RIOT
description: TRENTON, March 1Fortyone prisoners have been indicted on criminal charges growing out of the Thanksgiving Day uprising at the state prison in RahWay.

title: Rutgers Sinks Navy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 1 (AP)John Somogyi scored 35 points, including 12 of Rutgers last 17, as he led the Scarlet to an 8072 victory over Navy tonight.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NASHVILLE, March 1The Tennessee Legislature voted today to place a referendum on the school busing issue on the, May 4 Presidential primary ballot.

title: Miss Proell Skiing Victor, Takes World Cup Again
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 1 (UPI)  Annemarie Croell of Austria wrapped up her seeond consecutive World Cup Skiing title today when she lynn the women's giant slalom at Heavenly Valley in 1 minnte 18,96 seconds.

title: Executive Changes
description: Walter D. Dance and Reginald H. Jones were elected yesterday vice chairmen and executive officers of the General Electric Company. They will become members of the fiveman corporate execttive office headed by Fred J. Borch, chairman. This group will be reduced to four on May 1 When William H. Dennler will retire after more than 38 years with the company.

title: Theater: Sticks and Bones at Golden
Reflections Given By Joffrey Ballet At the City Center
description: Good dancing. That is what took place Tuesday night on the stage of the City Center where the City Center Joffrey Sallet held forth so appealingly in the season's first performanee of Reflections.

title: Teaneck Man Wins Million
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 1 (AP)Werner D. Whol of Teaneck, a 50yearold Germanborn former promoter for Aufban, a Germanlanguage newspaper, won $1million today in the New Jersey State Lottery. Married and the father of two children, Vivian, 15, and Ronald, 11, Mr. Whol recently took a job with a frame and molding company in Paterson. The drawing was held at the School of Dentistry at Fairleigh Dickinson University here.

title: Court Voids Jersey Abortion Law
description: TRENTON, March 1  A threejudge Federal court has struck down New Jersey's 122 yearold abortion law, declaring it unconstitutional on two groundsvagueness and invasion of privacy. The vote was 2 to 1.

title: City Planners Urged to Back A Container Port in Red Hook
description: A city official, labor leaders, longshoremen and Brooklyn businessmen turned out at City Hall hearing yesterday to urge approval of a container port in Red Hook.

title: Sports of The Times
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1It seemed more than coincidence. First of all, a picture of Pete Reiser emerged hauntingly from amid a photo montage from the nineteen forties. He was not identified but he was recognizable. Then during the course of a check of Brooklyn Dodger personnel in the Larry MacPhail era, memory was jostled a little more because a key figure in the thrilling 1941 pennant drive of the Brooks was this same Pete Reiser. someone was trying to tell me something, I was quite willing to listen. After all, he had long been a favorite of mine, this unbelievably talented ballplayer with the incredible bad tuck.

title: Lam Tops 600 Mark
description: Kenny Lam became the first St. Francis College basketball player to score more than 600 points in a season as he led his team to a 10694 victory over. Wagner last night on the winner's floor.

title: PERON IS COURTED BY THE MILITARY
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 1Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, Argentina's military president has a Mandate from the armed forces to negotiate on Argetine's Political future with his old enemy Juan G., Peron, the exiled former dictator.

title: Editor in Onassis Case Reports Galella Tried to Hide, Evidence
description: A magazine editor testified in Federal Court here yesterday that Ronald E. Galella, the photographer, had urged her to destroy all his photographs of Mrs. Aristotle Onasis that the magazine had in its files.

title: Moroccans Vote Overwhelmingly for Charter
description: RABAT, Morocco, Thursday, March 2 (AP)Moroccans voted overwhelmingly yesterday for new constitution proposed by King Hassan II that he said would gradually transform him from absolute ruler to an arbiter.

title: Senate RollCall On Busing Ban
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate defeated today an attempt to revive an amendment by Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, to prohibit Federal courts from ordering busing to desegregate schools:

title: Shop Talk
description: The new theme on Lord & Taylor's furniture floor is The Summer of '72. But depending on which of two featured decorators one prefers, the ambiance is either the summer of '42 with Jay Steffy's movie camp of fat, upholstered furniture, or the summer of 1872, with David Barrett's Victorian tufted sofas and spool chairs. To celebrate the fact that the designs of Mr. Stet fy and Mr. Barrett are making their first department store appearance, the store has let them loose on their ideal rooms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Makarios Reported Set to Yield Arms
description: ATHENS, March 1  Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, has reportedly notified the Greek Government that he will allow a United Nations peace force to control the Czechoslovak arms he imported clandestinely last January.

title: Moscow, in a Shift, Seeks Better Ties With Rumania
description: MOSCOW, March 1  The Soviet Union, reversing its approach last fall of strongly criticizing Rumania and even hinting at military intervention there, has been making a shoii lately of easing tensions With Bucharest.

title: Actor Takes the Long Road to Sucess
description: The Life of Will Hare, 11lusions and Reality should be a nonelective course for any young man moving toward a career in the theater. It is a harrowing account and the fact that Mr. Hare has survived it, with grace, suggests the indestructibility of a certain kind of purpose.

title: Rabbi Samuel Blumenfield, Headed College in Chicago
description: Rabbi Samuel M. Blumenfield, former dean and president of the College of Jewish Studies in Chicago, died yesterday in Kings Highway Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old and lived at 1330 East 17th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Edward Plaut, 80, Former Head Of Lehn &
description: CAREFREE, Ariz., March 1 Edward Plaut, a retired president of the Lehn.& Fink Products Corporation, died yesterday while on vacation here. He was 80 years old and made his home at 801 Rockrimmon Road, Stamford, Conn.

title: Personal Finance
description: Major efforts to regulate homemortgage closing costs are under way on a Federal level.

title: Pappin Paces Hawk Victory
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 1 ((UPI)Jim Pappin recorded the fourth threegoal game of his National Hockey League career tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks from a 2.0 deficit to a 64 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Prices Up Briskly on Amex and OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose briskly yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: House Leaders, Indignant, Want to Go to China, Too
GUNN DEFENDS. PUBLIC TV FARE
description: Hartford N. Gunn Jr., president of the Public Broadcasting Service, vigorously defended public television's role in public affairs programing yesterday against critics in, positions of real power who attempt to influence a public medium on the basis of their own personal biases.

title: Union Protests Airport Restaurants Sale
description: Nearly 1,000 airport workers staged a fourmile protest march through Kennedy International Airport yesterday in a continuing labor dispute that has been marked by violence and court actions.

title: Small Business
description: DETROIT, March 1With 265,000 registered snowmobiles, Michigan is rivaling Minnesota for the lead in registrations, but the state that put the world on wheels has had only limited success in making a snowmobile to exploit the country's fastestgrowing recreational market. A group of Detroit area men decided to do something about it, and in 1970 they formed Leisure Vehicles, Inc., in suburban Troy to make the Raider snowmobile.

title: Memories of SmootHawley
description: With the strong support of the A.F.L.C.I.O., Senator Vance Hartke, Democratic Presidential candidate from Indiana, and Representative James A. Burke, Democrat of Massachusetts, have introduced a bill supposed to protect the jobs of American workers by curbing foreign imports and imposing heavy penalties on foreign investment by American firms. But the bill; if passed, would be a disaster to the American economy, to labor and the consumer alike.

title: Welsh Salute St. David Here With Hearty English Banquet
description: As almost every Welshmanand almost no one else  was aware, yesterday was St. David's Day, celebrated here with the singing and daffodils of tradition and the roast beef and trifle of accommodation.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON., March 1The recent.announcement by Mercedes University that will offer an experimental course in bank robbery during the spring semester has created quite a stir on campus, not all of it favorable.

title: VILLANOVA NAMED TO N.C.A,A. EVENT
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association filled its 25team, basketball championship field by selecting nine independent teams yesterday, includ ing Villanova, which had to forfeit its runnerup finish in last year's N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Court Bars Suits on Higher Phone Rates in State
description: Suits to prevent higher telephone rates throughout the state were dismissed in Federal Court here yesterday, leaving a decision on the disputed, rates in the hands of the Price Coramission in Washington.

title: 3 Hurt Slightly in 2 Fires At Macy's on Herald Sq.
description: Two firemen and a store employe were reported treated for smoke inhalation after a fire last night in a subbasement of Macy's Herald Square store.

title: Muskie and McGovern Forces Plan Role for RankandFile Members in the Delegate Selection Process
description: New York supporters of Senators Edund S. Muskle and George McGovern lave completed plans to include rankandfile Democrats in the pitoess of seldeting candidates this month. for Democratic. National Convention delegates.

title: How a City Wins a Race for a Party's convention
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 The process by which one city wins the right to play host to a national political conventon Involves a complicated and largely secret combination of financial haggling, synthetic bookkeeping and, not surprisingly, politics.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 1Former Gov. James E. Folsom has qualified to run against Senator John J. Sparkman in the May 2 Alabama Democratic primary.

title: Bullins Play to Be Staged By Irving Despite Protest
description: The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center has turned down Ed Bullins's request that it refrain from using his name or the title of his play, The Duplex, which is scheduled to open next Thursday in The Forum, the experimental playhouse beneath the Vivian Beaumont Theater building.

title: Advertising:
description: Subaru of America; Inc., the marketing company, for the Japanese car, has found some friends in Philadelphia to do their, advertising and public relationsthey're all at Spiro & Associates.

title: CLASH DESCRIBED AT ULSTER INQUIRY
description: COLERAINE, Northern Ireland, March 1A Londonderry Roman Catholic told an official British inquiry today that he had been shot in the arm and hit with a rubber bullet while attempting to remove his dead son from a barricade.

title: Chess: Hort Demonstrates Wisdom Of Care in Picking Rivals
description: Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia is one of the strongest players in the world and, of course highly accomplished in all phases of the game. However the basic principle of which he seems to have the best grasp as the one that advises the careful choosing of opponents. He has recently won, two tournaments in a row, and in both he was the only grandmaster competing.

title: PUBLIC OFFER FILED BY HARTZ PET FOODS
description: Hartz Mountain Pet Foods, Inc., filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 1,750,000 shares of common stock, marking its first public offering.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
