description: Thorndike Deland Sr., founder of and a patrner in Thorndike Deland Associates, 1440 BrOadway, specialists in executive recruiting, died Wednesday in. Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and hadlived for 50 years in Scarsdale N. Y.

title: Theater: Sage Mencken
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Before An, Unpleasant Delining with H. L. Mencken opened at Fords Theater last night, the National Parks Service, which, owns Ford's, suggested that certain material in the show be deletedspecifically Menckeres derogstory references to South.

title: Pakistan Sees Aid Resumption
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 9A Government official announced today that aid to Pakistan from Western nations was about to resume.

title: CONTRACTS TO AID ADDICTS DELAYED
description: Complaining that it was being asked to rubber stamp $3Million for narcotics programs fin the basis of scanty information, a coalition on the Board of. Estimate forced the Lindsay administration yesterday to postpone approval of contracts for 14 programs.

title: Volcker Calls Outlook Good
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Treasury took a calm view today of the foreign exchange market developments in Europe.

title: T.W.A. PLOTTERS REPORTED SILENT
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that there had been no contact since Tuesday night with the extortionists seeking $2million in planebombing scheme and that no ransom has been paid.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Moscow, Showing Concern, Attacks Treaty Opponents in Bonn
description: MOSCOW, March 9  The Soviet Union showing serious concern about the prospects for its nonaggression pact with West Germany, has started putting public pressure, on the Christian Democratic party in Bonn to alter its opposition to ratification.

title: Plan to Use Prisoners on Staffs Of State Mental Facilities Urged
MRS. KLINGHOFFER
description: Mrs. Lillian Yerich Klinghoffer, wife of Samuel Klinghoffer, president of the Newark Newsdealers Supply Company, died Wednesday in Miami. She was 64 years old and lived at 3 Glenview Road, South Orange, N. J.

title: Clinics Accused of Medicaid Fraud
description: A group of clinics run by two Queens chiropractors was accused yesterday by the city of Medicaid fraud involving several hundred thousand dollars in claims.

title: GUARDS FORCE 2 INTO COURTROOM
description: Two brothers who had, refused to leave their cell at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men because, they said, they were not being given a chance to prepare for a robbery trial, were teargassed yesterday morning and carried by force to a courtroom.

title: F. P. C. Will Allow First Imports Of Liquefied Natural Gas to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Federal Power Commission authorized a. Boston corporation today to begin the first longterm importation of liquefied natural gas into the United States.

title: Jersey Rule Bears Down On Health Insurance Ads
description: TRENTON, March 10New Jersey insurance officials have drafted a regulation that would require all mailorder health insurance companies, doing business in New Jersey to submit their advertising to the state before it could appear in newspapers or other media.

title: Store Sales Rise 13%
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 The Commerce Department today estimated last week's departmentstore sales at $688million, up 13 per cent from the yearearlier $607million. Last week's total retailstore sales were $7,821,000,000, up 14 per cent from $6,879,000,000.

title: INDIANS PROTEST DEATH OF SIOUX
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 9 (UPI)About 300 Indians, apparently enraged over the death of an Indian in nearby Gordon, Neb., stormed a trading post and museum today in Wounded Knee, scene of the last clash between the Sioux and the United States cavalry.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Starts New PriceRaising Policy
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced three related price moves yesterday that the company said will affect products accounting for more than 50 per cent of the aluminum sheet markets. Sheet products have such varied applications as aluminum siding for the home and pots and pans. The company said that it was raising the actual selling price of a wide range of highvolume com modity sheet items by an average of about 3 per cent. Kaiser added that it was also increasing, by one cent a pound, the actual selling price, but not the published price, of all other sheet and plate products. Excepted are products in that category that received higher price tags earlier in the year.

title: DominguezBijur Duo Gains
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 9Luis Dominguez of New York and Jerry Bijur, winner of the recent Gold Racquet tournament, defeated the local team of Dick Boenning and John Mirkil, 63, 62, 62, in the opening of the United States amateur court tennis doubles championship today at the Racquet Club.

title: U.S. Command, in Shift, Bars Filming of Briefing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP)The United States military command, in a reversal of longestablished practice, refused today to permit the daily war briefing to be filmed by television cameras.

title: N.B.C. Head to Seek PrimeTime Rule Revocation
description: Julian Goodman, president of The National Broadcasting Company, said last night that his network plans to petition the Federal Communications Com mission for revocation of the primetime access rule.

title: In the Matter of Busing
description: As one examines the various antibusing legislation and constitutional amendments now being discussed in the United States Senate and in the White House a common denominator, for an inherent constitutional and moral crisis emerges. All of these proposals, including the ScottMansfield compromise, have as their central fact that for the first time since the Emancipation Proclamation the legislative and executive branches of the Federal Government are seriously entertaining action to limit the rights of racial minorities to unqualified equality of opportunityand are also attempting to limit the duty of the Federal courts to assure and protect these rights.

title: Relief Supplies Await Unloading in the Clogged Ports of Bangladesh
Two Food Landmarks of Very Different Ilk
description: Garden Dairy Cafeteria, 165 East Broadway, AL 46962.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have read in the March 1 Guardian that Senator Mustile, whilst being interviewed on television, broke down and cried.

title: Witness Says He Cashed Thaler's Notes
description: An art dealer testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had acted for Seymour R. Thaler in cashing $250,000 in United States Treasury bills that were stolen from a Wall Street bank.

title: Nixon Assures Peace Corps of Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 The Peace Corps, which has been threatened with Congressional cuts in its budget, Was assured by the White House today that it would receive the funds it needs to continue operating at its present level.

title: Deposit Inflow Near Peak
description: Mutual savings banks had a nearrecord net deposit inflow of $800 billion during February or $11.9billion at a seasonally adjusted annual ratethe National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. reported yesterday. Savings banks in New York accounted for $421million of the gain.

title: Books of The Times
description: In his second novel, The Late Great Creature, Brock Brower has nearly proved what I've always suspectedthat a good book can be written about anything, even a subject as outrageously campy as the old Saturdaymatineehorrormovie industry. I know: Whole generations of Americans these days sit down to their morning bacon with more love M their hearts for Lon Chaney Jr. and the gang than for George Washington and the Founding Fathers. But seriously, a whole three dimensional novel plumbing the immoral depths of Simon Moro, Germanic 68yearold Hollywood horror man? The real significance of Ghoulgantua Moro's. greatest creation? His Gila Man's slimy heart of darkness? Come now, trivia hath its limits: The only fitting spot for yet another Dracula story is right after the Mery Griffin Show. And yethey presto!Mr. Brower has coaxed his creature out of the crypt and made it flap. Watching it take off, we are caught somewhere between a gasp, a giggle and s genuine curiosity about its grisly destination. And, the heavens help us, we even find ourselves reflecting seriously on the significance of the vampire in American culture, on the gospel according to Edgar Allan Poe and on Transylvania as a possible new Golgotha.

title: What's Up, Doc?, A Stylish Comedy
Tough I.T.T. Chief Harold Sydney Geneen
description: Harold Sydney Geneen, a 62yearold Britishborn naturalized citizen, has built reputation as one of the toughest corporate chiefs in American industry and has been periodically under fire for his business tactics since he took command as president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation 12 years ago. The highestpaid executive in the country (his salary in 1970 was $766,000), he has built International Telephone in the last decade into a massive conglomerate with annual sales of more than $7billion, starting with a modest $811million, foreignoriented communications company.

title: R.O.T.C. Volunteers to Fill All Active Duty Openings
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The Army announced today that only volunteers would be ordered to active duty from this year's graduating Reserve Officers Training Corps cadets.

title: LOUIS I. NEWMAN, NOTED RABBI 78
description: Rabbi Louis I. Newman, national Jewish leader who served for 41 years as rabbi of Congregation Rodeph Snolom, 7 West 83d Street, died here yesterday after a year's illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 271 Central Park West.

title: FORD ANNOUNCES SAFETY BAG TEST
description: DETROIT, March 9The Ford Motor Company announced today that it is selling to the Allstate Insurance Company 200 new Mercury cars equipped with experimental air safety bags to be used in a test program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This Headmistress is more than slightly horrified in response to Rita Reif's Feb. 27 article In Many Schools, The Headmistress is a Man. It can not be denied that women Heads are becoming extinct, a fact that saddens me both for the school that will miss having them and for the fulfillment they themselves will miss in not being there.

title: 5DAY TOWN RUNT FAILS TO FIND BOY
description: GREENWOOO Lake, N. Y., March 9Though hope seemed to be waning, a search continued there late today for a 7yearold boy who was last seen on Saturday sitting on the steps of a church and crying.

title: Children's Zoo to Get Two Lesser Pandas
description: Two lesser pandas which look like a cross between a Teddy bear and a raccoon, are being given to the Children's Zoo in Central Park and will arrive next month.

title: STOCKS ON FENCE AS VOLUME RISES
VW Plans Yugoslav Plant
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, March 9 (Reuters)  Volkswagen today announced it would set up a plant for assembling cars and making parts in Yugoslavia. The plant, to be built at Vogosca near Sarajevo, will have an annual production capacity of about. 10,000 vehicles.

title: Notes on People
description: The new president of the United Service Organizetions is Maj. Gen. Francis L. Sampson, who retired last year as Army chief of chaplains. General Sampson succeeds Gen. Emmett (Rosy) O'Donnell, who died in December.

title: East German Parliament Approves Free Abortion
description: BERLIN March 9The East German Parliament passed a bill today allowing free abortion on demand within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.Dr. Mecklinger took note of the opposition of the churches and of a religiously motivated sense of morality among some East German women. He said the new bill left it to the women concerned to make use of the right or to waive it.

title: No One Likely to Knock U.C.L.A. Off Title Road
description: New faces appear each year on the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team to surpass the accomplishments of their predecessors, who were stamped irreplaceable by all but their coach, John Wooden. And each year this master director melds the new with the experienced to produce the. National Collegiate Athletic Association championship team through discipline, pressure defense and speed that exceed anything seen in college basketball.

title: New Jane Trahey Comedy Is Scheduled for Broadway
description: Ring Round the Bathtub, a new comedy by Jane Trahey, Was announced yesterday for Broadway production on April 26 at the Martin Beck Theater by Jacqueline Babbin and Jay R. Wolfe.

title: THIEU IS FORMING A POLITICAL PARTY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9  President Nguyen Van Thieu is working slowly and secretly to form a political party that will include not only oldline politicians but also large numbers of military officers, village leaders and most of the, powerful province chiefs.

title: Education Industry Is Marketing A B C's
description: CHICAGO, March 9  A permanent exposition facility to display and demonstrate materials for the $70billionayear education industry was formally opened here today.

title: City vs. Suburbs3 Families a ly the Score
description: When the Morton Greenbergs decided to move to suburbia in 1969, their longtime friends, Jesse and Lola Meyers spent many hours trying to persuade them not to give up the good life of the city.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
No Decision on Rearming Pakistan, U.S. Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) State Department officials said today that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India had raised a nonissue when she charges that the United States planned to rearm Pakistan.

title: Basil O'Connor, Polio Crusader, Dies
description: Basil O'Connor, who raised hundreds of millions of dollars for research into poliomyelitis that led to the development of the first vaccine for the disease, died yesterday in Phoenix, Ariz., of a heart ailment complicated by pneumonia. He was 80 years or age and lived at 23 East 74th Street in New York.

title: Senate Committee Asks U.S. To Recognize Bangladesh
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today resolution calling for United States recognition of Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan.

title: WILLARD E. BULL
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., March 9Willard E. Bull of 1815 Northgate Road, former pricing manager for the Western Electric Company in Kearny, died yesterday at a nursing home in Old Saybrook, Conn. His age was 75. He retired in 1961 after 42 years service with Western Electric.

title: Renault's Head Tells of Threats As Police Hunt Kidnapped Aide
description: PARIS March 9 (AP)  Pierre Dreyfus director of the governmentowned Renault automobile concern said tonight that his family had been menaced apparently by the Maoist guerrillas who kidnaped a Renault executive yesterday Mr. Dreyfus also said threats had been made to blow up his apartment.

title: Justice Agency Official Defends Death Penalty as a Deterrent
description: WASHINGTON, March 9A representative of the Justice Department defended the practice of capital punishment today before a Congressional panel although he said he personally abhorred it.

title: U.S. AIDE HOPEFUL ON AN ARMS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, March (UPI)Gerard C. Smith, the chief United States arms negotiator, said today specific agreements between the United States an dthe Soviet Union on limiting defensive missile systems would be the aim of United States negotiators during the seventh round of talks with the Soviet Union opening March 28 in Helsinki.

title: Executive Changes
description: George A. Oberle and Robert J. Padovano have been elected first vice presidents of Walston & Co,, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Bows in Softball, 21
description: MANILA, March 9 (AP)Guam upset the United States, 21, today in the men's world softball tournament. It was the first loss in six starts for the defending champions from Cedar Rapids,. Iowa, and only the second triumph in seven outings for Guam.

title: Humphrey: Why I Run
description: WASHINGTONI have devoted my life to public service as mayor of great city, as a leader in the United States Senate, as Vice President of the United States. I have come to know this nation, its problems and its people as few candidates have.

title: The Forgotten Taiwanese
description: President Nixon's journey to Peking last month has finally shattered the sustaining illusions of the Chiang Kaishek regime on Taiwanthe claim that it is the only legitimate Government of China and the hope for triumphal return to the mainland. This was inescapable. Support for Chiang's pretensions and the maintenance of American military bases on Taiwan, Which Mr. Nixon has now pledged ultimately to withdraw, were obviously incompatible with the AmericanChinese rapprochement that reality has long dictated and which the President has prudently sought.

title: Court is Asked to Abolish Bail System
description: The Legal Aid Society asked the Appellate, Division here yesterday to throw out the present system of determining bail in Manhattan's. courts, charging that it discriminates against the poor and denies them due

title: Time to Act on Ulster
description: More than a month ago, British officials said Prime Minister Heath was merely waiting for the right moment to unveil a bold new plan for Northern Ireland. If Mr. Heath still holds back in the hope of getting an extended period of calm in which to launch his plan, he surely has things turned around. A program aimed at eliminating longstanding injustices for Ulster's Catholic minority and building a climate in which the communities can work together would do more than anything else to remove support and sanctuary for the Irish Republican Army gunmen, whose cowardly terrorism continues apace.

title: Insurer's Net Up In 1971
description: Net income of the American International Group, Inc., rose 30 per cent last year to $31.3. million, or $3.21 a share, from 1970's $23.87million, or $2.47 a share, the insurance holding company reported yesterday, Net realized gains amounted to an additional $4.2million last year, up from $1.5million.

title: Price Controls Are Eased for LowProfit Companies
description: WASHINGTON March 9 The Price Commission announced today new regulations providing relief from price controls for companies incurring losdes or low profits.

title: Nixon's Team Uses Primaries to Train
Busing Ultimatum
description: The majority of the House has voted to ram its extreme antibusing position down the Senate's throat. By instructing its conferees to insist that these uncompromising antibusing amendments must remain unchanged, the House has resorted to the device of nonnegotiable demands that used to be considered a mark of radical adolescence.

title: Chrysler May See a Need To Raise Funds Overseas
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday it may need to raise funds overseas this year.

title: Advertising:
description: The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation, one of the biggest names In direct mail, has added something to its envelope of tricks.

title: U.S Aide Arrives to Inform Malaysians on Nixon Visit
description: KUALA LUMPUR Malaysia March 9 (UPI)Marshall Green a United States Assistant Secretary of State arrived here today to inform Malaysian leaders about President Nixon's visit to China.

title: Bridge: FalseCarding by a Defender Gives a Problem to Declarer
description: Some falsecarding possibilities available to the defenders are not easy to think of in the heat of battle.

title: U.S to Send an Aide to Venice Biennale
description: Walter Hopps, director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, has been named by the Smithsonian Institution to organize the United States exhibition at this year's Venice Biennale, opening June 11.

title: Press Institute Plans 1972 Groundbreaking
description: The American Press Institute plans to break ground this year for its home in Reston, Va., outside Washington.

title: F. M. ISSERMAN, 74, A RABBI IN ST. LOUIS
description: ST. LOUIS, March 9 (AP)Rabbi Ferdinand M. Isserman, who was active in social justice and community relations and who served at Temple Israel in St. Louis from 1929 until 1964, died Tuesday at the age of 74.

title: BHUTTO MAY VISIT SOVIET THIS MONTH
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan March 9President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will probably visit Moscow in the next two weeks, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I find the Feb. 14 OnEd article The Right to Choose Death out of touch with reality as I know it. Having carried a large number of people through serious, fatal illness I find that the choice of death by the patient is virtually never expressed. It has been so rare an occurrence as to raise the question whether it is not a manifestation of abnormal mental function when it does occur.

title: Police Kill a Deputy Wound 3 In a Tragic MixUp in Detroit
Position Seems Stronger
description: PARIS, March 9Prince Sihanouk appears to have consolidated his position as the leader of the struggle against the Americanbacked regime of Premier Lon No1 in Pnompenh.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Police Begin Connecticut Slowdown.

title: Aides of Panama And the U.S. Deny Impasse on Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat of Staten Island, said at a news conference today that United StatesPanamanian negotiations on a new canal treaty had reached an impasse.

title: Doubt Is Cast on McGrawHill's Memoirs of Red Fox
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Even if one disregards for the momeat the question of the $400,000 and Mr. Kleindienst in the I.T.T. case, one cannot help but be struck by the gist of the negotiations between I.T.T. and the Justice Department (news article March 3). For the aim of the Government's case was to prevent I.T.T. from becoming so large as to exercise an inordinate amount of unilateral power in the marketplace of a free economy. Yet. Mr. McLaren, the antitrust chief, was swayed from his view that I.T.T. should dispose of Hartford Fire Insurance because he was convinced by I.T.T. that the result of such a severance might be a general slide in the stock market, and... the conglomerate's lack of liquidity would handicap its foreign operations and damage the United States position in its balance of international payments.

title: Shell Announcess Oil Find
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 9 (Reuters)The Shell Petroleum Company announced today what it described as an im portant oil find in the Diyarbakir region of eastern Turkey. The company said the Barbes One well is currently producing crude at a rate of about 2,000 barrels a day and this is expected to increase to 4,000 barrels.

title: Hirshhorn Gives Museum 326 Works
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Joseph H. Hirshhorn has given 326 additional works of art to the museum here that will bear his name.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Lighter Line
description: Beginning this month, the International Game Fish Association is establishing new category for world record marine fish in the sixpound line test class.

title: TV LOSS MAY SHUT A PAPER IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, March 9  Barring a legal or financial miracle, a venerable but tarnished journalistic institution known as The Boston Herald Traveler appears to be heading for extinction.

title: U.S.Brazil Fishing Accord Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The United States and Brazil have reached an agreement in principle aimed at avoiding seizures of American fishing vessels off the Brazilian coast, according to United States officials and foreign diplomats here.

title: Haywood Of Sonics Out For Remainder of Season
description: SEATTLE, March 9 (AP)Spencer Haywood of the Seattle SuperSonics will be out for the rest of the season with a knee injury, the National Baskotball Association club said today.

title: Belfast Bomb Explosion Kills 3, Including 2 Alleged I.R.A. Men
description: BELFAST Northern Ireland March 9  Three men were killed and three seriously injured today when a 20pound bomb blew up a house in the Falls Road area, a Roman Catholic section of Belfast.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON DRUGS PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) Senate and House conferees reached agreement tonight on a $1billion, threeyear plan of attack on drug abuse.

title: RailTon Mileage Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Association of American Railroads reported that freight traffic in the week ended March 4 totaled an estimated 14.9 billion tonmiles, up 5 per cent from the corresponding week last year. Carloadings totaled 488,373, down 0.6 pet cent. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported that the week's tonnage rose 4.2 per cent.

title: Council Unit Acts To End Long Fight Over Corona Homes
description: A bill that is expected to resolve the bitter fiveyearold battle to save the modest homes of a. group of Corona, Queens, homeowners from condemnation for a new high school was voted out yesterday by the City Council's State Legislation Committee.

title: I.L.A. on South Atlantic And Gulf Favors New Pact
description: The tally on how dockworkers from Maine to Texas voted on a new contract Wednesday continued to itickle into International Dongshoremen's Association headquarters here yesterday.

title: DAVIS ATTORNEYS ACCEPT THE PANEL
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 9A jury was nearly seated today for the trial of Angela Davis.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Aide Opposes Draft of Black Preamble
AnimalShelter Closing Brings Furor
description: A furor is brewing over the closing of private animal shelter in Woodhave, Queens, from which 81 dogs were carted away Tuesday by the Board of Health and the American Society for the Prevention of cruelty to Animals.

title: The Frustrated Voter
description: Nothing is more frustrating for a citizen than to discover he cannot vote because he has not lived his state or community long enough or because he forgot to register weeks or months before Election Day. Nothing could be more ironic since democracy thrives on popular participation.

title: EMBARGO ON COPPER COMPLETED BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 9 (UPI)The Chilean Government announced today the ernbargo of the remaining bank accounts and real estate in Chile of the Anaconda and Kennecott Copper Companies.

title: PIANIST, IN DEBUT, JOINS VIOLINIST
description: Wanda Wilkomirska, the Polish violinist who first appeared here 11 years ago, was partnered by the Brazilian pianist Antonio Barbosa for a program in Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night. For Mr. Barbosa it Was a New York debut, although he is known here through his recordings.

title: Subway Station in Paris Becomes a Temporary Art Gallery
description: PARIS March 9Art is being brought to the straphanging masses this Month with 14 sculptors exhibitng their avantgarde work in a subway station.

title: 42 FOOD PLACES ARE CITED BY CITY
description: Two restaurants in the Pan Am Building, the Trattoria and the Zum Zum, were among 42 food establishments cited yesterday by the city's Health Services Administration as having serious violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Dun &
description: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., the creditreporting and communications company, has started selling group life insurance this week in a move that could add significantly to earnings over the long term, Hamilton B. Mitchell, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

title: $700,000 Stolen From an Armored Car
description: ROCHESTER, MarchTwo apparently unarmed thieves stole canvas sacks containing about $700,000 in cash from a parked armored truck here today while its Myer and guard were delivering money in a nearby Eastman Kodak Company plant.

title: 409Pounder Helps Iowa State Take N.C.A.A. Wrestling Lead
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 9 (UPI)Seven Iowa State wrestlers led by 409pounder Chris Taylor, powered through preliminary rounds of the National Collegiate wrestling championships tonight to give the Cyclones a commanding early lead in the battle for the team title.

title: TWO TILE TO OPPOSE CANDIDATE OF AMEX
description: The American Stock Exchange confirmed yesterday that two of its specialists have filed petitions that place them in a threeway race for the vice chairmanship of the Board of Governors when members vote on April 10.

title: Albee and Barr Are Signed
description: Edward Albee, the playwright, and Richard Barr, the producer, have been engaged as codirectors of the John drew Theater of Guild Hall, the cultural center in East Hampton, L. I. The summer season is expected to open with a double bill, Thornton Wilder's The Long Christmas Dinner and Mr. Albee's The American Dream. Also scheduled is the world premiere of The Palace at Four A.M., a drama by Howard Moss, poetry editor of The New Yorker.

title: Mrs. Onassis Contends Privacy Includes Errands, Even in Public
description: Mrs. Aristotle Onassis declared yesterday that when one is engaged in private errands, even in a public place, that's private.

title: 2 Arrested in Hawaii Protest
description: HONOLULU, March 9 (AP)A professor and a former teacher at a Roman Cathoic school have been arrested for pouring what they said was human blood on secret military documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced. James W. Douglass, assistant professor of religion at the University of Hawaii, and James V. Albertini, former teacher at St. Ann's Catholic School in Kaneohe.

title: Advertising:
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I, March 9Long Island's largest bank, Security National, took its first major step into New York City today when its shareholders approved a merger with the Royal National Bank of New York.

title: Mitchell Leads by Shot With 66 in Citrus Open
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The marijuana problem, to be understood, must be viewed in the context of the whole drug movement in our nation. A sort of crisis is before us againnot with alcohol, which we accept, or narcotics, which we don't accept, but with marijuana, where there is indecision.

title: Chase Weighs New Unit For Investment Work
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the parent company of the nation's, thirdlargest bank, is actively considering a spinout of its $12billion investment, management business, Herbert P. Patterson, president of the company, said yesterday.

title: Taiwan Plans Parliamerztary Election
description: TAIPEI Taiwan March 9The Central Committee of the Kuomintang or Nationalist party laid the groundwork today for new national parliamentary elections the first since the late nineteenforties.

title: RIG INCREASE URGED FOR HEART RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 1 Legislation that would almost double Federal spending on heart, lung and blood diseases was introduced today by Congressional leaders in the health field.

title: U.S. Pair Is 3d in Figure Skating
PENN STATE LEADS EAST GYMNASTICS
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 9Penn State took commanding lead tonight in its bid to represent the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League in the National Collegiate gymnastics championships at Ames, Iowa, April 6 to 8.

title: Legislature Asked to Study Free Fare Concept
description: The Legislature was urged yesterday by 66 of its members to undertake a statewide study of whether to do away with publictransit fares because of declining ridership and revenues.

title: Morton Opposes Change in Environmental Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said today that he was opposed at this time to an amendment to the National Environmental Policy Act proposed by Russell E. Train, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality.

title: CASE AGAINST VESCO DROPPED IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, March 9 (AP)Jean Eger, Geneva Attorney General, confirmed today that his office had dropped its case against three top executives of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., who had been criminally charged with illegal practices in obtaining control of the mutualfund complex.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG GAINS IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, March 9 (UPI) Topseeded Evonne Goolagong rallied from a 53 deficit in the second set tonight to defeat Helen Gourlay, 6.3, 76, and move into the quarterfinals of the $30,000 Maureen Connolly. Brinker tennis tournament.

title: The Army's Strength
description: WASHINGTONIn a recent column on this page I provided an assessment of the Army as it is today and mentioned briefly some of the measures we are taking to revitalize it as we enter the postVietnam era.

title: Waldheim Is Urged by Blacks to Assist SouthWest Africa
description: WINDHOEK South West Africa, March 9Secretary General Waldheim on the last day of his tour of SouthWest Africa today was handed a petition from a black group, demanding that the United Nations bring an immediate end to South African rule over the territory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Many of the statements that have been made regarding the I.T.T., consent judgment show how few Americans understand the entire situation.Consent judgments are not sellouts.

title: Chou Said to Visit Hanoi to Discuss Nixon Trip and Help, Settle Dispute Among Indochina Insurgents
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Authoritative reports received today by the United States Government said that Premier Chou Enlai of China secretly visited Hanoi last weekend to acquaint the North Vietnamese leadership with the highlights of his conversations with President Nixon.

title: BOND PRICES VARY AMID MIXED MOOD
ReadiniPlan Developer Hopeful That Black Children Will Profit
description: WYANDANCH, L. I., March 9 Charles Jackson, who is 8 years old and in the third grade at the Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School here, picked up an eighthgrade reader and read a passage that visitor had selected random on how the moon's ??rface was formed from the inpact of meteorites. Then he explained what he had read.

title: BROOKLYN BLUES HEARD ON 34TH ST.

Essentially sympathetic to the plan, he should take courage; there is a world of difference between the two proposals.

title: C.O.P. Said to Seek End of I.T.T. Pact On Convention Aid
SATO SEES PEKING LIMITING HANOI AID
Books of The Times
description: Souls on Fire is an informal, highly poetic survey of the Hasidic movement through sketches of its major figures and eloquent summaries. of their teachings. But it is even more, a significant document in its own right. For it is an attempt to reaffirm for modern Jewry the strength of Hasidic teaching, which many will say in sad decay; and the validity of message and methods: the parable, the legend, the f a b l e. Although. Elie Wiesel refers to himself merely as the narrator, he is very much part of the contents of the volume. For his book is a testimony and he is a witness in it. At the end he says that he sees himself as the transmitter of an ancient tradition, one who stands in the chain of narrators, a link between links, to paraphrase Martin Buber. Were not the author who he is, Souls on Fire could be considered a lyrical evocation of a certain chapter in the history. of East European Jews. But Elie Wiesel is no ordinary witness and his affirmation of the lifegiving force. of Hasidism will appear to many readers as strange as any of the strange accounts he has recorded in his book.

title: Autopsy Shows No Torture
description: RAPID CITY, March 9 (AP)  A second autopsy on the body of Raymond Yellow Thunder, a 51yearold Sioux who died last month in Gordon, Neb., showed no evidence of mutilation or torture, a lawyer said today.

title: Hartke Said to Consider Ending Active Candidacy

Despite a spurt of aggressive personal campaigning in New Hampshire, Mr. Hartke managed to poll only 3 per cent of the vote there. He finished fourth, trailing Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, who was not on the ballot but conducted a costly writein effort.

description: To the Editor: Recently, public attention has been focused on, school, busing because of its use in achieving racial balance. With the outcry against using busing for this purpose several important aspects of the problem have been missed The development of school bus routes for a school district is, highly complex problem. For the last few, years a group of us have been working on computerassisted route constructiOn. The mathematical aspects of the problem place it as one of the most difficult and challenging combinatorial Problems. In fact our pocedures incorporate ideas we developed working, for NASA on scheduling a space shuttle system.

title: Film: Music and Its Roots
description: Anybody who loves the scheen for what it can quietly accomplish with skill, honestly and economy, admist anything-goes chaos, shouldn't miss "A Well Spent Life" and "Spend It All."These two color documentary featurettes, one on an old Negro blues singer in Texas and the other on a group of Louisiana Cajuns, are wonderful to watch. Both were made by Les Blank, who previously won acclaim for "The Blues Accordin' to Lightnin' Hopkins," also culled from Texas sources.The two new pictures, showing this weekend and next at the uptown Film Forum, already have been hailed with the first as "three of the best films on music and its cultural roots ever made by an American," and all we can do is second the motion. Mr. Blank is a gifted man, born to the movie camera.There is nothing conventionally pretty or picturesque about either of the new films. Using his camera and sound track like an inquiring eavesdropper, with his subjects speaking to the camera and each other, Mr. Blank simply records their lives and utterances. His camera welds them to their backgrounds. Their music says the rest."Spend It All" centers on a group of part-time musicians, happily rooted in Louisiana's Cajun bayous, whose lusty old-time ballads and chanteys memorably evoke their traditions and realistic contentment.Even more impressive is "A Well Spent Life," centering on the 75-year-old blues singer, Mance Lipscomb, who is truly a man of remember. This remarkable old Negro plays his guitar, sings, reviews his life, ambles about his native Texas countryside (an intimate close-up that few Northern whites or blacks know) and somehow, by his very proximity, makes our own lives a little better.

title: Helicopter Aids in Capture Of 2 Youths in Car Chase
description: Two teenagers who alleged. ly stole one car, banged into five others and almost ran over two.policemen in a 70mileanhour chase yesterday in Brooklyn proved no match for a police helicopter that followed them until they were captured.

A spokesman for the group said that, after all, this kind of thing has been going on for years, though admittedly without benefit Of selentific purpose. He found it rather paradoxical that when we do it on a nonsexual and platonic basis, it becomes a news issue.

title: Peacock Pulling in Its Feathers
description: Everybody's been saying that the male fashion pace has slowed down to a conservative walk. If there was any doubt about the swing to the right, Ohrbach's presentation of its spring and summer men's fashions yesterday cast the decisive vote. In the past, many of the store's men's shows have been wingdings with rock bands, dozens of models and huge audiences. This year's performance was a minishow, with just three mannequins and no fireworks. A store spokesman explained that the abbreviated show was not an economy measure, but that men's clothes are back to their presixties simplicity and not as adaptable to dramatizing as in the hippie era..

title: Prime Rate Is Raised By First National city
description: The First National City Bank, New York's largest bank, announced yesterday that its base; or prime, lending rate for the week beginning Monday would be 4 per cent, up from 4 per cent previously.

title: First Aid for Mass Transit
description: Compared with a Federal farm subsidy of $5.5 billion, a mere $400million contribution to the operation of the country's mass transit lines may seem too modest to warrant enthusiasm. But that is what the Institute for Rapid Transit estimates to be the annual operating deficit of the nation's bus, subway and commuter lines. And it is what an emergency bill introduced by Representative Koch of New York would have the Federal Governinent put up in order to stabilize fare structures and save the lines from further deterioration.

title: 'Georgia, Georgia' Arrives at the Forum
description: Maya Angelou, the black-author-actress-singer-poet who is making her debut as a screenwriter, along with Diana Sands and the rest of the interracial cast of "Georgia, Georgia," which opened yesterday at the Forum, cannot be faulted for lack of purpose and sincerity.They speak with passionate feeling about the stark state of blacks in a world of terrible misunderstanding and dissension. But their emotions are, sadly enough, too often projected in rhetoric and surface histrionics rather than drama.Miss Sands, in the role of an American pop singing star on a concert tour in Stockholm, is caught up in the genuine ecstacy of a love affair with a white, expatriate American photographer. She is also dependent on but dislikes her militantly black, mother-figure of a maid-companion and her homosexual, black manager. And she is constantly importuned by a group of black G.I. deserters from Vietnam who want her help in enlisting sympathy for them back home.These frighteningly real issues are couched in explicit, with-it dialogue, but they are for the most part merely stated, often stridently, and not resolved. Miss Angelou's unexpected, shocking climactic scene, involving Miss Sands and her companion, appears to be not so much of a resolution of the film or her tortured heroine's problems as simply a melodramatic device.Credit Miss Sands with a finely tuned performance as the troubled entertainer desperately seeking identity in her hectic surroundings. She may be, as one of the principals wrly says, a cool, superior type who has "just about kicked the habit" of being black.But she is also the lonely success who, detesting her companion, still needs in private her mammy-like lullabies and ministrations. And she is a woman suddenly and defiantly in love.Dirk Benedict, now on Broadway in "Butterflies Are Free," makes his film debut with a sensitive, restrained performance as a young man in love. Minnie Gentry of Broadway's "Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death" is forcefully natural as the officious maid-companion consumed by hatred of whites.Along with other actual black deserters, Terry Whitmore, the G. I. subject of a 1969 documentary about his desertion, gives reality, though not much impact, to the proceedings. And Roger Furman, as the homosexual manager, gives a merely conventional performance.Stig Bjorkman, the film's young Swedish director, has competently kept the story and cast moving briskly against the colorful background of Stockholm, where the film was shot. But the basic, essentially important source material provided by Miss Angelou is too often simplistic and only occasionally memorable.

title: Accident Loss a Record

The exhibition is called Rodin Drawings: True and False.

In favoring the construction of the bridge, Mr. Barra thereby also favors bringing more cars and more carbon monoxide from these into the various communities involved. [Editorial Feb. 7.]

title: Nothing in Common With Whites
description: ITHACA, N. Y.Only a white person would ask me how I feel as a black student on a white university campus. Arid no doubt you'd expect me to, say I am alienated and going through all kinds of changes with my white classmates, white professors and White oriented courses. While all this is true, it is not by any means the most important problem facing me. It would be if. I had expected to be treated differently.

title: No Military Bands For Parading Irish

description: A Federal judge rejected yesterday socalled class action status for a suit against the Chemical Bank involving charges that it engaged in illegalreciprocal business practices in its trust department.

title: Dave Anderson
description: As inconspicuously as possible for anyone 6 feet Inches and 255 pounds, Wayne Embry, has eased into history as the first black general manager in major league sports. He has been entrusted with the operation of the ball club, as he describes it. meaning the Milwaukee Bucks, the National Basketball Association champions. Incredibly, sports has survived the arrival of an Afrotopped brain in the front office.. In two games since his appointment, the ball hasn't gone flat, the backboards haven't toppled, the polished floors haven't opened into a chasm. Equally important, Wayne Embry, who will be 35 years old in two weeks, has survived his new stature.

title: Taiwan Envoy Says U.S. Assured. Him on Deals
description: TAIPEI Taiwan March 10Taiwan's Ambassador to Washington, James Shen said here today that while relations between his Government and Washington were at an alltime low, American officials had assured him that President Nixon had made no secret deals, during his talks with Chinese Communist leaders in Peking.

title: Catamaran Is Devised That Mops Up Oil Spills From Waterways
description: WASHINGTON, March 10A catamaran named the MopCat cleans up oil spills from waterways. A drum that revolves between the twin hulls absorbs the oil in its plasticfoam surface, from which it is squeezed out and colleeted.Patent 3,646,901, as signed to the Worthington Corporation, Mountainside, N. J., was granted for the catamaran this week to four Worthington employes and two staff men from the Marine Applications Company, Inc., Mineola, L. I.

title: Agnew to Give Students View of Administration
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)Vice President Agnew announced last night that he would visit several college campuses in the coming months to present American students with the Nixon Administration's point of view and to find out what is on the young people's minds.

title: 2 MIG's OVER SINAI REPORTED BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, March 10Two jet fighters identified as MIG23's flew over Israeli positions the occupied Sinai Peninsula today, military headquarters here reported.

title: 2 Germanys Report Progress In Talks Toward Traffic Pact
description: BERLIN, March 10East and West Gemany reported progress today in their talks toward achieving a general traffic agreement between the two countries.

title: Talent Festival
description: "New Directors/New Films" is the omnibus title for the very interesting film series currently being shown at the Museum of Modern Art under the joint sponsorship of the museum and the Lincoln Center Film Society.With perhaps remarkable restraint, the members of the selection committee (Richard Roud, for the film society, and Willard Van Dyke, Donald Richie and Adrienne Mancia, for the museum) have imposed no arbitrary theme on the festival. Each of the 10 selections simply represents either the first or second feature by a promising new director not yet known in this country.On the basis of the quality and intensity (if not always the complete success) of the festival's first five film's, which I saw this week, it's particularly disappointing to learn that the seriesending Monday nightis attracting something less than capacity audiences.The show is the first major collaboration of New York's two most imposing film establishments since the "American Voices" series, which they presented in conjunction with the 8th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center in 1970. More importantly, the show is providing some talented young filmmakers with the kind of unhurried presentation not possible at a more or less conventional festival, where the Buuels, the Bergmans, the Godards and the Olmis occupy the attention (with, I should add, some justification).Following the lead of the selection committee, I won't attempt to impose a theme on my report on the first half of the festival. The order in which the films are discussed is the chronological order in which they were seen:"Dear Irene" is the first feature by two young Danish film critics, Ch. Braad Thomsen, who directed the film and wrote the screenplay with Mette Knudsen, who plays the title role. Irene pretends to be politically concerned but she's actually bored with everythingher husband, her lover and her job.For a film about boredom, "Dear Irene" is remarkably humane and unmannered and, finally, very touching as Irene finds herself literally cornered, in a freeze frame, a likely recruit to the ranks of the alienated strangers whom she encounters, talking to themselves, in an anything but gay Copenhagen. Mr. Thomsen's techniques are not new, but the emotions are always genuine."The Role of My Family in the World Revolution," the second feature by Bata Cengic, is another chaotic Marxist political comedy from Yugoslavia, the country that gave us Makavejev's "WRThe Mysteries of the Organism" for no great gain. The movie utilizes slapstick comedy techniques, songs, sketches (Adolf and Eva Hitler spending an evening at home with TV) and a number of eccentric actors to pass on what seems to me to be an especially mysterious kind of cynicism (perhaps because I'm not Yugoslav)."The Truce" (French), the first feature to be directed by Claude Guillemot, is a long, gentle gag film about two Parisian con artists, rivals at their trade, who, with their doxies, spend a very funny weekend in the country, which is, of course, alien ground. One of them likes to fish, not with a pole but with hand grenades; the other by electrifying the waters. Nicely acted by Daniel Gelin and Charles Denner, and very very mild."Dot Dot Dot" (meaning ". . ." for the ellipses used in writing) is the first feature by Edgardo Cozarinsky, a young Argentine whose program notes for the film are much more eloquent than the film itself. From the notes I learn that the film is about a priest who has been defrocked because his views are too right-wing even for the church. (I wouldn't have known otherwise.) The style of the film is nothing if not elliptical, but its comments on the Argentine church and on the bourgeoisie are sometimes quite funny."The Anxiety of the Goalie at the Penalty Kick" is the second feature by Wim Wenders, a young German director. Based on a novel to be published here next month by Peter Handke, the film is the most ambitious and most successful of the museum series so far, a beautifully acted and photographed tale of existential alienation, set in a world that is all the more terrifying because it is so familiar. It will deserve further comment when, as I hope, it finds a commercial release here.

title: Liquidation of Quality
description: Eight years ago the election to Congress of two outstanding Reform DemodratsJonathan B. Bingham and James H. Scheuerdelivered a death blow to the sleazy political machine headed by former Bronx boss Charles Buckley. Ever since, these two legislators have been refreshing exceptions in a New York delegation on Capitol Hill that abounds in mediocrity.

description: Abe Grauer, a fur merchant who retired recently as. a part owner of Revilion Freres and formerly had been an owner of Grauer & Hershkowitz, died here yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived at 241 Central Park West.

description: WHITE FLANS, March 10 people, who do not live in Westchester County, the title Sheaf of Westchester may ?? up an image that is quaint or even amusing. The county's residents know better.

description: MIAMI March 10They are waitresses and gas station attendants machinists and sales clerks and housewives. Some of them go to school part time. Many of them, are unemployed. description: To the Editor: President Nixon stated that he changed the world by making his muchpublicized trip to China.

title: Good Rhetoricand Quack
description: SHIPPENSBURG, Pa.Rhetoric today suffers under a general misapprehension. For many readers, rhetoric is always dishonest or specious, innocuous at best, always the decoration of falsehood for its acceptance as truth. By rhetoric we often mean bad rhetoric, confusing the proper and the pejorated meanings, the art and the perversion of itself.

description: TO the Editor: Somehow, as one follows the debate on whether to bus or not bus children to achieve a racial mix (for whatever reason), :there emerges a nightMarish qualitY to this volatile issue: Columnists, editorial. writers, educaiors, islators and jurists batter opponents of busing with the necessitynay, the unswerving duty of the Republicof establishing a virtual racial quota for each component of the public school System.

Safeguarding the Airlines

Even before last week, many planes had been hijacked and many others had been subjected to bomb threats.

description: A rise in the price of frozen boneless beef futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange was attributed by traders to Thursday's Presidential proclamation that would raise the United States meatimport quota by 7 per cent. Most of the increased imports would be frozen boneless beef.

description: TOKYO March 10The first Chinese trade mission in six years arrived in Japan tonight to discuss the purchase of a syntheticfiber plant and related technology.

title: In Spoleto a Quake Is a Welcome Diversion
description: SPOLETO, Italy, March 7 Tradition here has it that before the pagans cut off St. Ponzlano's head in A.D. 175 he declared: Spoleto tremera ma non cadra (Spoleto will shake but not fall).

description: SINGAPORE, Saturday, March 11 (Reuters)Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green arrived in Singapore today to explain President Nixon's China visit to the republic's leaders.

description: VIENNA, March 10  Walter Dejaco the former Pal architect who designed and built the Auschwitz gas chambers and cremation furnaces in which three million Jews died was acquitted of murder and released Iron custody here today.

description: Stringent security measures at airports across the country won the praise of pilots and the apparently growing acceptance of passengers yesterday as bomb threats continued to plague the industry, but in declining numbers.

title: Hanoi Exhibit Depicts 71 Victory in Laos
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 11The defeat of South Vietnamese troops during the Laos incursion a year ago was a disappointment to American military planners, but it has been widely described in Washington as only a setback along the inevitable road to successful Vietnamization.

description: To Tim EDITOR:

title: Smooth on the water and easy on the eye
description: The Chinese are innately conservative yet paradoxically inventive, even though an innovation may take a thousand years to complete. In the watercraft of the Yangtze the vast river (fourth largest in the world) that bisects China and carries much of its commerce  the character and activities of this remarkable race are succinctly and graphically portrayed. The maritime record shows originality of thought, a distinct appreciation and knowledge of the principles of naval architecture, minute specialization of type as related to place and function, skillful use of available materials, and incredible patience and labor with the simplest of tools to produce varieties of junks and sampans that are efficient and in many cases beautiful. To Western eyes the junk may appear clumsy and unhandy  but this is not necessarily true, as shipmasters and yachtsmen who have had a sailing brush with these craft can testify.

title: Kheel and Union Leaders Assail Curbs on Public Worker Strikes
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and labor mediator, and union leaders spoke out emphatically at a meeting here last week against the state's Taylor Law that prohibits public employes from going on strike.

title: Movies
description: IT was with more than a little apprehension that I approached the moated Scottish fortress that is the home of filmmaker R. T. Maihem on recent afternoon. Maihem, the brilliant director of such provocative and ultraviolent movies as Orange Dogs and The French Mole and probably the foremost proponent of the let'sfaceitmanisananimal school of cinematic art, has a reputation as a tough subject to interview, and his antipathy toward journalists is well known.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE DOLLAR came under heavy selling pressure as nearly every major currency sold at or near its upper limit against the dollar. The Fed said $196billion was added to dollar holdings in the week ended Wednesday.... Herbert Stein,. chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, rejected suggestions that the U.S. should raise interest rates protect the dollar... In a step toward monetary union the E.E.C. narrowed margins of fluctuation on members currencies against each other from 4 to 2%.

title: But All is Not Lost: The Concierge Remains Indispensable

Hethat great repository of all knowledge, that unexampled purveyor of all servicesis simply not dug by most Americans. They are either afraid of him, or distrustful of his ministrations. Fools ye know not what ye do.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Those who followed the lead of Imam Baraka and Hoyt Fuller in developing the concept of a Black Aesthetic were well aware of the opposition which awaited them from the American literary establishment. Such opposition, calculated and defensive, was initiated by critics from The Saturday Review and The New York Review of Books, in separate reviews of the anthology, Black Fire, edited by Imamu Baraka and Larry Neal. Our Mutual Estates, written by Theodore Gross and published in Antioch Review, was another broadside, attacking those who questioned the arrogant premise put forward by white critics and reviewers that they were more qualified than blacks to evaluate the cultural artifacts of black people. The most recent and perhaps the most insidious of the literature in defense of this position is your article, No Franchises Available Mlle Last Word by

description: WOODBURY, L.I., March 11 The first Eastern women's hardcourt tennis championships in singles and doubles has been scheduled by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association for the Woodbury Country Club beginning May 30.

title: Kenya, to Ban Hippies
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 Visitors have been warned that they risk being turned back if they arrive at Kenya's borders with long, shaggy, unkempt hair. The Vice President and Minister for Home Affairs, Daniel Arap Moi, said at rally: We'll turn them back at Nairobi airport. They can go back to their own country, be it America, Canada, Australia or Britain.

title: Stamps
description: THE 1972 National Park stamps series will be completed with issues for the littleknown but impressive Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts in Virginia on June 26, and for the wellknown McKinley Park, Alaska, on July 28. The Wolf Trap Farm Park issue will be a 6cent stamp, normally for use on private postal cards; the McKinley stamp will be of 15cent denomination, for surface mail overseas.

title: Legislative Notes: Redistricting Is Still Touch and Go
description: TRENTON  On Thursday, the State Senate is scheduled to vote on four plans to reapportion New Jersey's 15 Congressional Districts. Republicans control the Senate by a 24to16 edge, but have not yet been able to put together more than 18 votes for their version.

title: The World
description: We have averted a confrontation that would have been disastrous for the nation. We got the best agreement we could under the circumstances.

title: Filling the nonexistent gap
description: Mozart is dead. Whatever remains unclear about his life, personality and career, as well as his art, that much is certain. Thus, with an inauspicious thud, begins Michael Levey's biography. Although the remainder of the book seldom rises to the numbing fatuity or that intrada, the entrails are there to be read: we are not going to learn much from this one. Mr. Levey is no musician, to judge from internal evidence, and his scholarship is confined to gleaning from the standard works on Mozart. The result is another piece of Mozart idolatry, this one aimed at the audience for which B.H. Haggin wrote his Music for the Man Who Likes Hamlet"the literate but marginally musical man.

title: C &
description: WASHINGTON  Hikerbiker nuts, antique stonework obsessives. Civil War and Revolutionary War fans, folklore lovers, horseback devotees and birdwatching zealots, as well as rockhounds, fishermen, canoeists, strollers and plain lovers of peace and shady quiet, are all delighted that last winter their beloved old Chesapeake & Ohio Canal was at last made a National Historical Park from one end of its 184mile length all the way to the other.

The marriage was the first for Miss Kellerman, 34 years old, and the second for Mr. Edelstein, 44.

title: Man Killed in L. I. Crash
description: CALVERTON, L. I., March 11 A 25yearold man was killed here shortly after 3 A.M. today when his automobile, eastbound on State Route 25, veered off the pavement, struck a tree, and then hit a utility pole. The victim was identified by the police as Robert Zemlicka of 52 Country Club Road, Southampton, L.I.

title: Till pragmatism, American philosophy was too philosophical
description: When the St. Louis Hegelians founded their Journal of Speculative Philosophy in 1869 they chose as motto Philosophy can bake no bread, but she can procure for us God, freedom and immortality. This mixture of crackerbarel and Rant seems on the surface just right for the situation of philosophy in Americaon the one hand philosophy cannot be expected to make any contribution to practical affairs, on the other it can be counted on to provide spiritual uplift in categories sufficiently remote from those affairs to pose no threat to them. Practical affairs have, after all, always seemed to take first priority in the American mind, and everyone has always agreed that American philosophy did not really come into its own until the emergence of pragmatism, the doctrine that practical consequences are the criterion of significance and even of truth.

title: GIELGUD IN LONDON IS INCOMPARABLE
description: LONDON, March 11Everyone has heard tales of distinguished old actors marooned in Godforsaken movie locations, waiting to speak their lines while technicians work. Such is the situation of Charles Wood's Veterans at the Royal Court Theater, a handmade vehicle for Sir John Gielgud and John Mills, and the first play known to me staged on a fillet set.

Published by Friends of the Earth, the conservation org, it boasts 60odd beautiful reproductions of paintings, just taposed with comments, by artists ranging from the 16tIth century limner John White, who came here in 1585 with Sir Walter Raleigh, to Milton Avery, Fairfield Porter and

title: New &
description: Intellectually, Mrs. Jo Baer is an idealistic excollege radical who held her own with a Congressional committee in the Joe McCarthy era. At heart, she is a middleclass yenta who delights in simple pleasures; like lunch at the Palm Court of the Plaza. Neither of these two sides of her character can put her in touch with son Peter, a nice kid currently dropping out in a Baltimore ghetto with a mixed up apparstchick named Sally. Peter's politics have as much to do with Freud as with Marx, and the only line of communication still open is his dirty laundry, which Morn is allowed to trundle home for sudsing and return. Ergo: a drift into anarchic violence  the bombing bit  moving Peter further outside the pale of the straight life.

March 11I'll be back in half an hour, Vinnie Clements said to the secretary as he left his office at the modern Burritt Mutual Savings Bank building to take a visitor on a tour of this aging city 10 miles southwest of Hartford. Clements, a tall darkhaired youth 23 years old, has a wellpaying job promoting savings among young peo pie; a degree in marketing from the University of Connecticut; a fine apartment for himself and his wife plus a new sports car, a Capri, Furthermore he is living happily in the area where he grew up and was a famous high school football star.

title: Travel Notes: Tipping at Sea, Skiing In the Buff, Europe by Private Plane
description: ALPSYCHOLOGIST who recently took a Caribbean cruise has computed that 61.5 per cent of the conversation among passengers during the final 36 hours of the voyage was devoted to how much they should tip the stewards. Nobody seemed able to come up with definite advice, and when some of the perplexed passengers asked the cruise director, even his response was vague. By all accounts, the question of the size of tips is one that has cruise passengers floundering, and the shipping lines are often unwilling to toss them a lifebelt. So, in response to requests for help, 1 took a survey among old seadogs, including cruise line officials, and came up with the follow

Jorgensen, United States Consul General to Thailand, and Mrs. Jorgensen of Bangkok have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brenda Janice Jorgensen, to William Douglas Lowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Lowe of Locust Valley, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Problems of Water gate In Place of the Capital, Anger Many Residents
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 Mrs. Herbert Salzman lives next door to a Senator in a $100,000 apartment in the Watergate complex herean apartment where, she complains, every time I give dinner party I have to use Mrs. Ribicoff's stove.

title: The beauty and the saint
description: In this intimate faMily book Eileen O'Casey gives an account of the ups and downs of fortune in 37 years of marriage with Sean O'Casey. She is a talkative writer, very frank about herself and the strange man she married. Like so many good marriages, this was a risky one. Years ago Harold Macmillan, the Prime Minister, who knew him well, described O'Casey as a saint. A saint may very well marry a beautywhich she was when he met herbut he was getting on in his forties and she was a lively actress of 22. She was Irishborn but had been brought up in English convents and came of a genteel Catholic family who thought nothing of a man who, only three or four years before, had been a manual laborer. Also he was a Socialistlater to become a Communistwho had been with Connolly's Irish Citizens Army during Easter week. He was a Gaelic speaker, and through malnutrition and neglect in the Dublin slums, he had very bad eyesight. The worst was that he was a Protestant and sounded like an atheist. In a decent, humanist way, he was.

title: Export Profits From.. DISC's
