title: Mother and 2 Die in Plunge
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., March 14 (UPI)A mother threw her 4yearold son out of her 10thfloor apartment window yesterday and leaped after him with her 3yearold daughter in her arms, the police said. All three died after hospitalization. The police identified them es Mrs. Ruth Ratti of 311 Harrison Street; her daughter, Cemitria, and son, Christopher.

title: PRICES MOVE UP IN AMEX TRADING
Stolen Paintings Recovered
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 14 (UPI)The police announced today., the recovery of two paintings; a crucifixion by Til tian and an annunciation by Giovanni Cuercino, valued at $2.4million. and: stolen this month front a church in the Adiatic port city of Ancona.

title: CARLOAD OF MAIL, LOST IN 70, FOUND
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 14 (AP)Postal inspectors have found a railroad car missing for more than two years with a load of parcel post packages a Postal Service official said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The gross weekly earnings and purchasing power of factory workers in the New York Northeastern New Jersey area rose $10 a week or 7.2 per cent in the 12 months period ending in January, Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor statistics said yesterday. After adjustment for Federal income and Social Security taxes and a 4.8 per cent rise in area consumer prices, purchasing power rose about 2.3 per cent during the year, he said.

title: Ducks Rehire Stankiewicz
description: COMMACK, L. I., March 14 (AP)Ed Stankiewles, general managercoach of the Long Island Ducks of the Eastern Hockey League the last two seasons, was rehired today for the 197273 season.

title: Court Puts Off School Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)The Supreme Court postponed today until its next term any decision in a Denver school desegregation case, the first from a nonSouthern city to reach the Court. In a brief announcement, the Court announced that oral arguments had been put off until fall. The Court now has scheduled its last arguments for this term for April 20.

title: Theater: A Ballet Behind the Bridge'
Nixon to Name Bunker Aide
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)  President Nixon announced today that he planned to nominate a career diplomat, Charles W. Whitehouse, to be Deputy Ambassador to Ellsworth Bunker in South Vietnam.

title: Nebraska Hires an Aide
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 14 (AP)Bill Myles, a coach at Southeast High School in Kansas City, has been appointed to the Nebraska football staff. Myles will replace Bill Thornton, who resigned to become a coach for the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League.

title: Mitchell Denies Discussing 3 Cases With I.T.T. Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that he discussed the Government's antitrust policies privately with Harold S. Geneen, the president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for some 35 minutes during a 1970 meeting, but he said he refused to talk about the Government's three cases against the company.

title: S.D.S. to Defy Harvard Ban
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 (AP) of Students for a Democratic Society said today that they would hold a national convention at Harvard and risk a confrontation even though the university has denied them permission to meet there. S.D.S. wanted to use Harvard buildings for a convention against racism March 3041, but Archie C. Epps, the dean of students, turned down the request because classes were scheduled those days.

title: council Approves HomeRule Bill for Corona
description: A bill that is designed to end the fiveyear fight by a group of homeowners in Corona, Queens, to save their homes from condemnation for a new high school was approved today by the City Council.

title: Knicks Win Minus Lucas,115107
description: Playing without Jerry Lucas and with only token help from Earl Monroe, the New York Knicks polished off the Atlanta Hawks, 115.107, at Madison Square Garden last night before a capacity crowd of 19,588, their 25th sellout at home this season.

title: E.A.GUGGENHEIM,88, PHILANTHROPIST,DIES
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 (AP)Edmond A. Guggenheim, president of a New York City dental clinic that serves 1,100 indigent children daily, died yesterday in a hospital, He was 88 years old and had homes in Scottsdale and New York.

title: Bank Officers Got Big Raises in 1971
description: The heads of many of the nation's largest banking concerns, despite a sharp squeeze on their own companies profits, received substantial increases in salary last year.

title: Two Who Were Gassed Come to Court Voluntarily
description: The Pyles twins, who twice in the last week were teargassed by Correction Department personnel and carried to their trial, appeared in court yesterday without coercion:

title: Swiss Deny Implication Of Bank in Irvings Fraud
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, March 14The Zurich prosecutor said today, that the passage in a Federal indictment in New York implicating one of the largest Swiss banks in the Clifford and Edith Irving fraud does not correspond to the facts.

title: Market Place: Eberstadt Bids For Turnaround
description: Last fall when the man who ran the Eberstadt Fund retired on doctor's orders, the F. Eberstadt & Co. organization faced a problem.

title: House Panel Votes to Maintain Cities Share of Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The House Ways and Means Committee, which is moving slowly toward agreement on a revenuesharing bill, voted today to require states to maintain present levels of financial aid to the cities and counties within their borders or lose some of the money that revenue sharing would provide them.

title: FULL SPIRIT BUOYS TINA KAPLAN SONGS
description: Tina Kaplan is, as her name seems to.suggest, a teeny, tiny girl. But she is singing with such energetic high spirits at the Downstairs at the Upstairs that there are times when she appears to be 10 feet tall.

title: THALER DISPUTED ON SALE OF BILLS
description: A codefendant presented evidence on the witness stand yesterday that contradicted the grand jury testimony of former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler about arrangements to sell $800,000 in stolen United States Treasury bills.

title: AllWhite Jury, With8 Women,
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 14  An allwhite jury was seated today for the murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy trial of Angela Davis.

title: Hidden Costs Seen In Japan's Exports
description: One of Japan's industrial leaders, whose countrymen have often criticized him for his liberal views, said here yesterday that Japanese export prices would be 5 per cent to 10 per cent higher if determined on the same basis as domestic prices.

title: Grocers Group President
description: George W. McKay, president of Super Valu Stores, Inc., Hopkins, Minn., has been sworn in as president of the NationalAmerican Wholesale Grocers Association. He succeeds T. Howard Timberlake, president of the Thomas & Howard Company, Columbia, S.C., who becomes chairman of the association.

title: KING'S PLAN SEEN AS A BOLD EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, March 19King Hussein's reported proposal for the eventual establishment of an autonomous Palestinian state is described by United States offiicals and by diplomats here as a bold effort to shore up his deterioraing position in the Arab world.

title: N.B.C.WTV Investigative Series Planned for Prime Time in Fall
description: N.B.C.. Reports, a 36week series of weekly onehour primethne news programs devoted to investigative reporting and topical issues, will be televised next season on the network of the National Broadcasting Company. The series, which will bow Sept. 5 will be seen Tuesdays from 10 to 11 P.M.

title: 8 Killed as Fire Sweeps Cargo Ship in Caribbean
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 14 (AP)  Fire swept through a Brazilian cargo vessel in the southern Caribbean today, leaving eight dead, one missing and four seriously injured, according to the Coast Guard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: There are a lot of theories about why the economy's been like It has been for the last few years. Here's another: Corporate decision makers have been too busy responding to questionnaires seeking their opinions on this and that to make decisions.

title: More Young Men Here Complaining of Impotence.
description: Three New York psychiatrists say they are seeing more cases of sexual impotence among young men than ever before. They say the cause appears to be that the increased sexual freedoml of women in recent years is leading women to demand more of their male partners.

title: News Analysis
description: While state losses from the strike at Aqueduct headed toward the $3million mark yesterday, the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation continued making hay from separate action on races at outofstate Pimlico.

title: Italian Reds Emphasize Maturity And Put Up Guests at Milan Hilton
description: MILAN, Italy, March 14A special convention desk in the lobby of the Milan Hilton is fielding inquiries these days from Soviet functionaries, Vietnamese women in flowing dresses, Hungarian and Czechoslovak party functionaries and secretive types from Arab countries, Africa and Latin Americaall attending the 13th Congress of the Italian Communist party.

title: fur Trappers Range the Wilds as if the Frontier Bad NevorDied
description: ASKOV, Minn. Terry Wolfe and Vern Ward had a few free hours the other day. So they drove to this little crossroads community 125 miles north of Minneapolis and set out into thewoods. struggling several miles on snowshoes into a frozen swamp.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 14 (UPI)  Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, congratulated Gov. Reubin Askew today on his stand in favor of school busing but said that he did not fully agree with Mr. Askew's position that busing was necessary, temporary means of ending segregation.

title: LAKERS WIN, SET AN N.B.A. RECORD
Cyprus Delivers Her Reply to Greece's Demands
description: ATHENS, March 14Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, after delaying for more than a month, delivered his reply today to the Greek, note of Feb. 11 that demanded his submission to Athens.

title: Humphrey Names Donors; 121 Gave $1 ,000 or More
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota disclosed today a list of 121 contributors, of $1,000 or more each to his campaign for the Demcratic Presidential nomination.

title: Dredging Project Planned For New London Harbor
description: NEW LONDON, Conn. March 14 (AP)The Army Corps of Engineers today proposed a $12.51million dredging project that would allow New London harbor to accommodate larger ships.

title: Political Justice?
description: The listing by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of those Government officials with whom Harold S. Geneen, the company's president, met during the litigation of the company's antitrust suits a roster of power in Washington. It includes Cabinet officers and White House advisers. Among them was John Mitchell, then the Attorney General.

title: ASBESTOS JOBS TIED TO CANCER OUTBREAK
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)The A.F.L.C.I.O. said today that a rare type of cancer was afflicting an increasing number of asbestos plant workers and their families and that the situation might prove to be the largest epidemic of occupational cancer ever recorded.

title: World's Catholics Rose By 7 Million in 2 Years
description: ROME, March 14 (AP)The number of Roman Catholis in the world increased by 7 million from 1969 to 1971 but the number of priests fell, as it has done steadily for about a decade. Priests were down 4,228 to 347,481.

title: Rumsfeld Is Hopeful of 3% Rate of Inflation
description: Donald Rumsfeld, the director of the Cost of Living Council, said yesterday that he was hopeful but could not guarantee that the annual rate of inflation would decline to between 2 and 3 per cent by the end of this year.

title: Japanese Search Pacific Isles for Bones of War Dead
description: TOKYO, March 13They go in groups of 10 or so, mostly older people, often accompanied by Buddhist priests, and they scour the jungles of Pacific islands for the bones and relics of the Japanese war dead.

title: Hanol Economio Mission Due in Japan Next Week
description: TOKYO, March 14 (Reuters) The Japanese Justice Ministry has approved the entry of a 14member North Vietnamese economic mission Into Japan next Monday for a 40day stay. ministry sources report. The mission will come here at the invitation of the JapanVietnam Trade Association, a group that seeks to promote contacts with Hanoi. Last month two Japanese Foreign Ministry officials visited Hanoi for the first time at the invitation of the North Vietnamese Chamber of Commerce.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: 50 Blacks Seek Jobs As Troopers In Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 14 (AP) Approximately 150 blacks have applied for jobs as state troopers since a Federal judge last month ordered the Alabama Highway Patrol integrated, the State Personnel Board reports.

title: Youth Shot at Kent Sues
description: CLEVELAND, March 14 (UPI)Robert F. Stamps, who was wounded by National Guardsmen during disorders on the Kent State University campus in 1970, has filed a $550,000 negligence suit against the State of Ohio. The suit was filed yesterday

title: Ban on Plastic Grass Voted
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14 (Reuters)  The Los Angeles Council's Public Works Committee has voted to bar the city from using plastic grass or plants to replace living greenery. The ban came following a public protest over the use of plastic trees in a highway dividing strip in southern Los Angeles. The trees were removed.

title: 4Day Week in Contract
description: CLEVELAND, March 14 (AP) A 10hour workday and fourday week were included in a new threeyear contract between Local 486 of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association and Ceilcote Company of Cleveland. About 100 employes are covered by the agreement.

title: COLLECTION AGENCY IS ORDERED TO PAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner ordered today a nationwide bill collection agency to repay franchise holders and merchants money they allegedly lost as a result of the agency's deceptive practices.

title: State Senate Votes to Lift Limit on Earnings for Student Aid Loans
description: ALBANY, March 14The State Senate unanimously approved a bill today that would expand the state's college tuition loan program to students in families earning $15,000 or more a year.

title: Raids on Enemy Base Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 (AP)United States military sources reported today that B52 aircraft destroyed a major North Vietnamese jungle headquarters in eastern Cambodia last night as they flew raids to open the way for a South Vietnamese armored drive.

title: Humphrey's List of Donors
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Following is a list of 121 contributors of $1,000 or more to the Hubert H. Humphrey campaign, released today by the Humphrey for President headquarters here:.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Party Wins Rule In 14 States, Shattering Its Foes
description: NEW DELHI, March 14Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party has gained control of 14 of the 16 states and one of the two union territories that elected new governments last week.

title: Executive Changes
description: Henry J. Brock has been elected senior vice president and associate general counsel of the Prudential Insurance Company, while Charles J. Jordan has been named vice president, group pensions.

description: LANGHORNE, Pa., March 14 (UPI)One of the country's oldest auto racing tracks was officially closed today to make way for a shopping center., Closing of the Langhorne Speedway was announced by its president, Irvin Fred.

title: Norman Armiitage, Fencing Star And Textile Executive, Dies at 65
description: Norman Cudworth Armitage, a vice president of the textile company of Deering Milliken, Inc., and one of the greatest fencing champions in modern competition, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old.

Thurmon Munson's walk, singles by Jerry Kenney and Torres and a walk to Horace. title: FOREIGN AFFAIR

Mr. Nixon met Emperor Hirohito at Anchorage, Alaska, in 1971 when Japan's sovereign stopped off on a Hight to Europe. And he conferred with Premier Sato in San Cletnente, Calif., last January. But to complete the process in a sense that compares to Presidential talks with chiefs of other principal power areas, ha. must visit Tokyo.

title: Rise in SpsnishSpeaking
description: BOSTON, March 14 (AP)The Spanishspeaking population of Massachusetts is growing rapidly, the Census Bureau reports, Preliminary estimates show that Boston has 65,000 Spanishspeaking residents, a gain of 47,000 over the figures shown in the census of 1960.

title: The Cambodian Model
description: President Nixon last fall described Cambodia as a model recipient of United States assistancerunning at about onethird of a billion dollars a yearunder his new foreign policy. Cambodia is the Nixon Doctrine in its purest form, the President told a news conference.

description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy's criticism of the United States relief commitment to Bangladesh is a classic example of tempest in a teapot, the State Department said today.

title: Bronxite Convicted Of Raping 2 Women At Fordham in 70

The decline followed commissionhouse and trade liquidation. The active May contract closed at $1.53.30 an ounce, down 2 cents.

description: DENVER, March 14A Roman Catholic priest from Brooklyn told delegates to the National Federation of Priests Councils today that it might seem they were being asked during their current convention to become social workers, sociologists, economists and political scientists.

Garbage Recycling Helps Out a Village

title: SUPERSTAR'S $1.5MILLION SUPERPAD
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14Two years ago, Wilt Chamberlain, the basketbgll superstar, stood on a spectacular point atop the Santa Monica Mountains overlooking Los Angeles and tried on for size some drawings to see what design felt most comfortable for the house he wanted to build. Just the other day, he stood on a cantilevered platform that juts out into a wondrous complex of interlocking triangles and surveyed the great room below as he talked of the $1.5million sanctuary he moved into four months ago. I wanted the feeling of the house to be like the Baptist church I remember when I was growing up, said the 7foot1 1/2inch center who is finishing one of his best seasons with the toprated Los Angeles Lakers. The structure itselfa soaring edifice of redwood, glass, concrete and canyon stoneis almost ecclesiastical in spirit. Scaled to its giant owner, the vast interior is five stories high at the central core, where a 45foothigh chimney over a huge stone fireplace anchors the unfolding, doorless spaces and provides the main structural support.

It is harder to characterize the class of 1974 in its sophomore year, just aS it is harder to locate the many sophomores who have fled their freshmen dormitories for lessconfining apartments around Morningside geights.

Monday, the day of the performance, that his physician absolutely forbade Nicolai Gedda to step on the stage of Carnegie Hall that evening. He was supposed to have sung the tenor role in Rossini's William Tell with the Opera Orchestra of New York conducted by Eve Queler. For the role of Arnold, a tenor needs not only health but pluperfect health. Those high C's and two C sharps!

Connally prepared a speech on the issue that he will deliver tomorrow.

description: MEMPHIS, March 14 (UPI) A. S. (Bert) Hart resigned today as president of the Memphis Pros so his investment banking company could handle financial arrangements for the American Basketball Association team.

title: Maid in Israel
description: Want to see a crude, broad, chaotic old-time comedy scramble about a big-mouthed cleaning woman who solves two murders in a department store? That's '"999Aliza the Policeman." One viewer who doesn't understand a word of Hebrew found the picture good, simple-minded fun.The film, made in Tel Aviv, with a genial, limber cast and some nice color photography, has English titles that can hardly keep up with the commotion. Opening yesterday, the film is the new screen entry, with the regular vaudeville fare, in the Israeli evening programs at the Mayfair Theater, 235 West 45th Street.The substance and tone of the picture, directed and produced by Menahem Golan, may go back to the Keystone Kops. The gags may be worn out but assuredly not the brashly good-natured cast, headed by Edna Flidel, a kind of Israeli Polly Moran. And everybody in sight yells his head off. Ride with it, though, for the sake of old-fashioned fun, and you'll be no worse

title: City Garment Trade Will Sell Its Image In a Publicity Drive
description: The various segments of New York's garment industry have agreed on a program to promote the city's fashion trades.

title: Carole King Wins 4 Grammys As Record Industry Lists Bests
description: The 14th annual Grammy Awards were announced last night at the Felt Forum and in a television show on the American Broadcasting Company network. The prizes are presented by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences to performers and technicians in 44 categories. For the first time in the history of the Gratnmys (short for gramophone), major presentations were made on a live television show, of which Andy Williams, was the host.

title: ROSE SNOW
description: Rose Snow, who retired 15 years ago as assistant principal of Evander Childs High School in the Bronx, died yesterday morning at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., after suffering a stroke. She was 85 years old.

title: PARLEY EXAMINES ROLE OF DIASPORA
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 14A prominent figure in world Jewish affairs warned today against what he described as an extreme tendency in Israel to disregard the role of the Diaspora, or Jews Uving outside Israel, and the Jewish state's attempt to dominate its thinking and actions.

title: Impact of New Directors Series:Works of 5 Countries Shown at Museum Self-Discovery Theme Found in Each Piece
description: The second five programs in the New Directors/New Films series just completed at the Museum of Modern Art offered movies from Switzerland, Hungary, Cuba, England and the United States. They are all first or second features by youngish directors generally unknown here, and, taken all together, they constitute the loveliest body of new cinema work that I have seen in some years. Taken individually, there are distinctions to be made, and I have my favoritesthe Swiss "Salamander" and the Cuban "Memories of Underdevelopment," both already acquired for United States distributionand my least favorite alsothe Hungarian "Horizon."Pal Gabor's "Horizon" is a sensitive, slightly too artful study of a Budapest teenager who skips his school examination, quits his job, and takes off in a few directions that his mother, whom he loves, and the girl who loves him can't follow. He ends up with a factory job as dumb as the office job he's just left, but along the way he had had a few adventures and made some starts in the very crucial process of self-discovery.To a considerable degree, self-discovery is what "Horizon" is about. It is also what all the other four films are about, and it constitutes a theme, for at least this part of the series, of quite astonishing consistency.This search for a sense of oneself is not simply a preoccupation of the young. The hero of Tomas Guterrez Alea's "Memories of Underdevelopment" is 38 years old, and he is the most boyishly lost of the lot. But the search is a highly individualized activity (consider even the title of Barney Platts-Mills's "Private Road," in which the identity crisis grows out of a love affair that fails between two attractive upper-middle class English kids) and one that presupposes the value, the ultimate legitimacy of personal perceptions.Sometimes such priority of values seems hard won, as in David Schikele's fine "Bushman." Mr. Schikele's film, an unusual blend of documentary and fictional vignettes, deals with a Nigerian (Paul Eyam Nzie Okpokam) teaching at San Francisco State, who in fact, and in the middle of production, was deported by the Government for the alleged possession of a bomb. The movie ends with the deportation, but despite all provocation its mood is relaxed, tolerantly ironic, sophisticatedwith a delight in subtle complexities that seems, in its lack of stridency, post-revolutionary.Even more complex, and distinctly more post-revolutionary, Mr. Alea's "Memories of Underdevelopment" begins as its bourgeois hero contentedly sends his wife into Stateside exile and settles back in his Havana apartment to wait for whatever will come next. A lot comes, much of it very funny, and none of it the triumph of ideology you might have expected. Mr. Alea's model is early-to-middle Antonioni, but he is dealing with real rather than mythic history, and unlike Antonioni, all his perceptions are touched by wit.Alain Tanner's "Salamander" acknowledges its debts more directly, as its heroes, a pair of writers named Pierre and Paul (of course, after Truffaut's "Jules and Jim") develop a story based on the life of a shop girl named Rosemond, who may or may not have shot her uncle in the shoulder. They meet Rosemond (Bulle Ogier), are both seduced by her, and ultimately drop the story, find themselves, and lose the girl into a kind of mild insanitywhich is her freedom in this rich, tough, technically modest and marvelously alert new film.

title: Jordanian Denies Negotiations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14Jordan's new Ambassador, Abdul Harnid Sharaf, said here today that there had been no secret negotiations between King Hussein and Israel.

title: Staunton Williams, ExHead Of Capewell Manufacturing
description: Staunton Williams, former president and chief executiveofficer of the Capewell Manufacturing Company, producers of hardware products, died Friday in Naples, Fla. He was 73 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, March 15Antiwar groups announced today plans for a demonstration at the White House March 26 as the start of their spring protests against President Nixon's policy on the Vietnam war.

description: His Presidential candidacy alive but hardly healthy after the Florida primary, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that his immediate job was to raise.. least $300,000 to wage an effective campaign in the Wisconsin primary less than three weeks away.

description: Paul Plumadore's vibrant fantasy has led him and his company successfully into the odd, beautiful! and funny world of dreams. His piece called Paperweight was performed Tuesday evening at the Cubiculo.

title: Shop Talk
description: The West Town House, which opened seven years ago at 260 West 86th Street, has a brand new branch in the new Sherman Square building at 2047 Broadway (between 70th and 71st Street). Like the original, the new West Town House is stocked with a variety of things for the home  from colorfully displayed furniture and lamps to kitchen equip ment and gadgetry dear to the hearts of apartment dwellers. We've been talking about it for some time and decided that with all the highrise apartments going up in the area, this was the right time, Adele Handel said. The first shop more or less runs itself now, which leaves Pat and me free to concentrate on the new one.

title: Debt limit Increase Cleared by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  Congress gave approval today to an increase of the national debt ceiling.

title: Advertising:
description: Despite a climate that might have encouraged more growth, privatelabel food products increased their share of market onetenth of I per cent last year, according to SellingAreasMarketing.

description: Henri G. Courtais, an 83yearold muralist and restorer of old paintings, died in his West Side apartment building last night after gasping out that a young couple who had been in the elevator with him had taken his wallet.

Volcker, would begin conferring with officials of other countries to solve, first, the question of the right forum for negotiations.

description: There used to be a simple answer to the question of what bridge experts do between tournaments: They played rubber bridge, often for high stakes.

title: Democrats After Florida
description: No election could have followed the expected pattern of voting more clearly than did the results of the Democratic primary in Florida. It could hardly have surprised anyone that Mr. Wallace polled a substantial fraction the vote. Most of Florida is culturally and racially part of the old rural South. Many of its citydwellers are recent arrivals from the farms and small towns of neighboring Georgia and Alabama. Under these circumstances, Mr. Wallace's minority victory is unimpressive, despite much postelection comment to the contrary.

title: Galella Tells How He Obtained Forbidden Onassis Pictures
description: Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that two young women had helped him get pictures of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and members of her family.

description: To the Editor: The proposed new city expense budget contains a startling 48 per cent increase in the cost of debt service. Debt service for the year 1972.73 is estimated to cost $1.023 billion, an increase of $330 million over the current figure of $693 million.

Mr. Montgomery, 41 years old, received a new heart on Jan. 23, but was readmitted to the hospital on March 2. The operation was performed by Dr. Marius Barnard, brother of the heart transplant pioneer, Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard.

title: Egyptians See Collusion Dispatch of The Times London
description: CAIRO, March 15King Hussein's propo'sal was denounced here today as a new collusion with Israel against the Arab cause. Although there has been no official reaction so far, the influential daily, Al Abram, which usually reflects the government's views, said the ultimate goal of the proposal was to liquidate the Palestine issue. It is the first step of a plan already agreed upon by King Hussein and Iserel, the paper said in a frontpage report.

title: PIANO RECITAL GIVEN BY LETEA CIFARELLI
description: Letea Cifarelli chose an enterprising program of, infrequently performed piano pieces for her Tuesday night recital at Carnegie Recital Hall, but not until the second, allItalian half of the program did her playing really measure up to the music.

title: Laird Urges Arms Aid to Bar Gap in Free World Security
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Secretary of Defense Melvin It Laird told Congress today that it would have to assume responsibility for a gap in free world security if it failed to approve the full $2:15billion in foreign military aid that the Administration had requested for the year beginning July 1.

title: Advertising:
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, the country's 16th largest agency, with gross billings last year of $143.8million, yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission o make a public stock offering.

title: Market Place:
description: Everybody knows that it is easy to lose money in the stock market. Just how easy becomes apparent when you look at the results of GuarenteFlarrington Associates, a hedge ftind with a blueribbon list of clients.

title: Rotary Engine Autos Will Be Shown Here
description: A line of rotary engine automobiles will be displayed for the first time in the United States during the International Automobile Show, which begins April I at the New York Coliseum.

title: Johns Hopkins Will Admit Some Still in High School
description: The high school diploma has been eliminated as a requirement for admission for tep students to Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

title: Guerrillas Plan Strategy
description: BEIRUT, March 15Palestinian guerrilla leaders have been meeting here to work out their strategy, toward King Hussein's plan.

title: COURT TURNS DOWN CHALLENGE ON JURY
description: A challenge to the constitutionality of jury panels in State Supreme Court in Queens was dismissed yesterday before two more jurors were seated in the murderarson trial of Mark Holder, a Black Panther.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 3 P.M.

title: Burke Mt. to Join Irish Parade
description: EAST BURKE, Vt., March 15Here near the Green Mountain State's rooftop, Burke Mountain is getting ready to join the St. Patrick's Day parade. It is following the shamrock trail blazed by Brodie Mountain in the Berkshires and subsequently by Hunter in the Catskills.

title: AGNEW CENSURES MIME'S ATTACK
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, March 15  Vice President Agnew charged today that. Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine had acted demagogically last night in calling Gov. George Wallace of Alabama a demagogue of the Worst kind and a man whose, politicking threatened the nobility of our country.

title: MORTON RELEASES LAND IN ALASKA
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton set aside today 274 million acres of Federal land in Alaska for possible selection by Alaskan natives and the state government and for a reserve for possible future use.

title: Communists Agree to Hold Vietnam Peace Talks Today
description: PARIS, March 15 (AP)The Communist delegations to the Vietnam peace talks agreed today to a proposal by the United States and South Vietnamese negotiators that they meet tomorrow. It will be the first session of the peace talks in three weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Frank Lynn's Feb. 26 article about Norman A. Levy and his cochairmanship of Mayor Lindsay's homestate campaign reveals another facet of the confidence the Mayor and his staff have in the gullibility of the public.

title: I.R.A. Aide to Be Tried
description: DUBLIN, March 15 (AP)Thomas MacGiolla, a leader of the outlawed Irish Republican Army's Official wing, was ordered today to face trial here on charges of membership in an illegal organization.

title: VLADIMIR G. DUROV
description: MOSCOW, March 15Vladimir G. Durov, one of the Soviet Union's most popular circus animal trainers, died yesterday at the age of 62.

title: Bache Reports Profit Returned in Year
Texas House Speaker Convicted of Bribery Plot
description: ABILENE, Tex., March 15 All Gus Mutscher, Speaker of the Texas House, and two aides were convicted today of conspiracy to accept a bribe.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A study recently released by the Environmental Defense Fund asserts that the proposed Tocks Island Reservoir on the Delaware River is economically and environmentally unsound.

title: AGENCY DISCLAIMS TIE TO DAM FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Assistant Secretary. of the Interior Hollis M. Dole testified today that the Bureau of Mines was not responsible for inspecting the water impoundment whose collapse flooded the Buffalo Creek area, in West Virginia because there was no hazard until the day before.

title: Release of 100 Rikers Inmates Is Sought by Legal Aid Society
description: The Legal Aid Society asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to release about 100 young inmates on Rikers Island immediately and to reduce the sentences of about 90 others, on the ground that their detention in the reformatory there was unconstitutional,

title: Iraq Suggests Arab Ties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 15 (UPI)Iraq offered tonight to join with Egypt and Syria immediately to prevent a breakup of Arab solidarity that she said was threatened by King Hussein's plan to create a Palistanian state within his kingdom, the Baghdad radio said.

title: Family Counseling Cheaper Cheaper by Comparison
description: Mrs. Ralph Jackson didn't know where to turn. Her marriage was falling apart, her 12yearold daughter was becoming increashigly hostile and alienated, and the family income precluded most professional assistance.

title: Chile to Import Tractors
description: SANTIAGO, Chile (Reuters)Chile will import 10,000 tractors this year to increase its program for mechanizing farming, President Salavador Allende announced.

title: Industrial Output Showed Strong Gain in February
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Industrial production rose strongly in February for the third consecutive month, new and revised figures of the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today.

title: The Busing Issue
description: The score sheet of the Florida primary indicates that majority of the voters were united on just one issueopposition to school busing. This message is certain affect those who plan their candidates campaign strategies, Republican and Democrat alike.

title: Hogan Subpoenas Records Of City on Union Members
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office has subpoenaed the payroll records of city agencies that would show which city employes were working fulltime on union matters, Herbert L. Haber, director of the city's Office of Labor Relations, said yesterday.

title: MRS. THOMAS J. DEEGAN
description: Mrs. Thomas J. Deegan, mother of Thomas J. Deegan Jr., who was chairman of the New York World's Fair Corporation, died yesterday of heart attack at St. Joseph's Manor in Trumbull, Conn. She was 86 years old and had homes here and in Washington.

title: A TV Satellite Plan For U.S. Is Speeded
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Federal Communications Commission took a step today toward the longsought goal of setting up the nation's first domestic communications satellite system.

title: PROFIT RISE LISTED
description: The Florida Power Corpora. tion reported yesterday that operating revenues increased by 11,6 per cent to $176,539,619 in 1971 This compared with $168,144,572 a year earlier, Net income of $35,231,529, or $3.14 a share, compared with $31,294,306, or $3.08 a share on fewer shares, in 1970.

title: Control of a Key Ridge Is Lost and Then Regained by Laotian Forces
description: VIETNIANE, Laos, March 15 (AP)Control of a ridge overlooking the key base of Long Tieng reportedly passed to the North Vietnamese yesterday and back to the Laotians today as enemy pressure slackened somewhat.

title: judge Weds Alyce P. Hill
description: Miss Alyce Patricia Hill, an instructor of French at Vassar College and a doctoral candidate at New York University, was married here last evening to Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright. Criminal Court Judge Alfred Kleiman performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: Rabbis Leader Calls for Equality
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 15The newly elected president of the Rabbinical Assembly, the international movement of Conservative rabbis, called on the American Jewish community today to meet head on the problems raised by the black revolution and the role of Jewish women in religious life.

title: Mayoral Veto of Budget Curbs Called Likely to Be Overriden
description: Any mayoral veto of a restriction on some spending written into the city's $1.8billion capital budget would be overridden, a poll of the Board of Estimate indicated yesterday.

title: R. H. Macy Earnings Up
description: Sears Roebuck & Co. and R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., reported yesterday big gains in profits and sales for the latest quarter.

title: GERMAN TAXPAYERS TO RECEIVE REBATE
description: BONN, March 15West Germany's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller, announced today that a.10 per cent antiinflationary surtax imposed for 12 months on all taxpayers in 197071 would be repaid on June 15.

title: REGISTRATION BILL KILLED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A coalition of Senate Republicans and Southern Democrats succeeded today in killing legislation that would have established a national system of voter registration by postal card.

title: J.D.L. Member Pours Blood Over Soviet Aide's Head
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)A member of the Jewish Defense League poured blood over the head of a Soviet diplomat tonight after crashing a reception given by the president of American University, George Williams. A spokesman for the J.D.L. said a quart of blood was poured over the head of Alexandr P. Yevstafyev, counselor in the Soviet Embassy, to shouts of, Murderer, free the Jewish prisoners.

title: Advertising:
description: When Albert Frank opened his oneroom, twoman ad agency in lower Manhattan it caused no stir In the Wall Street community.

title: Second Largest U.S. Pullout Ordered in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 15 (UPI)The United States command today ordered its second largest pullout of troops from the war zone, with the deactivation of 42 Air Force and Army units that total 5,700 men. Last July 42 units totaling 6,100 men were withdrawn.

title: Port Agency Seeks Successor To Tobin Within the Authority
description: The committee to select successor to Austin J. Tobin, former Port of New York Authority executive director, has so far considered only members of the bistate agency's top management.

title: Personal Finance: Tourists Money
description: Americans traveling abroad nowadays have to be cautious in their financial arrangement. The reason is the weakness in the price of dollars relative to some of the world's strong currencies such as the West German mark and the Swiss franc.

title: A Truly Silent Minority
description: Scattered throughout the land but gravitating toward the larger cities where jobs are more abundant and fellowship with their own kind possible, a silent minority is growing restless under the yoke of centuriesold discrimination and denial of their right as Americans to equal treatment under the law.

title: Arbitrators Seek to Speed Labor Pacts
JOHN WALDEN MYER OF CITY MUSEUM, 70
description: John Walden Myer, who retired in 1958 as director of the Museum of the City of New Stork, died Tuesday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Wiscasset, Me.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 Send Them a Message, said George Wallace's billboards in Florida, and no one can deny that his 42 per cent of the Democratic primary vote in that state has delivered the word, loud and clear, to the politicians, the press, the pointyheaded intellectuals, the bureaucrats and the liberals.

title: Chicago Exchange Offers 250 Seats On Monetary Unit
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which plans to start trading soon in foreign currencies, announced yesterday that it was offering 250 member1 ships in the International Monetary Market, the exchange's new currencytrading division, at a cost of $10,000 each.

title: Teacher Indicted on Drugs
description: A 32yearold Bronx teacher, described as a largescale narcotics seller, was indicted yesterday, by a Bronx grand jury on a charge of heroin possession. Louis Castellano of 3016 Bronxwood Avenue, was arrested at his home Feb. 19 by Bronx detectives, who said they had found seven and a half pounds of heroin valued at nearly $750,000 in his posession. He was held in lied of $73,000 bail.

title: Water Certificate Voided For Can Ed Power Plant
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation acted in excess of his authority and in violation of law in granting a water quality standards certificate for Consolidated Edison's proposed Storm King power plant.

title: Texas Court. Upholds the Death Penalty!
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 15 (AP)The State Court of Criminal Appeals upheld the constitutionality of the death penalty today, rejecting the same legal view that led the California Supreme Court to outlaw capital, punishment in that state.

title: Graham, Violist, Will Join Juilliard Quartet for Series
description: Mozart's six String Quintets will he played by the Juilliard Quartet and John Graham, guest violist, in a subscription series of three concerts at Tully Hall on April 3 and 25 and May 2. The works are scored for two violins, two violas and cello.

title: AQUEDUCT STRIKE ENTERS 10TH DAY
description: The strike that has kept Aqueduct racetrack closed to thoroughbred racing since March 6, continued yesterday, with picket lines drawn up at the entrances to the Big A. So far nine racing days have been canceled, with a financial loss to the state treasury calculated at $3million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: List of Committed Votes For Democratic Parley
description: MIAMI, March 15Following are the delegate votes committed to the Democratic Presidential candidates, as compiled by The New York Times:

title: PIANIST RETURNS FOR ANNIVERSARY
description: Wiltold Malcuzynski has not given a recital here since 1963. Perhaps one reason the Polish pianist decided to return once more is that this is the 30th anniversary of his American debut, which he made in Carnegie Hall. His appearance on Tuesday night in Philharmonic Hall showed that he has not lost his audience, for the place was virtually full.

title: Defense Witness Contradicts Thaler
description: Herbert R. Jacobs, a textile business consultant, maintained under crossexamination yesterday that former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler had signed an agreement to share a 10 per cent commission for selling $800,000 in United States Treasury bills.

title: Mrs. Leah Schimmel, 64, Directed Synagogue Group
description: Mrs. Leah F. Treiger Schimmel, former executive director of the National Women's League of the United Synagogue of America, died Tuesday in Jerusalem, where she had lived since 1969. She was 64 years old

title: Westchester Home Values Lead Suburbs
description: Westchester County still leads all suburban counties in the metropolitan area in terms of the monetary values placed on homes by their owners.Continued on Page 52, Column 1

title: NETS ON TOP, 94, AS GENTRY EXCELS
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 15  The New York Mets, who seem to keep winning in spite of their troubles, treated themselves today to a 94 victory over the worldchampion Pittsburgh Pirates, against whom they open the season three weeks from tomorrow.

title: Sodium Chromate Price Up
description: PPG Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of anhydrous sodium chromate by $1.50 a hundredweight, to $19.50. The product is used in the manufacture of pigments and in water treatment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It would surely be more appropriate if Mayor Lindsay, wore a black armband at the St. Patrick's Day parade in New York in remembrance of the Innocent people who have died in Northern Ireland at the hands of the I.R.A. [Mayor Lindsay on March 1 said he would wear a black armband as memorial tribute to the thirteen killed on Bloody Sunday."] More than 100 of those who have lost their lives since the terrorist campaign began in 1969 were completely innocent civilians, killed when going about their normal everyday businessa girl shot while waiting to be serve'? in a drugstore, child killed when a bomb blew a wall on top of its baby carriage, a man shot from, the Irish border while brushing out a customs post, five women cleaners and a gardener killed by a single bomb. Do none of these rate an armband?

title: Bank of California Rate Cut
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 (Reuters)The Bank of California said it would reduce its interest rate paid on regular passbook savings accounts to 4 per cent from 41/2 per cent, effective April.1. The reduction brings the bank down to the levels set by major banks in California in January.

title: Chess: Reshevsky Loses 2 of 25 In a Simultaneous Match
London's Ulster Reforms Seen Near
description: LONDON, March 15Prime Minister Heath today, invited Brian Faulkner, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, to London next week amid indications that, after weeks of agonizing, the British Government was near a decision on a plan of political reform aimed at breaking the deadlock and reducing the violence In the province.

title: Cape Canaveral Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)A bill approved today by the Senate Interior Committee would redesignate Cape Kennedy as Cape Canaveral. The bill would restore the old name of the Florida cape, but the launching facilities of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration would continue to be known as the John F. Kennedy Space Center.

title: Ansonia Hotel Wins Official Designation As a City Landmark
description: The Ansonia Hotel, which has been the home of many intellectuals, musicians and artists, has been designated an official landmark, it was announced yesterday by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: OUSTER OF A DEAN RUFFLES PELHAM
HATCHER REVIEWS PARLEY OF BLACKS
description: GARY, Ind., March 15Mayor Richard G. Hatcher sought today to soften the sense of antibusing resolutions passed last weekend by the National Black Political Convention here, and he called a resolution to dismantle Israel very unfortunate.

title: Loading and Testing Rights Granted to Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that a loading and testing license for the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant in Vernon, Vt., had been authorized.

title: School Bus Crash Kills Man
description: FRESNO, Calif., March 15 (UPI)A car driven by a 70yearold Fresno man ran past a stop sign yesterday and collided with a bus carrying 61 elementary school children. The car's driver, Enos Mares, was killed and 16 students and the school bus driver were injured.

title: The Sorrow and the Pity Begins Run at Beekman
U.S. Balance of Payments Shows a Narrowed Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 The deficit in tha nation's basic balance of international payments shrank in the fourth quarter of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Maddox Fears Rabble Won Races in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, March 15 (UPI) Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox today called the selection of Georgia's delegates to the Democratic National Convention a farce, shame and disgrace and said, 'It is altogether possible that many delegates were elected by Communists, anarchists, Republicans and ragtag bands from out of state.

title: 2 BOMB EXPERTS KILLED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15 (AP)  Two British Army bomb experts were killed tonight by a bomb they were trying to defuse.

title: BUSCH STANDS UP TO STRIKE THREAT
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (UPI)  August A. Busch Jr., president of the St. Louis Cardinals, said today that he didn't give a damn whether big league players struck over demands for an improved fringe benefits program.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The night they invented Phase Two some of the most theoretical economists in America were gathered around a big table at the White House with a man everybody called Dick.

title: Democrats Heading North To Vie in Midwest Tests
description: MIAMI, March 15  The Democratic Presidential cavalcade moved from Southern sunshine into the blustery Midwest today after a Florida primary that seemed to all the candidates to have opened wide the contest for the nomination.

title: ADM. READ, CREATOR OF MOTHBALL FLEET
description: Rear Adm. Oliver Middleton Read, who devised the concept of the Navy's mothball fleet, died Tuesday in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: Russi Shatters World Record in Downhill Triumph
Federal Reserve Aide Assails Media
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board assailed the news media today, contending that they are being used to undermine the credibility of everyone who represents authority.

title: Brownstone Front: It's a Renovated Cake
description: A lot of themes came together at Deirdre Stanforth's house last night at a literary party that celebrated a revival of some old fashions in home furnishing, food and family life.

title: Working Together
description: In the aftermath of war and disaster, the Red Cross builds a bridge between the stricken and those who can help. Working together through their federation, the League of Red Cross Societies, the national Red Cross societies of 115 countries pool their resources to help alleviate the distress.

title: 3 Die in Coast Hotel Fire
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15(Reuters)Three residents died and five were injured today in a fire at the Barclay Hotel in downtown Los Angeles.

title: Adolfo Now Designs Even for Cradle Set
description: Do you like your dress? the designer asked solicitously. Michele Biondi, aged 2, blew him a kiss. Adolfo beamed.

title: Swallows Due in Capistrano
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif. March 15 (UPI) The swallows are expected to come back to Capistrano next Sunday. They've been doing it nearly every year since 1776, when Father Junipero Serra founded the old mission here. Legend has it that the birds come back on March 19St. Joseph's Dayand leave on San Juan DayOct. 23.

title: Jersey Disorders Held Riot
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., March 15 (UPI)A Superior Court jury determined today that the civil disorders in Asbury Park in July, 1970, which resulted in an estimated total of $4million in property damage, constituted a riot. The jury's decision opens the way for 14 merchants on Springwood Avenue to sue the city for $10,000 each, under a law designed to protect uninsured businesses.

title: RYOSUKE HONDA
description: TOKYO, March 15 (UPI)Ryosuke Honda, president of The Japan Press, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: MOVES BY ROBBINS DANCED BY JOFFREY
description: Moves. Jerome Robbins's ballet without music, calls for the hot glower benath the cool surface. An expression of the atitudes of the uncommitted 1950's, it is saved from the dated look of other works about alienation through the professionalism and invention of its choreography.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Faulkner, Dawkins & Sullivan Securities, Inc., manager of the underwriting group, has announced a public offering of 400,000 shares of Telco Marketing Services,, Inc., common stock at $21 per share. Telco leases medical and scientific equipment to hospitals and clinical laboratories. There has been no previous, offering of the company's stock.

title: 2 Quit Michigan Primary
description: LANSING, Mich., March 15 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, have formally ruled themselves out of the May 16 Michigan Presidential primary.

title: F.B.I. IS ACCUSED OF AIDING A CRIME
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 15The informer who collaborated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Camden 28 case said in an affidavit filed today that the bureau had used him as a provocateur.

title: Soviet Promoting Private Farm Markets
description: MOSCOW, March 15The most direct route for, fresh produce from farm to dinner table, as any Soviet housewife knows, is not through the Govermnent's bureaucracyridden food marketing network but through the collectivefarm markets, the list remnants of private enterprise.

title: Cahill, Shapp Seek To Bar Shutdown Of Central Railroad
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 15The Governors of Pennsylvania and New Jersey met here this afternoon in an effort to avert a shutdown of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

title: Jackson Is Buoyed
description: MIAMI, March 15 Buoyed by his thirdplace finish in the Florida primary, Senator Henry M. Jackson left Miami for Milwaukee today convinced that he was now among the frontrunners for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Humphrey Aims at Wisconsin
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Hubert H. Humphrey left Florida for Wisconsin today with apparently undiminished confidence in a campaign strategy that includes a decidedlY indirect approach to the political phenomenon of George C. Wallace.

title: NETS BEAT PROS, MAKE PLAYOFFS
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 15 Rick Barry exploded for 20 points in the last quarter and led all scorers with 43 points tonight while leading the New York Nets to a 119112 victory over the Memphis Pros before 6,321 fans in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: RAYMOND DE ROOVER, ECONOMICS EXPERT
description: Dr. Raymond de Roover, professor of economics at Brooklyn College since 1961 and an authority on medieval and Renaissance economic history, died Tuesday in Kings County Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 641 East 24th Street in Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Party Winner
description: NEW DELHI, March 15 (Reuters)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party today clinched victory in state elections in Tripura in the far northeast of India, thereby winning absolute majorities in 14 of the 16 states that went to the polls this week. Only in Meghalaya and Manipur in the northeast did the Congress party fail to win enough seats to form a Government without coalition allies.

title: President Sees Expansion Of the Economy This Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (CPI) President Nixon told Congress today that he thought the economy would expand enough this year to provide many new jobs, but he said that additional manpower training efforts were also needed to cut back the unemployment rate.

title: TV: Away From Rigidity
description: Changes could be the name of the game, If so, Channel 13 WNET has been playing the game with surprising success.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Good Grief! The Rev. Vincent P. Miceli's Nixon in ChinaA Political Pilgrim (OpEd Feb. 19) reads like a press release from the Inquisition. Can moral philosopher Miceli really believe that God himself is the architect of the past twenty years of American foreign policy visitvis China, and that our deluded President is trying to join together... what God himself necessarily keeps asunder"?

title: 90 Physicians Quit Sea View Hospital; Services Continue
description: Some 90 physicians from the Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island, who tendered resignations to the Health and Hospitals Corporation to protest the makeup of the hospital's community board, refused to remain at the hospital and left yesterday, a spokesman for the corporation said.

title: WALLACE PLANS TO STEP UP DRIVE FOR NOMINATION
description: MIAMI, March 15Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, after his victory in yesterday's Florida Presidential primary, said today that he would broaden his efforts to capture the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: 112 Believed Dead On Danish Airliner In the Persian Gulf
description: DUBAI, Union of Arab Emirates, March 15 (Reuters)There apparently were no survivors in the crash yesterday of a Danish chartered airliner with 112 persons aboard as it was trying to land here to refuel.

title: Late Goal by Zelmo Beaty Gives Stars 109108 Victory
4Car Train Is Stolen From Bay State Yard
description: BOSTON, March 15 (AP)A fourcar Boston & Maine Railroad train was stolen today and one of the four cars was damaged. when it was backed into a turntable pit.

title: Assembly Acts to Bar Sabbath Antipoverty Voting
description: ALBANY, March 15  Although black and Jewish legislators differed sharply today, the Assembly approved a bill to ban antipoverty elections in New York City on the Sabbath.

title: The First Lady of the Land at 60 Thelma Catherine Ryan Nixon;Woman in the News
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Thelma Catherine Ryan Nixon, better known as Pat to her husband and as the First Lady of the land to the nation, will be 60 tomorrow. But she will celebrate her birthday, with a nod to her Irish ancestry, on St. Patrick's Day, Friday. Within the last year, said one of Mrs. Nixon's White House aides, she has really sort of come into her ownthere's so much confidence in her, and people's awareness of her has really grown.

title: Danang Base, Attacked
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March16 (AP)Vietcong gunners shelled the provincial capital of Quangngai and a United States base camp on the outskirts of Danang yesterday and today. In the air war, American fighterbombers resumed attacks over North Vietnam after a threeday absence.

title: Penn Central Is Absolved In Case of Missidg Mail
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) The Postal Service absolved the Penn Central Railroad today of any blame in the disappearance for more than two years of a railroad car loaded with parcel post packages.

title: FAREWELL PARTY FIRST AT HIALEAH
description: MIAMI, March 15 (UPI)Farewell Party, a 4yearold grandson of Native Dancer, won his first race since he captured the Governor Handicap at Belmont Park last September, as he recorded a halflength victory today in the $33,100 Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah.

title: MRS.AUCHINCLOSS,83, MOTHER OF AUTHOR
description: Mrs. Priscilla Dixon Stanton Auchincloss, mother of Louis S. Auchincloss, the author, died yesterday in her apartment at 49 East 86th Street. She was 83 years old.

title: Tennessee to Vote on Busing
description: NASHVILLE, March 15 (UN) Legislation providing for a referendum on school busing in conjunction with Tennessee's first Presidential primary May, 4 was signed today by Gov. Winfield Dunn. He also signed a bill that will allow 17year. olds to vote in the Presidential primary if they will reach the age of 18 by the time the gene eral election is held Nov. 7.

title: F.B.I. Informer Says Pakistani Plotted Kidnapping of Kissinger
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 15Boyd F. Douglas Jr., a paid F.B.I. informer, insisted today at the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy trial that, although he never met Dr. Eqbal Ahmad prior to Dr. Ahmad's indictment as one of the seven defendants, he positively identified him on the basis of two telephone calls.

title: SUIT. ON SCHOOLS FILED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, March 15The Boston branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accusing the city's school officials of racial segregation and discrimination, filed suit in United States District Court here today calling for equalized school spending and the linking of city and suburban schools to achieve integrated classrooms.

title: Joffrey Shifts Schedule
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet will present After Eden, its fourth new production of the season, for the first time on Tuesday instead of tonight. Postponement of the company premiere because of delays on another ballet, Double Exposure, have caused the following program changes: Kettentanz will replace the fourth new production tonight and Sunday evening. Chabriesque will be the replacement on Saturday night.

title: 100 Parents of Retarded Children Picket Rockefeller
description: Perents of children in four downstate schools for the re, turded took to the streets yesterday to demonstrate for improvements in the care for their children. They said everything elseprotests, pleas and publicityhad failed.

title: AGRICULTURE REPORT CITES SUBSIDY FLAW
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)  A ceiling imposed last year on subsidies to big farmers had no significant effect because they were allowed legally to subdivide their farms, an Agriculture Department report to Congress said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REP. RYAN TO RUN IN REVISED 20TH
description: Representative William F. Ryan said yesterday that he would seek reelection in the 20th Congressional District and that he could not conceive of Representative Bella Abzug's running ageing him.

title: STRIKE IS STAGED BY LONGSHOREMEN
description: Philadelphia dock workers staged a wildcat walkout that closed the port at midday yesterday and threatened to blossom into a fullfledged strike today.

title: Books of The Times
description: MUTANT 59: THE PLASTIC EATERS. By Kit Pedler and Gerry Davis. 246 pages. Viking. $5.95.

title: If All Chinese Had Wheels
description: STANFORD, Calif Now that the People's Republic of China has been admitted to the United Nations and American leaders are jetting to Peking, It is inevitable that we will be hearing more proposals for trade and aid to help the Chinese bring themselves up to our standard of living. The idea of helping less developed nations industrialize or catch up seems as American as baseball. Few people question the common wisdom behind these programs, the idea that the developing areas of the world can somehow catch up with contemporary consumptive standards of living in industrial societies.

title: Brazil Devalueis Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 (Reuters)The central bank tonight devalued the Brazilian cruzelro to 5.810/5.845 per United States dollar from its previous level of 5.750/5.785, the Government announced today.

title: Yale Adds Woman, An Illinoisian, 22, To Its Police Force
description: NEW HAVEN, March 15 (AP) Yale University's 46man police force will put a woman on the beat tomorrow. She is 22yearold Mary Almasov, who has a college degree herself.

title: Zaidee Parkinson A Different Pianist With Kreisleriana
description: Schumann's Kreisleriana can seem, in the hands of two or three of the greatest pianists, the ultimate Romantic fantasy. To bring it off in the grand manner a pianist must sail in and take big chances, playing the music and letting the notes fall where they may.

title: Notes on People
description: I didn't come here because it would be an enjoyable experience, said Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint, Chiefs of Staff, as Princeton University sdudents saw to it that he certainly could not enjoy his only scheduled address to a college audience this year. As the 60yearold admiral walked to the podium, 100 students in the front row turned their backs on him. Others raised antiwar posters, including one that read No Moorer murder.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Hussein
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 15 (Reuters)Following are excerpts from King Hussein's speech to a group of Jordanian and Palestinian dignitaries today.

title: Four Airmen Die in Crash
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., March 15 (UPI)An air force C47 cargo plane crashed today at the Lake Charles Municipal Airport, killing all four crewmen aboard. No one on the ground was hurt.

title: Executive Changes
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday the nomination of Mrs. Jewel Stradford Lafontant, a Chicago attorney, and David Packard, former Secretary of Defense, to its board of directors. Their election is expected to take place at the, annual meeting on April 27. They will succeed Hughston M. McBain and BenFleming Sessel, who will become directors emeritus. Mrs. Lafontant is a partner of the Chicago law firm of Stradford, Lafontant, Fisher & Cousins. Her husband is H. Ernest Lafontant. A native of Chicago, she received a B.A. degree from Oberlin College and a doctor of laws degree from the University of Chicago. She was a trial attorney with the Legal Aid Bureau from 1947 to 1954 and an assistant U. S. District Attorney in Chicago from 1955 to 1958. Mr. Packard is a native of Pueblo, Colo., and holds an A.B. from Stanford University (class of 1934). After holding executive posts with the General Electric Company, HewlettPackard Company, Palo Alto, Calif., he became Deputy U. S. Secretary of Defense in 1969. He resigned in 1971 to rejoin HewlettPackard as chairman of the board.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding the $350,000 appropriation made by the State Legislature to the Scott Commmission:

title: Miami Company Employing ExMarines For Training Members of Haitian Forces
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A Miamibased company that is reported to have a link with Haiti's National Defense and Interior Minister is employing a group of former American marines to train members of the Hatian armed forces, and the United States Government is investigating the legality of the arrangement.

title: Rents to Rise 7.5% in May for 100,000 in City Housing
description: The city's Housing Authority announced plans yesterday to impose a reluctant and minimal 7.5 per cent across the board rent increase on public housing that would affect 100, 000 families beginning May 1.

title: Ethnic Leaders Discuss the Assets of Diversity
description: Ciao Is Italian for Hi! and CIAO is the short name for the fiveyearold Congress of ItalianAmerican Organizations.

title: Ford Recalls Lincoins
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 15 (AP)  The customer service division of the Ford Motor Company is notifying owners of 24,481 Lincoln Continental Mark IV's to return their cars to their dealers for inspection of the hoodlatch release, the company announced today.

title: U.S. Curb on Traveling To 3 Nations Continued
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  Secretary of State William P. Rogers has decided to continue passport restrictions on travel to North Korea, North Vietnam and Cuba until March 15, 1973, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: 2 Atom Power Plants Proposed Off New Jersey as First of String
description: NEWARK, March 15The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced plans today to anchor two floating nucleargenerating stations three miles off New Jersey and to put them into operation by 1980.

title: A Touch of Fall in the Late Wintertime
description: DALLAS, March 15 (AP)Duane Thomas is optimistic about continuing his career in professional football but not, he insists, at the sacrifice of his individuality and pride.

title: ADDICTS TERMED PERIL TO WELFARE
description: Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday that the disruption and expense generated by rapidly expanding number of addicts on welfaremany of whom use their relief checks to buy drugsthreatened to paralyze the city's welfare system.

title: ECOLOGICAL BONDS RECEIVE SUPPORT
description: ALBANY, March 15  Conservationists and local government officials urged legislative approval today of a proposed $1.2billion bond issue to pay for air, water and land environmental projects in the state during the next five years.

title: 4 ARRESTED HERE IN MARIJUANARING
description: A customs inspector and three other persons have been arrested in connection with $20million marijuana smuggling operation from Jamaica in the West males to Kennedy International Airport here.

title: THADEUS DABROWSKI OF CONSERV ATIVES
description: Thadeus S. Dabrowski, chairman of the Conservative party in Queens since 1966, died yesterday at the Dewitt Clinton Hotel in Albany. He was 53 years old and lived at 40.09 170th Street in Flushing.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15 (UPI)A $50,000 tournament on the W.C.T. tour was announced today for June 27 through July 2 here in conflict with the Wimbledon championship.

title: HUSSEIN REVEALS FEDERATION PLAN; ISRAEL ASSAILS IT
News Analysis
description: MIAMI, March 15There were not many cheers for democracy here this morning as the Democrats roundrobin spring tournament packed off to the Middle West. The men who finished fourth, fifth and sixth were denouncing 40 per cent of the electorate as dupes of the demavogues. The men Who placed and showed were claiming to have won. The man who won was celebrating the new rules of reform. The authors of reform were ruing what they had wrought.

title: BRAZIL IN ACCORD WITH ARGENTINA
description: BRASILIA, March 15Argentina and Brazil agreed today to ignore, at least formally, their differences over trade and hydroelectric power development in rivers that flow through both countries, and to seek means of cooperation.

title: L.I. Growth Rate Lowest in 20 Years
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 15Long Island's population growth rate has slowed to the lowest in nearly two decades, according to the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Merger News
description: The Justice Department yesterday opposed the proposed merger of Northwest Airlines and National Airlines. In brief filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board, the Justice Department said that the very modest public benefits that the merger would produce are outweighed by its anticompetitive effects. In its brief, the Justice Department also warned the C.A.B. against the potential for un, due concentration in the airline industry posed by pending mergers of carriers.

title: U.S. and Japan Exchange Papers on Okinawa Pact
description: TOKYO, March 13  The United States and Japan today exchanged documents ratifying the agreement signed last June on restoration of the Ryukyu Islands to Japanese administration.

title: Muskie Aides Pleased
description: MIAMI, March 15Senator Edmund S. Muskie, abandoning a lowkey centrist style, sought today to recast himself as an underdog liberal challenger for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Husband Is Indicted for Murder; Sought Wile's Insurance Funds
description: A 34yearold Queens man was indicted yesterday for the murder or his wife last October in what a county grand jury said was an effort to reap $600,000 in life insurance payments.

title: Boston Labor Urges Halt To Takeover of TV Channel
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  Boston labor groups have urged the Supreme Court to consider the human aspect of the fight for control of Channel 5.

title: Davlin Sentence Suspended
description: NEWRY, Northern Ireland, March 15 (AP)  Bernadette Devlin, the Catholic civil rights leader, and 22 others received suspended sixmonth sentences today for participation in an illegal demonstration. They were convicted of defying a ban on parades by marching Feb. 6 to protest the killing of 13 civilians by British paratroopers in Londonderry.

title: Times Survey Finds Nixon Is Florida's Hidden Victor
description: Despite Gov. George C. Wallace's large plurality victory in the Florida Democratic primary Tuesday, the hidden winner clearly appears, from a special crosssection survey of Democratic voters, to have been President Nixon.

title: 3 Coaches From Italy Size Up Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15For the fifth time in their 13 exhibition games, the Yankees were shut out tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat _them, 34 But at least three observers were impressed by the New Yorkers.

title: WILLARD I. WEBB JR.
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 15Willard I. Webb Jr., president of the Ohio Citizens Trust Company, the city's third largest bank for 24 years, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: Shaky Start in Uruguay
description: Long before the 1971 election, it was clear that Uruguay's traditional democracy could survive only if large segments of the two big parties would work together to revive the economy, end Tupamaro terrorism and rebuild national unity. The failure of a leftist coalition at the polls showed that President Allende's pattern Chile was not the inexorable wave of the future in the Americas, but it did not insure Uruguay's survival freedom.

title: PRICE COMMISSION OPENS A CAMPAIGN TO TIGHTEN CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Price Commission, after reviewing staff studies projecting the results of its current price policies, embarked today on a program of more restrictive controls.

title: House Authorizes $174 Million More for Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The House voted today to authorize an additional $174million subsidy for the Governmentbacked network of passenger trains.

title: Head of I.T. T.Denies Link Of Suits and Aid to G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Harold S. Geneen, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, swore today that there Was absolutely no connection between his company's pledge of up to $200,000 toward the expenses of the Republican National Convention and the Justice Department's settlement of three antitrust suits against the concern.

title: Edward A. Kiley, 76, Dies; ExDeputy Police Inspector
description: Edward A. Kiley, who as a New York City detective uncovered information that led to the 1922 capture of Gerald Chapman, a notorious bank robber, died yesterday at Misericordia Hospital after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 529 East 235th Street, the Bronx.

title: State Prison Guards Vote To Walk Out if Talks Fail
description: ALBANY, March 15 (AP)Correction officers at four New York State prisons have voted to strike at the end of the month unless the state meets their pay demands and speeds up its promised prison reform.

title: HUSSEIN WILL SEE NIXON ABOUT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  King Hussein of Jordan will discuss the details of his new proposal for a semiautonomous Palestinian state with President Nixon in Washington at the end of this month, United States officials said today. The dates of the visit have yet to be announced.

title: RHODESIAN GOODS PROTESTED IN U.S.
description: BURNSIDE, La. March 15A protest is building against the resumption of United States imports of strategic materials from Rhodesia.

title: Britain Apportions More of North Sea To Oil Explorations
description: LONDON, March 15  The Government tonight announced allocations of new blocks in the North Sea for oil and gas exploration, with the hope that by 1980 they might be supplying Britain with 50 million tons of oil a year.

title: Hughes Occupying a Suite on the 20th Floor of Hotel in, Vancouver After Flight From Nicaragua
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 Howard R. Hughes, unaccounted for since he left Nicaragua about midnight Monday,.was found today in a hotel in Vancouver, B. C. Mr. Hughes spent more than an hour with, the President of Nicaragua and the United States Ambassador to that country before he left on Monday evening.

title: News of Dogs
description: Although the ,poodle ranks No. 1 of the 103: breeds in the American.Kennel. Club stud book, a proud, perch he has occupied since displacing the beagle in 1960; in Japan he's just another breed.

title: Slower Fee Drop Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)  Major stock exchanges urged today that if the negotiated commission rate was further lowered it should be done on a gradual stepbystep basis to test the overall impact on the securities market.

title: Br'er Lawyers in Albany
description: In rare bipartisan accord, both the Beer Rabbits and the Br'er Foxes in the State Legislature are about to commit nofault automobile Insurance legislation to the briar patch of the Senate's Judiciary Committee. Dominated by lawyers, this committee can be counted on return a bill that will bear no resemblance to genuine reform.

title: MET LA FILLE  JOINED BY MONICA SINCLAIR
description: With the entrance of Monica Sinclair into the cast of Donizetti's La FiIle du Regiment on Tuesday night, the Metropolitan Opera had assembled all but one of the principals from London's Covent Garden production, which was the inspiration and source of the Metropolitan's.

title: Times Promotes 4 Executives, Appoints New Vice President
description: The promotion of four vice presidents to new positions of senior vice president and appointment of a new vice president were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times.

title: Seoul Voices Skepticism On Overtures From North
