description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 15South Korea is taking a skeptical attitude toward the recent overtures by North Korea for a peace agreement and political discussions between the two parts of this divided country.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Appellate Division judge yesterday granted a stay of a 30day jail term ordered for Edwin A. Goodman, manager of radio station WBAI, on contemptofcourt charges.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Hussein Negates Cause of Peace
description: JERUSALEM, March 15A spokesman for Premier Golda Meir said today that King Hussein negates the cause of peace with his new proposal for a Jordanian federation in which the West Bank, now occupied by Israel, would be an autonomous province.

title: MISS DAVIS QUIZZES VENIREMAN AT TRIAL
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 15 (UPI)Angela Davis took personal hand in her murderkidnapping trial again today by interrogating a potential alternate juror at length about racism, violence in America and the rhetoric of revolutionaries.

title: Disabled Soviet Submarine Has Steady Tow Homeward
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)The disabled Soviet nuclear submarine sighted 19 days ago 700 miles northeast of Newfoundland is under continuous tow and headed back toward the Soviet Union, the Pentagon said today.

title: DOOR STILL OPEN IN TENNIS DISPUTE
description: LONDON, March 15  Basil Reny, secretary of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, said today. that World Championship Tennis's decision not to allow its professionals to play at Wimbledon need not mean the end of open tennis.

title: Edmond Guggenheim Is Dead; Retired Copper Executive, 84
description: A private funeral service will be held today in Phoenix, Ariz., for Edmond A. Guggenheim, Whose grandfather's copper kingdom grew to rival the Rockefeller interests as America's greatest family fortune. Mr. Guggenheim died Monday in a Phoenix hospital at the age of 84.

title: New Ambassador Invites Trudeau to Visit China
description: OTTAWA, March 15 (Reuter)Peking has officially invited Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to visit China, the Canadian Government said today.

title: RCA DEMONSTRATES MINIATURE TV UNIT
description: The RCA Corporation demonstrated here yesterday an experimental blackandwhite television camera, that is roughly the size of an electric razor. It weighs less than one pound and uses integrated circuits as its image sensor.

title: Man Who Is Said to Be Bormann Is Reported Seized in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 16 (Reuters)Official sources here said that Germanborn Johann Ehrmann, alleged by a Bogota magazine to be Martin L. Bormann, the Nazi war criminal, was arrested by the police tonight in a remote jungle area of southern Colombia.

title: Eastman House Gets Grant To Reproduce Silent Films
description: ROCHESTER, March 16 (AP) Two $40,000 grants will enable the George Eastman House, a photographic museum, to make fresh copies of deteriorating silent movies, a museum spokesman reported yesterday.

title: TV: A Black Situation Comedy Settles Into Top 10
description: When the black man begins securely. making it In American society, what will provide the incontrovertible proof? That question can be put in the category of Games White People Play. The answers, of course, vary..

title: PROFITS OF A.TE. CLIMB IN QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has begun the new year with record revenues for the three and 12 months ended Feb. 29. Net income for the 12 months was also at a high. However, share earnings in both periods declined because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: BANK UNIT WEIGHS MONEYRATE INDEX
description: Allen P. Stults, president of the American Bankers Association, said yesterday that the trade organization was studying the possibility of starting moneyrate index in order to show how shortterm Interest rates change each day.

title: Bonn Price Index Higher
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, March 16 (Reuters)The West German index of industrial producer prices for February rose 0.4 per cent from January to 114.4, 2.6 per cent above the level a year ago, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The index, which excludes the valueadded tax, is based on 100 in 1962.

title: Advertising: F. T. C.'s Chief Answers Charge of Unilateralism
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 16Miles W. Kirkpatrick, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, today characterized parts of a recent widely circulated criticism of the commission as intemperate name calling that adds nothing to what would hope to be continuing and reasoned exchange of views.

title: ELLSBERG IS GIVEN FREEDOM AWARD
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who said that he gave the Pentagon Papers to news media, was presented last night with the Freedom of Speech Award of the Americans for Democratic Action.

title: Vida Blue Retires From Baseball To Accept Job in Steel Business
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 16 (AP)Vida Blue, baseball's top attraction and the American League's most valuable player in 1971, said today he was retiring from the sport because the Oakland Athletics owner, Charles 0. Finley, had refused to raise his contract offer.

title: TWINS CONVICTED IN HOTEL HOLDUPS
description: A State Supreme Court jury here yesterday convicted 26yearold twin brothers who had refused to participate in their robbery trial and on two occasions had had to be teargassed and carried to court.

title: Murtaugh to Manage Stars, Interrupting His Retirement
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 16 (UPI)  Danny Murtaugh, the retired manager of the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates, was named today the manager for the National League in the AllStar game at Atanta July 25.

title: MoneyRate Spiral Slowing Markedly; Rise in Prime Seen
Shop Talk
description: It was Valentino's day to shine. Lord & Taylor put its copies of the Rome designer's couture colledtion on sale yesterday and they were being snapped up by people who never heard of Valentino. Richard Velez, for example. The merchant seaman was wandering through the store looking for a present for his girl friend, when he was attracted by the evening dress with the dolman sleeve top in deep pink and the long black skirt ($125). He thought she'd look pretty in it. Pink was the. de signer's second color. The cognoscenti knew white was his first preference. They filled the fitting rooms! with his white dresses; they slipped the white, coats over whatever they had on.

title: Tiny Colony of Americans in China Lives Quietly, Keeping to itself
description: PEKINGAt least one of them came to China decades ago, working for the Communists during their long struggle for power. Others came only after the Communists took power in 1949. Still others came against their will, as prisoners during the Korean war, but chose to stay on after their release.

title: CARRERAS, A TENOR, MAKES SOLID DEBUT
description: The New York City Opera has found a new tenor who could be a valuable addition to the company if his singing is as pleasing in other works as it was in Puccini's Madame Butterfly on Wednesday night.

title: STOCKHOLDER SUES BOTANY ON AUDIT
description: A dissident stockholder of Botany Industries, Inc., has filed a class action complaint against the company's officers, directors and auditor charging that it overstated its financial condition and understated its losses in the year ended July 31, 1971.

title: President in Appeal For Science to Help With U.S. Problems
Fairness on Pay Curbs
description: The majority vote in the Pay Board to scale down the fat strike settlement on the Pacific Coast docks reflects a recognition that no antiinflation program can survive if it is not founded on fairness.

title: 2 Plead Guilty hi Theft Here
description: Two men arrested last year in the theft of Mexican currency valued at $517,000 from the American Banknote Company printing plant in the South Bronx pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to conspiracy. The men, Arthur Green Jr., 26 years old, of 535 Havemeyer Avenue, the Bronx, Carlton Brown, 51, of 227 West 149th Street, are to be sentenced April 28. They face a maximum term of four years.

title: U. S. Military Credits for Haiti Said to Get Favorable Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 16State Department officials said today that the Nixon Administradition was giving favorable consideration to a request from Haiti for credits to purchase military equipment in the United States.

title: Start of Nixon Trip To Moscow May 22 Announced by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The United States and the Soviet Union announced officially today that President Nixon would begin his trip to Moscow on May 22.

title: McGovern Attacks Speech For Fear and Opportunism
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 16 Before a cheering University of Illinois audience here, Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, denounced President Nixon's busing speech tonight as a message of fear and hypocrisy and opportunism.

title: Dr. Ralph Edward Noble,72, Of Vermont Junior College
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 16 Dr. Ralph Edward Noble, president of Vermont Junior College from 1949 to 1966 and Vermont Commissioner of Education from 1940 to 1949, died today. His age was 72.

title: G.E. GETS ORDERS FOR NUCLEAR UNITS
description: Middle South Utilities, Inc., has signed a letter of intent to purchase two 1.26 millionkilowatt boiling water nuclear power units from the General Electric Company. The two units are the largest nuclear power units ever ordered by any utility.

title: Notes on People
description: New York City is the center of the earth, said John Lennon, explaining why ho and his wife, Yoko Ono, will fight deportation on charges that their visas have expired. Their deportation hearing was adjourned until April 18 to give them time to apply for permanent residence.

title: Senate Republicans to File A Separate Brief on Gravel
description: WASHINGTON, March (AP)Senate Republicans decided today to file their own brief with the Supreme Court in the Pentagon papers case involving Senator Mike Gravel thus turning aside Democratic sentiment for a united front.

title: Sports of The Times
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16Vida Blue, whose work for the Oakland Athletics last year won him the Cy Young Award as the American League's best pitcher, achieved similar stature as a holdout today with the boldest, most imaginative, most carefully thought out and adroitly timed ploy ever made in a baseball contract dispute.

title: Market Place: The Best Policy For WriteOffs
description: A number of Wall Street observers are wondering how major companies can get so deeply in the hole that they suddenly write off millions of dollars. A number of cases In which this happened recently concerned companies that sold at high priceearn ings ratios.

title: Applause for Bench To Fall on Deaf Ears
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16Johnny Bench, still annoyed over having been booed often last year when he batted only.238 for the Cincinnati Reds, plans to spite fans this season by refusing to tip his cap when applauded.

title: British Taken by Surprise
description: LONDON, March 16President Pompidou's announcement of a French referendum to ratify enlargement of the Common Market surprised the British Government tonight and brought demands from antiMarket forces that Britain do the same.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert L. Spang has again been elected senior vice president, investment, of the Fiduciary Trust Company of Now York. He had previously held the post before leaving in 1968 to join Eastman, Dillon, Union Securities Company, Inc.

title: NIXON BARS DATA SOUGHT BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 President Nixon has refused to supply Congress with information about the United States aid programs in Cambodia.

title: MRS. MEIR ASSERTS HUSSEIN'S PLANS SKIRT PEACE ISSUE
description: JERUSALEM, March 16Premier Golda Meir lashed out against King Hussein of Jordan today, accusing him of pretension and of refusing to recognize realities or admit the need to make peace with Israel.

title: Books of The Times
description: A WORLD IN REVOLUTION. By Herbert L. Matthews. 462 pages. Scribners. $12.50.

title: In Time for Bicentennial, a Deflating British View of the Revolution
description: The Tories may yet have it their waythe American Revolution,.that is. Not, of course, in history, but what is more important, in the history books.

title: Pie Traynor, Star 3d Baseman For Pittsburgh Pirates, 72, Dies
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16 (AP) Pie Traynor, Hall of Fame third baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates during the 1920's and 30's, died today at the age of 72.

title: CITY FILES BRIEFS ON FOREST HILLS
description: Mayor Lindsay and Simeon Golar, chairman of the city's Housing Authority, contended yesterday that construction of public housing would be virtually impossible if the courts required resubmission of the lowincome housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, to the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.

title: Bengalis Ashamed Of Burst of Revenge Against the Biharis
description: KCHULNA, Bangladesh, March 16Nearly everywhere in this Bengali city people are nervously trying to hide their shame.

title: HUNTER AIDES FEAR LOSS OF A SCHOOL
description: Parents of: the 300 pupils at the 102yearold Hunter Col. lege Elementary School have been told that the school may close when the semester ends in June.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Major New Work By Tetley Danced In the Netherlands
description: THE HAGUEWith less than a fortnight to go before the opening of its New York season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Netherlands Dance Theater has presented at the Royal Theater a major new work by Glen Tetley that will form part of the repertory for the company's American tour and subsequent world trip. Called Small Parades, the new work is a set of dances for five Men and five women that may well prove as deer.; sive in the career of Mr. Tetley and the company as Symphonic Variations was in the history of Frederick.Ashton and the Royal Ballet.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Commerce Department toclay estimated last week's department store sales at $728million, up 16 per cent from the yearearlier $629million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,704,000,000, up 9 per cent from $7,058,000,000.

title: Lawyer For Londonderry Kin Condemns Troops at Inquiry
description: LONDON, March 16  The British Army was accused today of having sought to provoke Roman Catholics in Londonderry on Jan. 30 in an attempt to shatter the Irish Republican Army there.

title: YCAZA IS AWARDED $225,000 IN SUIT
description: MIAMI, March 16 (UPI) A Circuit Court jury awarded Manuel Ycaza $225,000 yesterday on the jockey's claim that the poor condition of the turf course at Hialeah race track was the cause of injuries suffered two years ago.

title: Muskie Stops National Staff's Salaries In Further Effort to Cut Campaign Costs
Remapping Passes The Jersey Senate By Narrow Margin
description: TRENTON, March 16  A Republican Congressional redistricting plan for New Jersey that would eliminate one of Hudson County's two Democratic representatives and create instead Republican district in the rural northwestern part of the state squeaked through the State Senate here today.

title: British Expert Said to Find Saigon Capable on Security
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Sir Robert Thompson, the British counterinsurgency expert, reportedly assured the White House last week that the South Vietnamese forces will be capable of handling their country's internal security after United States troops are reduced to the 69,000man level by May 1.

title: Biharis Still in East an Issue for Bhutto
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 16  Demands for the repatriation to Pakistan of nonBengalis living in Bangladesh are posing a difficult, and perhaps insoluble, problem for President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: Pay Board Reduces Raise For Coast Dock Workers
description: WASHINGTON, March 16In a decision that may precipitate a new dock strike, the Pay Board voted today, 8 to 5, to reduce substantially the West Coast longshore contract settlement.

title: Chinese Mission Buys a Motel on West Side
description: The Chinese have purchased a 10story motel with a rooftop pool near Lincoln Center and their United Nations delegation hopes to move into its new liying and office headquarters within two weeks.

title: U.S. PRISONER BID REJECTED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, March 16The United States proposed to North Vietnem and the Vietcong today that prisonerofwar camps be opened to international inspection in return for an undertaking by both sides to refrain from efforts to liberate prisoners from the locations visited.

title: Game Dishes on the Menu Make the Trip Worth while
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Books of The Times
description: LEAP STORM AND OTHER STORIES. by Gabriel Garcia Marquez Translated from the Spanish by Gregory Rabassa. 146 pages. New York: Harper & Row. $6.50

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The unspoken premise of Harold A. Meriam Jr.'s letter of March 6 is that our original Federal Constitution of 1787 treated slaves as nonpersons. On the contrary, in no fewer than three clauses, slaves were explicitly referred to as Persons"the Enumeration clause (art. I, 12, cl. 3), the Slave Trade clause (art. 1, 19 cl. 1), and the Fugitive Slave clause (art. IV, 1 2 cl. 3). The original Constitution did not treat all Persons as equalthat would not be commanded until the Fourteenth Amendment (1868)but it did refer to all persons as persons.

title: PENNSY PLANNING APRIL DISMISSALS
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company announced plans yesterday to dismiss, starting April 1, 6,000 of its 18,000 conductors and, brakemen to save $99.5million a year. Their union warned that such action would bring immediate retaliation.

title: VIRTUAL REJECTION BY MAKARIOS SEEN
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 16Reliable sources reported today that President Makarios of Cyprus had virtually rejected Greek demands that he recognize Athens as, the highest policymaking center of the Greek people, including Cyprus, and that he reorganize his administration to make it more acceptable to Greece.

title: Truck Spill Causes Flats
description: FLINT, Mich., March 16 (AP)More than 75 autos got flat tires today as steel shavings trickled from a truck traveling along a 15mile stretch of Interstate 17. The police said that the shavings had also pierced some gas tanks, causing loss of fuel.

title: Bloomingdale's Names Aide
description: Leslie Rogell has been named manager of the new Bloomingdale's store in Garden City, LI., on May 1. Mr. Rogell is currently manager of Bloomingdale's store in New Rochelle, N.Y. He will be succeeded in New Rochelle by Stephen Spiro, presently branch divisional merchandise manager in the Short Hills, N.J., store.

title: U.S. War Losses in Week Are the Lowest in 3 Months
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP)  Two Americans were reported killed in action in Indochina last week and 19 wounded. The casualty total of 21 was the lowest since midDecember.

title: U.S. as LawBreaker
description: Even the British Government now anticipates that the Pearce Commission will report to Prime Minister Heath that the projected settlement with Rhodesia is not acceptable to that country's black majority. If that happens, Mr. Heath will have no honorable choice except to persevere with the mandatory sanctions invoked against Rhodesia In 1968 at Britain's request by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Cambodian Cache Explodes
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 16 (AP)  The main ammunition dump at the Pnompenh airport blew up today, and explosions continued for three hours four miles from the center of the city.

title: T.W.A. Is Held Liable for Injury To Passenger in A rab Hijacking
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a passenger on a plane hijacked by Palestinian commandos was entitled to recover damages for fright and distress.

title: Investment Club With ares in Vineyard
description: They could have put their money in taxfree municipals. They could have bought fur coats for their wives or taken round theworld cruises. Instead, they bought a vineyard in France, Well, half a vineyard.

title: Curbs Being Sought On Synthetic Drugs By Geneva Parley
description: GENEVA, March 16  A proposal for international regulations aimed at limiting the production of synthetic drugs by requiring annual reports from producers won preliminary approval here today at a conference on narcotics sponsored by the United Nations.

title: Letters to the Editor; Pentagon's (Buying) Power
description: To the Editor:

title: E.E.C. BARS SHIFT IN FARM PRICING
description: PARIS, March 16The European Economic Community has made a gesture in favor of American foodexporting interests and British consumers with a decision reached in the early morning hours today barring any change in its basic. unit for valuing farm goods.

title: In Ophuls Film, just Living in a War
description: The Sorrow and the Pity, a widely acclaimed 4hour documentary on the World War II occupation of France that opened Wednesday at the Beekman Theater, suggests strongly that the majority of Frenchmen did not actively resist the Germans.

title: Policeman Is Hurt In $90,000 Holdup Of Bank in Bronx
description: A 28yearold patrolman was wounded in a gun battle and chase yesterday after the $90.000 robbery of a Bronx bank.

title: Garden Is Cocker's First Stop As He Resumes Concert Tours
description: English rock star Joe Cocker's return to the concert wars at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night left much to be desired. Cocker has never had a reputation for the effldent organization of his music and It was fairly evident that the success of his last American tour, more than a year ago, was;due in no small measure to the musical and professional skills of Leon Russell.

title: Surge in Lending Abroad Aggravates Dollar Drain
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Lending by banks to borrowers in foreign countries contributed a substantial amount to the deficit in the nation's balance of international payments last year for the first time since controls on this kind of lending were imposed, a member of the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Priests Convention Backs Harrisburg, 7; Denies Membership to Married Clergy
description: DENVER, March 16The National Federation of Priests Councils strongly backed the Harrisburg Seven defendants today and denied membership in the Roman Catholic organization to a married priests group.

title: NIXON ASKS BILL IMPOSING HALTINNEW BUSINGORDERS; SEEKS EDUCATION EQUALITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 16President Nixon said tonight that he would ask Congress for legislation imposing a moratorium on the Federal courts to prevent them from ordering any new busing of schoolchildren to achieve racial balance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Applause for your Feb. 29 editorial Insecure Borders. Your diagnosis of the ills of the Middle East is accurate. The 'root cause of the problem is not, as the Israeli representative charged, Lebanon's failure to control terrorist organization on its soil. This form of Israeli double tyranny remains unconvincing and unacceptable to men of conscience everywhere.

title: Pompidou Calls Vote On Enlarged Market
description: PARIS, March 16President Pompidou today unexpectedly announced, a referendum on the entry of Britain, Ireland, Norway and Denmark into the European Common Market.

title: Ali Arrives in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, March 16 (AP)Muhammad All arrived in Tokyo today and predicted he would knock out Mac Foster in five rouns. He also said he planned to learn karate and visit mainland China. His 15round bout with Foster is scheduled for noon April 1 and will be seen on closedcircuit television in the United States at 10 P.M., Eastern time, March 31.

title: A Concert Demonstrates The Strength of Strings
description: The American Symphony Orchestra da Camera, as the name implies, is the American Symphony Orchestra distilled to chamber size. Moreover, if Wednesday night's scrupulously prepared and skillfully performed program at Town Hall is a fair measurement, the distillation has resulted in pure, unclouded success.

title: British Petroleum Raises 1971 Profit, But Quarter Is Off
400 RELIEF WORKERS HOLD BRIEF STRIKE
description: Four hundred welfare caseworkers and clerks walked off the job at two South Bronx welfare centers yesterday which was check dispensing dayto protest what they said were mounting case loads and declining standards of safety.

title: SAIGON SAYS FOE STEPS UP ACTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 16 (AP)A large increase in enemy attacks in South Vietnam was reported today by the Saigon command.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If there is a socially useful purpose in treating the villain and the victim alike; if it is deemed advisable for our society to embrace the drunken driver, the traffic offender, the reckless motorist and reward them if they are injured in a car accident by treating them in the same manner that their innocent victims are treated, then certainly New York State should adopt a nofault auto insurance law.

title: Yank Blomberg Has Goal: Learn to Hit LeftHanders;
Citrus Industry Criticizes F.D.A. on Drink Labeling
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  The Florida citrus industry said today that labeling standards for watered orange drinks issued last week by the Food and Drug Administration were not adequate to clear up the mass confusion among consumers surrounding these products.

title: A Presidential Panel Supports Abortion on Request
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 A Presidential study commission formally recommended today that all states  following New York's example  greatly liberalize abortion laws and permit a doctor to perform an abortion at a patient's request.

title: Council Unit Votes Housing Aid Here
description: The City Council Finance Committee approved a bill yesterday that would enable the city to obtain $700million for new housing and the rehabilitation of old housing but would impose restrictions on how it could be spent.

title: Miss Gudde Gives A Dance Program With a Difference
description: Lynda Gudde is a dancerchoreographer of originality and imagination who is doing something so startlingly different from any other choreographer today that she deserves wider exposure than she has at present.

title: Company Profits Remained Steady In Final Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 Corporate profits remained essentially flat in the fourth quarter of last year at the level of the second and third quarters, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GELFAND TO SEEK SURROGATE'S POST
description: City Councilman Bertram R. Gelfand of  the Bronx annoticed yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for surrogate.

title: Strange Spoiler
description: Four years ago Eugene McCarthy burst upon the national political scene as an attractive, unorthodox spokesman of the developing revulsion against the Vietnam war. When he declared again this year, this newspaper welcomed his candidacy because he seemed likely to clarify issues and improve the Democratic dialogue.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The American Natural Gas Company announced yesterday plans to sell approximately $55million of its common stock in the first half of this year. Proceeds will be used to repay bank loans. The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 36 down

title: The I.R.A. Connection
description: Fifty years ago this day, a young exiled Irishman, Patrick Connor, made the mistake of coming to Fifth Avenue to watch the greendecked marchers on Saint Paddy's Day. He should have stayed at home Connor was trapped into being the victim of the only known shooting staged by the Irish Republican Army on the sidewalks of New York.

title: AQUEDUCT TALKS T0 BE STEPPED UP
description: Vincent B. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday that he would call for nonstop negotiations between the Independent Association of Mutuel Employees and the New York Racing Association as a means of ending the strike that has shut down thoroughbred racing at Aqueduct since March 6.

title: XRays Slated for Fregosi
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 (UPI)Jim Fregosi of the New York Mets, who hopes to start working out this weekend, will have Xrays taken again tomorrow of his broken right thumb. Fregosi said the thumb was healing and he thought he could start fielding grounders and taking batting practice again Saturday or Sunday.

title: BUSH CITES PERIL TO U.N.DIPLOMATS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16George Bush, the United States representative at the United Nations, implored Congress today to enact an Administration bill making it a Federal crime to harass or attack foreign diplomats in this country.

title: 2 Jailed Slayers to Be Subject Of Documentary on N. B. C. TV
description: Two men convicted of murdering six persons and wounding several otherS in Salt Lake City in 1966 will be the subject of a onehour documentary Tuesday, April 18, at 8:30 P.M. on the National Broadcasting Company network.

title: Advantages of a Weird System
description: Presidential primaries are fully as haphazard and illogical as their critics say they are; and, now that half the states have adopted one form or another of the primary, the argument for transforming this de facto national primary into a uniform and rational system is strong indeed.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Statement on School Busing
description: Good evening. Tonight want to talk to you about one of the most difficult issues of our timethe issue of busing,

title: Bank's Head Teller Indicted With Four In $89,000 Holdup
description: The head teller of a Brooklyn bank was accused yesterday of having plotted with four outsiders to stage an armed robbery of the bank that netted $89,000.weapon at Mr. Jenkins's head and obtained keys to the inner vault.

title: NEVADA UNIT ASKS A HUGHES MEETING
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 16  The Nevada State Gaming Control Board today demanded a facetoface meeting with Howard R. Hughes, whose seven casinos make him this state's biggest gambling operator. The decision could lead to a $100million test of wills.

title: The Talk of Albany
description: ALBANY, March 16While the Governor and the Legislature and their minions As in and out of this grimy capital, Albany is gradually changing Its way of lifefor better and for worse.

title: Powell in Critical Condition
description: MIAMI, March 16 (AP)The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. is in critical condition at Jackson Memorial Hospital here. The former New York Representative was placed on the critical list yesterday, eight days after the United States Coast Guard airlifted him here from his Baharnian retreat on Bimini Island.

title: GMELLA CHANGES EL MOROCCO STORY
description: Ronald E. Galena, the freelance photographer, changed his testimony in Federal Court here yesterday and gave a new version of how he had managed to obtain pictures of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis while he was under a court order not to take pictures of her.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN SLOW TRADING
LOCAL SCHOOL UNIT SCORED IN REPORT
description: A hearing officer appointed by School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has held that the Community School Board 23 in Brooklyn had, on at least two occasions, selected to lease and renovate buildings in which members of or contributors to the United Political Club have a significant interest.

title: Employe Purchase Urged For Struck Line in Jersey
description: John J. Gilhooley, president of Transport of New Jersey, which has been shut down for 16 days by a, bus drivers strike, suggested yesterday that management and employe representatives explore the possibility of purchasing the company.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: HONOLULU  Military withdrawal from Asia causes the United States to fall back strategically upon its huge Pacifie empire about which most Americans are almost wholly unaware. They do, of course, know that Hawaii is now a state of the Union and that this same political condition applies to Alaska's barren and sparsely inhabited Aleutian archipelago extending toward Soviet Siberia and Japan.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today to require corporations that maintain voluntary political action committees to make full, public disclosure of the groups transactions in their annual reports to stockholders.

title: The Indira Wave
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's sweeping victory India's state electionsdubbed the Indira wave by Indian newspapersconsolidates the exceptional grip on Indian politics that Mrs. Gandhi first achieved in her national election triumph one year ago. The final rout of her old Congress party foes and of opposition parties of both the right and the left gives Mrs. Gandhi a unique opportunity to deal decisively with staggering problems that still threaten the stability of India and the peace the subcontinent.

title: BARNETT F. DODGE, ABOMB SCIENTIST
description: Barnett F. Dodge, a former dean of the Yale University School of Engineering who worked on the Manhattan Project to develop the atom bomb, died yesterday at YaleNew Haven Hospital after surgery. He was 76 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Physicist in Israel Said to Prove Part of Einstein Theory
description: TEL AVIV, March 16  Tel Aviv University announced today that it had the first scientific evidence that gravity efts in waves. An experiment by Prof. Dror Sadeh of the depertinent of physics was said to have proved an assumption that has been part of the Einstein theory of relativity for 55 years.

title: King Hussein Says His Plan for the West Bank Will Be Carried Out Only After Israeli Occupation Ends
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16  King Hussein of Jordan, faced with an Arab political storm against his proposal for the establishment of a federation to include the Israeliheld West sank of the Jordan River, declared today that the plan would be carried out only after the occupation had been eliminated and our people there liberated.

title: BHUTTU ARRIVES IN SOVIET UNION
description: MOSCOW, March 16President Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan arrived in Moscow today in an apparent effort to mend political and economic relations impaired by the Soviet Union's advocacy of independence for Bangladesh, the former East Pakistan.

title: Wallace Populism Scored By His Wisconsin Rivals
Democratic Leaders in House Propose $5Bi11ion Public Works Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 16House Democratic leaders assailed the Administration's economic policies today as they proposed a $5billion crash program to construct community facilities and provide jobs for the unemployed.

title: OFFSHORE DRILLING PLANNED IN SUMMER
description: The United States Geological Survey said yesterday that would sink the first test shafts in the floor of the Atlantic Continental Shelf next summer seeking oilbearing shalerock.

title: State Panel Issues Its Proposals for Prison Reforms
description: ALBANY, March 16  A special state panel created after the Attica prison revolt in September offered more than 30 recommendations today for changes in the state's prison system, but skirted the question of how much money such changes would require.

title: Pie Traynor Dies at 72
description: Harold Joseph (Pie) Traynor, who was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame in 1948 after compiling a 320 batting average and a fielding mark of 921 in 17 seasons as the third baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old. An obituary appears on Page 44.

title: APlant Licenses Urged Without Impact Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Administration proposed today that the Atomic Energy Commission be permitted to issue interim operating licenses to nuclear power plants through June, 1973, without having to submit the final environmental impact statements required by the National Environmental Policy Act.

title: Big Board Supports $300,000 Fee Point
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted preliminary approval yesterday of a constitutional amendment to permit sales commissions to be freely competitive on all transactions above $300,000 in. value.

title: TWO NEW IN ROLES IN MET'S FALSTAFF
description: Vevdi's limber score for Falstaff, sounds a little arthritic these nights at the Metropolitan opera, but it is almost better to have it around, limping along, than not to have it at all. Two members of the cast Wednesday night joined the production for the first time, Judith Blegen as Nannetta and Matted Manuguerra as Ford. They were capable in their.roles but tended to share the general inperfections of the performance.

title: JANE GRANT DEAD; AIDED MAGAZINE
description: Jane Grant, who helped her first husband, Harold Ross, to found The New Yorker magazine in 1925 and who organized the Lucy Stone League, a forerunner of the Women's Liberation movement, died last night of cancer at her home in Litchfield, Connecticut. She was 80 years old.

title: To Julie and Abigail
description: WESTPORT, Conn.As you know, I'm 41 Divorced. Of course you know that. And I am fairly well liberated for the most part, having worked as a journalist for the last eight yearsas soon as one of you left for nursery school and the other to first or second grade.

title: Court in U.S. Denies Czech The Return of Her Children
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 16 (AP)A woman in Czechoslovakia has been denied custody of her two children, whom their father brought to the West when he defected 10 days after the Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968.

title: Knapp Inquiry's Expenses: $582,722
description: The Knapp Commission reported yesterday that it had spent $582,722 during its yearandahalf investigation of New York City police corruption.

title: BOSTON U. SEXTET GAINS TITLE FINAL
description: BOSTON, March 16 (AP)apt. Jake Denby scored three times to lead Boston University to a 41 victory over Wisconsin in a semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championships at the Boston Garden tonight.

title: Discovery of Publisher's Body Near Bomb Sari Storm in Italy
description: ROME, March 16The Milan police said tonight that Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, a leftwing millionaire publisher, had been found dead in a field near the city, apparently the victim of an explosive charge as he was preparing to blow up a powerline pylon.

title: Texas Oil Rate at 100% for First Time Since 48
description: EL PASO, Tex., March 16The Texas Railroad Commission today increased allowable oil production of wells in the state for April to 100 per cent of their maximum efficient rate for the first time since 1948. The rate for March was 86 per cent.

title: Prosecutor Lauds Berrigan Informer In Harrisburg Case
description: HARRISBURG, March 16Boyd F. Douglas Jr. ended his testimony against the socalled Harrisburg Seven today with final denial that he had extortion in mind when he infiltrated an antiwar group led by one of the defendants, the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan.

title: Rehnquist Urged a Busing Ban In 1970 Memos to White House
description: Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist in I970 presented to the White House at its request a proposed constitutional amendment prohibiting busing as a means of desegregating school systems and a strong defense of the use of such an amendment.

title: NEW CURBS STIR DISPUTE IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March I6Editors and students in this teeming capital are complaining of tightened Government restrictions since President Park Chung Hee declared a state of national emergency Dec. 6.

title: MWSKILL ASKS BID ON TRASH DISPOSAL
description: HARTFORD, March 16Gov. Thomas J. Meskill has invited companies around the country to come up with ways Connecticut might best get rid of the 10,000 tons of trash it accumulates each day, preferably turning it into new products or burning it to produce energy.

title: Suspect in Swindle Involving $100,000 In Bronx Is Sought
description: A nationwide alarm was issued by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts yesterday for a man accused of swindling 400 gypsy cab drivers in the Bronx out of $100,000.

title: Jersey Assembly Rejects Major Extension of Pike
description: TRENTON, March 16In a dramatic and surprising reversal here this evening, the Assembly overwhelmingly rejected a plan by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority build a $322million extension from Exit 9 in East Brunswick south to Toms River in Ocean County.

title: Hughes Remains in Room
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 16As far as could be determined; Howard Hughes remained in his topfloor suite at Vancouver's Bayshore Inn today. He flew here early Tuesday from Nicaragua.

title: Florida House Bans Busing
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 16 (UPI)The Florida House of Representatives passed, by a vote of 1031, a bill today allowing parents to keep their children home rather than have them bused to achieve racial integration of schools. Supporters of the bill, which was sent to the Senate, said Tuesday's statewide referendum against busing mandated passage of the bill as a partial solution to the busing issue.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Operating Rights said today the proposed merger of Northwest Airlines and National Airlines should be disapproved.

title: Two State Senators Will Retire This Year
description: ALBANY, March 16Two ranking members of the State Senate, Samuel L. Greenberg and Dalwin J. Niles, are retiring this year.

title: Okker Ousts Newcombe At Chicago Net, 76, 64
description: CHICAGO, March 16 (AP)John Newcombe of Australia, who won the Chicago stop last year on the World Championship Tennis tour, was eliminated by Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 76, 64, tonight in the second round of the $50,000 Kemper international tournament.

title: ROLLINS AND SAX GIVE JAZZ A LIFT
description: During a career that began more than 20 years ago, Sonny Rollins, the tenor saxophonist, has developed a reputation as the great willo'thewisp of jazz. He plays for several years, then disappears. Suddenly he returns and, after a few years, disappears again.

title: SALE AGREEMENT DENIED BY THALER
description: Former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler declared on the witness stand yesterday that he never saw or signed an agreement to share a commission for selling $800,000 in United States Treasury bills that had been stolen.

title: Sadat Says Egypt Makes Her Own Advanced Arms
description: CAIRO, March 16 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat said today that Egypt was producing her own advanced war weapons, according to a report by the Egyptian Government's Middle East News Agency. The report did not indicate whether Mr. Sadat mentioned any specific weapons.

title: Block Faces Tax Inquiry
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP)An investigation to determine whether H. & R. Block, one of the nation's largest tax consultants, paid its city taxes was ordered today by the city. Joseph P. Braig, Licenses and Inspections :commissioner, raised the question when it was learned that only six of the 25 Block offices had mercantile licenses.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Five former members. of Jersey City's Model Cities agency were indicted yesterday on charges of misconduct in office, extortion, bribery and conspiracy. The Hudson County grand Jury also named the Bismarck Research and Development Corporation as a defendant.

title: Bridge: Spring Nationals Begin Today With Vanderbilt as Highlight
description: CINCINNATI, March 16The Spring National Championships, which begin here tomorrow, will be one of the biggest such tournaments ever held.

title: Report Assails Inquiry on Slaying of Black Panthers
description: Neither the Federal Government nor the state sought to establish the truth In the killing of two Black Panther party !eiders during a raid on a Chicago flat in 1969, the report of eblue ribbon commission contends.

title: Filming Will Begin In City on Monday On V alachi Papers
description: A movie produced by Dino De Laurentiis, based on Peter, Maas's book The Valachi Papees, will start filming in New York on Monday.

title: $1,500 Damage Award Upheld for Clinton Inmate
description: The United States Court of Appeals upheld by a 2to1 vote yesterday a $1,500 personal damage award to an inmate against the warden of a prison in which he was mistreated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Concerned about the rising antagonism among large sections of our population, we consider it our duty to bring sober social science thinking to bear upon the controversy surrounding the Forest Hills Housing Project.

title: U.N. Group Offers Environment Plan, Asking Reorientation of Man's Values
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16In the first program ever propounded for worldwide action to improve and protect the environment, a United Nations body called today for a major reorientation of man's, values and redeployment of his energies and resources.

title: FIRST DRAFT OF YEAR LIMITED TO NO.'S 115
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)Selective Service issued the year's first draft call today under a new fairness system in which only men with lottery numbers from 1 through 15 will be inducted.

title: Jacksonville and Ford ham Fives Meet in N.I.T. Here Tonight
Port Authority Polite Vow job Action
description: Port of New York Authority policemen voted last night to observe all work regulations 200 per cent in a job action that many said would tie up truck traffic today at all the authority's New Jersey New York City crossings.

title: MEETING CALLED ON YONKERS SALE
description: YONKERS, March 10  A special meeting of the board of directors of Yonkers Raceway will be held next Tuesday, at which time the 11member group, which owns about 475000 of the 979,784 shares of stock, is expected to vote to formalize the sale of the corporation and all its assets to the five Rooney brothers of Pittsburgh.

title: AIDE REPORTS I.T.T. SHREDDED PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The general counsel to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation testified today that many sacks of papers from files of the corporation's Washington office were destroyed the day after Jack Anderson, the colurpnist, informed the corporation that he had obtained a memorandum written by its Washington lobbyist, Mrs. Dita D. Beard.

title: Tornadoes Strike Louisiana
description: KENNER, La., March 16 (UPI)  Five tornadoes struck the suburban and rural areas surrounding New Orleans today, destroying six homes, damaging 21 and knocking clown utility poles and power lines. At Lafitte, in coastal Jefferson Parish, a tornado tore through a marina, just rebuilt after a tornado wrecked it two years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Little attention has been paid to the Incompatibility of the Vietnamization policy with a serious offer of meaningful elections or U.S. withdrawal.

title: Population Report Excerpts
description: Washington, March 16Following are excerpts from the second report of the Federal Commission on Population Growth and the American Future, made today to the President, Congress and the public:

title: DECLINE FORECAST FOR SUGAR OUTPUT
description: F. O. Licht, the European commodity statistical concern, reported yesterday its estimate for world sugar production in the current season ending Aug. 31 at 73.9 million metric tons, or 926,000 tons fewer than were estimated last November. Tonnage in last year's production season amounted to 72,751,000 tons.

title: CONFIDENCE VOICED IN ENVOY TO PARIS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (Reuters)  The State Department expressed confidence today in Arthur K. Watson, Ambassador to France, following a newspaper columnist's report that he had been gloriously drunk on an airliner.

title: Underground Labrador Plant Yields Power
description: CHURCHILL FALLS, NewfoundlandBeneath the frozen lakes, sparse black spruce and snowcovered rock of Labrador, electricity flows from the world's largest underground powerhouse.

title: VOLPE IS OPPOSED ON TRANSIT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe's plan to use some of the Federal highway money for public transportation received a cool reception today front the first Congressional committee to get a crack at it.

title: Three's a Crowd
description: The second part of the report of the President's Commission on Population Growth, issued yesterday, is model of courage, candor and clarity. The commission has tackled head on such sensitive issues as sex education, genetic research, abortion and the dissemination contraceptive information and services. In every case it has taken a forceful stand for open discussion and freedom of individual choice.

title: Title Table Tennis Opens Today
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 16With a match with the, People's Republic of China team imminent, the United States national tabletennis championships start a threeday run tomorrow at Hofstra University.

title: U.S. Agency Decides on Delay In Carrying Out Nuclear Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Officials of the Anna. Control and Disarmament Agency disclosed today that the United States had decided not to comply immediately with a treaty provision that would require it to halt the supply of fissionable nuclear fuels to West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Belgium.

title: RailTon Mileage Up 3.2%
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic in the week ended March 11 totaled an estimated 14.8 billion tonmiles, up 3.2 per cent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings totaled 487,004, down 2.9 per cent. The American Trucking intercity Inc., reported ntercity truck tonnage rose 3.7 per cent.

title: Samuels Suggests Plan to Give More OTB Funds to the Tracks
description: Howard J. Samuels, in an at tempt to forestall rising complaints by the state racing industry about offtrack betting's inroads on profits, proposed formula yesterday whereby the Offtrack Betting Corporation would increase payments to the tracks in exchange for more cooperation.

title: NORTH CAROLINA, PENN WIN TO GAIN FINAL IN THE EAST
ST. JOE LIFTS PRICE OF ZINC 1C A POUND
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the price of zinc by 1 cent, to 18 cents a pound, effective immediately.

title: Ideas for the Weekend Cook
description: In the menus below, the dishes.marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Florida Study Finds War Topped Busing
Farmers Will Cut Corn Acreage 8%, U.S. Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)Farmers intend to cut 1972 corn planting to 68.46 million acres, 8 per cent below the acreage planted in last year's record crop, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: The Screen:
description: There are those who live as if their lives were works of art. In the case of the Page family of Newhaven, south of London, the work of art might be an unsuccessful Ronald Searle cartoon. The Pages brothers Peter and Jim, sisters Kathy and Nancy, and their old dadlive in the woods, inhabiting a kind of verdant junk heap of their own collecting, and they are the subject of a new documentary, dismally titled The Moon and the Sledgehammer, which opened yesterday at the Bleccker Street Cinema.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Those who contributed most to the American Littoral Society's fishtagging program in 1971 received recognition at the society's fifth annual symposium at Hunter College last weekend.Members of the society, which is an organization of scientists, anglers; naturalists and others dedicated to the conservation and understanding of the littoral, or coastal, areas of the sea, have now tagged and released more than 40,000 fish of various species, from striped bass off Long. Island to brown trout in in New Zealand.

title: Port Notes
description: Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, stroked the greendyed rabbit's foot that hung from the lapel of his St. Patrick's Day finery yesterday a green pinstriped suitand conceded that his union might need a little bit of luck when it applies for Federal Pay Board approval of its new contract. He sported the goodluck piece at a luncheon meeting of the Institute of Collective Bargaining 24 hours after the Pay Board sliced about onefourth off a firstyear wageandfringe benefits increase submitted by the West Coast International Longshoremen's & Warehousemen's Union. Mr. Gleason was tactically ambivalent about the prospect of a national dock strike if the I.L.A. doees not get the raise it has negotiated.

title: 7 DEMOCRATS LISTED IN MICHIGAN PRIMARY
description: LANSING, Mich., March 17Seven Republicans were listed today in Michigan's Presiden1 tial primary May 16.

title: NEW ISSUES SHOW STRONG ADVANCES
description: The hot newIssues marketlong expected by Wall Street seemed yesterday to have arrived.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, March 17President Nixon's move against busing, like the rapprochement with China and the resort to wage and price controls, will stand among his bold reversals of the policies of several Administrations. The legal, political and social repercussions will long be felt throughout the country. But even more than the other Nixon turnabouts, it was designed for dramatic shortrange impact In this election year and leaves many more questions than It resolves for the future.

title: I.T.T. AIDE DENIES SHE WROTE MEMO CITED AT HEARING
description: DENVER, March 17Mrs. Dita Davis Beard branded as a hoax, a forgery and a cruel fraud today a memorandum attributed to her linking the settlement of antitrust actions against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with its donation to the Republican National Convention.

title: 14 Years, in Orbit
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, March 17 (Reuters)The world's oldest manmade satellite, Vanguard I, marks its 14th birthday in space this week. The grapefruitsize satellite no longer used, but latest estimates give it a life span in orbit of at least 5,000 years.

title: Executive Changes
description: Edward J. MeColgan has been elected executive vice president of the Franklin Society Federal Savings and Loan Association. James N. Hotted war named senior vice president and treasurer.

title: GUITAR BRILLIANCE SHOWN BY BITETTI
description: The list of firstrate guitar virtuosos seems to get longer every year. Ernesto Bitetti, who played foi. the first time in New York Thursday night at Hunter College, belongs somewhere in the very top categoryhe is brilliant technician as well as a versatile, sensitive and communicative musician.

title: False Busing Crisis
description: President Nixon has snatched the antibusing ball off the muddy field of Florida primary politics and is trying to carry it to a November touchdown, whatever the price in national division. In his televised address Mr. Nixon rejected demands for a Constitutional amendment to ban school busing, not because it would trivialize the Constitution, but only because it takes too long.

title: Underwriters to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (Reuters)  Some of Wall Street's leading underwriters have been called to testify at next week's Securities and Exchange Commission hearings on hot issues, S.E.C. sources said today.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: CHICAGO, March 17In a lowermiddleclass suburb of Miami, two days before the Florida primary, 60yearold widow was explaining why she was going to vote for George Wallace. These politicians, she said, you can't believe em. You put good man in there, and he's a crook when he comes out.

title: Art: Downtown Scene
description: Soho Photo, an 80member cooperative that opened only two months ago in secondfloor loft at 143 Prince Street, is rapidly emerging as one of the most interesting galleries in the area. Although it has mounted but three exhibitions, it has already shown a rich diversity of quality photography and has given public exposure to many talented young photographers who otherwise might not have had a chance to exhibit their work.

title: PMC Colleges Changing Name to Widener College
description: CHESTER, Pa., March 17 (AP)Dr. Clarence R. Moll, president of PMC Colleges, announced today that the 150yearold institution would change its name to Widener College, effective July 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I appreciated your March 7 editorial, Revolt of the Robots. However, please caution the editorial board to reconsider the statement in the editorial which places Lordstown, Ohio, in the conservative heartland of middle America. Lordstown is but fifteen miles from the Pennsylvania border, hardly the heartland, of America. If it is, the good people of Kansas City will be greatly disappointed.

title: OPERATIONS CURBED ON JERSEY CENTRAL
description: NEWARK, March 17 (AP)The trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad Company of New Jersey announced today he had taken steps to suspend temporarily all operations of the railroad in Pennsylvania as of April 1.

title: Lesson in Police Courtesy
description: A captain in the Police Department's intelligence division will spend six months at a police college in England learning what makes British policemen so efficient and courteous, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced today. Mr. Murphy said at a news conference, that the captain, Richard Condon, would attend the British Police College at Bramshill under a partial grant from the recently formed New York City Police Foundation Inc.

title: BRITAIN LISTS RISE IN GROSS PRODUCT
description: LONDON, March 17Britain's gross domestic productthe total of all goods and services produced In the nationrose 12 per cent last year, to $123.5billion, but most of the increase represented inflation rather than real growth.

title: Shaggy Ape Vanishing, Sleek Hairdos Return
description: The Ape has died a King Kong kind of death. That shaggy monkey of haircut, the beehive of its day, has gone down with a crash, according to hairdressers. Shag backlash has moved In, bringing shorter, sleeker hair and revival of hair geometry, updated from the sixties to the seventies. And it goes by many names, from Dutch Boy to China Doll to Zelda.

title: 7YearOld Shot in Back By a Sniper in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 17 (Reuters)  A sevenvearold boy was shot in the back by a sniper's bullet as he played near his home in a Belfast street tonight. He was rushed to a hospital in serious condition.

title: Reflections On a Trip To Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandThe first sight, particularly for an Englishman, of a British soldier pointing cocked rifle at your car in Britain is unforgettable.

title: Koscot Cosmetics Accused Of Illegal Business Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused Koscot Cosmetics today of an illegal business practice by building huge pyramid of distributorships.

title: I Am Not Bormann
description: BOGOTA, March 19 (AP)I am not Bormann, Johann Ehrmann said today in a radio interview in the southern Colombian city of Paste. I only fought in the First World War.

title: Anthony A. Henninger Dies; ExSyracuse Mayor Was 81
description: SYRACUSE, March 17 (AP)  Anthony A. Henninger, mayor of Syracuse from 1957 to 1961, died today in CourseIrving Memorial Hospital's coronary care unit. Ho was 81 years old.

title: A Minefield, Heykal Says
description: CAIRO, March 17 (UPI)Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, editor of the semiofficial daily Al Abram and a confidant of President Sadat, today termed King Hussein's proposal a minefield from beginning to end.

title: GOLDBERG SCORES BUSING PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur 3. Goldberg today called President Nixon's proposed antibusing legislation a proposal to restore the separate but equal concept and said he cannot conceive that the Supreme Court would uphold it.

title: Appeals Court Rules Brown Must Be at His Sentencing
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit threw out a fiveyear jail sentence against H. Rap Brown today, ruling that a lower court had no right to sentence the black militant without his being present in the courtroom.

title: 3 Robbers Get $57,000 From a Bank in Flushing
description: Three armed men held up a branch of the Kings Lafayette Bank at 14461 Northern Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, last night and escaped with more than $57,000.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia yesterday rejected a plea by Carmine J. Persico for a new trial on hijacking charges. The petition was made after a key prosecution witness had recanted his testimony.

title: Illinois Is Closely Watched Despite Slim Ballot
Table Tennis: The Sound and Flurry
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., March 17The sound of 40 balls clicking against SO racquets, of kibitzing from the stands, of sellers hawking their equipment from booths, and the steady flurry of activity dominated the opening round today of the United States open table tennis championships.

title: ARTHUR ARNOLD
description: GREAT NECK, L. I, March 17 Arthur Arnold, executive vice president of Budd Looms, Inc., carpet retailers and distributors with headquarters at 306 East 61st Street, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 51 years old and lived at 12 Hemsley Lane.

title: Woman Has 7 Babies; 2 Are Stillborn, 2 Die
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., March 17 (AP)A young woman who took fertility drugs for four years gave birth to seven babies today. Two were stillborn and two died five hours after their birth.

title: Hunt for Tanker Crew Ends
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (UPI)The Coast Guard said today it had canceled a search for 28 men missing in the sinking on March 5 of the Liberian tanker San Nicolas in the Gulf of Mexico. Only two of the 30 crewmen aboard the San Nicolas were saved. They were picked up by a passing ship. Reporting the sinking, they said they heard a loud noise, the engines speeded up and the ship tilted down sharply.

title: Sony Shows New System
description: The Sony Corporation has developed a color video projection system that projects prerecorded programs from a video player or, with the aid of an additional TV tuneradaptor, can project programs taken off the air. The company expects to market the system this fall for about $2,000 with an additional $250 for a special large screen that measures 50inches diagonally. It has a low power consumption of only 120 watts.

title: Fugitive Denied Legal Aid
description: TORONTO, March 17 (UPDKarleton Lewis Armstrong, a fugitive from the United States, said today that he had been refused legal aid and voiced doubt he would have a lawyer for his extradition hearing here. Mr. Armstrong, 25 years old, wanted in Wisconsin for murder and three counts of arson in the 1970 bombing of a University of Wisconsin Army research center, was remanded a further week to allow United States authorities more time to gather evidence for the hearing.

title: City and Sanitationmen Extend Term of Contract
description: The city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association have agreed to extend the term of their current contract to 30 months from 27 and to include) additional pay increases totaling $225.

title: Ehrmann Said to Laugh
description: BOGOTA, March 17The police officer who took Johann Ehrmann into custody told a radio station here today that Mr. Ehrmann chortled with delight at the suggestion that he is Martin Borrnann.

title: POLICE CHECK FAILS TO DISRUPT TRAFFIC
description: Traffic moved normally at the Hudson River crossings between the city and New Jersey yesterday despite a rulebook job action in which Port Authority policemen had threatened to inspect every truck extensively for violations, causing tieups.

title: AGENT IS ENJOINED ON SUPERSTAR ROLE
description: A Manhattan booking agent was enjoined yesterday from mounting any road shows that use any of the songs from Jesus Christ Superstar in the same order that they are sung in the Broadway production or from using costumes or dramatic action.

title: For City Children Who Can't Live at Home, a New Way of Life
description: Just a few months ago, Linda, a lively, talkative 14. yearold, was one of 80 girls staying at Callagy Hall, city shelter on East 12th Street for children who can't live at home and are not considered juvenile delinquents.

title: Aflred Powell Morgan Is Dead; Engineer and Inventor Was 82
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 17Alfred Powell Morgan, a retired electrical engineer and an inventor and author, died yesterday at his home, 69 Brookfield Road, at the age of 82.

title: Bogota Investigates Bormann Suspect
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 17 (Reuters)Secret police agents brought a Germanborn recluse out of the remote Amazon jungles of southern Colombia today for an investigation of whether he is Martin Bormann, Hitler's deputy.

title: Baffling Maneuver
description: President Pompidou's decision to call a referendum France on expansion of the European Economic Community to ten members is baffling, to put it mildly. It bound to make it even more difficult for Prime Minister Heath to steer through a reluctant House of Commons the legislation necessary for British membershipa goal Mr. Pompidou insists he ardently desires.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON DAY CARE PACT
description: The negotiating committee for Local 1707 of the Community and Social Agency EmI ployes Union voted unanimous approval last night of a new contract with the Day Care Council of New York, a union spokesman reported.

title: Traynor Funeral Monday
description: PITTSBURGH, March 17 (UPI) A funeral service for Pie Traynor, considered by many the best major league third baseman, will be held at 2 P.M. Monday at the Samson Funeral Home in Pittsburgh. The former ballplayer died last night at the age of 72. His widow, Eve, survives.

title: 100,000 Join the St. Patrick's Parade
description: The Irish and their adherents marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday. Some wore black armbands and some carried banners saying, England Get Out of Ireland, but their mood, as it nearly always is on St. Patrick's Day, was festive nonetheless.

title: Nixon's Plan Splits Rivals; Ervin Leads Busing Attack
description: WASHINGTON, March 17President Nixon's call for a halt in forced busing of schoolchildren left Democratic candidates for the Presidency further divided today, Southerners far from satisfied and some Congressional leaders dubious about the constitutionality of the move.

title: Turkish Chief Due Today on U.S. Visit
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 17 The problems of enforcing permanent ban on opiumpoppy cultivation in Turkey will be high on the agenda of talks next week between President Nixon and the Turkish Premier, Dr. Nihat Erim.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 17, 1972 THE PRESIDENT

title: State Criticizes Claims Made For a Spray to Relieve Asthma
description: An overthecounter aerosol spray sold to relieve asthma suffering has come under attack from Attorney General Louis X. Lefkowitz's Consumer Frauds and Protection Bureau for the advertising claims made for it on the speed of its action.

title: Bridge: Cincinnati Team Tics Aces On Eve of Spring Nationals
description: CINCINNATI, March 17Before the Spring National Championships of the, American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, the host city had good reason to be pleased with itself.

title: Jordanian Aide Denies Hussein Seeks Settlement With Israelis
description: BEIRUT, March 17Foreign Minister Abdullah Salah of Jordan denied today that King Hussein was seeking a unilateral peace settlement with Israel.

title: Dr. Arthur L Hutner, 44, Radiologist at Columbia
description: Dr. Arthur I. Hutner, an attending radiologist at Roosevelt Hospital since 1960 and assistant clinical professor in radiology at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Thursday in an auto accident in St. Ann's Bay, Jamaica, W. I., where he had been vacationing with his wife, who was injured. He was 44 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue.

title: Regional Labor Aide Named
description: Clayton J. Cottrell, a Federal manpower program official, has been appointed to the newly created post of regional director of the United States Department of Labor. Mr. Cottrell, a 48yearold native of Huntington, W. Va., and formerly manpower administrator with the Labor Department in New York, will be one of the 10 new regional directors across the country.

title: The Talk of Beaver Island
description: BEAVER ISLAND, Mich., March 17When Walter and Vera Wojan marked their 25th wedding anniversary here the other day, virtually the entire island turned out at the Shamrock Bar to help celebrate. The next night everybody celebrated the birthday of Phil Gregg, Lloyd McDonough and Rosie Connaghan. And the next night they had another party to finish off the food from the first two parties. Wednesday they had a party when the mail plane could not land in the fog. Yesterday they would have had another if it had landed. And today. Well, today was very special.

title: South Korea Now Permits Calls by Vessels of Cuba
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 17 (Reuters)Cuban ships are now allowed to call at ports in South Korea, the Transportation Ministry announced today.

title: HARRY PRAGER
description: Harry Prager, a general insurance broker and special representative of the Travelers Insurance Company, died Wednesday at his home, 40 Park Avenue. His age was 74.

title: Highway TrustBuster
description: The recommendation of Secretary of Transportation Volpe that politically sacrosanct highway trust funds be spent for mass transit projects is refreshing. He wants to provide a Single Urban Fund for rail and highway transportationplus money for rural roadsout of the swelling surplus now piling up in a fund nourished chiefly by the Federal tax on gasoline. Since highway users have long contributed, however unwittingly, to the deterioration of the general environment, there is every reason to use at least part of that tax to reclaim the environment rather than damage it still further.

title: ANDREW WILLONER
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 Andrew Willoner, retired motion picture sound engineer for C.R.S. News here, died yesterday at Leland Memorial Hospital in Riverdale, Md. He was 66 years old and lived in College Park, Md.

title: Laotians Open a Drive
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 17 (UPI)  Military sources reported today that Government troops had begun an attempt to reopen the highway between Vientiane and the royal capital of Luang Prabang 150 miles north of here.

title: PROF. HENRI SACK, PHYSICIST, IS DEAD
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 17Dr. Henri S. Sack, Walter S. Carpenter Jr. Professor of Engineering and professor of applied physics at Cornell University, died yesterday at Tompkins County Hospital after a short illness. His age was 68.

title: News Analysis
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 16For the last six months, about once a week, a small motorcade escorted by a police car has left Seoul for the 35mile drive north through the mountains to the demilitarized zone dividing North and South Korea.

title: WOMAN, 20, JOINS MISS DAVIS'S JURY
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 17 In an unexpected lastminute shuffle, a 20yearold secretary was added today to the jury in the trial of Angela Davis.

title: MRS. ADA WHITNEY, EXSOCIAL WORKER
description: Mrs. Ada Ellen Kelly Whitney, a retired social worker and religious leader, and widow of Joseph R. B. Whitney, editor of The Canadian Observer died last Saturday of a heart attack at her home in South Ozone Park, Queens. She was 78 years old.

title: Group Urges Lowenstein To Run Against Rooney
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein has been urged by a group of Reform Democrats and civic leaders in Representative John J. Rooney's 14th Congressional District to run against the veteran Brooklyn Democrat in the June 20 primary.

title: Celebration in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, March 17St. Patrick's Day was celebrated here and in other Irish towns with church services, industrial parades and marching bands.

title: TWO MAKE DEBUTS IN MARIA STUARDA
description: Act I of Donizetti's Maria Stuarda is dominated by the roles of Queen Elizabeth and the Earl of Leicester. In Thursday night's performance by the New York City Opera, the roles were sung by two artists making their debuts with the company, Marisa Galvany and Luciano Rampaso. Because of nervousness, the difficulty of the music or whatever, they sang badly. One wondered why a socalled bel canto opera should be performed if there was no beautiful singing to be had.

title: New Leader Is Elected By Italian Communists
description: MILAN, Italy, March 17The 13th Congress of the ItalianCommunist party, the strongest in the nonCoMmunist world, ended today with a longexpected shuffle in the top leadership.

title: Motor Inn Purchased by Chinese To Give Stall Severance Pay
description: After a daylong work stoppage, vows to hold a sleepin, and the threat of eviction by the police, workers at the Lincoln Square Motor Inn settled for $40,000to be paid by the management  as compensation for the loss of their jobs.

title: Market Place: Annual Reports: New Approach
Scribner Assigns Aide as Chief of East Side Board
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner assigned one of his aides yesterday to serve temporarily as chief administrator of District 1 on, the Lower East Side after the local school board could not agree on a new acting or permanent superintendent.

title: BankersTrust and Chase Weigh Joint Credit Unit
description: The Bankers Trust Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank disclosed yesterday that they were discussing the possibility of forming a jointly owned company to handle the creditauthorization and dataprocessing operations of their creditcard activities.

title: Simeon Karavaeff, 77, Dead; Dancer Partnered Pavlova
description: Simeon B. Karavaeff, a dancer, died Wednesday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 134 West 58th Street.

title: Rozelle's Mother Dies
description: LYNWOOD, Calif., March 17 (UPI)  Mrs. Hazel Viola Rozelle, mother of Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, died yesterday at the age of 73. She is survived by her husband, Raymond; two brothers, two sons and two grandchildren.

title: MANY SAIGON DAILIES CEASING PUBLICATION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. March 17 (Reuters) Nearly half of Saigon's Vietnameselanguage newspapers have ceased publication after a Government ordered increase of 125 per cent in the price of newsprint, official sources said today.

title: Thais Attack a Rebel Stronghold
description: LOM SAX, Thailand, March 16Two Thai Army battalions, using United States equipment and tactics developed by the American Army in Vietnam, are trying to dislodge Communist insurgents from milehigh plateau 16 miles northwest of here.

title: Italy Opens Wide Probe Into Publisher's Death
description: ROME, March 17A largescale investigation was under way in many parts of Italy today into the death yesterday of Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, the publisher who introduced Boris Pasternak's Dr. Zhivago to the West.

title: Man Acquitted in Slaying
description: Themes Brodie, 29 years old, of 12907 Liberty Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, was acquitted in State Supreme in Queens yesterday of the 1971 slaying of a restaurant owner. The victim, Sigmund Westfal, the owner of Westfal's Restaurant, 11102 Atlantic Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, was shot to death last July during robbery of the restaurant.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE GAS SHOWS PROFIT RISE
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday a gain of 35 per cent in net income for 1971 on an increase of 19 per cent in total operating revenues. The company's annual report placed revenues at $8885,506,000 against $741,252,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $126,003,000, or $3 a share, from the $93,432,000, or $2.46 a share, reported in 1970. Edward R. Eberle, president of the New Jersey utility, reported that the company's position improved substantially over 1970. He noted that the gain in total revenues was the largest annual increase in the company's history.

title: Tories Seeking to Explain Denial of Aid to Industry
description: LONDON, March 17The Conservative Government has launched a campaign to explain an apparent reversal of policy of denying financial aid to failing private enterprises.

title: Tashkent Quake Reported
description: MOSCOW, March 17 (AP)Tags reported an earthquake in the Tashkent area of Central Asia today. A quake in 1966 left 300,000 persons homeless in Tashkent.

title: PEKING AFFIRMS INDOCHINA POLICY
description: HONG KONG, March l7 Peking today completed a new round of endorsements of the war policies of the Communistled forces in Indochina by issuing a statement of support for the rebel Sihanoukgovernment of Cambodia.

title: ROANOKE FIVE TAKES TITLE AT EVANSVILLE
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 17 (AP)Unheralded Roanoke College of Salem, Va., led all the way tonight to defeat Akron 8472, and win the National Collegiate collegedivision basketball championship.

title: Media Said to Ignore Freedom of Information Act,
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)Although reporters and broadcasters were in the fore front of those pushing for the Freedom of Information Act, the media have made little use of it during its first four years of operation, a Congressional report said today.

title: $1BILLION IS VOTED FOR DRUG CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)The Senate sent to President Nixon today a bill authorizing $1billion to be used in the next three years for an intensified campaign against drug abuse.

title: Excerpts From Nixon's Message to Congress Calling for Moratorium and Permanent Restraints on Busing
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message on busing delivered to Congress today:

title: NIXON AID SOUGHT ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Citizens Advisory Council the Status of Women called President Nixon today to endorse the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: 7,000 Books on Blacks Fill a Home
description: By the time Clarence L. Holte retired after more than 20 years as an advertising specialist in ethnic markets, he had a $400,000 hobby to come home to.

title: CITY AIDE ACCUSED OF $129,600 THEFT
