description: A $10,600ayear employe of the city's Finance Administration was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing $129,500 from the city in the last 10 months.

title: BOYLE JURY CHOSEN FOR FEDERAL TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)A jury of four men and eight women was selected today to hear the Federal criminal trial of the United Mine Workers president, W. A. Boyle, on charges that he and other officials funneled union money into political campaigns,

title: 5 Die in CarTruck Crash
description: SCOTRUN, Pa., March 17 (UPIFive youths, traveling to New York City to celebrate St. Patrick's Day, were killed last night in a cartruck crash on Interstate 80 near here. The dead were passengers in an auto driven by Ellen Scott, 20, of Scarsdale, N. Y. Miss Scott was hospitalized. The dead were identified as Winifred Scanlon, 21, of Scranton, Pa.; William O'Brian, 20, Hastings, N. Y.; Kathleen Sullivan, 19, Edison, N. J.; Ellen McCarty, 18, Parlin, N. J.; and Margaret Ann Kitson, 18, Flushing, Queens. The truck driver escaped injury.

title: Art: Duveneck's Brilliant Fragments
description: Frank Duveneck (18481919), if not exactly a genius manqu, was at least a painter who promised to establish a major position in American art but stopped halfway through his career and settled for a minor one. His best paintings  strong, dark and slashed onto the canvas with a kind of muscular bravado  can still bring you up short when you run across one in a museum. They have the air of quickly executed classroom demonstrations by a painter who in his studio might have rivaled Menet. But Duveneck was at the top of his form he was a master of notation who had little ability (or perhaps It was only that he had little interest) in extended exposition.

title: ALBERT E. POSENER
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 17Albert E. Posener, who retired as a general partner of F. S. Moseley & Co, New York stockbrokers, last October, died here yesterday at the age of 62.

title: Antiques: Salt Glaze
description: Collectors should get to see the selection of 16thto 19thcentury salt glaze being shown at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts in the center of a gallery filled with examples of the ware being made today by artistcraftsmen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Leonard Buder's news article relative to the possible demise of funded programs dealing with narcotics education and drug abuse. Three points come to mind:

title: DOLLAR STRONGER IN TRADES ABROAD
description: PARIS, March 17The dollar put on a good show of strength in the European financial centers today in response to higher interest rates in New York and President Pompidou's signal that French monetary attacks against the United States are being called off, at least for the time being.

title: Koch's Paintings Likable Despite Style
description: A wise critic, I suppose, should avoid discussing the paintings of John Koch. They are unremittingly oldfashionedoldfashioned in style, oldfashioned in their subjects, oldfashioned, even, in their flashy technical skill.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS PERMANENT CURB ON SCHOOL BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, March 17President Nixon asked Congress today to place a moratorium on all court orders that would require busing to achieve school desegregation and to enact during the moratorium legislation that would place permanent restraints on the use of busing by the courts and the executive branch. His proposal, thus, went much further than he indicaterlin a special address to the nationlast night.

title: Patrolman Arraigned
description: A 33yearold Transit Authority patrolman, who allegedly gave a sample of heroin to a man he believed to be a prospective purchaser but who actually was a detective, was arraigned in the Bronx yesterday on charges of criminal possession and sale of a dangerous drug. District Attorney Burton B. Roberts identified the patrolman as William Brown Jr. and said he had been suspended from the force, which he joined lin 1965.

title: 300 Immates Break Out of Cells After Stabbing at Walpole Mass.
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Saturday, March 18 (AP)About 300 prisoners at the Walpole State Prison broke out of their cells into the prison yard late last night following the stabbing of an inmate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his column of March 1, James Reston writes that Mr. Nixon now needs at a minimum, not only the absence of war, but the cooperation of all the major Asian powers, Russia, Japan, China to establish a more dependable world order.

title: FamilyPlanning Stamp Is Shown Here
description: The United States Postal Serivce will issue a stamp today commemorating family planninga move that proponents of birth control feel constitutes an important recognition of their respectability by the Nixon Administration.

title: Mass Said in Gaelic For Local Leagues In East Side Chapel
description: In ainm an Athar agus an Mhic agus an spioraid Naoimh, intoned Father Barth Keohane from County Cork.

title: City Hospital Repair Fund Cut to a Sixth of Request
description: The City Health and Hospitals Corporation was notified yesterday that it would receive $5.7million this fiscal year to correct violations of health, building and fire codes at the 18 public hospitals it operates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dr. Albert Sattin's statement that Medical and scientific understanding of the consequences of marijuana use is in its infancy [letter March 3] raises a pertinent question: Just how sophisticated and precise must our knowledge of marijuana be before the laws can be reformed? It. has already been established that marijuana is neither addictive nor lethal and that any toxic effects it may have are so minor that they have been undocumented after 4,000 years of use and nearly a century of comprehensive research. Granted it would be best to have perfect information before we act, but this would require waiting an additional 50 or 100 years. Not only is this absurd, it is unnecessary. Our present knowledge of marijuana is more than adequate to justify a new approach to marijuana control, one which is rational, effective, and enforceable.

title: 15 Go on Trial in Athens On Illegal Explosives Charge
description: ATHENS, March 17Fifteen persons, including three lawyers and three physicians, went on trial today before a military tribunal on charges of illegal possession and use of explosives, which carry possible life sentences.

title: Farmers in State Plan A MilkDrinking Drive
description: ALBANY, March 17  New York State's dairy farmers have voted to tax themselves up to $5million a year, starting May 1, to promote the lagging consumption of milk, the state's main agricultural product.

title: Candidates'
description: DECATUR, Ill., March 17Senator Edmund S. Muskie called on the Federal Trade Commission today to conduct an immediate, largescale investigation into the takeover of farms by large, nonfarm corporations.

title: Notes on People
description: Casper the Friendly Ghost is going to the moon. So is Orion, a constellation usually found elsewhere in spaces Casper and Orion were chosen by the Apollo 16 astronauts as the names for the two spacecraft scheduled to fly them to the moon beginning April 16.

title: Untaxed Cigarettes Seized
description: PERRYVILLE, Md., March 17 (AP)A New York man was arrested today as agents of the Maryland Controller's Office seized 12,272 cartons of untaxed cigarettes. Arrested was James Russo, an unemployed mechanic from Brooklyn.

title: Youth Wins Place on Ballot
description: TYLER, Tex., March 17 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the city of Longview to let an 18yearold resident run as a candidate for City Commissioner, ruling that ownership of property was not a requirement for holding public office. United States District Court Judge William Justice issued a preliminary judgment ordering that the name of the youth, Richard Lee, be on the ballot.

title: U.S. Copter Crash Kills 11 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 17 (AP)  A United States helicopter carrying an American combat team into action crashed today in a river 20 miles northeast of here, apparently killing all 11 aboard.

title: Housing Starts Set Mark; Personal Income Climbs
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 The boom in housing continued in February at a record annual rate of almost 2.7 million starts, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DETROIT ALTERING DECOY OPERATION
description: DETROIT, March 17  The operations of a police unit here that uses plainclothes men to fight street crime have been modified as the result of the shooting of three deputy sheriffs by three members of the unit last week.

title: 2 Suits Call for Eventual Phase Out of Willowbrook
description: A broad legal attack on the Willowbrook State School for

title: Temple U. Student Slain
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (UPI)A teenager stabbed a student to death and wounded, another last night in a subway station near Temple University when they refused to give him a cigarette or a dollar bill. Carey Dillinger, 19 years old, a sophomore at Temple, was pronounced dead at Temple Hospital from a chest wound. His roommate, William Snyder, 20, was treated at the hospital for a shoulder wound. The assailant fled.

title: Trademark Groups to Meet on Treaty That Cuts Costs
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 A proposed trademark treaty, which may save considerable sums for American companies doing an international business, will be discussed next week. Economies are expected not only in filing fees but in administrative expense for both government and industry.

title: Schoolgirl, 16, Wins Mile As U.S. Beats Russians
DEATH PENALTY BAN AFFIRMED ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP)The California Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its 6to1 decision of Feb. 18 outlawing the death penalty under the state constitution.

title: Books of The Times
description: The ability to invoke a world beyond the immediate settings in the stories in In the Reign of Peace must be a gift, like drawing a certain tone from a violin. It's not something that can be learned. Hugh Nissenson has it. Time and again in these eight tales two worlds, two traditions are at odds rather than two individuals who speak for them. Because the meeting ground for these oppositions is the family, the kibbutz, the closed community, the sounds of battle are muted, the differences revealed in a word, a gesture. These differences are not resolved; they lie too deep in the hone for that. But although the voice of the author is never heard, one side does manage to make his own view clear to the other.

title: Thaler Repeatedly Denies He Knew Treasury Bills He Sold Were Stolen
description: Seymour R. Thaler repeated ly denied under crossexamination in his Federal Court trial here yesterday that he had knowingly sold stolen securities in 1970, when he was a State Senator.

title: CORNELL SIX WINS IN SEMIFINAL, 72
description: BOSTON, March 17 CAP)Dave Westner, a senior from Toronto, scored four goals for Cornell tonight to lead his team to a 72 victory over Denver in a semifinal of the 25th National Collegiate hockey tournament at Boston Garden.

title: MEDIA INVESTMENT A LOSER IN FLORIDA
Delaney and Bonnie Excel at Carnegie
description: Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, Delaney and Bonnie Bramlett proved again that they are one of the most musically entertaining acts in popular music. Accompanied by the usual melange of musiciansalways called Friendsthey jumped and shouted their way through a program of the gospeltinged, bluesbased country music that is their very special forte.

title: SENATE RACE.BEGINS AT SERVICE STATION
description: ALBANY, Ga., March 17 (UPI)Representative Fletcher Thompson, Republican of Georgia, announced his candidacy for the Senate today to startled service station operator.

title: Testimony of Londonderry Priests Challenged at British Inquiry
description: LONDON, March 17A lawyer for the British Army said today that Roman Catholic priests in Londonderry had been blinded by their emotions in accusing paratroopers of indiscriminately killing 13 demonstrators on Jan. 30.

title: Hit Souvenir of VietnamCeramic Elephants
description: SAIGON, South VietnamWhen the American soldiers saw the ceramic elephants of South Vietnam, it was love at first sight.

title: VIDA BLUE DRAWS A YANKEE OFFER
description: MIAMI, March 17Michael Burke, president of the New York Yankees, asserted tonight that he would consider offering as much as $1milmlion for Vida Blue if Charles 0. Finley, owner of the Oakland Athletics, were willing to deal the star lefthanded pitcher who quit baseball yesterday.

title: Suit Over Constitutionality of Budget Is Dropped
description: ALBANY, March 17  Controller Arthur Levitt today dropped a court suit he had brought against Governor Rockefeller challenging the constitutionality of his budget format after Mr. Rockefeller submitted moredetailed budget bills to the Legislature.

title: Will Maoism Survive Mao?; The basic absurdity of Maoism is its dogmatic reliance on the outmoded experience of guerrilla days.
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md.As Mao Tsetung, 77, nears his twilight, the most important question is: Will Maoism long survive the death of its creator? In my opinion, the answer, is no.

title: A Mass Written by Mozart At Age 11 to Be Performed
description: Tile first mass ever composed by Mozart will be performed by the St. Andrew Music Society Chorus and Orchestra at the Madison Avenue Presbytarian Church tomorrow at 4 P.M. It is believed to be the first performance of the work in New York.

title: Candidates'Day
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 17 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey defended today a 20.9 per cent wage and fringe benefit increase for West Coast longshoremen and said it was regrettable the Pay Board had trimmed it.

title: EARL WILD PLAYS ABSORBING CHOPIN
description: No one whose ears are properly connected to his central nervous system can possibly fail to become excited at an Earl Wild recital. The whitehaired pianist gave an allChopin program at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night that often stirred the blood and invariably kept one absorbed by its purring power and brilliance. If you have ever been held rapt by the sound of a finely tuned Ferrari, you know the sensation.

title: U.S. Union Officials On Peace Mission Welcomed in Hanoi
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17  Three American labor leaders were greeted with bouquets today on their arrival to begin a oneweek vi sit whose aim is. in the words of one, to do what we can to see an end to this immoral and senseless war.

title: F. D. A. PROPOSES A CHEMICAL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 The Food and Drug Administration moved today to reduce human exposure to PCB's, a widely used group of industrial chemicals thought by some scientists to rival DDT as a potential health hazard.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)California asked the United States Supreme Court today to stay, pending appeal, enforcement of the California Supreme Court ruling that the death penalty violates the state constitution. In a petition signed by Deputy Attorney General Ronald M. George, the state gave notice of intention to file a formal appeal to the Supreme Court.

title: Merger News
description: Directors of the Kendall Company and the ColgatePalmolive Company agreed yesterday on a plan for Colgate to acquire Kendall, an ethicaldrug, textile and hygienicproducts producer, in, a taxfree transaction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although extortion in your country is a crime, its relative prevalence in large measure due to the victim acting in practical selfinterest instead of on the basis of principle and the public good.

title: JANET STEELE SINGS A PLEASING PROGRAM
description: Janet Steele, a soprano whose clear voice, fine musicianship and stylistic sensitivity have brought her to the attention of New Yorkers as a member of the Western Wind, and as soloist with the Amor Artis Chorale, among other things, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night.

title: North Carolina Is Favored to Defeat Penn in N.C.A.A. East Final Today
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., March 17I think North Carolina will beat Penn. That was the prediction from Jack Kraft, whose Villanova team lost to Penn, 7867, after North Carolina whipped South Carolina, 92.69, in the East Regional semifinals of the NatiOnal Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament last night.

title: Seminarians Plan Protest To Back Harrisburg Seven
description: The twomonthold National Union of Theological Students and Seminarians yesterday designated March 29 as a day of public demonstration in support of the Harrisburg Seven defendants.

title: I'll Be Seeing You Again, I Hope; Whoever invented the myth that America is a melting pot?
description: Though I've lived more than half my life in the States, am an American citizen (which I expect to remain), have acquired a short a and that wonderful verb gotten and have learned to say aside from instead of apart from. I cannot, of course, call myself an American. do, however, think of myself as a New Yorker and believe that I shall continue to think so, even in Oxford.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Many drastic changes have taken place in this country in the last ten years, but nothing is more devastating than the rise of drug addiction. Feeble attempts have been made by various legislative bodies to see that money is appropriated for research, therapeutic communities and methadone programs but, as you know, bills have been defeated and the monies that were funded were minimal.

title: KAUFMAN QUITS RACE IN ELECTION AT AMEX
description: Joseph L. Kaufman, president of Cohn, Delaire & Kaufman, Inc., has withdrawn his name from a threeway race for the vice chairmanship of the American Stock Exchange, the Amex said yesterday.

title: Goodby, Faithful Detroit Product
description: DETROITI, as so many of my colleagues, used to consider the automobile a necessity as well as a luxury. Now, I regard it as an abomination which, with some willpower, we can all do without.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A Feb. 10 news story reports that advisers to the City of New York and its Mayor have urged that the amount of amphetamines produced in the United States be reduced. As a member of the advisory committee I should like to register a minority report.

title: South African President Is Welcomed in Malawi
description: BLANTYRE, Malawi, March 17 (Reuters)President J. J. Fouche arrived by air today for the first visit by a South African head of state to an independent black African country.

title: Nixon Due Monday to View DrugAbuse Center in City
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)President Nixon will fly, to New York Monday to look over activities of the first of nine regional centers of the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement he created in January.

title: Danish Furrier Broadens Scope
description: Conservationists, reluctant consumers and young women determined to look classlessly poor threw the fur industry into the slough of despond last year. But in the same period, Finn Birger Christensen, a thirdgeneration Danish furrier, cheerfully became a multinational entrepreneur.

title: Rule Shifts to Be Made Public
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (Reuters)The S.E.C. said today that it had agreed to a Congressional proposal to make public proposed rule changes made by stock exchanges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent suicide of the black assistant principal at an integrated high school in Flint, Mich., should alert us to the grave dilemma of the black official trapped in the crossfire between assertive black students and white students and faculty. There is significant psychological conflict found among black administrators caught in this maninthemiddle predicament in both our business and educational institutions.

title: Soviet Backs Indian Subcontinent Talks
description: MOSCOW, March 17Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union voiced confidence today that if talks between Pakistan, India and Bangladesh were held they would lead to stable peace on the Indian subcontinent.

title: Russification on Baltic
description: Minority nationalism has been growing in the Soviet Union, as elsewhere. The demands of Soviet Jews for permission to emigrate to Israel, the complaints Ukrainian intellectuals about the slighting of the Ukrainian language and culture and the littleconcealed dislike Georgians feel toward Russian domination have been frequently noted. Now the native peoples of the Baltic statesinvoluntarily incorporated into the Soviet Union three decades agoare apparently worrying Moscow by their resistance to Russification, particularly to the influx of Russians and other Slays who form an everincreasing proportion of the population in the three Baltic states.

title: U.N. Ending Taiwan Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17The United Nations will end Its technical assistance to Taiwan within three months and recall the last of 26 experts working there.

title: Price Changes
description: The number of zinc producers that have turned their backs on the zinc market increased yesterday.

title: Officer's Wife Charged In British Spy Case
description: PORTSMOUTH, England, March 17 (UPI)Mrs. Maureen Bingham, who had said publicly that she nagged her husband into spying for the Russians, was charged today with violating Birtain's Official Secrets Act.

title: Candidates'
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 17Gov. George C. Wallace arrived here today hoping to capitalize on the fact that the busing issue will be on Texas primary ballots May 8 and a new Democratic state party convention rule calls for selecting delegates by Presidential preferences.

title: WORLD CUP LEAD TAKEN BY AUGERT
H. DUDLEY BIERAU, INSURANCE AIDE, 77
description: H. Dudley Stem, an Insurance specialist and former member of President Kennedy's Committee on Safety, died Wednesday in Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 77 yeara.old and resided at 1713 Dorwaldt Parkway, Schenectady.

title: A Minister Is Seized in 5 Connecticut Stranglings
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 17  A white clerk in the Darien Post Office  who bad ordenied himself a minister and who gave street corner sermons  was arrested today and charged with strangling five black women here over a fouryear period.

title: GRAYSON ASSAILS BUTZ FOR HAILING FARM PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The chairman of the Price Commission, C. Jackson Grayson Jr., sharply assailed today, as damaging to the entire economic stabilization program, statements by Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz praising higher farm prices.

title: Soviet Embassy Won't Press Charges in BloodThrowing
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The Soviet Embassy has decided not to press charges against a 17yearold girl, member of the Jewish Defense League, who splashed a cup of blood on one of the embassy's officials this week, the State Department said today.

title: Pope Links Violence To Ulster Stalemates
description: ROME, March 17Pope Paul VI deplored the stalemate and violence in Ulster in a St. Patrick's Day message published by the Vatican today.

title: INDIA OPENS WAY FOR DACCA TRIALS
description: DACCA,Bangladesh, March 17  The Indian Government said tonight that all Pakistani military prisoners against whom Bangladesh presents prima fade cases of atrocities and similar crimes would be turned over to the Bangladesh Government for warcrimes trials.

title: NEW YORKER HELD MONTH BY POLES
description: WARSAW, March 17A 24yearold student from New York has been held by the Polish authorities for a month, as part of an investigation into the smuggling of synthetic diamonds, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: State Rates Brooklyn Last in Phone Service
description: ALBANY, March 17 Brooklyn continued to rank last in the state in receiving quality telephone service, according to an analysis by the Public Service Commission of telephone service in 24 areas of the state.

title: Two Guilty on Jail Weapons
description: Two inmates at the Bikers Island Adolescent Remand Shelter pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to having makeshift weapons in their possession. The two, Angel Cabrera, 17, of 115 Simpson Street, the Bronx, and Fred Civers, 18, of 2119 Eighth Avenue, Manhattan, were among seven inmates charged with promoting prison contraband.. A search of cells and prisoners Feb. 10 turned up 300 such weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For the past three weeks I have searched in vain for an editorial comment by The Times on the city's proposals to institute a limited heroin maintenance program. The city's two other dailies have discussed the positive and negative aspects of the proposal while The Times has only treated the matter peripherally. The heroin maintenance proposals are highly cone troversial and deserve a chance as potential crime if not addiction deterrent.

title: Air Force Plans Cutback Of Its Planes on Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, March 17High Administration officials said today that after President Nixon's return from China, the White House directed the Air Force to plan the gradual withdrawal of a substantial part of its forces on Taiwan over the next year or two.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS DISCLOSES A LOAN
description: DETROIT, March 17 The American Motors Corporation borrowed 50 million Swiss francs, about 613million, for five years on March 1, according to a prospectus linked to the Kaiser Industries Corporation's sale of $5.5million A.M.C. shares. The interest rate is 6.5 per cent a year and the loan is repayable in Swiss francs. American Motors also is In the process of borrowing $6million from a realestate investment trust at 9.5 per cent interest per year repayable over 20 years. The company plans to set up dealer facilities with the proceeds from the $6million loan and from borrowing secured by mortgages on the new facilities.

title: Sports of The Times
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17Near the low woodpaneled office and locker rooms of the Holiday Park Tennis Center, three palm trees swayed like lazy sentries. In the glow of the late afternoon sun, youngsters and adults filled 18 municipal courts while others waited. On the wirefenced court where Jim Evert gives lessons, supermarket cart held about 40 balls. Another 40 were strewn around the greenish clay court and the club pro stroked forehands from the baseline with his I7yearold daughter. Every so often the teenage girl with the sunstreaked pony tail reprimanded herself.

title: Ecological Aim Taken at Jersey Mosquito
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 17 The problem of how to reduce the number of mosquitoes in New Jersey without damaging the environment has become a matter of urgency and is being given prime consideration by the hundreds of people involved in the state's mosquito control programs.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Stay Transfer of Boston TV Station
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)The Supreme Court declined today to delay a switch in ownership of Boston's Channel 5, a ruling that could lead to the end of the HeraldTraveler newspaper.

title: Law Panel on Flood Named
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 17 (AP)Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. announced today the appointment of a threemember panel of lawyers to examine how the law can best help and relieve residents of the flooddevastated Buffalo Creek hollow in Logan County. Those named to the panel were Forest J. Bowman, Ralph C. Dusci Jr. and Fred Davi.

title: WALLACE PRINTZ
description: WILTON, Conn., March 17 Wallace Printz, president of the Clifton Coat and Apron Supply Company of Brooklyn, New York, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at Grey Rocks Road here.

title: Jackson Picks Stratton To Lead Drive in State
Attica Inmates Elect Committee To Meet Officials on Grievances
description: ATTICA, N.Y., March 17Inmates at the state's maximumsecurity prison here selected 28 of their fellow prisoners today to present recommendations and grievances to, prison administrators in what was described as an exercise of the convicts civic responsibilities.

title: MARGUERITE D. DANA
description: NORFOLK, Conn., March 17 Mrs. Marguerite D. Dana, concert singer in the United States and Canada, died Thursday in the Good Samaritan Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 80 years old and lived here and in Palm Beach.

title: Case Against Harlem 4 Said to Be Based on Lie
description: The major thrust of the Manhattan District Attorney's case against four men held eight years without bail on charges of murdering a Harlem shopkeeper was described as untrue in a defense motion filed here yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: $1 Billion Soviet Program To Combat River Pollution
description: MOSCOW, March 17The Soviet leadership, evidently concerned over growing pollution of the nation's waters, today unveiled a billiondollar pollutioncontrol program expected to affect a third of the population.

title: Economic Advisers Named By Commerce Department
Busing Foes Map Drive
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)A national coalition of busing foes claiming 1.6 million members announced today that it would shift emphasis from lobbying for a constitutional amendment to seeking the election defeat of 25 big busers of America in Congress. Dr. Mitchell Young, a Texarkana, Tex., surgeon and president of the Unified Concerned citizens of America, said the group's list was obtained through study of House and Senate debates, votes on busing legislation and interviews with probusing members of Congress.

title: Galella Testifies Strangers Helped On Rare Occasions
description: Ronald E. Galena, a freelance photographer, testified In Federal District Court here yesterday that on rare occasions he had given his camera equipment to strangers to take pictures for him.

title: Party for Mrs. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Mach 17 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon celebrated her 60th birthday with a family gathering at the White House tonight. President Nixon and their two daughters were present, as was Mrs. Helene Drown of Rolling Hills, Calif., a close friend of Mrs. Nixon.

title: PACT VOTE IN BONN AWAITED TENSELY
description: WARSAW, March 17  The possibility that the West German Parliament will fail to ratify nonaggression treaties with Warsaw and Moscow this spring is creating a climate of apprehension throughout Eastern Europe.

title: Journey to Moscow
description: The, official announcement that President Nixon will visit Moscow in May ends speculation that the Moscow visit might be aborted either because of Soviet suspicions born of the Nixon trip to Peking or the complications attendant on ratification of West Germany's treaties with Moscow and Warsaw.

title: Jurors Queried for Chaplain's Trial
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 17The examination of prospective jurors continued today in the military trial of Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, who is believed to be the first chaplain in the 197year history of the Navy to face a general courtmartial.

title: New S.E.C. Move on Institutions Seen
description: The issue of who should be permitted to buy seats on the nation's stock exchanges probably will hive to be decided in a formal, quasijudicial proceeding by the Securities and Exchange Commission:

title: Citizens Rally to Protect Historic Bamberg
description: BAMBERG, West Germany, March 1A most peculiar intelligence operation is under way in this thousandyearold town, manned by citizen volunteers equipped with cameras and binoculars. Their declared mission: Save Bamberg.

title: Ernst Wolff, 70, Partner In MetalImporting Firm
description: Ernst Wolff, a partner in Winter, Wolff & Co., an import firm specializing in steel and nonferrous metals, died here Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Atlantic Highlands Building Is Stalled
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDSEfforts of a local developer to clear obstacles from the path of a proposed pair of highrise luxury apartment buildings on a bluff 265 feet above Sandy Hook Bay have run into opposition from a combination of environmentalists and municipal real estate tax champions.

title: Bullins: Not the Play I Wrote
description: I GREW up in the jungle, says playwright Ed Bullins with a cynical smile, referring to his childhood in a section of North Philadelphia given that nickname by its own inhabitants. That was during the years from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Dwight D. Eisenhower. Bullins will tell you when he was born  July, 1935  but, as far as his personal life is concerned,. very little else.

title: Mills to Receive Award
description: LITTLE BOCK, Ark., March 18 (AP)Reprasentative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, has been named the 1972 recipient of the National Brotherhood Award of the Arkansas branch of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. The award will be presenter at a dinner April 20.

title: An elegant Easter pie
description: Spinach and cheese pie, or torte di spinaci, is a favorite choice for springtime picnics on the Italian Riviera. It is delicious warm coldcxn.d it seems even more so when accompanied by a bottle of Bardolino, the dry red wine of the region. The pie on this page is an adaptation of the traditional regional Easter pie, lona Pasqualina. The important difference is the addition of smoked pork.

title: More Civil Service Posts Open to British Women
description: LONDON, March 18 (Reuters)Women Civil Servants In Britain have won a better chance to get top postssuch as the governorship of the Tower of London.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Jerre Mangione's They May Just Be the Greatest Guidebooks Ever Published (Travel section, March 5), which described the production of the American Guide Series by the Federal Writers Project, a New Deal agency, in the 1930 s was discerning and timely. As a producer of numerous centennials and historic commemorations, I have found that the series remains, after a generation, the most comprehensive reference on our states and cities. With the United States Bicentennial approaching, it would be a valuable permanent contribution to the nation if each state and city were to update these works, including those volumes now out of nrint'Perhaps this could be done with the financial aid of the Federal Bicentennial Commission, which has stated its determination to endorse projects of residual value.

title: SO HOW COME?
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: STATE WARNS CITY ON DELAYS IN PLAN FOR WORK RELIEF
Criminals At Large
description: Rabbi David Small is back, in the fourth of Harry Kemelman's books devoted to the smart Jewish head of a Massachusetts congregation. Previously the rabbi had been occupied on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Now, in MONDAY THE RABBI TOOK OFF (Putnam's, $5.95), the rabbi is on holiday in Jerusalem.

title: Bilingual School Lowers Language Hurdles
description: UNION CITYSome of the tots in the kindergarten class at Roosevelt Public School may one day want to go to college and become physicists or city planners, rather than preordained failures. Thanks to a Federal grant and a drastic change in teaching methods, such aspirations no longer seem unfeasibleeven for a child who enters school knowing not a word of English.

title: Fight Far From Over, Dismissed Ridgewood Elk Asserts
description: RIDGEWOOD  The recent dismissal of Richard J. Zelenka from the Elks has not daunted the past exalted ruler; in fact Mr. Menke says the fight is far from over.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGO We're going to shake their eyeteeth out, George Corley Wallace liked to tell his rallies on the sultry evenings that led up to the Florida primary last week. We're going to send them a message, those national Democrats.

title: Black Radio Network Set To Start Within 3 Months
description: The first blackowned, blackoperated and blackoriented tional radio network is scheduled to go on the air within three months, according three black executives who have recently obtained the $1.5million financing they ,need for the venture.

title: Radio Implant Helps Paralytic Breathe,
description: A 38yearold electrician, who was totally paralyzed in a racing car accident that left him unable to breathe without a mechanical respirator, now is able to get around in a wheelchair because he carries small pocket radio transmitter to stimulate the nerves that Control his breathing.

title: Side Bets Part of Action When Reisman Performs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I, March 18 It was 12:15 in the morning and on paper it was a simple match22yearold Peter Pradit, the highly ranked Thai, against Marty Reisman of New York, 42. The winner would advance to the round of 16.

title: 5 Seized in Raid on Hells Angels Club
description: A police raid on the East Village headquarters of the Hell's Angels Motorcycle Club yesterday resulted in five arrests and the seizure of guns, knives and explosive devices.

title: Armed Forces School Seeks to Cut Racial Tension
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 4The Department of Defense is operating a school in an old wooden post office building at Patrick Air Force Base that some military men believe can be as important to the future of the armed services as West Point, Annapolis or the Air Force Academy.

title: Satellites:
description: For years now, Government and industry have been dreaming an impossible dream: a system of communications satellites in permanent orbit over the linked States, providing vastly improved television, telephone and data transmitting service to the entire nation. Last week, the dream seemed a lot closer to reality. The Federal.Communications Commission made public recommendations by its staff to allow several private companies to get into the communications satellite business either individually or in concert with other firms. It set May 1 as the date for the beginning of hearings on the, report.

title: Jewish Surgeon Charges Bias In Tax Indictment in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, March 18Dr. Maurice L. Silver's 10year battle against what he calls religious discrimination by Honolulu's major hospitals will take a new turn next week when he is arraigned in Federal District Court on income tax charges.

title: Theater: Shaw's Captain Brassbound
description: WASHINGTON  It has long been apparent that New York was no more the beall and endall of the American theater, and Indeed this year, I understand, for the first time there are more Equity actors working outside New York than inside.

title: LOUDON WAINWRIGHT HAS AWAY TO GO YET
description: Last year's revival of interest in folk musicbased performers propelled a number of new artists to prominence. Among those who sounded like sure bets for stardom. was a modest, extremely gifted guitaristsongwriter named Loudon Wainwright 3d, who is performing at the Gaslight at the Go Go this week.

title: Two Brothers Shot After Fleeing Site Of Rape Attempt
description: Two plumbers who are brothers were shot, one of them critically, by an offduty patrolman who had chased them four blocks on foot early yesterday after they allegedly tried to rape a barmaid changing clothes in the basement of a bar in lower Manhattan where they were fixing a toilet.

title: Was the king in Camelot in fact a cold warrior?; Cold War and CounterRevolution; The Foreign Policy Of F.Kennedy.; By Richard J. Walton.; 250 pp.New York: Viking Press.; $7.95.; The Kennedy Doctrine; By Louise FitzSimons.; 275 pp. New York:Random House.; $7.95.
description: To the tune of Home, home on the range, President Nixon maneuvered his chopsticks to lift a water chestnut to his mouth, encouraged by his host, Chou Enlai, who smilingly raised his glass in honor of two birthdays: Tricia Nixon's and the President's most illustrious predecessor, George Washington's, the man who warned his countrymen to avoid foreign entanglements.

title: Miss D'Apice Fiancee Of Bohn C. Vergari
description: YONKERS, March 18Mr. and Mrs. John D'Apice, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Edith D'Apice, to Bohn Carl Vergari. He is the son of Carl Verger, District Attorney of Westchester County, and Mrs. Verger'. Both families reside in Yonkers.

title: Strawberries By the Quart
description: ROBERT GREIG of Red Hook, N.Y., the largest commercial grower of strawberries in Dutchess Courtty, has some words of advice for the novice home berrygrower:

title: Cahill Aides Hail Tax Poll Results
Ambulance Responds to Call of 108 and a Life May Hang in the Balance
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.The alarm telephone did not sound its harsh, jarring summons until nearly 10 o'clock. Meanwhile the 7 to 11 P.M. ambulance crew and Jean Anderson, serving as dispatcher, had been passing the time reading, chatting and taking turns at amiable and not excessively expert games of pool.

title: Systems Analyst Weds Mary Dwyer
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 18Miss Mary Ellen Dwyer, daughter of Dr. and Mr. Gregory Kennedy Dwyer, was married here this afternoon to Francis Hopkinson Van Deventer Jr., son of Mr. Van Deventer and Mrs. David Henkel, both of Greenwich. The Venerable Grant A. Morrill performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: Passaic County Census Counts an Influx of Blacks in Decade
description: Passaic is one of those closein counties on the edge of New York City that have had a substantial spurt of black migrants into the area during the last decade and a net outward migration of whites.

title: HEAD OF NEWSPAPER SENTENCED IN PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, March 18 (AP) The new director of the Lima newspaper La Pram, Pedro Beltran Bellen, has received a suspended sixmonth jail sentence for violating Peru's controversial press statute.

title: Reform Jews Find Busing Issue Used For Inciting Fear
description: Washington, March 18Lay and spiritual leaders of American Reform Judaism criticized political figures today for inciting fear in the American public by manipulating the issue of busing for political advantage.

title: Pro, Golf's Strugglers Seeking A Way Out 0f Their Straggling
description: Will frustrating Mondays be banished from the pro golf tour?

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:MY most fervent appreciation and congratulations to David W. Rintels for his powerful, clear and wellaimed statement on political censorship of TV fare (How Much Truth Does The FBI Tell About the FBI?), and to you for featuring it in the way you did. This is a courageous public service,

title: The World
description: The greeting was proper if restrained as Soviet Premier Aleksei Kosygin walcorned President Zulfikar All Bhutto of. Pakistan to Moscow last week. Mr. Bhutto was making the trip in an apparent effort, to mend political and economic relations impaired by the Soviet Union's advocacy of independence for Bangladesh, the former East Pakistan. He was reported to be anxious to have the Soviets renew an aid program frozen during the IndoPakistan conflict over Bangladesh last December.

title: Las Vegas ReMains in Lead In Golden Gloves Tourney
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 18 (UPI)  Las Vegas continued to hold a 2point lead hi the national Golden Gloves tournament today after half of the quarterfinal matches were completed.

title: The Easter Shopping Spree
description: Yesterday, there was quite a crowd on the fifth floor of Maison Blanche, the big New Orleans department store. Children in a wide range of ages were trying on shoes, the older ones soberly contemplating new styles, the younger ones finding an opportunity to squirm out of reach and dash across the floor.

title: Vatican Plans to Exhibit Bibles and Manuscripts
description: ROME, March 18 (AP)The Vatican has announced that it is organizing an exhibition of manuscripts and Bibles.

title: Architecture
description: I HARDLY know where to begin. Perhaps the best place is where I left off in New Englandwhere the driveIns are driving out so much of the American scene and heritage. The quantities of mail that come to this office from the heart, in every sense, of the country, about what is happening to the landmarks and amenities of our cities and towns deserve to be shared. So back to Vermont, for a start.

title: KENNETH N. WIRE, EXN.Y.U, DEAN, 68
description: Prof. Kenneth N. McKee, who retired last year as associate dean of the Washington Square. College of Arts and Science of New York University and professor of French, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 15 West, 11th Street.

title: Science;Math Models:;Wise Up! That Computer Is Just a Giant Moron
description: The average layman Is awed by the computer and its accomplishments. But as these machines are increasingly used to analyze and forecast major social and economic issues, there is a danger that he may fail to understand that they are merely giant moron  calculating machines that simply add and subtract very rapidly. The hot that a policy has been decided upon with the help of computers doesn't make it necessarily correct, merely harder for the ordinary citizen to judge.

title: FALSE PREMISE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Fine Madison Roses Losing Outto Imports
description: MADISONIf you live in New Jersey and buy roses locally, you can count on the freshest flowers in the East. But the question is just how much longer you can count on them.

title: Hey! Who Pinched My Libretto?
description: ON Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera, Verdi's Otello will go into the history books as the very last new production in the 22year reign of general manager Rudolf Bing, and also as the very first Italian opera conducted in New York by Karl Boehm. But the man who will dominate the actual experience of the audience will be Franco Zeffirelli, who designed the enormous sets and directed the staging.

title: Do We Need a New may to Play the Classics?
description: TWENTY years ago Debussy used to be played in a misty style well suited to the wonderful tonecontrol of Walter Gieseking, with the rhythmic contours slightly blurred under a delicate wash of pedal. Today, pianists and many conductors like a different Debussy, with the rhythmic skeleton in greater evidence so that the subtle interlocking movement from one rhythm to another becomes clear.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: I'm amazed by the omission of J. F. Powersthe king and master of them allfrom Garry Wills's essay on AmericanCatholic novelists. (Jan. 16).

title: Movie Mailbag; SIMPLY CHEAP
description: To THE EDITOR:It was because of his otherwise cleareyed observations on Cabaret that was surprised Farber did not see through the obviousness of the singing of Tomorrow Belongs to Me. A pullback or a cut would have boon sufficient to establish the irony of the singer's being a Hitler youth. But.the director chooses instead to pan, in closeup, from the boy's face to his arm band so that the swastika fills the screen and one waits for a cue card instructing the oak

title: MEDIOCRITY
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Democrats Still Uncommitted Wyoming Presidential Race
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., March 14 The Wyoming Democratic party, still split between 1968 supporters of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Fenner Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, both of Minnesota, remains uncommitted to any national Presidential candidate after two weeks of sometines stormy county conventions.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: An author who writes to complain about a book review obviously starts off with two strikes against him, but in fairness to you as well as to myself I cannot remain silent. Your review of The Young Die Quietly (Feb. 13) argues with the book in a fairly patronizing way on the basis of the author's suggestion that the logical response to the spread of narcotics is stiffer penalties.

title: Corona Pressing Final Offensive To Save Homes
Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:IN his review of Cabaret, Stephen Farber criticizes the film for implying a simple causal relationship between decadence and totalitarianism.

title: Princeton CoEds Form Crew for Intercollegiate Races
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PENN CENTRAL said it would dismiss 6,000 of its 18,000 conductors and brakemen starting April 1 to save $97.5million a year. Union spokesman promised to retaliate.

title: A Selective Killer to Be Used On Gypsy Moths in Connecticut
description: When Connecticut opens. its annual battle with. the gypsy Moth this spring, it will be usfrig a biological Weapon called Bacillus thuringiensis, or B. T. for short.

title: Letters,ACCESS TO FEMALES
description: To THE EDITOR: Fooey on Erich Fromm. In his article, The Erich Fromm Theory of Aggression (Feb. 27), he described man's vital interests as life, food, access to females, etc. Females, indeed. Either the author, a psychoanalyst, is insufficiently sensitive to his own unconscious slips, or his character retains more male chauvinism than he wot.

title: VERMONT APLANT MY START SOON
description: BRATILEBORO, Vt., March 18  Vermont's first nuclear power plant could go into operation on a testing basis as early as next weekend unless a major national conservation group obtains an injunction.

title: RunThrough A Memoir. By John Houseman. 507 pp. New York: Simon &
description: John Houseman's RunThrough is such an entertaining book that it could be read, more or less shamelessly, for the backstage gossip alone. A drama critic venturing to Harlem for the opening of the Federal Theater's Negro Macbeth and asking to be seated, if possible, not next to Negroes. Another drama critic done to death by voodoo. A fire marshal putting a match to a strip of the cellophane cyclorama for Four Saints in Three Acts and nearly halting, before a note of It had been heard, one of the century's most exhilarating evenings in the theater. Orson Welles furiously berating his fellow actors for being fearful of open Araps in the stage floor and promptly plunging through one to the concrete 15 feet below. Orson Welles taking such fanatical pains to get the sound effects for a radio show right that he required two tif the actors in The Count of Monte Cristo to lie at the base of a toilet seat in the men's room to achieve the right subterranean reverberation, while a second microphone, placed inside a toilet bowl at the other end of the building and constantly flushed, gave a faithful rendering of the waves breaking

title: Paris Maoist Unit Threatens To Blow Up Soviet Airliners
description: PARIS, March 18 (UPI)The police said today that a Maoist radical group that kidnapped Renault automobile executive last week had threatened to blow up Soviet Aeroflot jetliners unless the airline paid a ransom of two million Swiss francs, about $525,000.

title: Women Stars Match FiguresWith Fashions
description: New uniforms have solved the problem for United States sailors, but our women golfers are still at sea because designers don't put pockets in their golf clothes.

title: A DEATH PENALTY IS PETITION'S AIM
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 18A campaign to gather more than half a million signatures for a constitutional amendment to restore the death penalty in California officially began this week.

title: Ceylonese to Be Registered
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 18Adults in Ceylon will be registered and issued identification cards to help stamp out illegal immigration, particularly from South India, the Govern. ment announced.

title: F.C.C. to Grant Licenses To Parolees Upon Release
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission says it has granted a request by the Bureau of Prisons that qualified parolees be allowed to obtain commercial radio licenses immediately upon their release.

title: Special Units Halt Sinking of Shanghai;
description: HONG KONG, March 18By injecting water into layers of underground soil, workers and geologists have saved Shanghai China's largest city, from slowly sinking into the mud flat on which it is built.

title: OKKER AND ASHE GAIN TENNIS FINAL
description: CHICAGO, March 18 (UPI)Tom Okker of the Netherlands upset Ken Rosewall, 62, 6.3, to gain the final of, the 650,000 Kemper tennis tourney for contract pros today. It was Okker's first victory over the 37yearold Australian since 1968.

title: Sunset Park to Be Cleaned Up
description: Sunset Park, a grassy, windswept knoll commanding what may be Brooklyn's best view of New York Harbor, is to be spruced up this spring, the Borough President's office has announced.

title: The Mountain Of Truth; By Dale Carlson. Illustrated by Charles Robinson. 169 pp. New York: Atheneum. $5.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: Anyone who sets out to write teenage novel that deals, from title to closing paragraph, with a search for Truth must have a great respect for the young. Both in broaching the spiritual mysteries of the Far East and in her mature literary style, the author here is expecting a great deal from her junior audience. One needs an element of youthful innocence to believe in itthe story of a group of bored, uppermiddle class kids transformed from idlers into mystics.

title: Child to the Mecklers
description: WESTON, Conn., March 18 A daughter was born March 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Alan Marshall Meekler in the Stamford Hospital. Mrs. Mockler is the former Miss Ellen Finkelstein.

title: Complex Is Sought For New England
description: HARTFORD, March 18 (AP) A major statesponsored study proposed this week the creation of a huge industrialtransportation complex on the ConnecticutRhode Island border to spur the sagging regional economy and to compete commercially with Boston and New York.

title: Briton Leaves on Tour
description: LONDON, March 18 (AP)The Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, left today for a threenation tour. He will go first to Teheran, Iran for talks on the situation in the Persian Gulf and then is to go to Pakistan and Israel.

title: Black Delegates Seek More Contacts
description: A survey of participants in the National Black Political Convention has disclosed enthusiasm and a nearuniversal anxiousness to maintain a network or a conduit aimed at keeping the geographically and philosophically diverse black communities in contact with one another.

title: Air Force Gets New Aide In a Shuffle of Generals
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)Gen. Horace M. Wade, chief of staff at Supreme Allied Headquarters in Europe, will become Air Force Vice Chief of Staff.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The prototype of the American Guide Series was the Connecticut Guide, which was published in 1935. Our copy of the book states that it was a project of the State Planning Board, was initiated under the Civil Works Administration and published by the Emergency Relief Commission. In the preface to the Connecticut volume of the American Guide Series, John B. Derby, state director of the Federal Writers Project, acknowledged, We are especially indebted to Mr. Edgar L. Heermance whose Connecticut Guide was our predecessor and inspiration, and who graciously allowed us the use of his files containing valuable field notes and historical information. All of these guidebooksare indeed valuable, and Government funds have often been less wisely spent.

title: SOLAR SALUTE WINS SANTA ANITA RACE
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 18 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr. kept Solar Salute in front nearly wire to wire for the bay colt's sixth consecutive triumph, edging Quack by threequarters of a length today in the $68,800 San Felipe Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: Prostitute's Talk Disputed
description: CRANSTON R.I. March 18 (UPI)The school board has reprimanded three teachers for allowing a prostitute to speak to a group of seniors involved in a special class at Cranston High School West. Several students protested the official reaction.

title: Merckx Wins Bicycle, Race
description: SAN REMO, Italy, March 18 (AP)Eddy Merelot of Belglum won the 170mile MilanSan Remo bicycle race today, averaging about 27 miles an hour.

title: Hotchltisses Have a Son
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., March 18  A son was born on Jan. 28 in the Stamford Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Warner Hotchkiss 3d.

title: Big Powers Asked To Give Debt Relief To Poor Nations
description: GENEVA, March 18  A United Nations Agency has called on the industrial powers to lighten the debt burden of the poorer countries before they face the danger of having to default on their loans.

title: Ban Eased for Passover
description: PARIS, March 18 (Reuters) A ban on packages to prisoners in French jails, imposed as a result of smuggling of drUgs and weapons, has been partially lifted for Jewish detainees. They will be able to receive kosher foods during Passover.

title: Horse Show News
description: The United States Equestrian Team's threeday squad the silver medal winner in both the 1984 and 1968 Olympic Gameswill leave for Europe and five months of training and competition on March 29.

title: PLASTIC IS FOUND IN SARGASSO SEA
description: Countless small bits of floating plastic, apparently the refuse of industrial society, have been found drifting over wide areas of a region of the Atlantic Ocean called the Sargasso Sea.

title: 2 CHILEAN PARTIES TAKE A HARD LINE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March lb The Communist and Socialist parties have publicly assumed a hard line that comes close to advocating violence against the antiMarxist opposition and severe discipline against op: portunists within the governing leftwing coalition.

title: Floods Strike Philippines
description: MANILA, March 18 (AP)Thousands of people are homeless and millions of dollars worth of crops and livestock have been destroyed by heavy floods in the southern provinces of Davao and Bukidnon, Red Cross volunteers reported today.

title: Saudi Paper Backs Hussein
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18 The first Arab support for King Hussein's federation proposal came today from the Saudi Arabian newspaper Al Medina Al Munwara, which in an editorial condemned as demogogic Arab attracks against the king.

title: AROUND THE  GARDEN
description: The lawn is still quite soggy, stay off if you can and postpone raking and cleanup.... mail soil for testing.... last call for dormant spraying to control scale... sow vegetables indoors: eggplant, peppers, broccoli, early tomatoes.... spray elms to control elm bark beetle with methoxychlor. repair fences and gates.... check out the tool shed; repair and replace where necessary... keep mulches on; push back heaved perennials.

title: Union Sues for Sick Pay For Women Having Baby
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)A union has filed what it says is the first lawsuit seeking to win sick pay for women temporarily off the job to have a baby.

title: Campbell Captures Crown In MatchRace Sail Series
description: LONG BEACH, Calif, March 18 (UPI)Argyle Campbell, 23yearold University of Southern California graduate student, posted three victories today and won the Congressional Cup match race yachting series for the second time in three years.

title: 2 Jersey Democrats Received Biggest Labor Fund Gifts in 70
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and Representative Frank Thomson Jr., both liberal New Jersey Democrats, received larger campaign contributions from organized labor than any other Congressional candidates in the 1970 elections, a survey of political spending by special interest groups disclosed today.

title: Tree Blights, Wilts And Diebacks
description: THE word blight means many things to many people. To some it means the billboards along an otherwise scenic highway, or possibly the graveyards of junk cars dotting the countryside. To others of us concerned with plants it means a pathogenic disease often capable of causing great economic losses.

title: Miss Drake Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Drake of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Samantha Ann Drake, to Martin Barry Rapp, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. William Rapp of New Rochelle, N. Y. The marriage will take place on April 16.

title: The World
description: BRASILIAAt the peak of a fourday state visit to Brazil last week, Lieut. Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, the President of Argentina, was 20 minutes Ute without apparent reason for his only working meeting with Gen. Emilio G. Medici, the President of Brazil. So General Medici was 40 minutes late in arriving at General Lanusse's state banquet that night.

title: Why LILCO Is Gettin. at Worried
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The electric power crisis is now tentatively snaking out from New York City to Long Island.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: If we're not careful, someone's going to give advertising a good name.

title: Meany Calls Special Parley of Unions
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., has called a special meeting of the federation's Executive Council to decide what action organized labor should take in the wake of the Pay Board's decision to reduce the West Coast longshore contract.

title: Columbia Plans 6Year Course For Completion of Law Degree
description: Michael I. Severn, dean of the Columbia Law School, announced yesterday an experiment to reduce to six years the time needed to complete college prelawstudies and law school.

title: 1962 Dispute Still Persists on Tenafly High Rise Plan
description: TENAFLYIn the spring of 1962, Norman Blankman, a New York land developer, purchased 274 acres of undeveloped property in the East Hill section of this town, a wealthy community of 15,000 people.

title: Brooklyn Median Rent
description: Looking for a lowrent apartment? Something like four rooms and under $100 a month? Then Brooklyn is the place.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: In planning an Easter vacation for my two young sons and myself I wrote to various Chambers of Commerce in Florida, Puerto Rico and the lower Caribbean. I received brochures of what has come to be known as firstclass hotels and motels, to me a synonym for concrete boxes with TV in every room; decor in pseudoPolynesian style, cocktail lounges and coffee shops. This is not what I had in mind when I decided to get away from it all, but it seems impossible to convince any Chamber of Commerce that the inquirer is not the typical American tourist looking for a replica of the home he has left behind. The resort people should have a list for oddballs like us, listing small guesthouses where the traveler can get a tasteful room at moderate cost. Until someone comes up with one, guess it's back to our simple Fire Island house for us over the holiday.

title: SO Little Is Left at Wounded Knee
description: GORDON, Neb., March 7 [AP]A band of Indians [from the Pine Ridge, S. D., reservation]... are demanding that a Federal grand jury be summoned to investigate... the death of Mr. Raymond Yellow Thunder.... The Indians contend that Mr. Yellow Thunder was tortured, burned with cigarettes and castrated before he died. Nebraska Indian Commissioner Robert Mackey... has asked for a Federal grand jury investigation of Mr. Yellow ,Thunder's death. Mr. Yellow Thunder, 51 years old, an Oglala Sioux, was found dead in a used lot in Gordon on Feb. 20.

title: General Motors Will Sell JapaneseBuilt Trucks Were
description: TOKYO, March 18General Motors will begin selling pickup trucks built by Isuzu Motors of Japan on the American market next week.

title: Antitrust as Usual
description: Even more disturbing than the still incompletely answered questions about political machinations in the settlement by consent decree of the Justice Department's three antitrust cases against I.T.T. is the illumination the current inquiry has provided on how susceptible improper influence the whole antitrust process is.

title: Carol E. Hume, Teacher, Bride Of W. Richard Bingham, Banker
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18Miss Carol E. Hume and W. Richard Bingham, Son of Wheelock H. Bingham of Southbury, Conn., and Mrs. Evelyn E. Bingham of NOV York, were married here this afternoon in St. Luke's copal Church by the Rev. Spencer M. Rice. The Iletr. Lesley Wilder assisted.

title: They didn't think we meant it
description: In describing the parliamentary activity of Lord North, George Ill's chubby Prime Minister during the Revolution, Michael Pearson comments, He could push bills through adroitly and displayed the resilience of a feather mattress when fending off attack. This book was written by an English professional author with humor vividness and narrative skill.

title: The Young Filmmakers of L.I.
description: As films, they may not end up in the vaults of the Museum of Art, but for the cultists of cultural anthropology, they provide rich pickings, indeed. For as one of my more hirsute students said, pointing at the projection screen in class, Up there is where it's at.

title: Crime and Violence Rise in City Schools
description: The number of reported acts of crime and violence in and around city schools increased from 333 in 1970 to 580 last year, according to Board of Education figures.

title: ARAB BLOC ASSAILS PLAN BY HUSSEIN
description: CAIRO, March 18The Federation of Arab Republics, comprising Egypt, Syria and Libya, today denounced the proposal of King Hussein of Jordan for a federation consisting of the Palestinian West Bank of the Jordan River and the East Bank under his leadership.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S. D., March 19Clive Gildersleve: I can'tbelieve Indians did this Why? I can never replace what they destroyed. But what can I do now but mend what I can and keep the museum going? Nothing will make me close the museum. It means too much.

title: Milan Says Leftist Publisher Died From a Loss of Blood
description: MILAN, Italy, March 18 (Reuters)  Giangiaconio Feltrinelli, the millionaire leftist publisher whose body was found near dynamite at an electricpower tower this week, died of loss of blood, the Milan deputy public prosecutor said tonight.

title: Rangers Down Flyers, 53, With Four Late Goals
BURTON CAPTURES MILLER BOWLING
description: MILWAUKEE, March 18 (AP)Nelsod Burton Jr. of St. Louis won the $80,000 Miller open bowling, tournament today, outscoring Gary Dickinson in the final match, 201191.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: As long as you have traveled as far as Katmandu. Nepal (Travel section, Feb. 6), why not continue and see the country? Take a plane from the capital to Pokhara, and from there take a trek up the valley past the Tibetan refugee camp of. Hianja, spending the night in the hilltop village of Nau Danda. Get up early next morning and see the sun rise on nearby Annapurna and Machhapuchhare, then return to Pokhara along the ridge trail with the mountains in view. You won't find roads, restaurants, hotels or piped water in this part of Nepal; you will, however, find Nepal. Our son took us on this trip when he was in the Peace Corps.

title: A doctor's guide to religious education
description: RELIGION is not unlike sex: those with a healthy attitude can derive a great deal of satisfaction from It while others only become frustrated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Along with all the other woes of New York City, Manhattan housing and rent increases seem to be rapidly approaching the point of no return.

title: Trotsky suffered from presbyopia
description: The French Revolution was the only spontaneous revolution in modern history in the sense that its participants, lacking a model to follow, had to improvise as they went along. Ever since 1789, revolution has become the object of intense study, not only by professional historians, but also and above all by professional revolutionaries, who, like military theorists, analyze the record of past wars in search of guidelines for the next. The histories of 1789, 1848 and the Paris Commune of 1870 have been endlessly dissected in polemical works which became part of the education of every European radical.

title: The Case of the Disappearing Pension
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: From recent press reports it appears that the public may be facing another sudden foodadditive loss patterned after the demise of the cyclamates, but this time dealing with saccharin. To the more than three million diabetics such a loss would be a disaster. To millions of other Amerftans it would be a distressing disruption of their eating habits. To a substantial segment of the food industry it would spell chaos.

title: Eleanor And Franklin Revisited
description: With others of my generation adored Eleanor Rooseveltmore, suppose, than anyone else I have known in public life. In my case it was mostly from a distance; during the late Roosevelt years, I was one of the many young liberals in Washington who regarded her as an exceptionally well placed ally, but my concern was with economics which was not hers. Our acquaintance really began with the founding of A.D.A., and I got to know her well only in the Stevenson campaigns.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What if they gave an election and everybody bothered to come paraphrases a current slogan. In 1970 members of the House of Representatives were elected by less than 45 per cent of the votingage population in the United States. In New York State this figure was leas than 46 per cent. Nationwide, in the last three Presidential elections, the largest percentage of citizens to cast their vote was 64, in 1960. (Statistical Abstract of the U.S., 1971.)

title: Art: Exhibit of Drawings
description: There was a time when drawing in the established hierarchy of the arts occupied a very lowly position. Considered a halfsister to painting and sculpture, it was usually treated as a mere preparatory step to the creation of a canvas or a statue, an insignificant prelude to a more important work.

title: Photographic and Poetic Reflection of Queens in the Thirties Is Revived
description: Ah, Queens! In the late nineteenthirties, a young man named Rudy Burckhardt often wandered over from Manhattan to snap pictures of the city's biggest borough and its twostory houses, empty lots, scrapyards, boulevards, factories, cemeteries and children at play.

title: FOOD TALK
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I.George Jonassen and his wife, Solveig, live in a neat ranch house, a block from the water in this South Shore community. But when they want to do a special kind of shopping, they still head back to the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn where they grew up.

title: Snow Peas and Bok Choy
description: ONE of the continuing joys in exploring the Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Indian and Indonesian cuisines is the seemingly limitless range of ways in which vegetables are so attractively prepared and served  for the eye as well as the palate.

title: Movies
description: DANIELE GUENOT, the heroine of Andre Cayatte's French film To Die of Love did not, in fact, die of love. Nor did her reallife prototype, Gabrielle Russier. In that sense Cayatte is true to Gabrielle Russier's tragedy, as he is in his barebones chronology of the events leading to her suicide.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Miss Edith Larkin Is Fiancee Of James Windsor Hubbell 3d
description: Mrs. Edith G. Larkin of Cos Cob, Conn., and New York and. Frank Y. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Brewster Larkin of Sommerville, Mass., to James Windsor Hubbell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubbell Jr. of Des Moines.

title: Music
description: HAS anyone ever had so much taste as Diaghilev? Stravinsky once asked, It was this taste that made Serge Diaghilev one of the seminal figures in the cultural history of the 20th century Diaghilev, born a hundred years ago today, was not himself a creator; he was not even (Stravinsky said) an intellectual. But he automatically responded to the significant currents of his time, and he had the ability to present the new art to a wide public.

title: With the rosy glow of hell
description: The burning of the dirigible Hindenburg, although it took place 35 years ago, is probably still the best remembered of all air disasters. With fascinating detail, Michael M. Mooney tells of that great Zeppelin's last flight, which ended in its fiery destruction on the landing field at Lakehurst, N. J. His lifelike characterization of its passengers and crew, his indepth description of the craft itself, and his successful recreation of a transAtlantic airship voyage are the work of an artist with words.

title: One Man's Tennis Family
description: SINCE the early nineteensixties, when the movie Where the Boys Are hit the silver screen, Fort Lauderdale has been known mainly as the site of an annual Easter invasion by college students who come in search of sun, surf, suds, and, they hope, sex. But now, this palmy city of 140,000 people and 270 miles of picturesque inland canals has something else going for it  something more wholesome, according to a Chamber of Commerce spokesman.

title: Lundy Is 12 Miles Off England's Coast But Centuries Away in Tradition
description: BIDEFORD, EnglandAnyone with a half million dollars in 1969 could have becomefor all practical purposesa king. Of course, he wouldn't have had many subjects, but he could have issued his own stamps committed almost any crime with impunity and would have owed no taxes'The kingdom? Lundy, a 1,000island in the Bristol Channel, off Bideford on the coast of England's Devonshire.

title: Dance
description: CHINA'S The Red Detachment of Women, and the City Center Jeffrey Ballet may not seem even remotely connected, but at least they show how far classic ballet has traveled around the world. Talk about entrechats across the sea, classic ballet is one of the few art forms that practically every civilized nation has in common. Strangeperhaps it is only when we use words that we start to misunderstand another.

title: European Swim Mark Set
description: BERLIN, March 18 (UPI)Hansje Bunschoten of the Netherlands set a European 800meter women's freestyle swim record of. 9 minutes 16.7 seconds today at a junior meet with East Germany in Dresden, the East German News Agency said.

title: Jenmist Dougal,a Sealyham Terrier,Is Judged Best at Harrisburg Show
In Hartford Insurer, L T. T. Got Control of a Gold Mine
description: Harald S. Geneen, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has a reputation for paying handsomely, for something he wants.

title: Aqueduct Remains Closed As Negotiations Continue
description: Aqueduct remained closed for the second straight Saturday yesterday as the strike by partimutuel clerks at the track reached the end of its second week.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Hounding the Gray Ghost
description: GRAFTON, N. H. Running far ahead of the dogs on two feet of snow and under a bright New Hampshire sky, the Gray Ghost of the Grafton Mils eluded us all afternoon.

title: Why I Hate Birds
description: IREALIZE that most people consider it pure heresy to dislike our little flying friends, and certainly the garden page is the most dangerous place to expose such a despicable attitude. So before I am tarred and appropriately, feathered, I had better hurry to explain.

title: Amid Laughs and Complaints, Master Plan Hearings End
description: Outbursts of community pride, some laughs, but mainly complaints  complaints about the lack of city services in the areas of housing, parks, traffic and sanitation highlighted recent hearings in Brooklyn on the city's proposed master plan.

title: Tear Gas Used on Riders In Massachusetts Prison
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 18 (Reuters);State policemen and prison guards used tear gas today to quell a riot at the Massachusetts State Prison, by about 150 inmates who set fires, smashed windows and broke furniture in the gymnasium, library and, auditorium.

title: Women impossible not to love and impossible to love right
description: When I finished Larry McMurtry's last novel, Moving On, which was an exhaustingly long fiction centered on the rodeo world, I was very much put off by a peculiar laxness in the writing. I read the book in a small cabin in Pine Creek, Mont., during a cold rain and was often disturbed by dairy cattle staring in the window. In the mood and texture of the novel they should have been beef cattle. Then as several months passed I discovered  as with McMurtry's previous work, especially The Last Picture Show  that I could remember at will nearly every incident in the novel, that the whole book was disturbingly back there in my brain with the rest of my sainted fictional heroes whether I be not, that like it or not McMurtry was incapable of even remotely indifferent fiction.

title: Optimistic Frenchmen Are Really Digging It
description: PARIS This message comes to you on the eve of my departure for the brawling Tech and Tet, Pyrenees mountain streams both, cold and fast and Just possibly purveyors of, somebody's sudden fortunelike mine.. The, way the European gold markets have been leapfrogging these days, you can ,forget about California (high taxes) and AlaSka (no lecal wines) and start prospecting for the valuable yellow stuff while in France on your next vacation. Mire's a brand new book on the French market that tells you how to go about it.

title: Dziedzic Paces East Stars To 2142 Wrestling Victory
description: CHATTANOOGA, March 18 (AP)The East squad defeated the West, 21 points 0 12, today, in the sixth annual college AllStar Wrestling Classic at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga. In the 158pound match between Stan Dziedzic of Slippery Rock, and the twotime National champion Carl Adams of Iowa State, Dziedzic won, 3.2, on riding time of 1 minute 2 seconds.

title: Harvard Pastor to Resign
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18 (AP)The Rev. Charles P. Price, pastor of the Memorial Church hi Harvard Yard and Plummer, Professor of Christian Morals at Harvard, will resign this summer, Harvard announced yesterday. He will return to teach at the Protestant Episcopal Theological Seminary in Arlington, Va.

title: The Charisma Campaigns
description: Jack Matthews has a connoisseur's eye for foibles, some of which are treasured in this wonderfully effervescent life of a salesman. Nothing really good happens in The Charisma Campaigns. It is a succession of anticlimax and disappointment which leaves its hero, a usedcar dealer, the victim of a horrendous car crash. What gives the novel its unusual sparkle is the author's inclination to be upbeat about the offbeat. Mr. Matthews presents us with a parade of failures, crazies, ingrates and fools. But he doesn't condemn them; he marvels at them.

title: How to make quilts and slaughter hogs
description: This excellent book is an unabashed chronicle, often in the vernacular of the people, of the trials and pleasures, customs and folkways, tools and crafts, of country living. The book had its beginnings six years ago in the 240pupil Rabun GapNa coochee School in northern Georgia's Appalachians, hard against the North Carolina border, when Eliot Wigginton, fresh from his A.B. and M.A. at Cornell, found that conventional teaching techniques were not reaching his students.

title: Harriet Hoyle ,and Paul F Tuttle to Wed on June
