description: GLENCOE, Ill., March 18Miss Harriet Hulbert Hoyle and Paul Frederick Tuttle will be married. June 3 in Trinity Episcopal Church in Highland Park, by the bride's uncle, tiM Rev. Irwin Hulbert of WaShington.

title: New Hampshire to Get Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)PresIdent Nixon today declared New Hampshire to be a major disaster area, eligible for special Federal aid, because of coastal storms and flooding on Feb. 1820. Governor Walter R. Peterson estimated property damage at $1,271,000.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEEKS EASED NARCOTIC AID
description: ALBANY, March 18Governor Rockefeller said today, that ho would seek legislation changing current formulas, on state aid to localities for narcodes programs. The changes would permit a larger share of the funds to be used for drugpreVention programs.

title: The Nation
description: Scattered through New York's East 60's and 70's are palatial townhouses, apartments and hotels that have become the headquarters of foreign delegations to the United Nations. Central Park has been a kind of grassandtree curtainthrough which foreign diplomats do not pass to the West Side. But last week, the curtain was breachedby the Chinese Communist delegation to the United Nations. After months of househunting, they bought, for $4.85million, the 10story Lincoln Motor Inn on West 66th Street near Broadway and just north of Lincoln Center.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The space program has to be at once the most practical and the most noble item in our Federal budget. Man's thrust into the unknown fires the imagination and bolsters the spirit. Human destiny is historically obvious In its movement toward space exploration and colonization.

title: Nets Beat Colonels, 109108, On Paultz's LastSecond Goal
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 18 A jump shot by Billy Paultz with only 4 seconds to.play gave the New York Nets a 109.108 victory tonight over the Kentucky Colonels at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Bored? Creatively I'm Bored, But...
description: FORTYONE floors above Park Avenue, TV reception was crystal clear. ABC's The Mod Squad was coming in beautifully, and the hotel suite's parlor echoed to the jumpy, herecomestrouble rhythms of the show's theme. On the tuba, series stars Michael Cole, Clarence Williams III and Peggy Lipton were well on their way to exercising their Squadder's rights, which meant getting into modishly hot water with lawbreakers and getting out again in time for the closing commercial.

title: Art
description: RECENT disclosures of American museums longestablished but very quiet practice of selling works of art entrusted to them as public property have brought some very noisy arguments on both sides (the public's and the museums'). In this column it has been argued that an inviolable rule against disposing of objects, once a museum has accepted them  a rule that holds in French national museums and makes the storerooms of the Louvre an unviolated but, alas, invisible treasuryis the only sure protection against irremediable errors of judgment on the part of curators and directors. But next best, or perhaps fug as good, would be protective regulations that would have to be observed, by law, when a museum enters the market place.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIA cartoon in one of the New Delhi newspapers last week showed two campaign workers of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's political party talking to a dubious voter, a poor peasant farmer. Why do you think we will forget our promises? they are asking the peasant Didn't we make the same promises five years ago?

title: Legislative Notes: No Mrs.for Voters
description: TRENTONWhy should woman have to tell whether or not she's married in exchange for her right to vote?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Why the Computer Chose. Cancun by Robert J. Dunphy (Travel section, March 5) reminded Jne of a trip that I took from Merida to Puerto Juarez and Isla Majeres in Mexico in 1966. There Wasn't even a town at the ferry stop on the mainland and not a single paved road on the island. We slept in hammocks at a beach hostel for 80 cents a night. Now the whole areaCancun included is becoming a tourist resort, that breed of nonplace which is exactly the same whether it is in Miami, Mexico, France, Spain or even Yugoslavia. Colorful natives will replace real people, and the proud local inhabitants will become servants, even required to live in a segregated town, away from the tourists who will pay so much money to be in a hygienic, sterile, nonplace, where they need never fear the slightest intrusion of realitynot even a mosquito. Money talks, but I can't help asking, money for whom?. For the. Gevernment; for the Bank of Mexico? And for what? The Yucatecans appear to have been betrayed by their Government.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Lest your readers be slightly misled, I should like to point out an error concerning the Lutece cover: whereas the cover box on the index page says that the cover photo and the enlarged bills represent luncheon for four at Lutece, this amount does represent dinner for four, not lunch.

title: Tennis's Biggest Fault
description: The decision by World Championship Tennis to stage a $50,000 tournament for its 32 contract professionals in St. Louis during the same dates as Wimbledon this year has added confusion to the administrative; chaos in the sport.

title: Lower Drinking Age Opposed
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., March 18 (AP)Mayor Donald G. Butler has vetoed a resolution passed by City Council that advocates lowering the drinking age to 18.

title: Christians call it grace, Zen Buddhists satori, Jews kavanna
description: These lucidly conceived smallscale stores are enlisted in a large enterprise. Not in the sense that they aspire to be novelsinlittle, as some short fiction does, mistaking inscrutability for breadth or psychology for an idea, but rather in that they have a subject of uncommon scope. The subject is simultaneously elusive and persuasive: what Christianity means by grace, Zen by satori and Judaism by kavannaunderstanding in the grip oif benediction.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 18It would. be comforting to think that President Nixon's proposal to put an end to the desegregation of the schools is merely the shabby and cynical political de. vice of a President at home in such dealings. It is that, all right, but it also recognizes and represents a profound failure of the national will, coma parable to but more dangerous than the abandonment of Reconstruction little more than a century ago.

title: BOB UNSER WINS RACE AT PHOENIX

description: Andrew Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman, has been named recipient of the 1972 Herbert H. Lehman Human Relations Award, Philip E. Hoffman, president of the American Jewish Committee announced last night. Mr. Goodman was cited for his Creative achievements and career in public service.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The Italian Ferraris, off to a strong start in the world manufacturers championship, will try for their third consecutive victory of the season in the 12hour en. durance race at Seabring next Saturday. The 5.2mile airport layout in the shuffleboard country of central Florida Is rough on race cars, especially on the erraris, but recent tests have been encouraging Florida Is rough on race cars, especially on the erraris, but recent tests have been encouraging for the Italians. Mario Andretti tested one of the 3liter sports cars for about 800 miles without breaking the gear box, which he considers the car's most vulnerable component. There also was speed bonus: Andretti turned one lap at 2 minutes 29.6 seconds, or fourtenths of a second faster than the course record.

title: Anne Meissner To Be Married To A. W. White

Meissner of Wellesley Farms and West Falmouth have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. White Jr. of New Canaan,. Conn. and West Falmouth.

description: The neighborly impulse to help others in time of need is a basic tenet of the Red Cross, which has been serving for more than 100 years as a good neighbor to mankind around the world. This spirit of extending a helping hand is the real meaning of belonging to the Red Cross. You don't just give, you Join.

He is Mitchell Wilson, an American physicist who some time ago abandoned the laboratory for the typewriter and seems not to have regretted the shift.

description: TRENTON, March 18The annual championship race for Modified and sportsman stock cars, for 21 years a fixture at Langhorne, Pa., will be run this year at the 1.5.mile Trenton Speedway on Oct. S.S.

description: To the Editor:

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR: The Feb. 20 cover with the enlarged bill of $147.62 for four dinners at Lutece is the sort of obscene publication our moral censors should be striving to prevent. To have it appear in a country where there are so many hungry people turns the stomach. The whole haute cuisine business is nothing but a racket aimed at parting ignorant snobs and wouldbe snobs from atrocious amounts of money. Good food, better than most overfrilled and overrich haute cuisine, can be found at reasonable prices in many unpretentious restaurants. Unfortunately, most of these are not in Fun City, where sham and facade mean more than content. However, if you're ever in Boulder,DIETRICH E. THOMSEN.Washington, D. C.

title: Brazil vs. Oil Giants
description: RIO DE JANEIROBrazil, the industrial wonder of Latin America, is now preparing to become an important international petroleum producer despite the fact that this huge country is critically lacking in oil deposits.

title: Alioto Case Is Set to Go to the Jury
Challenge of Wisconsin
description: The Democratic primary in Wisconsin on April 4 gives every indication of being the Florida of the North. Although 58 per cent of the Democrats of Florida voted for other candidates last Tuesday, Gov. George C. Wallace won valuable publicity and most of the delegates because his minority support was united while his majority opposition was divided.

title: U.S. USES COMPUTERS FOR TRANSLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 18As part of its. Vietnamization efforts the Defense Department is using computers that can rapidly translate complex English technical and instructional manuals into Vietnamese:

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:The monumental issues of the state of our prisons and the photographer's ability to document injustice and influence social change call for a more appropriate, mature and responsive treatment than they received in Gene Thornton's absurd review of Danny Lyon's Conversations With the Dead. The review may be taken as a barometer of our contemporary insensitivity to images and of the popular demand to be titillated with the brutal and the sensational. Could it be that the news media have bombarded us with so many images of injustice, horror, and war that we have become visually anesthetized, able to respond only to the execrable and the atrocious, unable to perceive in less violent images the essential human bonds that tie us each to each other?

title: Open Hostility in San Diego Greets Vanguard of Activists Planning Protests at National Convention of G.O.P.
description: SAN DIEGO, March 18The vanguard of thousands of young activists who are expected to converge upon San Diego for protest demonstrations at this summer's Republican convention has begun drifting into the city's already crowded hippieland along the ocean front.

title: Kalichstein Plays. Fantaisies For Piano Competition Series
description: If Joseph Kalichstein's piano recital at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Friday night had ended with Mozart's Fantasy in D minor (K. 397), the report of the event today could have been one of unadulterated praise.

title: New &
description: If you'd like to know what Whistler's mother was really like off her rocker (a holy terror!) Mr. Berkman's novel will fill you in. It also fleshes out the life and times of the belligerent Butterfly himself: his esthetics, his artistic integrity, his Bohemian private life and his magnificent feuds. Never has there lived so litigious a painter. Or hardly ever.

description: William (Buddy) Gilmour, a driver, and Maurice Pusey, a trainer, will be honored as Yonkers Raceway's champions of 1971 at a meeting of the New York Chapter of Harness Writers Wednesday night.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 18 When Clayton Cash and his buddies were hauling burley tobacco to auction last December, they didn't expect to get this far.

title: Law
description: Writing in the Elks Magazine for August, 1965, J. Edgar Hoover, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, denounced those who indulge in sabotage by semanticsthey stigmatize patriotic Americans with the obnoxious term informer when such citizens fulfill their obligations of citizenship by reporting known facts of the evil conspiracy to properly constituted authorities. It would require very little time for these critics to pick up a dictionary. Webster's Unabridged volume specifically states that. en informer is one who informs against another by way of accusation or complaint. Informer is often, informant never, a term of opprobrium.generalizations about agent provocateurswho sometimes are recruited from within the target organization, other times are planted from the outside and other times are defectors or dropouts who return at the behest of a police agencybut there are two dominant theories. One, the zealous agent theory, has it that virtually all agent provocateurs are acting on their own without instructions from the home office. A sophisticated version of this theory is held by Frank Donner, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Political Surveillance project, who concedes that ocassionally an agent will directly involve himself in the commission of a crime as part of a planned intelligence strategy, but more generally believes that the idea that you can control informers ignores the strange drives and hostile passions that cause people to act as spies in the first place. Besides, Mr. Donner adds, it's hard to tell those guys to hang your clothes on the hickory limb of involvement, but don't go near the water of

title: College Clinics Give LowCost Dental Care
Article 9  No Title
description: MILLIONS of American homeowners are opening their mail these days to discover gas bills that containin addition to the usual ad for a gas barbecue grill or humidifiera polite request to turn down the thermostat a bit. Builders and buyers of new homes in New Jersey and parts of the Midwest are being denied gas connections. Industrialists in Ohio and elsewhere are changing plans to construct factories that use natural gas or are relocating in areas where fuel is available or pollution controls are less strict. That's not just a flicker in the widely advertised blue flame; the United States is really running out of natural gas, the source of third of its

title: JERSEY LINE RAISES INTERSTATE FARE 10c,
description: NEWARK, March 18 (UPI)A 10cent increase on all interstate bus routes of InterCity lines, approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, is scheduled to become effective on Monday.

title: Pop
description: IAN MATHEWS: Tigers Will Survive (Vertigo, VEL 1010). Once around with this album and the plea to please be my friend which closes the first side will be joyously and affirmatively answered. Perhaps the tigers will survive in the end, but for the time being, I'll take the softer creature portrayed here.

title: Busy Summit Art enter Plans Expansion

Through the bright red, door of the tiny Summit Art Center 17 Cedar Street swing a variety of artitists at. various hours of the day and night from. octogenarian Mary Bayne Bugbird, who helped found the center with 12 other artists back in 1937, down to 9yearold Sonia Anglin who lives in the nearby neighborhood. Contmutfirg businessmen use its facilities after work hours.

description: Training programs for health care workers axe proliferating at such a brisk rate, with no overall planning, that many health administrators and workers are already beginning to wonder where and how newly trained personnel will be used in'the future.

description: To the Financial Editor:

description: RCA Records has developed a new type of quadraphonic, or fourchannel, phonograph record,, that reproduces four separate, discrete, tracks and is compatible with existing stereo equipment.

title: One is good, two is better
description: Sweater collectors should be doubly happy this spring, since two sweaters are better than one. The twinsweater set is making a dramatic reentry into the modern way of American dressing. The baggy sweater set so popular in the Forties has been slimmed down for a neat Seventies look. When worn with slithery, anklelength skirts or extravagantly full pants and bold accessories, the effect is far from sporty. It's strictly elegant.

title: Police Fire Into Air At a Demonstration By the Young Lords
description: Three persons were arrested yesterday after policemen fired several shots over the heads of about 150 demonstrators, most of them Puerto Ricans, after a gasoline bomb was thrown through the window of a bank in the south Bronx, the police said.

title: Nuclear Test by China InAtmosphere Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuters)China today Set off a nuclear explosion in the atmosphere with a fOrce of from 20 to 200 kilotons. the equivalent of from 20,000 to 200,000 tons of TNT, the Atomic Energy Commission announced here.

description: State Senator John J. Marchi, long a favorite of the Conservative party, faces a possible repudiation by it in his reelection effort this yar.

title: Alison Grace Byers Betrothed To Marshall Lawrence Norton
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I. March 18Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Gibson Paine have made known the engagement of Mrs. Paine's daughter, Miss Alison Grace Byers, to Marshall Lawrence Norton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Read Norton Jr. of Bedford Hills, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Old Irish Castle Is TranquilFor the Moment
description: ADARE MANOR, IrelandThings are quiet right now at Adare Manor, an imposing Tudor Gothic castle with a family history that goes back to the middle of the 17th century. But perhaps that's just as well because the slender young woman in blue jeans who usually can be spotted digging away at a flower bed or sawing vigorously at the dead limb of a tree has other things on her mind.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:The otherwise splendid article about Sanibel Island, Fla. (Travel section, Feb. 6), said, With twothirds of the acreage owned by the Federal Government, relatively little space remains for private development. We only wish this were so. In fact, the 4,700 acres of wildlife preserve mentioned represents about onethird of the island. Unplanned, haphazard private development is proceeding at a shocking pace on the other twothirds. We are seeking to raise funds to save a little more from the bulldozer.

title: Nicholas Johnson to Forgo Race for Iowa Senate Seat
description: IOWA CITY, March 18 (UPI)  Federal Communications Commissioner Nicholas Johnson said today that he would not run against Senator Jack Miller of Iowa, a Republican, because he could not raise enough money in Iowa to run as a Democrat.

title: Bridge Mind your ethics!
description: RULINGS by the Federal Trade IN, Commission in recent years to insure that television advertisers play the game with viewers have long been paralleled in the laws of bridge. Communication must be within technical limits, and undue emphasis is unethical.

title: Nindl Takes Giant Slalom Is 2d at Steamboat
description: STEAMBOAT, Colo., March 18Hugo Nindl of Austria upset current money and points leader Spider Sabich today to win the giant slalom in the Bonnie Bell/Hart pro ski race.

title: I.T.T. Aide's Lawyer Hints at Evidence on Forgery
description: DENVER, March 18  The lawyer for Mrs. Dita Davis Beard, the ailing lobbyist for International Telephone mid. Telegraph Corporation, said today that further evidence ex.; fisted to substantiate her charge that the memorandum attributed to her was a partial forgery.

title: Publishing:
description: The plan, since changed, was for Publisher's Weekly ad that would Proclaim 1972 McGrawHill's best year. The reaction of Albeit R. Leventhal, the company's group vicepresident, had a touch of selfmockery. I beg to differ, he said.

title: Kresse Is Named by Nets As Director of Personnel
description: The New York Nets have named John Kresse director of player personnel. Kresse has been assistant coach and chief scout for two seasons and will continue those duties.

title: Home Improvment
description: THE closet Wall pictured here was built as a divider to separate a large room into two separate rooms, while at the same time adding muchneeded extra storage spacea welcome improvement for most homes. and apartments.

title: Cahill Accepts Invitation to Lead Nixon's Campaign in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 18Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he had accepted an invitation to serve as New Jersey campaign chairman for the reelection of President Nixon.

description: Syracuse and Maryland reached the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tournament different ways yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pop
description: KENNY LOGGINS and JIM MESSINA: Sittin In (Columbia,C 31044). It may not be the most couth way to describe an album these days, but Sittin In is pretty. Each cut. is plain and simply stated, both musically and lyrically. Backup instruments, in addition to the leaders guitars, are used because they fit, not just because they're available (E.g. the fiddle on Danny's Salm, and the flute on Peace of Mind.). The vocals are also completely natural; both Loggins and Messina sing as though they were seated beside their listeners.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since 1934 American citizens have been forbidden to own gold bullion. One rationale for this regulation was the fact that a citizen could theoretically turn his dollar holdings into its equivalent in goldin effect, the Gov. ernment had guaranteed a certain specific gold backing for the dollarand as long as the guarantee existed was felt that the citizen did not require the actual conversion privilege.

title: The Temple of Segesta: An Unfinished Legacy
description: SEGESTA, SicilyThis Doric temple, which has stood for 25 centuries in a valley in northwestern Sicily, is a testament to all things Greek by a nonGreek people. It was never finished, but it is beyond beauty.

title: Elizabeth Moeller Betrothed to Artist
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 18 The engagement of MissElizabeth Buchanan Moeller to Lloyd Kenneth Townsend Jr., son, of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend of Detroit, has been announced by the furture bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl William Moeller.

title: FINNEY'S TIRE DICK GUMSHOE THE FLICK, (Advt.)
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: J. M. Kaplan's radical proposal, that the Federal Government convert the New York Stock Exchange to a Government agency [0pEd March 1]. is absurd, The deficiencies within the current system are conspicuous. It is doubtful a system exists:, whether pub. lic or private, that is exempt from deficiencies. The problems of the existing system would be supplanted by new and potentially catastrophic problems.

title: Pop
description: TRACY NELSON: Tracy Nelson/Mother Earth (Reprise 2054). For several years Tracy Nelson served as lead singer for a rock band known as Mother Earth. With this album the roles have changed, and now its Ms; Nelson in the driver's seat. The significance of this somewhat semantic game is that at long last it is acknowledged that Ms. Nelson was and is the real, power behind Mother Earth, and now their music is moving more toward her rootscountry and gospel.

title: Coins
description: MORE than 1,000 years of United Kingdom coinage are commemorated by apedallymade proof sets, which will be made available to North American collectors early this spring, it has been announced through the Royal Mint in London.

title: Lockhart, 80, Still Yelling About Hockey
description: Memory's my greatest asset, said Torn Lockhart, following a waiter to a corner table in the Bull & Bear Room of the WaldorfAstoria. They say Lockhart's memory is better than the record book. And I was so dumb in school they promoted me out of spite.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Liquidation Of the National Board, of. The Coat and. Suit Industry, scheduled for April 1, marks the end of an era in the garment industry.

title: Miss Kellogg Is Bride Here
description: Miss Dorothy Mather Kollogg and James Robert Boryneck were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Patrick Walsh. The Rev. William Koffman assisted.

title: Housing:
description: ALBANY  The State Assembly had been proceeding at a basketweaving pace with minor bills, killing time in its threeday week. Then, last Monday, the issue of the three proposed towers of public housing in Forest Hills, Queens, came up.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S
description: WOOD RIDGE  Rainbow's End for a boy from Oklahoma and a girl from Far Rockaway has turned out to be a countrymusic club, which, once the sun goes down, offers the only signs of life along Hackensack Street in this little Bergen County town that nestles sleepily on a hill overlooking the Teterboro Airport.

title: Space Shuttle to Use SolidFuel Rockets
description: In its final major decision on the vehicle's structural makeup, the space agency last week picked reusable solidpropellant rockets to help launch the space shuttle that is due to start orbital flights. in 1998.

title: Chile Leads in Davis Cup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 18 (Reuters)Chile captured the opening singles matches against Peru in the American Zone (South Section) Davis Cup today. Jaime Pinto defeated Miguel Maurtua, 75, 61, 75, and Patricia Rodriguez beat Salomon Velasco 6.2, 6.3, 61.

title: Judith Haas Wed to Geoffrey Baker
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., March 18Miss Judith Crane Haas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Haas Jr. of Weston, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Geoffrey Scott Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elwood Baker of Athens, Ohio.

title: Stewart of Missouri Cited
description: KANSAS CITY, March 18 (AP)Norm Stewart, who has guided Missouri to improved seasons each of the five years he has been coach, was named Big Eight Conference basketball coach of the year today. Stewart won the honor in voting of sports writers and broadcasters. He beat out Jack Hartman, who coached Kansas State to the Big Eight championship.

title: At 90 M.P.H., Table Tennis Tries to Catch On in U.S.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 18Dereck Wall returned everything smashed at him, using a soft underhand stroke that sent the ball a fraction of an inch over the net.

title: GEORGIA G.O.P. PICKS A CONVENTION SLATE
description: ATLANTA, March 18 (UPI)Georgia Republicans elected 20 delegates and 20 alternates today to the Republican National Convention in Sari Diego next August.

title: News of Dogs
description: Golden opportunities await fanciers at the 50th anniversary show of the Bronx County Kennel Club in the Kingsbridge Armory next Saturday.

title: Mrs. Sherwin Has Child
description: A daughter was born Feb. 20 to Mr. and Mrs. James T. Sherwin of New York at the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Sherwin, a poet and shortstory writer, is the former Miss Judith Emlyn Johnson. Her husband is a group vice president of the GAF Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company. The child has been named Galen Leigh.

title: Kathy Paige Engaged
description: WESTBURY, L. T., March 18Mr. and Mrs. Joseph. Paige of Westbury and Quogue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathy Sue Paige, to. Ira Louis Zankel, sort of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Zankel of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for September.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Patras is not on the mainland of Greece, as shown in the map with Europe's Ferry Lines (Travel section, Feb. 27), but across the Gulf of Corinth, on the Peloponnesua. This is not significant if the motorist is bound for Athens from Patras because he can drive the superhighway and cross to the mainland near Corinth. If he wishes to go to Delphi, however, he takes the ferry from Rion, near Patras, to AndIrrion. A pleasanter way, omitting much mountain driving on the mainland, is to take the twohour ferry ride from Aigion to Itea, the part of Delphi.

title: the travelers world
description: PALMDALE, Calif.  The fashion trend today is toward the wide body .not for people, but for airplanes. Examples of the trend have been flashing across our horizons for two years, and now the latest model is about to be displayed in the form of the round, firm, wide body of the Lockheed L1011, also known as the Lockheed Tristar Jetliner.

title: The World
description: BEIBUTIf defeat [in the war with Israel] in 1967 has taught the Arabs anything, said the Jordanian Minister of Information, Adnan Abou Audeh, it is that they should be practical, not sentimental.

title: Biancos Have Daughter
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 18A daughter was born March 4 to Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. P. Bianco of Tokyo and Pocono Farms, Pa., in the Mount Helix Hospital here. Mrs. Bianco is the former Miss Macia Schroeder. Her husband is general banking officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank's Far East regional office in Tokyo. The child has been named Suzanne. She Is a granddaughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Schroeder of San Diego and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Bianco of Piscataway, N. J.

title: RANGERS TO MEET LEAFS AT GARDEN
Showdown on Hughes Near In Nevada
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 A showdown between Howard R. Hughes and State Gaming Control officials in Nevada appeared to be building this week.

title: Fencing Is
description: Residents of the Astoria section of Queens may soon be spared the sight of a muchhated 20acre dump that has marred the shore of Bowery Bay near La Guardia Airport for the last 15 years.

title: Laurie Weil Fiancee Of Howard Mandell
description: MONTGOMERY,Ala.,March 18The engagement of Miss Laurie Jean Weil, a senior at Smith College, to Howard Allyn Mandell, a lawyer here, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Adolph. Weil Jr., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mandell of Providence, R. I. A June 24 wedding is planned.

title: Art Mailbag; The Guggenheim Giacomettis? Still There
description: To THE EDITOR:IN last week's Letters to the Editor concerning the sales and exchanges of museum art, one letter signed by John Rewald, Professor of Art History, City University of New York, unequivocally accuses me of having sold some or all of Giacometti's drawings bought for the Guggenheim Museum by my predecessor, James Johnson Sweeney. For the information of your readers and for the sake of truth, let me state that Mr. Rewald's allegations in this respect are not 99 per cent inaccurate but 100 per cent false.

title: Union, Dealers Train Car Mechanics
description: If yen have to learn in the street, you'll never learn the right way, said Jack Ferguson, a 19yearold apprentice automobile mechanic, as he attended glasses recently at a major newcar dealer's here. Here they take more time out to teach you.

title: Woman jailed in Child Fraud
description: BAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 18 (UPI)Peggy McGinnis, 32 years old, has begun serving a 60day sentence after she, admitted collecting $740 in child support payments for a son'named Thomas she didn't have. The Authorities said that she lived alone with her pet dog, Thomas.

title: Linnard Hobler To Be the Bride Of K. D. Pettit 3d
description: Miss Linnard Ruth Nobler, assistant art director with KETCTV, the public broadcasting station in St. Louis, and Karl Dravo Pettit 3d, who is completing studies at the Graduate School of Architecture of Washington University there, will be married June 3 in Summit, N. J.

title: Space Reporter Honored
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 The National Space Club preSented its national press award to Howard Benedict, Associated Press aerospace reporter at Cape Kennedy, Fla., for excellence in reporting space devel opments, including some 1,800 launchings. The presentation was made Tuesday night by John H. Glenn Jr., first American to orbit the earth, during the club's annual Goddard dinner.

title: News of the Camera World
description: A NEW series of compact electronic flash units that can be fully recharged in only one hour ha been introduced by Ponder & Best, Inc., as part of the Vivitar line of electronic flash units. Available in four different models, two are fully automatic units (Models 271 and 281), while the other two are not (Models 171 and 181). The automatic units each offer a choice of f/stops so that the user can control the depth of field to some extent, while providing fully computerized control of the amount of light dispensed (after the f/stop setting is selected).

title: KENTUCKY ST. WINS N.A.I.A. TITLE, 7142
description: KANSAS CITY, March 18 (AP)Kentucky State stormed from behind on Travis Grant's shooting tonight to register a 7162 victory over topseeded Eau Claire (Wis.) State and capture its third consecutive National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship.

title: JOB PROGRAM TO AID YOUTHS THIS SUMMER
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)The White House announced today a program to provide more than a million summer jobs for youths aged 14 to 21.

title: After Iago, Rigoletto
description: SHERRILL MILNES is gradually making his way through the baritone parts of the Verdi operas, and as far as Metropolitan Opera audiences are concerned, the faster the better. On Saturday night he will sing Ingo in the new Zeffirelli production of Otello. A few weeks later he will appear as Rodrigo in Don Carlo here for the first time. In the Met's Verdi festival in June, he will do his initial Rigoletto with the company. Next season it will be Macbeth. The season after that, he will be the Renato in a new Masked Ball.

title: 2 Killed in Gas Blast
description: HASLAM, Tek., March 181 (UP1)Gas leaking from a butane tank touched off an explosion that destroyed a service station and a home in this East Texas town tonight. Two elderly women were killed.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., March 9 (AP) A second autopsy on the body of Raymond Yellow Thunder... showed no evidence of mutilation or torture, a lawyer [John Echo Hawk of Boulder, Colo., an attorney for the Native American Rights Fund] said today.

title: Sumatra Scores by Eight Lengths and Pays $8 in $28,500 Flirtation Stakes
Go to the ant, consider her ways and be wise
Addicts:;I just Kept Someone From Being. Robbed
description: Every time I give a check to an addict, said the matronly welfare caseworker, I say to myself, I Just paid for a fix. Then she added: But I also say, I Just kept someone from being robbed.

title: Mellifluous Sounds Of Solisti di Zagreb Mark End of Tour
description: The 11 string players who make up the Solisti di Zagreb produce a particularly mellifluous sound. It was very much in evidence in the ensemble's concert in Philharmonic Hall on Friday night. The event brought to an end the Yugoslays ninth American tour.

title: It's Easy to Spend at Le PirateThe Bill Depends on What's Broken
description: THERE is a crazy restaurant in the south of Prance where you are expectedto eat well and coPiously, to drink to excess, to listen to muslc and perhaps to spin to itand also to breakup the joint before you leave: The fume of the piece is Le Pirate. It sits on an otherwise. empty stretch of rocky heath at Cap.Martin and commands an unobstructed view across a bay to the lights of Menton. Relatively few people can avail :them selves of the, prospect, however, because te Pirate, in addition to being wild, is wildly expensive.

title: Fittipaldi Gains Pole Spot For Race at Brands Hatch
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, March 18 AP)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil drove his Lotus over the Brands Hatch Circuit at 113.70 miles an hour in trials today to win the pole position for tomorrow's Race of Champions.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR;

title: Article 11  No Title
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., March 9 (UPI)  About 300 Indians, apparently enraged over the death of an Indian [Raymond Yellow Thunder] in nearby Gordon, Neb., stormed a trading post and museum today in Wounded Knee... The operator of the trading post said that the Indians.barged in and roughed us up and then stole an estimated $50,000 worth of Indian artifacts from the Wounded Knee museum next door.

title: BLACK STUDENTS GET GREATER AID
description: A national survey of black and white college students, for the academic year of 196970 has shown that a higher percentage of black students received scholarships, grants and loans than white students.

title: New&Novel
description: You are one of the world's richest men, a fabulous, eccentric loner with headquarters at Las Vegas. You make a deal with a writer to help out with your autobiography. You begin to look mighty like a certain party who has been much in the news of late. Then Mr. Kane's dime novel (list price, $6.95) parts company with current events and suddenly you are just another paperback heavy, cooking up your evil schemes. I've got to blurt out to you that the evil schemes of Harold Hume (the mythical, mystical, legendary billionaire known to all the world but unknown) concern an organ transplant. Not the kind popularized by Christiaan Barnard. The kind that were done by Dr. Sergei Voronoff, the monkeygland rejuvenation man, whose work was written up in the Hearst Sunday supplements of the 1930's. Only thing isthe legendary billionaire wants a (gulp) human donor. A million laughs

title: Movie Mailbng
description: TO THE EDITOR:I must take exception to several things that Stephen Farber said about Cabaret in The Times.

title: FOLK ART SHOWN AT MUSEUM HERE
description: The fruits of collecting displayed in Eye on America, new show at the Museum of American Folk Art, set a standard that many collectors aspire to and few achieve.

title: Addicted ExG.I. Sentenced
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. March 18 (UPI)A young Vietnam veteran who resorted to heroin to kill the pain in his mineshattered leg has been sentenced to three years in prison for a holdup staged to support his $80aday drug habit. Officials said Thursday that Tom Murray 23 years old of New York City, had agreed to undergo an operation at Raiford Prison to have the leg, which has become cancerous, removed.

title: Hillel Center Fund Crisis
description: NEW BRUNSWICIC  The B'nai B'rith Hillel building at Rutgers University here, facing a possible shutdown this semester, has been forced to cancel its kosher eating program and Indefinitely curtail a number of stub dent activities.

title: Miss Schwabacher to Wed
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., March 18Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Schwabacher have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Schwabacher, to Robert S. Platner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Platner of Madison Township. Miss Schwabacher attended Mount Ida Junior College in. Roston. Her fiance studied at West Virginia University and was graduated from Monmouth College.

title: Airport Expansion Debated
description: The dispute over plans to improve Flushing Airport, small field aviation facility two miles east of La Guardia Airport in Queens, has flared anew.

title: The Life Guard
description: At the end of the closing short story in this collection of John Wain, the narrator asks: Does anything, ever, really change? The answer abstracted from Mr. Wain's stories might be: yes and no. The roles change. But the human frailty remains constant.

title: Northport To Vote on The Fate of Old Hotel
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.Voters here will decide Tuesday the fate of the Holiday Lodge, an old Northport hotel situated on four acres of waterfront property.

title: Woodcock Views Car As Threat to Health
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuters)  Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, says that the car is fast becoming a threat to health, safety and comfort in city areas. Mr. Woodcock assured the

title: Colombo Is Brought Back To Hospital to Take Tests
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, was readmitted yesterday to Roosevelt Hospital for a series of tests, the hospital announced yesterday.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: DESPITE public and private professions of confidence by highlevel Government officials over the state of the economy and the efficacy of the controls program, it is obvious that WaShington is watching apprehensively. as each new statistic plotted on the economic charts.

title: Aussie, Filipino Tied in Golf
description: CALCUTTA, India, March 18 (18)Brian Jones of Australia shot a threeunderpar 70 today and moved into a firstplace tie at 212 with a Filipino, Ben Arda, after three rounds of the Indian open golf tournament.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: My wife and I are the pleased owners of all 48 state books in the American Guide Series. We have used them in travel and find that they have an everlasting quality, and we wish we had guides on Hawaii and Alaska, which had not achieved statehood when the series was written, of similar rectitude. Incidentally, your list of state guides now out of print didnot include Connecticut, Maryland, New Hampshire and North Carolina we have them.

title: L.I. Pupils Learning
description: RONKONKOMA, L. I.There's a new business in townwholly financed and managed by eighthgrade students of the Peconic Junior High School here.

title: Court Dismisses Charges Against 2 at Graham Rally
description: KNOXVILLE, March 18 (UPI)The State Court of Appeals has dismis,sed charges against two University of Tennessee students accused, of disorderly conduct at a Billy Graham crusade attended by President Nixon here in 1970.

title: From Plate Glass to Float Process
description: At a symbolic ceremony in Carlisle, Pa., PPG Industries, Inc., the country's first successful producer of plate glass last week heated up the first of two melting furnaces in what will be the world's largest and most modern floatglass plant.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: In response to an avalanche of mail from conservationists in the United States and Canada, I write this open letter to all those who have voiced objection to a proposed wolf hunt on snowmobiles, organised by two Michigan operators and destined for the Province of Quebec. It is unlawful in Quebec to pursue en animal with any kind of motor vehicle. Our laws are as severe as those of any other Canadian province when it cornea to wildlife conservation and are as rigidly enforced.

title: 5 Die in Texas Collision
description: TYLER, Tex., March 18 (UPI) Two cars collided on a state highway tonight, killing five persons, including two small boys, No one survived the crash. The victims were not immediately identified.

title: Indiana Swimmers Rated 101 Choice
description: LOS ANGELES, March 18 About one chance in 10 is the Way Peter Deland, Southern California's swim coach, appraises the odds of dethroning Indiana's national champions next weekend at West Point.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The author, a past president of the American and World Associations for Public Opinion Research, takes a long, skeptical look at the polls, their uses and misuses. The basic fault of polls in elections, he says, lies in misinterpretation and an eagerness to make oracles of the pollsters. Similarly, polls are subject to manipulation by politicians (the Nixoncommissioned poll, for instance, that showed a majority of people favoring the Haynesworth nomination). The battle of the polls is warming up for the election; and Mr. Bogart, although he is mainly on the side of the pollsters, offers caveats for emptors and voters.

title: Equinox
description: The vernal equinox tomorrow signals the end of winter, by the charts. But, also by the charts, daylight and darkness were equal the day before yesterday and tomorrow daylight will exceed darkness by some eight minutes.

title: Lindsay to Offer Budget Compromise
description: City Budget Director David A. Grossman said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay would offer to make information available in advance to the City Council and Board of Estimate on how he planned to spend some $200million in lump sum capital appropriations.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: GAINS ARE CITED IN POSTAL SERVICE
description: George Washington viewed the Post Office as second only to Christianity as the right arm of our modern civilization, but almost no one since then has had many kind words for the postal system.

title: Pop
description: JIM DAWSON: You'll Never Be Lonely With Me (Kama Sutra, 2049). Jim Dawson has been at it as a solo performer for about year. With his mellow voice, unique interpretations of the songs of some of his contemporaries and with his own compositions, he has been building a loyal following. And though this second album will not introduce his stereo audience to Dawson's abilities as an interpreter, it should add to his reputation as a fine singer and songwriter.

title: The World
description: LONDONLondon glowed last week in rare March sunshine. Skirts rose with the crocuses. Office workers relaxed in the downtown parks at the noon hours. Euphoria spread to just about everywhere, except to 10 Downing Street.

title: Two Ships in the Atlantio Under Tow in High Seas
description: BOSTON, March 18 (UPI)The 750foot tanker Texaco Pembroke was in tow to Boston tonight after being adrift in high seas. off Chatham during the day. The Coast Guard said the ship was in no immediate danger.

title: 2Year Program Begins To Protect Atlantic Coast
description: HIGHLANDS, N. J., March 18 The American Littoral Society has begun a twoyear, statebystate campaign to help protect the wildlife and other natural resources along the Atlantic Coast.

title: A SNIPER IN SEATTLE KILLED IN GUN FIGHT
description: SEATTLE, March 18 (AP)The police said tonight that they shot and killed an unidentified man in a downtown hotel after a 25minute gun battle in which a sniper wounded at least two police officers.

title: Lynn Matthews Engaged to Joseph, P. Marrow, U. S. Lawyer;
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I. March 18Miss Lynn Marie Matthews and Joseph Patrick Marro plan to be married June 10.

title: Religion
description: For many American Catholic priests, there surely was something unreal to the messages emanating last week from Denver where the annual meetlug of the National Federation of Priests Councils focused on the theme justice and peace. The federation is an independent organization of 127 clergy groups representing 30,000 priests, more than half the Catholic clergy in the United States.

title: Increasing Numbers of Black Legislators Beginning to Have an Impact on Issues Throughout the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 18As the Alabama House of Representatives was approving Gov. George C. Wallace's request for 100 additional state troopers last year, the legislative body's two black members proposed that all of the now officers be black.

title: Miner Warner Marries Ellen Cabeen Murphy
Opera: Rare Vitality of Les Troyene
Britain Curbs London Protests
description: LONDON, March 18 The British Government, which is expected to present its proposals for political reforms in Northern Ireland next week, has banned from Trafalgar Square any demonstrations connected with Irish affairs. The square is the traditional meeting place for demonstrations.

title: ENOUGH REALITY
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Kaiser's Inside Trading in Canada
description: TORONTOThe latest disclosures about secret trading in the shares of Kaiser Resources, Ltd., of British Columbia by insiders of the company and its Oakland, Calif. parent, the Kaiser Steel Corporation, have raised freshbut not unfamiliar  doubts about investor protection in Canada.

title: CustomCar Maker on Coast Diversifies
description: LOS. ANGELES, March 18  What ever happened to those dream cars of Southern California? A decade ago every youngster in the San Fernando Valley wanted a soupedup Kandyapplered custom car with a choppedoff body, fastback roof, scoops over the wheels, a floating grille and maybe some hidden door handles. Von Dutch strips streaking :along the sides could make Sure it was the hottest thing at the drivein.

title: Spain, Torn by Ideological Conflict, Waits to Seed Franco Can Meet Challenge
Mrs: Onassis:
description: The best offBroadway shoW in town is in its sixth week on the 15th Moor of the Federal Courthouse on Foley Square. It features a glamorous central figure, dramatic trial counsel, films and colorful slides of the gay life in New York, Capri and Skorpios. The action: A legal duel between Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and freelance photographer Ronald E. GaleIla, with the United States Government sitting in the wings.

title: YOUTHS CONVICTED IN CAPITAL KILLING
description: WASHINGTON, March 18A United States District Court jury on Thursday night found two young men, products of the middleclass dropout generation, guilty of robbing two savings and loan offices here last May and of murdering a policeman who tried to stop the second robbery.

title: jewelry Problem: Gold
description: The jewelry makers are worried  at least many of them are  over one of their most glittering raw materials, gold.

title: Contract Awarded For S.Q.E. Work
description: Governor Rockefeller has announced the award of an $ 11million contract for reconstruction and widening of half a mile of expressway viaducts on the BrooklynQueens Expressway near the Kosciusko Bridge.

title: Brooklyn Handball Star Captures Canadian Singles
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, March 18 (AP)Americans swept all open competition in the Canadian handball championships, which ended today at the University of Alberta after four days of play.

title: Gates Helms Hawn Weds Miss Dayton
description: HANCOCK, Md., March 18 Miss Henrietta Gayton, an assistant utility analyst at Stone & Webster Securities Corporation in New York, was married here this evening to Gates Helms Hawn, who is with the securities markets division of the Bankers. Trust Company in New York.

title: DIAMOND UNSURE ABOUT ST0RM KING
description: Henry L. Diamond, New York State's top environmental official, who last year gave his official approval to the controversial Storm King power project, said last week that he now had grave concern about the work proceeding because of its1 scenic impact.

title: Son to the Aureliuses
description: ATLANTA, March 18A son was born on Feb. 25 to Mr. and Mrs. Brynn F. Aurelius in Northside Hospital here.

title: Turkish Premier Arrives; 3 Days of Talks Planned
description: Dr. Nihat ErIm, Premier of Turkey, arrived yesterday for three days of meetings with President Nixon and other officials confident that our talks will further strengthen the ties between our two countries.

title: Wild Tract in Northern Jersey Faces New Foreclosure Move
description: WEST MILFORD, N. J., March 18  The second fore. closure action in the months threatens to bring bulldozers into the 3,200acre Sussex woodlands property of Fred Ferber here and in ,adjoining Vernon TownShip. it is regarded as the best remaining private natural area hi. north ern New Jersey.

title: Pop
description: JIM HALL:... Where Would I He? (Milestone MSP 9037) Jim Hall is the guitarist's guitarist, the last of a line that included Durham, Christian, Raney and Farlow. The newest wave of improvisational guitarists has drawn from the instrument's African lineage (Sonny Sharrock) or from blues and rock sources (Coryell, McLaughlin), but has rarely evidenced a deep commitment to the jazz guitar tradition. In this sense, Hall is both a purist and something of an anachronism, but his taste, restraint and mature conception mark his music as timeless.

title: Bulls Cap Season Series Sweep of Cavaliers With 10941 Rout
Jersey Six Bows to Dayton In Amateur Semifinal, 43
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 18The BergenRockland Redwings were eliminated today by the Dayton Club in Region Three semifinals of the Pee Wee Division of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States.

title: Mansfield Says Nixon Plan May Aid Busing Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, suggested today that portions of President Nixon's antibusing proposal could be used as the basis for a compromise, between the House and Senate over the issue.

title: 5 in Iowa Elected to Share Role of Student President
description: IOWA CITY, March 18 (UPI) Five students who said that they would share the duties of student president have been elected at the University of Iowa.

title: Sweden Acting on Drugs
description: STOCKHOLM, March 18 (Reuters)The Swedish Government has announced legislation to raise the maximum penalty for drug offenses to 10 years from 6. A Government official said this week that the draft bill, which will go before Parliament shortly, was aimed at big peddlers.

title: Look ma, no straps
description: Sun worshipers, rejoicel Strapless days are here again, bringing the barest bathing suits to hit the beaches since the bikini. For sunnerswimmers, they mean freedom. Freedom from clutching straps, freedom from white strap stripes.

title: Hunter Students Get Free Legal Advice
description: Hunter College has begun free legalcounseling program for students and members of the administration designed to help them with problems ranging from parking tickets to allmony payments.

title: BigSchool Recruiters Go to Market at junior College Playoffs in Kansas; At junior college's tournament in Hutchinson, Kan., Benny Dees, left, assistant coach at Western Kentucky, chats with Greg McDougald, former standout at James Monroe in Bronx, of Seminole (Okla.) Junior College.
description: HUTCHINSON, Han., March 18This was a week when the nation's winning college basketball coaches went to the National Collegiate or National Invitation tournaments and the alsorans came to Hutch.

title: 36 More Food Outletis Cited as Dirty
Religious Community of Their Own Making
description: LOS ANGELES Janet. Barber lives in. a small Victorian house in a reeldentinl section of Hollywood and does her best to be a good citizen.

title: BRAZIL BANS HUNTING BY PROFESSIONALS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March IS The Brazilian Government has acted to conserve the country's wildlife by licensing sportsmen and forbidding professional hunting.

title: Peralta Stops Johnson
description: VALENCIA, Spain, March 18 (AP)Gregorio Peralta of Argentina knocked out Willie Johnson of Miami in the second round of a scheduled 10round heavyweight bout tonight. Paralta weighed 194 pounds, Johnson 182.

title: Miss Werthan Plans Nuptials
description: NASHVILLE, March 18Miss Patricia Werthan, and John Well Uhlmann plan to be married here May 13 Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Well Kuhn, stepfather and mother of the bride tobe, whose father the late Howard Meyer Werthan, was president of Werthan Industries, a textile and fiber firm here.

title: Blips on Radar Can Be Mosquitoes
Japanese at Work
description: Taro Suziuki is 26 years old, a high school graduate and has been working at the Takei Diecast Company in Tokyo for four years after quitting a tire factory be cause he said he couldn't stand the smoke and fumes there.

title: Investments: For Good or Gold?
description: It's test time again for university trustees and their portfolio managers.

title: Richardson Memorial Tourney Opens Metropolitan Golf Play
description: The 1972 amateur competitive golf aeason in the metropolitan district will get under way with the William D. Richardson memorial tournament, an annual event of the Long Island Golf Association. It is scheduled for May 1113, at the Sewane Club, Hewlett Harbor, L. I.

title: Amy Vanderbilt's Etiquette
description: There will be those who will no doubt feel that for Amy Vanderbilt to have devoted herself during this past decade of brutal and heartrending political assassinations and imprisonments, of escalating protective reaction raids and vocabularic overkill, of militant minority confrontations and innercity conflagrations

title: Bormann Suspect in Colombia Declares Is a Jew

description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 18 A victory, a forfeit and a tie Were all the Americans could manage last night in their first of four wrestling meets with the Soviet team touring the United States.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Many years ago, I had teacher who advised the members of his class that whenever we read a new book, we should go back and read an old one. So, after having read a great deal about today's problems, went back to a very old book written by a man named Luke. In his 18th chapter, he described how a Pharisee went into the temple to pray.

title: Still the elusive character
description: The principal Stalin biographies  those by Trotsky, Souvarine and Deutscherwere written during their subject's lifetime. Now that Stalin has been dead for nearly 20 years, our knowledge about him and his time has greatly increased.

title: Spain Honors Father of 21
description: MADRID, March 18 (Reuters) Jose Maria Pulido Tirado, a farmer said to be 107 years old, has won this year's National Birth Prize for having fathered 21 children. The prize, an unspecified amount of money, is to be presented by the Chief of State, Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

title: Queens Women's Five Wins
description: NORMAN, Ill., March 18A free throw by Barbara Riccardi with no time remaining gave the Queens College women's basketball team a 7776 overtime. victory today over Tennessee Tech in a consolation game at the national intercollegiate basketball tourney at Illinois State University.

title: This George Wallace Is Involved in a Different Race
description: YONKERS, March 18Over the fourday span from last Saturday through Tuesday, George Wallace was a name to be reckoned with, in sports as well as In politics.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT.
description: WASHINGTON,  John B. Connally, the SeCretary of the Treasury, emitted an obviously sincere lament last week at how badly equipped the United States Government had become to handle international economic policy. He said this area of poiicy is characterized by traits of ponderousness, division of responsibility, rivalry and, in some sectors, innocence.

title: FOOD TALK
description: A jungle grows in East New York, a miniature lush jungle of hundreds of shapes, sizes and colors of cacti and succulent plants.

description: CHICAGO, March 18Buoyed by the New Hampshire primary and dashed by the Florida one, Senator George McGovern starts over again in the Illinois primary on Tuesday, trying to show that there is a wide coalition backing him in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: I.R.S. Begins Drive Against Refund Mills in Metropolitan. Region
description: The Internal Revenue Service has started a drive in the New York region on what it calls refund mills"tax preparers who persuade people who pay income taxes to file claims for refunds to which they have no legal right.

title: Raseball Coach Is Named
description: Lee Roberts has been named head baseball coach at East Stroudsburg State College. He replaces Vern Watch, who is now director of physical education and athletics for the Onondaga (N. Y.) Central School District, Roberts has coached the East Stroudsberg freshman basketball team for the last three seasons.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The letter writer. who complained that the snowmaking equipment at many ski areas covers only a small part of the mountain (Travel section, Feb. 6) hit several points right on. However, she does seem to be painting all snowmaking areas with the same tinged brush. At Hunter Mountain we have a large snowmaking...plant.; and we cover about 90 pd. cent of our skiable terrain with patinemade snow. Most, of the areas wit's snowmaking equipment in Vermont, New York and New Jersey cover small portions of. their beginner areas or the lower part of the mountain. Most of the mountain may'e a sheet of ice, or even bare, while the reports indicate that the skiing is good to excellentindeed it may be on the small portion covered. Machinemade snow does ice up faster than natural snow. However, it stays on steep trails better and does not expose rocks quickly, and it also stands up better for spring skiing and during warm weather.

title: Soviet Is Looking for Wrestler To Halt Dan Gable, U.S. Star
description: Can anyone beat Dan Gable, United States amateur wrestling star in the Olympic Games?

title: Bengali Backlash
description: Last week's massacre of Biharis in Bangladesh is grim storm signal. It exposes passions, poverty and official impotence in the new Bengali nation that once More could set East Bengal and possibly the whole Indian subcontinent afire.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Even to votaries of the South's Lost Cause, the Confederacy's only President remains a granite statue on the state capitol grounds. To counter this, the Jefferson Davis Association and Rice University with help from a number of Southernbased funds and corporations  have begun publishing a complete, almost laundrylistandall edition of Davis's papers. The meticulous scholarship follows the tradition of the Franklin and Jefferson projects. This first volume brings together the fragmentary vestiges of the first 32 years a career at West Point (undistinguished except for some offlimits drinking), his years as an Army officer on the frontier (undistinguished except for charges that he highhatted a superior officer), his marriage to Zachary Taylor's daughter over Taylor's objection and her early death. But Davis is still a statue. Perhaps he will come to life in the 21 to 26 volumess to follow.

title: LOTTERIES MAKE FUNDING PAINLESS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 18The Quaker founders of Pennsylvania who, barred priz and gamesters would have been aghast, but the Commonwealth's 40th Governor Milton J. Shapp, showed only enthusiasm hi presiding at the first drawing this week of the Pennsylvania state lottery.

title: WHEELCHAIR TEAM OF ISRAEL DUE HERE
description: The world champion Israeli wheelchair basketball team will arrive in New York April 17 for a threeweek tour of the United States and Canada.

title: Mr. Bulllins Is Himself at Fault
description: THE first line in the printed text of Ed Bullins's 'The Duplex is: The people in this play are Black. Obviously the line spare, insistent, standing alone  is something more than a piece of information for the casting director. It means to say several things: that Black people are unlike people of any other color, that the Black experience is not an experience readily recognizable to white majority, that the play itself is not intended as a white, neatlytooled, traditionally wellmade play but as a play derived whollyin form and in feelingfrom Blackness.

title: Big Fleets Are Expected For Ocean Yacht Races
description: Competitionhungry yachtsmen aren't waiting until 7:22 A.M. tomorrowthe official beginning of springto get that urge to go down to the sea in ships again. Based on present entries, longdistance race organizers are predicting record fleets, while the roundthebuoy sailors are already ht high gear this Olympic year.

title: Gustavo Thoeni Captures Cup Ski Lead

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged the passage of a Iocal law to let the Taxi Cab Commission regulate socalled gypsy". cabs. It is folly to pretend that the nonmedallion industry does not exist, he said in a statement distributed at City Hall.

title: U.S.Born Greek Defendant Charges He Was Tortured
description: ATHENS, March 18An Americanborn Greek lawyer testified before an Athens military tribunal today that the Greek military police had extractor! his confession after making him stand up for seven days and nights without food, water or sleep.

title: Vincennes Takes No. 33, Wins Junior College Title
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan. March 18 (AP)Vincennes, ind., the shortest team in the 1972 National Junior College basketball tournament, won the title tonight and capped an unbeaten season with a 7361 victory over Ferrum, Va. Vincennes posted its 33d triumph.

title: The Gentlemm's A
description: Some thirty years ago, when scholars were locked in debate over the importance of school grades and college degrees, Robert Maynard Hutchins suggested that every baby born in the United States be handed bachelor's degree along with the birth certificate. Then, schools and colleges would be able to devote themselves to pure and honest education.

title: The Great Porpoise Massacre
description: PRINCETON, N. I.Many of the bounties of the sea have been tainted by man's profligate ways: mercury in swordfish, hepatitis virus in clams and shrimp. Our tables have long been graced with unblemished tuna, one of our children's favorites. Now we learn that our tuna is contaminated by the death of thousands of porpoises. Row come? Since the late 1950's American tuna fishermen have been capturing tuna by setting their purseseine nets on schools of porpoises.

title: The American Heritage History of The American People
description: What then is the American, this new man? asked the French essayist MichelGuillaume Sean de Crevecoeur in a small volume of impressions published in 1782. Monsieur de Crevecoeur had spent some years living in upstate New York, but even with this advantage, his answer was anything but certain. He could only say that the American was a brand new mixture: A new man, who acts upon new principles; he must therefore entertain new ideas and form new opinions.

title: The World
description: In Paris last Monday, a tall, slim American in a striped navyblue suit paid a morning call at an ivorycolored stone building on the Avenue George V. Fifty minutes later he was escorted out of the building by a burly Chinese in a gray jacket. The American called the Chinese cher anal and said: Thanks very much for your kind welcome. The normalizing of SinoAmerican relations, as envisioned in the communique issued at the end of President Nixon's visit to China, had begun.

title: Two on the Move in A MovementLess Time
description: DAVID DIAO, currently showing at the Reese Palley Gallery, is a young painter of already wellestablished reputation. Michael Goldberg's recent exhibition at Paley & Lowe Inc. marked the return to top form of a veteran ar tist whose fame has been in neartotal eclipse since his days as one of the most spectacular of the secondgeneration Abstract Expressionists. Diao and Goldberg have in common the fact that each, in this year of maximum confusion about the course of new American abstract painting, has achieved a strong, clear personal statement. Their separate cases suggest, encouragingly, that the current movementless state of painting may be a situation healthier and more fertile than many have supposed.

title: The Bomber Pilots Like Their Work (The enlisted men are not so gungho)
description: EACH day for the past year, when the clouds aren't too thick overhead, the North Vietnamese soldiers, drivers and engineers who travel the Ho Chi Minh trail down southern Laos can expect to witness the same thing. With the trucks pulled over and covered with branches, and the gasoline stored in camouflaged revetments, three specks come wheeling out of the eastern sky and start in over the trail. The two outside planes take the banking turn more steeply to cut their speed and fall behind the center plane, which plunges into a dive over the jungle. If anyone on the ground were still watching, he would see the two olivedrab bombs drop from the plane like eggs, wobble for a moment in the air and then plunge toward the ground. The jet pulls out of the dive at over 3,000 feettoo high for anyone to spot the NAVY markings on its hull. The men on the ground feel the shock of the bombs before they hear the explosion. Perhaps the bombs hit a truck, or a bunker. More likely, the bombs have put two more craters in the jungle, next to ones blown the day before or the year before; conical holes filling with green water or already blurred under a mat of creepers and brush.

title: Pop
description: CAPTAIN BEEFHEART: The Spotlight Kid (Reprise MS 2050). Captain Beefheart, AKA Don Van Vliet, once named as his influences the Delta blues of men like Robert Johnson and Son House and the freeform jazz of players like Albert Ayler and Ornette Coleman, and his previous album, Lick My Decals Off, Baby, was indeed a uniquely personal synthesis of these sources. Beefheart is virtually the only white blues singer to grapple with the asymmetrical form of much country blues. The recorded legacy of the 1920's abounds with twelveandahalf and thirteenandahalf bar structures, lopsided rhythms that drop a beat or two every verse, accompaniments that follow the singer's nuance and phrasing rather than determine it, as the codified twelvebar blues from often does.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: No informed person will question the statement that Berlin's Will Remains, the title of Phelps Phelps Feb. 12 letter. Many informed people will, however, challenge the accuracy of, his statement The stipulations represent meager concessions, grudgingly ounced out, indicative of the brutish construction typical of East Germany as proper characterization of the German Democratic Republic's attitude during the recent negotiations on travel and traffic regulations between East and West Germany. On the contrary, anyone familiar with the efforts of the Western powers and their protdge, the German Federal Republic (West Germany), to destroy the G.D.R. will consider these stipulations moderate.

title: Hartke Quits California Race
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 18 (AP)Senator Vance Hernia of: Indiana is pulling out of the June 6 California presidential primary, his national campalgn director discloSed today. Gerald N. Hill said Mr. Hartke had rnade the decision on the basis of his poor showing in the New Hampshire primary two weeks ago and a lack of campaign funds. The Senator is keeping his options open in regard to other primaries, Mr. Hill said.

title: Blow Ye Winds Westerly.; The Seaports & Sailing Ships of Old New England. By Elizabeth Gemming. Illustrated. 183 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Company. $4.95. (Ages 10 to 15)
description: Despite attractive design and interesting anecdote, much of this book fails to penetrate the deodorized and sanctimonious surface of history so visible in the replicas supplied by New England's flourishing nostalgia industry. Crockery being more comprehensible than the play of passion upon circumstance, the restorations cannot be faulted for enshrining fososils, But just as cowboy movies have created a West that never was, souvenir vendors sell us a version of New England history that never existed either, and this book does little to correct our vision.

title: Jail Fire Kills 4 Inmates
description: CLAYTON, Ga., March 18 (UPI)Four prisoners died of smoke inhalation and a fifth was hospitalized today when a smoldering fire broke out in a storage room of the Tabuns county Jail. The debt were identified as R. E. Thompson, 47 years old, of Clayton; Marvin. Edmons, 17, of Clayton; Romits. B. Scott, 21, of Pensacola, Flap and Fred Ererizer, 19, of Rochaster, N. Y.

title: The Nation
description: President Nixon faced a knotty problem growing out of his China trip, and last weekend, at his Camp David retreat, be pondered it. On Monday, the result was announced: Washington's National Zoo will get the two pandas given to the American people by China.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: For the first half of the 19th century the U. S. had what we'd now call an Establishment paperimportant for its reporting on the Federal government. (There is nothing quite like it today.) The National Intelligencer was founded in 1800 by Samuel Harrison Smith with the aid of Thomas Jefferson (who gave him an advanced copy of his inaugural address and many a public printing contract). Jefferson's successors continued the favors. Later, when Big Men in Congress became more powerful than Presidents, subsequent editors Joseph Gales Jr. and W. W. Seaton played ball with them. With the passing years, Gales and Seaton clung to their nationalism but swung from liberalism to conservatism; and the Civil War, the coming of industrial America and the hardening of G & S's arteries caused the paper to expire in 1865. The sheet was attractive, well written and genuinely informed about what was happening on the Potomac. Mr. Ames. who teaches at the University of Washington, is a sound historian; this is a firstrate account (as well as the first important history) of the paper, the men who ran it and the men who did business with it. Invaluable to anyone curious about the history of U.S. journalism and U. S. politics of the first half of the 19th century

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Faced by stiffening Federal, state and local pollution control requirements and becoming increasingly aware of new interest in the field of occupational health and safety, the foundry industry in the United States is not what it used to be.

Even several of Nader's friends shared the thought. It was fashionable to say that no one would have heard of him if General Motors had not put some dimwitted detectives on his trail, causing an uproar during the autosafety controversy of 1,967.

Most of those participating in the protest said they were concerned that busing blacks into area schools would eventually lead to busing white children out of the schools.

title: The Guest Word
description: The book came out in November, 1967, and generated controversy as soon as appeared. It purported to be the secret report of an anonymous Special Study Group, set up, presumably at a very high level of government, to determine the consequences to American society of permanent peace, and to draft a program to deal with them. Its conclusions seemed shocking.some of the harder questions of war and peace. But those who felt their own oxen goredwho could identify themselves in some way with the government, the military, systems analysis, the established order of powerwere not. They attacked, variously, the substance of the Report; the competence of those who praised its effectiveness; and the motives of whomever they assigned the obloquy of authorship, often charging him with a disingenuous sympathy for the Report's point of view. The more important thinktankers, not unreasonably seeing the book as an indictment of their own collective moral sensibilities and intellectual pretensions, proffered literary as well as political judgments: very bad satire, declared Herman Kahn; lacking in bite, wrote Henry Rowen, of Rand. Whoever wrote it is an idiot, said Henry Kissinger. A handful of farright zealots and eccentrics predictably applauded the conclusions.

It would round out a rewarding career and leave the remarkable Detroit outfielder with. as tidy a set of honors as, any athlete could corral this side of the Hall of Fame. And. Cooperstown should be his before the decade Is out.

Nixon asked that nearly two decides of legal tradition be countermanded and that Congress wrest from the courts the basic responsibility for: deciding how equal educational opportunity for millions of minority American school, children is to be achieved.

title: The autobiography of the Nobel Prizewinning Millie/Willie Niemann
description: The first novel is a curiously misnamed item. The term suggests the author's first attempt at a project more ambitious than short stories and term papers, and infrequently it is. But more often it means only that the novel is the first the author has managed to get published, and there's no telling how many others one? two? sometimes as many as 10 predecessors  have gone into wastebaskets or fireplaces or attic trunks instead of to press. This fact can be reassuring, for when a reader encounters a first novel as inventive and as skillfully written as Alan Friedman's Hermaphrodeity, it's nice to believe that Mr. Friedman, too, sat at home doing his lessons, rewriting, blotting out lines, rejecting false starts and unsatisfactory conclusions; in short, honing the craft which he now displays in this stunning example of literary creativIt is to how

title: TV Mailbag; COWARDICE; How Much Reality on TV?
description: To THE EDITOR:Those of us who work in the same field as David W. Rintels, and are privileged to be his friends, know that he jeopardized his career by testifying as he did about censorship in television before the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights. Knowing David, I'm sure that that is irrelevant to him, but it is nonetheless true and it adds a rather poignant dimension to his testimony.

title: The Hidden Soul of Europe's Hip Youth Capital
description: AMSTERDAM has a welldeserved reputation of being the least uptight, most tolerant city in Etirope, a city whose police do not automatically tremble with zeal at the acrid smell of marijuana and whose populace is not likely to bat an eye at the sight of the longest hair, the hottest pants, the shortest mini, ornow that maxis and wigs are inthe most trailing maxi topped, off by the kookiest wig, As a result of this tolerance and of a variety of other charms that draw people of all ages, the Venice of the North attracted more than 85,000 young people last summer and the influx is expected to exceed that total this year, Among Europe's many handsome and still livable cities, only Copenhagen, whose fame has recently spread for being equally hospitable and almost as freewheeling, can contest Amsterdam's title to being the youth capital of the western world.

title: Alexander Wharton to Marry Miss Susan Chase Blaisdell

title: Headliners
description: Ingrid Bergman is now 56 years old, her affair with Roberto Rossellinl two decades past, and she has been interviewed so often that her views are wellknown. But she is still beautiful, her affair is not forgotten, and people seem never to tire of hearing her views. Thus, when Miss Bergman, who performing at the Kennedy ,Center Opera House in Washington, appeared the National Press Club last week, she drew a sellout audience (500) as large as any attracted by the Kings, Prime Ministers and astronauts who have lunched at the club. She fielded the natal questions about her favorite role (Joan of Arc), Xrated movies (You don't need nudity) and others with such aplomb that one reporter wrote of the performance: Should Ingrid Bergman run out of roles to act, she can always play Ingrid Bergman.

title: Naval Ship Named for Black

Brown, was given the name of the Navy's first black aviator. Ensign Brown, who was from Hattiesburg, Miss., died in the crash of his plane on a Korean war mission.
