Y. The wedding is planned for September in St. Bonnet.

title: Personaland witty
description: As some interior designers reach ever higher flights of fancyplacing us all in minipalaces and 18thcentury mansions  the rebellious forces take aim on the opposite side. Young New Yorkers involved in creative careers prefer their own aesthetic judgment to that of society's gurus. This Greenwich Village duplex speaks for the opposition. It is the home of graphics designer and his wife, an illustrator and antique dealer, who can't take status that seriously. Their duplex is witty and personal, pairing notquiteantiques with street finds and a fine collection of Oriental art with European polychrome sculpture. We aren't concerned with what people think, explains the designer. What does matter is creating a visually nourishing environmentorderly enough not to be confusing and chaotic enough not to be dull.

title: Only 2 Local Candidates Enter Democratic Primary in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Voters of the District of Columbia will have a choice only between two local candidates in the city's Democratic Presidential primary May 2.

This conclusion, based on inescapable logic, seems supported by the U.S. Commander for the Pacific and Indian Ocean areas (known as CINCPAC in military jargon), Adm John S. McCain Jr.

title: Knick Work Ethic Pays Dividend
description: As the New York Knicks enter a final and meaningless week of the National Basketball Association's $2game schedule, both recapitulation of the regular season and anticipation of the playoffs point in the same direction: Don't underestimate what the Knicks can accomplish, but don't expect any Knick accomplishment to be achieved without maximum travail.

description: Season passes for the 503 municipal tennis courts will go on sale tomorrow at the five borough headquarters of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Subtitled Memoirs of a Kentish Childhood, this is a touching picture of English workingclass rural life in the twenties. Sarah Shears's father was a Regimental Sergeant Major and away for years in the Great War, her mother just making do with the help of a lodger. Sarah is bright, jumps a grade, is jumped on by a sadistic teacher and gets a stutter. Father comes home bearing gifts and good times, spoils the kids rotten, is bored with village life, rejoins the army abroad and dies there. Sarah has to leave school for service as apprentice maid for the vicar. She becomes ill, goes unattended for years for fear of the expense. End of book. Still this memoir is reminiscent of Akenfield, partly because of the great distance that separates village life of not so long ago from English village life today and partly for the social cruelties practiced by the Gentryon Sarah Shear's class.

title: Television
description: TELEVISION has given us two superstars of the professions: Marcus Welby, M.D., and Owen Marshall, Counselor at Law. But how often does the average American have to deal with his doctor or lawyer? What about those service people and tradespeople we meet almost every daythe folks who really keep the country going? They, too, deserve to be glorified.

The move reflects a further widening of the breach between environmentalists and agricultural interests in the state.

Its membership works in the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, producer of United States postage stamps and currency. That column was concerned with creation by Guildsmen of a memento of their craftsmanship prepared for the souvenir program of the International Plate Printers, DieStampers and Engravers Union of North America, of which the Guild is a unit. The union staged its 54th convention in Washington in

Starting late next month and continuing into May, Atlas Aviation Ltd. of Yellowknife, Northwest Territories, Canada, plans to provide the following, on trips limited to 10 persons at a time, at $2,900 each:

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Harold C. Schonberg, in his article, As It Was Then, Is Now... Or Is It?, takes the same limited view that has kept opera from enjoying the popularity it deserves in America. The star system which he approves is too costly and disguises many of opera's values.

title: Is Women's Lib A Passing Fad?
description: IT is curious that, in an age and nation so given over to information, we never seem to know what we want to know; in fact, the more we are told and the more we think we know, the less we really know. As a case in point, I suggest the Women's Liberation Movement. We will all accept, I am sure, that it exists, but beyond that, our certain knowledge ceases. The glare of publicity blinds us. One would like to know, for example, whether the movement, having so successfully captured our common attention, has, in fact, captured the sympathy of women, and if so, which women, and how deeply, and for how long. Are we dealing with something which matters, or which only seems to matter? Do we have here one more of those items of sociological entertainment which the educated classes invent and consume so relentlessly? Will Kate Millet and Germaine Greer go the way of Charles Reich and Timothy Leary, whom you may or may not remember; or do we indeed see the beginnings of something which will change our lives profoundly? The fact is that we do not know; not only do we not know what the future holds, which is understandable, we do not even know much about the shape of the present.

title: U.S. MINE BUREAU SCORED ON FLOOD
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 17John D, Rockefeller 4th said tonight, that the United States Bureau of Mines was responsible for supervising coal waste structures such as the one that collapsed at Buffalo Creek on Feb. 26, killing at least 117 persons.

title: Movies
description: REMEMBER Merrie Spaeth? In the movie, The World of Henry Orient"? It was the big Easter attraction at the Music Hall in 1964, and Merrie played one of the two 14yearold schoolgirls who got a mad crush on Peter Sellers, an amorous concert pianist, and pursued their idol all over Manhattan, effectively putting the kibosh on his sleazy love affairs. Today, while Merrie's flamboyant pal In the film, Tippy Walker, is pursuing a career in Hollywood, Merrie, who played the quiet one, is chasing votes in Philadelphia, where she's just been named as the Republican candidate for the State Legislature from her home district, opposing Mrs. Rose Toll, the Democratic incumbent.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To The Editor: I strongly object to a statement made by Mavis Gallant in her review of Georges Lemaitre's biography, Jean Giraudoux (Jan. 30). What I fear, says your reviewer, is that his book will drop into the university circuit and die of oxygen failure. I'm sure it was meant to have a better life.

title: Television

Most, however, have been made by observers outside broadcasting, creating the impression that all laborers inside the broadcasting industry would rather remain silent on the issue. That's not entirely so.

description: The key to the stock market is the earnings outlook. That's the current opinion of Eugene C. Sit, 33, a vice president and portfolio manager of Investors Diversified Services. For the last two years. Mr. Sit has managed the IDS New Dimensions Fund, an aggressive growth fund with assets now totaling $240million. In addition, he has just been named portfolio manager of IDS Growth Fund, sold under a new contractual plan with a spread frontend load. Mr. Sit, a native of Canton, China, and a 1960 graduate of DePaul University, came East from the IDS home base at Minneapolis one day last week and was interviewed by Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Excerpts from their conversation follow:

TV: Battle of Classroom Techniques on Channel 13
description: Once upon a time, public television used to be known as educational television. The change in name was made intentionally because, depressingly enough, education had become synonymous with dullness. Tonight at 8 o'clock public TV returns, for 90 minutes, to the subject of education with a documentary on Channel 13 here called What Did You Learn in School Today?

title: Murcer Hope: Southpaw Exodus
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10.On second thought, hobby Murcer thinks that Vida Blue is absolutely right to stick by his salary domands and to quit baseball.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is unfortunate Senator Muskie plans only minimal rankandfile participation in his choice of national convention delegates who will run in the June Democratic primary here. Unlike your report that Senator McGovern will hold open public caucuses to set up slates, Senator Muskie can do no better than setting a time and place in each district for interested Democrats to apply to run for delegate, (news story March 2). It appears that none of the other candidates, Democratic or Republican, plans even to give the appearance of open selection of delegate slates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 9 editorial Scrooge Goes to the Races demonstrates a woeful misapprehension of the economics of parimutuel racing. One assumes that you have been listening to one of the most expensive and certainly the most irresponsible publicity machines in the country, that of New York City's OffTrack Betting Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial Scrooge Goes to the Races (March 9), pointing out that as soon as New York City finds a device for increasing its revenuesin this instance, offtrack betting"the state comes along to grab control of the money, underlines, all too unhappily, the omnipotence of the state and the impotence of the city in the control of public revenues. The ultimate victims are, of course, the people of the city, eight million New Yorkers who, theoretically at least, have been guaranteed a measure of home rule.

description: PEKING, Monday, March 20China's top table tennis players, including the nation's foremost sports idol, will leave here March 28 for an extended tour of Canada, the United States and Mexico.

title: The Talk of Gordon, Neb.
description: GORDON, Neb., March 19 Like many towns lying near American Indian reservations, Gordon is mostly owned and operated by and for the white man.

title: MONEY RESERVES PILE UP IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, March 19 Japan's foreignexchange reserves are so embarrassingly large, maybe she should just buy Papua New Guinea. There are a lot of minerals there.

title: Daley on the Defense In Illinois Tomorrow
Dutch Immigrant Wins
description: ST. JAMES, LI., March 19Dutch Immigrant, piloted by Marty deLeyer, won the intermediate jumper championship at the Hollandia Farms horse show today with 8 points: Mr. and, Mrs. Joseph Cousins's Dutch Tide also finished with 8, so a coin toss decided the title.

title: Three Oil Concerns Agree In Principle to Iraq Pact
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19: (AP)The three Westernowned oil companies operating in Iraq have agreed in principle to a 20 per cent participation by the Iraqi Government in the ownership of their concessions, the official Iraqi news agency, reported today.

title: Gibson Is Irish as Newark Hails St. Pat
description: NEWARK, March 19  The Irish marched today down Broad Street in Newark, a city they have largely abandoned.

title: Communist Paper Moving
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 19, (UPI)  People's World, the principal West Coast newspaper of the Communist party, is moving its editorial offices to Berkeley. The Pacific Publishing Foundation, Inc., said the paper would take over Finn Hall, which has served for years as the party's Northern California district meeting place.

title: Shipment of Rhodesian Ore Set to flock in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (UPI)A shipment of Rhodesian chrome orethe first to enter the United States since the United Nations placed trade sanctions on Rhodesia's white minority Government six years agopassed quietly through the port of New Orleans today.

title: Defenses Bolstered
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, March 19The bad guys have gone 20th century, the young Air Force pilot said He was still shaken by a barrage aimed at his small observation plane by antiaircraft gunners on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 4 Die in Crash in Maine
description: RICHMOND, Mc., March 19 (AP)  Four persons were killed tonight in a cartruck collision in this Sagadahoc County town, the police said. Identities of the victims were withheld temporarily.

title: Mutual Aid Pact Signed
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 19 The friendship treaty signed by India and Bangladesh today contains mutual defense clauses similar to those in the treaty India signed with the Soviet Union last August, linking the three nations in a kind of collective security arrangement.

title: 40,000 See Swallows Return to Capistrano
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif March 19 (UPI)A crowd of more than 40,000 persons, most of them bundled against the early morning chill and a light drizzle, let out the traditional roar when the bells of San Juan Capistrano Mission sounded at 7:47.23 A.M. today to signal the return of the swallows.

title: Asbury Park Holds Parade
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 19A throng estimated by City Manager William Shiel at more than 75,000 lined the boardwalk here today to watch a St. Patrick's Day parade he described as an ethnic ensemble of 25 bands and more than 50 marching units. The marchers included black contingents, military units and school bands from all sections of New Jersey and surrounding states.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.The night of President Nixon's speech on busing, Senator George McGovern was here at the University of Illinois, speaking to nearly 3,000 students jammed into the auditorium. Just before nine o'clock he said he thought everyone should hear the President, A small television set was brought on stage, and a microphone held up to it so the sound came over the loudspeaker system.

title: The Indian Ocean Contest: I
description: ROXBURY, Conn.In the age of the missile and the nuclear warhead, the Indian Ocean, the world's third largest, represents a vast launching pad for missilefiring submarines.

title: Belgian Cardinal Bids Church Respect Past Amid Reform
description: Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, Roman Catholic Archbishop of MalineseBrussels, Belgium, and an outspoken advocate of church reform, warned churchgoers yesterday against breaking with the past.

title: $12,000 Stolen Outside Bank
description: A bank bag with $12,000 from the Eden Transportation System, Inc., a Bronx cab company, was stolen yesterday by two gunmen hiding in a parked rented truck as two cab employes were about to drop the money in a night depository of the Royal National Bank of New York at 326 East 149th Street.

title: Grass Signs Miss Phillips
description: Margaret Phillips has been signed for Keep Off the Grass, the new Ronald Alexander comedy, opening at the Longacre Theater during the week of April 24 under the auspices of Shepard Traube and Edwin S. Lowe.

title: Sports of The Times
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla.Among giants of American letters, perhaps the least appreciated are the authors of those little paperback booklets called rosters or press guides, which major league baseball teams publish each year. The men who create this prose are not eligible for the Nobel Prize, which is a pity, for Burton Hawkins clearly deserves one. But Hawkins, who used to be a newspaper man in Washington, now doubles as road secretary and flack for the Texas Rangers, who are the Washington Senators twice removed. (The original ones removed to Minnesota.) In the Rangers press guide for 1972 there appears this line:

title: Steel Shipments Rise Sharply, With Users Building Inventory
description: PITTSBURGH, March 19 Steel users spent last week building inventories. After reducing stocks by 12 million tons since last August, users were in the process of adding as much as onehalf million tons in March.

title: Vida Blue Meets With Finley But A's Ace Is Still Unsigned
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 19 (AP)Vida Blue, the Oakland Athletics pitcher who announced his retirement from baseball rather than accept a $50,000 contract, talked with his former boss over the weekend: It was the first personal contact between Blue and the A's owner, Charles O. Finley, since Jan. 8.

title: SIDNEY ROSENAU
description: Sidney Rosenau, fornier president and chairman of the board of Rosenau Brothers, manufacturers of children's wear, died yesterday at his home, 465 Park Avenue. His age was 88.

title: Pruning and Adaptation
description: WARSAW, March 19 Sesame Street, aimed at giving preschoolage children some basic learning skills in an amusing fashion, will be shown on Polish educational television after some major pruning and adaptation to make it suitable for Polish viewers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 3 editorial Contented Colonials is in my opinion onesided and biased and falls to inform your readers about the real issue in the problem of Gibraltar.

title: U.S. DENIES REQUEST FOR FILES ON I.T. &T.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Justice Department has refused to provide the Senate Judiciary Committee with the department's files on the settlement of antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: The Chossudovsky Plan
description: With President Nixon's visit to Moscow now only two months away, an unusually thoughtful and candid proposal for sweeping EastWest cooperation has just been published in this country by a loyal Soviet citizen who is also a highranking United Nations official. The article appears in Foreign Affairs where, those with long memories will recall, Nikita S. Khrushchev published his position paper just before coming here in September 1959.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your correspondence columns are filled daily with letters concerning problems which have no solutions short of eternity or Utopia. Here is a nationwide, perhaps worldwide, problem to which there must be a solution the failure of elastic in men's pajamas.

title: MRS. SIDNEY HOMER
description: Mrs. Marion Symrnes Homer, wife of Sidney Homer, a limited partner in Salomon Brothers, investment bankers, died Saturday in Tucson, Ariz., while on vacation. She lived at 36 Gramercy Park East..

title: Hempstead Loses U.S. Housing Funds For 70 Apartments
description: The Federal Government has refused to finance a housing project for a predominantly black area In the Town of Hempstead, L. I, until the town agrees to build. another project for lowincome tenants in predominantly white area.

title: ... and Clean Waters
description: The waterpollution control bill, which Senator Muskie sponsored and his colleagues long ago approved by vote of 86 to 0, is even more farreaching and hence worse trouble. Between heavy fire from industry and moderate fire from the Administration the Senate bill may be shot down, or existing controls may be seriously weakened in the name of improvement.

title: Percherons Head for History's Pasture
description: LE PINAUHARAS, France, March 13Even here in the Cradle of the Race, the Percheron is fallen on hard times.

title: Dr. George James Dead at 56; Mt. Sinai Medical School Dean
description: Dr. George James, dean of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, president of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and a former New York City Health Commissioner, died of a heart attack yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, L.I. He was 56 years old and lived at 45 East 89th Street.

title: President to Confer Here Today With Officials on Drug Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 President Nixon will fly to New York tomorrow to confer with state, local and Federal officials on the problems of drug abuse. Among those with whom Mr. Nixon will confer at Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan are Governor Rockefeller and officials in charge of the first of nine regional centers for drug abuse law enforcement.

title: Busing in New York: Ambivalence, Not Outrage
Cologne Hails Iowa Soprano
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, March 19  Carole Farley, a 23yearold soprano from Iowa, had a successful debut in Germany Friday night, singing the title role in the Cologne Opera production of Alban Berg's Lulu. She got 15 curtain calls. Her mastery of the German text was impressive and there were many favorable comments on her diction.

title: Chou Charges an Attempt To Split Sihanouk Group
description: PEKING, March 19Premier Chou Enlai charged tonight at a banquet for the former Cambodian Head of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, that certain powers were creating a third force to seek a cornpromise solution in Cambodia, in an attempt to split the ranks, of the Prince's government in exile.

title: Crum of Louisville Now Awaits U.C.L.A.,a Giant He Recruited
description: The National Collegiate Athletic, Association regional basketball championships took an odd bounce Saturday. As a result of Louisville's victory, the Cardinals coach, Denny Crum, now takes his club to Los Angeles to try to beat the University of California, Los Angeles, a team he recruited.

title: Turks in Cyprus Rebuild Town in No Man's Land
description: SELEMANI, Cyprus, March 19Two old people came home todaya man, bent and gnarled like the branches of the battered trees of this hillside village, and his wife, so aged and spent that when she was lifted off the truck that brought her she could only sit on the ground with her back leaning against the shins of a woman posted behind her.

title: Man in the News
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 19  Since William Christie was named the next Lord Mayor of Belfast, two of his paint stores here have been, blown up. Two other Christie stores have been burned elsewhere in Ulster and another has been reduced to half size. But Mr. Christie, who is about to assume one of the least enviable mayoralties in the world still hadat last count22 stores and was undeterred by the bombings. I don't think of myself as brave to take the job, he said. It's a privilege as well as a duty. I regard. it as the high point of my political career.

title: WILLIAM CONDON, WROTE:STRIKE LAW
description: YONKERS, 4 [March 19Former State Senator William F. Condon, who was cosponsor Of the contio,VerSial CondonWadlin Law and hid, served as chairman of, the Joint Legislative Committee.on. Insurance, died today In St. John'a Riverside Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 25 Holls Terrace North here and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Opening Up the Lists
description: Sometimes it just doesn't pay to be first. Though the feeble Corrupt Practices Act did not require him or any other Presidential candidate to do so, Senator Edmund S. Muskie in October 1970 voluntarily made public the names of those who had contributed funds to the Muskie election committee. This organization was raising Money both for Mr. Muskie's reelection campaign in Maine that year and also for his prospective Presidential campaign. None of his potential rivals followed his good example.

title: SINE NOMINE PUTS FOCUS ON BAROQUE
description: Compared to the relatively disordered multimusical revolutions of our contemporary era, the introducton of the radical new baroque style in the late 16th century and early 17th century was accomplished with sure, singleminded purpose end by composers of extraordinary genius. Harry Saltzman and his Sine Nomine Singers brought home this point with a magnificent concert Saturday night In Tully Hall, focusing on three key figures of the period: Heinrich Schutz (who died 300 years ago) and the two older Italian composers who especially Influenced him, Giovanni GabriMonteverdi.

title: A SEAPLANE WITH 3 HIJACKED BY COUPLE
description: KEY WEST, Fla., March 19 (AP)A neatly dressed man and woman who said they were on their honeymoon hijacked a small twinengine seaplane with three other persons aboard during a flight to the Dry Tortugas Islands today and ordered it flown to Cuba, the authorities said.

title: Parties in Michigan Unite to Raise Funds
MONTREAL BROKER LOSES COURT ROUND
description: MONTREAL, March 19 Judge Francois Auolair has rejected an application by the Montreal brokerage house of Holland Andrews Perrier & Co.. Ltd., for an interlocutory injunction preventing the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges from hearing charges, against it. The judge said he found the application premature and without sufficient grounds.

title: Zaire Troops Said to Disarm Angolan Guerrilla Mutineers
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 19 (UPI) Troops from Zaire hacked by tanks disarmed Angolan guerrillas in a training camp 160 miles west of here after the guerrillas mutinied and shot three of their officers to death, Government officials said today.

title: Lithographer Union to Join Bookbinders on Labor Day
description: A new Graphic Arts International Union is scheduled to be created next Labor Day by combining the 70,000member International Brotherhood of Bookbinders and the 60,000member Lithographers and Photoengravers International Union A. F. L.C. I.O.

title: LAURA E. LYON
description: Laura Elisabeth Lyon, member of the staff of The New York Review of Books, died Friday of a septic embolism of the lungs in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 24 years old and lived at 20 West 16th Street.

title: Common Market Experts To Reassess Farm Policy
description: PARIS, March 19Earlier I this year in the debate between two Common Market commissioners over some vitally, important principles of the farm policy, it was said that Sicco Mansholt won the battle but lost the war.

title: Memorial for Miss Wise
description: The memorial service for Ethel H. Wise, the welfare leader and former Board of Correction chairman who died March 5, will be held at Temple ErnanuEl, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, Thursday at 4 P.M.

title: G.A.O. Says Navy Misleads Congress on Torpedo Cost
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters)  The General Accounting Office has accused the Navy of misleading Congress by understating the cost of developing and producing a new, submarinekiller torpedo by up to $800million, a Representative said today.

title: Miss Doris Bleach Bride of Ezra Siff
description: Miss Doris Bloch, daughter of Mrs. Hersch Blech of Brooklyn and the late Rabbi Bloch, was married in Brooklyn last evening to Ezra Yehudah Siff, son of Mrs. Ephraim Siff of Jersey City and the late Mr. Siff.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: BOX OFFICE OPENS TODAY for the new musical comedy SUGAR at the MaJestic Theatre, W. 44 St. (advt.)

title: City Hall Notes
description: The city administration is redoubling its efforts to keep any neighborhoodgovernment referendum off this year's ballot. It looks as if the effort will work.

title: Sally Kingman Wed to Mark H. Reed
description: WAYZATA, Minn., March 19Miss Sally Welles Kingman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.. Henry S. Kingman Jr., was married here last night to Mark Honeywell Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lachlan Reed and grandson of Harold W. Sweatt, retired chief executive officer and honorary board chairman of Honeywell, Inc.

title: BHUTTO DAMPENS PEACE PACT HOPE
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 19 President Zulfikar All Bhutto, who returned here last night from Moscow, Indicated today that a peace settlement on the subcontinent was as distant as ever.

title: OpenPit Mining: Vise for Upper Michigan
description: MARQUETTE, Mich. Many residents of Michigan's Upper Peninsula consider themselves trapped by a major industry in a cruel, but classic economicenvironmental squeeze from which they see no easy exit.

title: News Analysis
description: CHICAGOOn the morning after the Florida primary, the politicians lounged around the swimming pools of Miami and Miami, Beach and guessed, like everyone else. One of the things they guessed, as they mulled over the muddled Florida results, was that no one would be able to put together a firstballot majority at the Democratic National Convention and that this would help Edward M. Kennedy. Mr. Kennedy, Democratic Senator from Massachusetts, brother of an assassinated President, brother of an assassinated Presidential candidate, does not agree.

title: New Delhi Bars a Flight Of U.S. Embassy Plane
description: NEW DELHI, March 19 (AP) The Indian Government has refused permission for Ambassador Kenneth B. Heating to use his embassy plane to fly to the dedication of a hospital built mostly with United States aid and donations, an American spokesman said today.

title: POMPIDOU'S VISIT WITH HEM MS IN PARTIAL ACCORD
description: LONDON, March 19Prime Minister Heath and President Pompidou of France ended two days of talks today in general agreement on the major goals of an enlarged European community, but apparently still at odds on some of the methods to achieve them.

title: DANIEL ARYAN
description: Daniel Aryan, a lawyer for 39 years, died yesterday at the White Plains Hospital after short illness. He was 92 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Princeton and Niagara Advance in N.I.T.
Musical Booked at Edison
description: That's Entertainment has been booked into the Edison Theater where it is slated to open April 13. The musical, produced by Gordon Crowe and based on hit songs of previous stage successes composed by Arthur Schwartz with lyrics by Howard Dietz, is directed by Paul Aaron.

title: Herrera Stops Olivares in 8th And Gains Bantamweight Title
description: MEXICO CITY, March 19 (AP)Rafael Herrera of Mexico won the world bantamweight title tonight with an eighthround knockout over a fellow Mexican, Ruben Olivares.

title: Impact of Youth Vote Slight in Primaries
Program by Watts Tests New Ground With Eager Skills
description: Unlike many young pianists, Andre Watts plays like oneand in the very best sense. He is full of fresh ideas and eager to communicate them; furthermore his polished virtuoso keyboard address is always governed by a constantly developbility.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: ENACTED

title: China Reports Finding Of 2 Huge Tang Tombs
description: HONG KONG, March 19 (UPI) Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today that Chinese archeologists had recently discovered the huge tombs of two medieval princes near the tomb of Empress Wu Tsetien of the Tang Dynasty, who ruled from 690 to 705 A.D.

title: Stricken Tanker Safe in Port
description: BOSTON, March 19 (AP) The 790foot tanker Texaco Pembroke, disabled by an engine breakdown at sea, reached port safely today at the end of an oceangoing tugboat's towline. The tanker sent out a call for help yesterday when her engines quit 50 miles east of Cape Cod as she sailed for the Persian Gulf to pick up cargo of oil.

title: FordCaprl Drivers Win
description: MONZA, Italy, March 19 (AP)  Gerard Larousse of France and Jochen Mass of Germany, in a FordCapri, won the FourHour of Monza auto race today. They covered 486 miles in 4 hours 1 minute 34.09 seconds for an average speed of 121 miles per hour.

title: Paris Theater Fete Will Stress Novel and Experimental Themes
description: PARIS, March 19This year's Theatre des Nations Festival will have some novel, experimental features, according to its new director, JeanLouis Barrault.

title: 17 Killed in Turkey
description: SAMSUN, Turkey, March 19 (UPI)A minibus and passenger bus collided headon today, killing 17 persons and injuring 15 others near Carsamba, 56 miles east of this northern Turkish seaport.

title: Alice Moore, ExPrinoipal Of Peking American School
description: POTOMAC, Md., March, 19Alice F. Moore, retired principal of the Peking. American School in China, died Friday at the age of 87.

title: Nathan's Employes Protest a Dismissal Over Pizza Dispute
description: Countermen and other employes of Nathan's Famous Inc. picketed the Times Square, Greenwich Village and Coney Island Restaurants yesterday in a dispute stemming from the baking of a pizza.

title: BrainDamaged Girl Found Fatally Stabbed in Queens
description: The father of a 17yearold braindamaged girl found her stabbed to death in her bedroom yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Peter Flanigan, the White House jackofAll Trades: A Problem Solver to Admirers, a Fixer to Critics
description: WASHINGTON, March 19To his admirers, Peter M. Flanigan is a skilled problem solver. To his critics, the White House aide is a manipulating fixer.

title: MRS. WALTER FURMAN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 Mrs. Gertrude Workman Furman, a former actress under her maiden name and later a playbroker in New York with the old Century Play Company, died here Friday night. She was 87 years old.

title: Myra Skluth Is Bride Here
description: Miss. Myra Louise Skluth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. L. Herbert Skluth of Norwalk mid Woodbury, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Stephen Zeche, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Zeche of New York. Rabbi Reuven Siegel performed the ceremony at the East 55th Street Synagogue.

title: RALPH C. JONES
description: Ralph C. Jones, owner of the Humbert &.Tones advertising agency, which serves automotive parts manufacturers and industrial clients, died Friday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. His age was 74.

title: Chess: Glory That Was Spain's No Longer Found in Chess
Pakistani Nationalization
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 19The life insurance business in Pakistan has been nationalized, effective immediately, it was announced today in a presidential order. The 43 companies involved will continue to handle other insurance.

title: Bridges Enters Negotiations For a Hawaii Dock Contract
description: HONOLULU, March 19 (UPI) Harry Bridges took a direct hand today in negotiations; for Hawaii's 900 dock workers:

title: Convertible issues Stirring a. Hubbub In Eurobond Arena
description: BRUSSELS, March 19Suddenly, there is a boom for convertible securities on the Eurobond market.

title: Bill by Steingut Proposes Mayoral Primary Runoff
description: ALBANY, March 19  Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, the Democratic minority leader, has quietly introduced in the Legislature a bill providing for a twocandidate runoff election if the primary election for Mayor of New York City next year does not produce a single candidate with a majority of his party's vote.

title: Nixon to Ask Minority Business Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 19President Nixon will ask Congress tomorrow to enact legislation aimed at providing more private investment money to help minority business.

title: Victory for 2 Local Seniors
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19The New York team of Peter Lemon and Amerigo Domestico won the senior doubles title in the Middle Atlantic badminton championships today, defeating Bill Goodman of Boston and Ed Phillips of Warwick, R. I., 315, 153, 155, at the Wissahickon Badminton Club.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EVANSTON, Ill., March 19 (AP)Tom Okker of the Netherlands captured the $10,000 top prize in the $50,000 Kemper open tennis tournament today with a 4.6, 62, 6.3 triumph over Arthur Ashe.

title: 97% of Poles Turn Out in Election Endorsing Gierek
description: WARSAW, March 19Poland's voters today provided Edward Gierek, the Communist party leader, with the endorsement Ye had been seeking to begin the last stage of his national reform program.

title: City to Let Children Visit Parents in Jail
description: Within the next few clays, children will be allowed to visit their mothers or fathers in the city's jails, according to Benjamin J. Malcolm, the Commissioner of Correction.

title: Buzzards Follow Flight Plan in Return to Ohio Town
description: HINCKLEY, Ohio, March18The buzzards returned to Hinckley today pursued by 25,000 curious sightseers eager for some reason, for a glimpse of the baldheaded birds.

title: Virginians Back Busing
description: RICHMOND, March 19 (AP)  The Virginia Crusade for Voters, starting a drive to have half a million black voters registered in the state by November, adopted a policy statement today endorsing school busing. as a valid tool to achieve quaiity education.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, March 19, ReutersRichard W. McLaren, formerly chief of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, said today that he was unaware of I.T.T.'s reported pledge of money to the Republican National Convention when he settled a monopoly case involving the corporation last year.

title: Arts Abroad
description: ROMEThe genius for selfmockery that flavored some of the most successful Italian films pervades the lone hit in a generally humdrum Roman theatrical season.

title: Secondary Offering Reset On Seaboard Coast Stock
description: A secondary offering of 435,000 shares of Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Inc., common stock, which a Morgan Stanley & Co. group had been expected to make on March 9, now is scheduled for this Thursday. The shares are being offered for sale by estates of one of the founders of the former Atlantic Coast Line Railroad.

title: It's Spring Again, a Bit Early This Year
description: Spring, a little early this year, thanks to Leap Year, arrives at 7:22 A.M. today as the sun crosses the equator to spend six months in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: Stage: An AllMale Trojan Women
description: At the Theater of the Lost Continent (113 Jane Street) in Westbeth, Donald L. Brooks has staged an allmale Trojan Women. Next month Joseph Papp will open an allmale Antony and Cleopatra at the Public Theater. Perhaps, as reprisal, Women's Lib should present en allfemale Julius Caesar or The Boys in the Band.

title: Aqueduct Stays Shut; Talks Resuming Today
description: Negotiations to settle the dispute between the New York Racing Association and the Independent Association of Mutuel Employes will resume at 3:30 P.M. today. The dispute has kept Aqueduct closed since March 6.

title: Concern on Viruses In Water Supplies Stressed by A.M.A.
description: The American Medical Association has called attention to the growing concern about pollution of water supplies in this country with viruses that cause infectious hepatitis and other diseases.

title: The Indian Ocean Contest: I
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Some commentators saw the statements about Taiwan in the Shanghai communique of Feb. 27 as the only concrete results emerging from President Nixon's talks with Chou Enlai. They said that the United States had made great concessions on Taiwan, without compensatory concessions from China, and that the settlement of the Taiwan issue was now clear because the door had been closed to a separate Taiwan. Neither of these conclusions is correct; in fact in both cases the exact reverse may be more accurate.

title: Shanker Boycotts Teachers'
description: Albert Shanker, the teachers union leader, refused to attend the annual luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association yesterday because the guest speaker was Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of, the militant Jewish Defense League.

title: Thomas Ahto, Lawyer, Marries Miss Lunitz
description: MILLBURN, N. J., March 19 Miss Judith Lunitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lunitz of Teaneck, was married here this evening to Thomas N. Ahto, son of George Ahto of North Bergen and the late Mrs; Ahto. Rabbi James Perman performed the ceremony at the Short Hills.

title: New District Maps
description: The State Legislature approved this month new Congressional District lines. Maps showing old districts and new ones in New York City and Rockland, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties appear on Page 46.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times of Feb. 27 published an article concerning a study by a state panel and recommendations with reference to a proposed uniform law pertaining to the acquisition of real property by reason of eminent domain. Such cases are referred to in some jurisdictions as appropriation cases and in others as condemnation cases. These recommendations leave much to be desired.

title: Advertising: Criticism of Nation's Press
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 19Two top advertising executives, whose agencies place over $1billion a year in advertising, yesterday charged the media with unfair coverage of their industry and said that something should be done about it,

title: Secret Service to Protect 5 Democratic Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally has decided that the Secret Service will protect five Democratic candidates for the Presidency. The protection, which begins tomorrow morning, will not include Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who has said he is not a candidate, Mayor Lindsay of New York or Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn.

title: 21 Killed in Crash Near Aden of EgyptianChartered Jet
description: CAIRO, Monday, March 20 (UPI)A Yugoslav DC9 twinengine jetliner, chartered by Misrqir Airlines of Egypt, crashed into a mountain near Aden in Southern Yemen last night, killing all 21 persons aboard, the semiofficial Middle East News Agency said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Yorkers can now apply for passports at any 61 post offices in the city, a spokesman for the post office announced yesterday. The passport applications are processed at the post offices and sent on to the State Department. The fee is $12

title: RED LANDS TO SEE SESAME STREET
description: Sesame Street, the television series for children, will soon be shown on a regular basis in Poland and Yugoslavia and perhaps in Rumania, Hungary. and Czechoslovakia.

title: Chinese, U.S. Teams Named
description: A Chinese table tennis team of 24 players that will play exhibitions in New York and other American cities was named in Peking. The United States selected 19 players to compete against the Chinese in the series. DalJoon Lee, who retained his national championship last night, is on the American team. Details, Page 53.

title: City Is Giving Its Superagencies More Authority Over Funds
description: The Lindsay administration has initiated sweeping management changes that strengthen the superagencies by enabling them to hire, promote, transfer and grant merit increases to city employes without the approval of the Budget Bureau.

title: CHINA AIDS LATINS ON OCEAN CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 19China has become in recent months an outspoken champion of the claim made by LatinAmerican countries to sovereignty over 200 miles of sea adjoining their coasts.

title: Schwarzkopf Stage Art Glows in Recital
description: Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, her famous million candlepower smile beaming light to the farthest crannies of Carnegie Hall, stood onstage at the conclusion of her recital Sunday afternoon like a queen accepting the homage of her loving subjects. And why not? The lieder program that she had given deserved every decibel of cheering and applause it received. It was a tour de force of theatrical craft and interpretative intelligence.

title: A Bust of Eisenhower Unveiled in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  A memorial bust of President Eisenhower by Felix W. de Weldon, the sculptor, was unveiled today at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a gift of the Texas State Society of Washington.

title: Bread Quartet Adds Lively Twist to Pop With Melodic Rock
description: Was ever a pop group more accurately named than Bread? For those who've lived in Afghanistan for the last five years, bread is a commonly used euphemism for money, and the pleasantly melodic rock produced by Breadthe group has made it one of the most successful rock bands in the country.

title: Hutchins, Stevens Score
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., March 19 (UPI)Sonny Hutchins of Richmond and Carl (Bugs) Stevens of Rehoboth, Mass., drove their Chevrolets to victory today in the Dogwood 500 Doubleheader Classic at Martinsville Speedway.

title: Thoeni Finishes 2d in Slalom To Win 2d World Cup in Row
RATE RISE POUND LIKELY TO GO ON
BIG BOARD BEGINS AUTOMATION UNIT
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it has begun a pilot project to test the automated execution of 100share market orders on the trading floor.

title: Unlumping the Budget
description: Some $200 million of the $1.8 billion contained in the city's new capital construction budget is reserved for lump sum appropriations, only vaguely defined by broad category. The lumpsum appropriation is not new, but the growth in its use under the Lindsay administration has now pitted the Mayor against members of the City Council and the Board of Estimate. The dispute ranges one good principle of budgetmaking against another good one.

title: 10,000 IN BELFAST JOIN CATHOLIC RALLY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 19 (AP)  About 10,000 demonstrators marched Itr a Roman Catholic district of Belfast today at the end of a St. Patrick's Day weekend that saw gunfire in scattered areas.

title: Doctors Find Many WorkRelated Ailments Difficult to Diagnose
description: Two doctors haVe solved the mystery of why a 50yearold female electronics worker suffered 40 attacks of gripping chest pain, fever to 104 dcgrees, sweating, shivering, sore throat, difficult breathing and weakness during a ninemonth period.

title: DAVIS CUP SERIES CLINCHED BY U.S.
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 19 (Reuters)The United States clinched the Davis Cup tennis series with the Caribbean Commonwealth today when Erik Van Dillen and Stan Smith beat Richard Russell and Lance Lumsden, 6.4, 62, 60, in the doubles.

title: lobby Allison Triumphs
description: HICKORY, N.C., March 19 (AP)  Bobby Allison, experimenting with a smaller 366cubicinch engine in his Chevrolet won the Hickory 276 Grand National East stock car race today. It was his first victory this year.

title: Risking Ulster Backlash
description: Protestant militants had two related objectives Saturday in organizing Northern Ireland's biggest political rally in half a century. They sought to strengthen Prime Minister Faulkner's hand for crucial talks with Prime Minister Heath in London Wednesday, and to warn a violent Protestant backlash if Britain should concede too much to Ulster's nationalist and Catholic minority.

title: Private DayCare Centers: Booming Business
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Laurie Hanson is a bouncing, blond 4yearold whose day begins at 7:30 each weekday morning when her mother, who works in a nearby factory, leaves her at the Learning Tree daycare center in suburban Robbinsdale.

title: Theater: A Quietly Rewarding Web and the Rock
5 Inmates and 2 Guards Hurt In New Walpole Prison Clash
description: WALPOLE, Mass., March 19 (AP)  Prison guards clashed with 18 inmates resisting a prison lockup today at the Massachusetts State Prison here, the authorities said, and five prisoners and two officers were injured.

title: Tax Avoidance Said to Rise As Amount of Income Does
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)  The higher you climb above the middleincome brackets, the better your chances, of paying no income tax at all, says Representative Henry S. Reuss; Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: It's Time to Find the Fashions, to Go With That Racquet
description: Ten and a half million people get on tennis courts often enough to be termed players, according to the United States Lawn Tennis Association, but that's just the tip of the iceberg, manufacturers of tennis fashions insist.

title: Proposed South Bronx High School Gets Off GroundBut Barely
description: Construction of a proposed high school for the South Bronx will beginbut just barelyin the near future, members of the community planning board learned last week.

title: PIANO SKILL SHOWN BY LAURENCE WILSON
description: Laurence Wilson brought unlusual intellectual focus to his piano recital yesterday afternoon at Tully Hall by playing three examples of the theme and variations form. Mr. Wilson, a member of the Manhattan Community College faculty, devoted the second half of his program to the two books of Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Paganini (Op. 35); the first half included two sonatas whose longest movements were also cast in the variations form the Beethoven Sonata in A Flat (Op. 26) and George Walker's Sonata No. 1.

title: MRS. GEORGE HOURWICH
description: Mrs. Andria Taylor Hourwich of 133 East 38th Street, a former editor of American Labor Education Service publications, died Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 66 years old and was the wife of George KeAan Hourwich.

title: Books of The Times; Young Blood and Cutts (Sic)!
description: After wading through military historian Martin Blumenson's eighth book, The Patton Papers, 18851940, I confess that what springs first to mind are about a dozen reasons why not to recommend this bulky tome. Nearly a thousand pages of personal correspondence, articles, lecture notes, and so forth by a soldier primarily remembered as a man of action? A thousand pages that don't begin to cover the period of Patton's greatest fame and notoriety  19401945, when he was promoted through the ranks of general officer and came to be regarded by some as the American soldier most responsible for victory in World War II? Who cares? Who needs the eyestrain?

title: Advertising:
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., March 19Officers and members of the Advertising Council, the advertising industry's esteemed volunteer public service organization, heard the suggestion here yesterday that they disband the council because it is no longer relevant.

title: Bullets Win Central Title By Turning Back Celtics
Life Magazine Says the Administration Blocked Prosecution of Donors and Nixon Friends in San Diego
description: The Nixon Administration was accused by Life magazine yesterday of having seriously tampered with justice in San Diego to protect highly placed campaign contributors and friends of President Nixon from criminal prosecutions over the last two years.

title: Elizabeth L. Gardner Is Married
description: BELMONT, Mass., March 19 Miss Elizabeth Lynne Gardner was married this evening to Stephen. Brooks Wyman. The Rev. Ernest R. Case performed the ceremony in the Belmont United Methodist Church.

title: Ghana in Firm Hands 2 Months After Coup
description: ACCRA, Ghana, March 19Two months after staging the coup d'6tat in which one of Africa's last democracies fell, Col. Ignatius K. Acheampong has gained firm control of this steamy land, and his popularity seems to be growing.

title: MONROE IS ADDED TO CASUALTY LIST
description: Earl Monroe is the latest Knick casualty.

title: ES. COMPANIES BID FOR SOVIET TRADE
description: MOSCOW, March 19American businessmen are cultivating new markets here in the expectation that President Nixon's visit in May will lead to a relaxation of restrictions on United States trade with the Soviet Union.

title: A Magician Doubles as Dentist in Vietnam
description: RACHGOI, South Vietnam, March 9When Duong Van Nho enters a village he heads straight for the central marketplace.

title: Hersh Back From Hanoi With Prisoners'
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 Seymour M. Hersh, an American freelance journalist who returned today from two weeks in Hanoi, said tonight that he had brought back with him 259 letters from American prisoners of war.

title: Fittipaldi Triumphs in Formula 1 Race
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, March 19 (AP)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil turned in superb display of driving today for an impressive victory in the Formula I Race of Champions auto race.

title: POLICE SHIFT MADE IN FIGHT ON CRIME
description: In an action reflecting a basic reassessment of the dangers facing New York City, the Police Department is reducing by half the size of the Tactical Patrol Force and the Special Events Squad, the two units created to handle riots, demonstrations and parades.

title: 1,600 From Ethnic Groups Organize Protest Against Institutions They Say Are Destroying Central Cities
description: CHICAGO, March 19About 1,600 representatives of black, Spanishspeaking and white ethnic community groups in 50 cities organized an angry national protest here this week.; end against the institutions they say are responsible for the systematic destruction of large areas of the central cities.

title: Visual Artists Get a Handbook on the Law
description: Visual artists, whether, or struggling, rarely take the formal step of copyrighting their paintings, drawings and sculptures.

title: Bridge: Crane and Fisher Capture National Open Pairs Title
description: CINCINNATI, March 19The national open pair championship, the opening event in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here, was won last night by Barry Crane of Los Angeles and Dr. John Fisher of Dallas.

title: Soviet Union Begins Producing a New Computer
description: MOSCOW, March 19  The Soviet Union, after much delay, has begun production of a new series of advanced computers on which Russian economic planners have been counting to solve their country's critical shortage of computing power.

title: Food Talk
description: Two new natural breadsone by Arnold Bakers, the other by Pepperidge Farmsare now available in supermarkets in the metropolitan area. Neither contains any chemical preservatives or softeners. Arnold calls its bread Health Loaf Nature, and it is firm and rough textured, light brown in color and has a pleasing, nutlike flavor. Pepperidge Farms is the Sprouted Wheat Loaf. It's a compact, textured, darkcolored loaf reminiscent of homebaked bread. Both loaves retail for 51 cents, but Arnold's weighs 17 ounces (19 slices) and the Pepperidge loaf is one pound (18 slices).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I question the analogy between the suggestion for a ceasefire in Vietnam and the conciliatory British proposalof the Carlisle Peace Commission in the American Revolution. Prof. North Callahan [letter March 5] is correct in his observation that in fact the Continental Congress did turn down what amounted to a ceasefire proposal, but I take issue with his explanation.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, March 19In the Congressional reapportionment approved by the Republicancontrolled Legislature 11 days ago, the new districts were often molded to exclude or include specific ethnic groups to the advantage of favored incumbent Congressmen.

title: Queens Women Place Fifth
description: NORMAL, Ill., March 10A 5551 triumph over Long Beach State today gave Queens College fifth place in the women's national basketball tournament at Illinois State University. Immaculata College of Pennsylvania defeated West Chester State, 5248, for the championship.

title: Personal Finance: Deferred Interest
description: You may remember the advertisements run by banks and other financial institutions that said something like this: Buy certificates of deposit and defer interest payments.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 Reuters)  Chile advanced to the second round in the Davis Cup American Zone competition today by winning the doubles for an unbeatable 30 lead over Peru.

title: For a Noisy Spring...
description: Two major bills for improving the environment are approaching legislative, crises that will determine whether they are to be mere gestures or serious advances. A revised pesticide control law passed by the House will have to be greatly strengthened in the Senate if it is to afford more than weak protection against toxic substances that kill not only insects and fungi but fish, birds and mammals as well, including humans. The other measure of doubtful future is a water pollution control bill that left the Senate in robust health four months ago only to emerge enfeebled last week from the House Public Works Committee.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS UNIT CHANGES LEADERS
description: One of the oldest civil rights organizations in the country celebrated its 34th anniversary here yesterday by reaffirming its goals and by changing its guard.

title: HORSE SHOW TITLE TO PARK AVENUE
Alaska Pipeline Called Vital Despite Risk
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Department of the Interior said today that no single pipeline system could be built to tap Alaska's oil riches without damage or potential threat to the environment.

title: BLOCKTRADE UNIT TO BE REVAMPED
description: The New York Stock Exchange's Block Automation System will undergo a reorganization involving the replacement of much of its existing equipment as a result of internal difficulties that finally are surfacing after months of speculation in Wall Street.

title: Democrats Plan Telethon
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Democratic National Committee plans a national network telethon costing about $1million to raise campaign funds the day before the party's national convention, the committee announced tonight. The Democrats plan to stage the 18hour telethon on the American Broadcasting television network beginning at 10 P.M. Saturday, July 8, and running to 6 P.M. the next day. Robert Strauss, committee treasurer, said the network time would cost about $700,000 and production would push the total cost to $1million.

title: Notes on People
description: Some months ago Dr. Janet Travel who was President. Kennedy's personal physician, said that Mel Baines Johnson Nugent, because of. her concern for people, would be the ideal choice as the nation's first woman President.

title: ENEMY REPULSED IN HILLS NEAR HUE
description: FIREBASE PHU XUAN, South Vietnam, March 20  South Vietnamese forces, after a week of sharp battles in the mountains west of Hue, appear to have won the first part of an annual struggle to prevent the Communist forces from attacking the populated lowland cities from their jungle base areas.

title: Commander's Wife Admits to Adultery With Navy Chaplain
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (AP)The wife of a Navy commander testified today that she had sexual relations four times with the Rev. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, who is on trial charged with misconduct by committing adultery.

title: Chilean Bus Plunge Kills 13
description: OSORNO, Chile, March 20 (UPI)Thirteen persons were killed and 34 injured when a bus with an inexperienced driver at the wheel plunged off a mountain road at Puyehue, near the Argentine border 625 miles south of Santiago, the police said today.

title: Social Security Number at Birth Urged to Curb Welfare Abuses
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Representative Martha W, Griffiths, Democrat of Michigan, proposed today that every American baby be assigned a Social Security number at birth.

title: Market Place: Annual Reports Division Details
description: A conversation with a Wall Street analyst brought nothing but praise for the annual report published some months back by Quaker Oats.

title: 27 Top Skaters Will Perform Here
description: Twentyseven of the leading figure skaters in the world will give an exhibition Sunday at Madison Square Garden as part of a 15city tour through the United States and Canada.

title: Penn Central Cuts Service
description: The Penn Central Railroad announced yesterday the immediate discontinuation of passenger service between Dover Plains and Chatham, N. Y. The, railroad said its service between Dover Plains and Grand Central Terminal would be unchanged.

title: Swallows'
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 20 (UPI)The swallows return to Capistrano last night on schedule after a 3,000mile trip from Argentina was just accidental, an ornithologist at the Museum of Natural History at Balboa Park in San Diego says.

title: Alaska: Yes, No, Maybe
description: A year ago the Department of the Interior issued preliminary statement declaring that, despite some adverse environmental impact, an oil pipeline across Alaska along the route eagerly desired by the international oil consortium was acceptable. That draft statement was so cursory in its analysis and so biased in its premises that intense criticism developed at the departmental public hearings. Under pressure of this criticism by scientists, conservationists and members of Congress, and confronted with lawsuits, the department withdrew the statement and began to prepare a complete substitute.

title: Iraq and Guerrillas Lay Plans To Balk Hussein on Federation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20The Palestinian guerrilla leader Yasir Arafat and Iraq leaders announced today that they had, agreed on practical steps to Combat King Hussein's proposal to create a federation of the East Bank and West Bank under his leadership.

title: An ExI.T.T. Aide Recalls Typing a Different Memo
description: WASHINGTON, March 20International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation released here tonight an affidavit;sworn to by one of its former secretaries saying that she had typed a memo relating to the Republican convention in San Diego but that the memorandum had not contained some of the sentences in a memo made public by Jack Anderson, the columnist.

title: CAMPAIGN DONATION REPORTED RETURNED
description: Frank Thornton, president of BarnesChase Advertising, Company and chairman of the 1968 Nixon Presidential campaign its an Diego, told The Associated. Press Press yesterday that $2,068 wag donated by the Yellow'Cab Company in that city to the campaign as reported in the current issue of Life magazine but he said that it had later been returned to the donor. It was never used In the campaign, Mr. Thornton said.

title: Lindsay Scores Humphrey
description: MILWAUKEE, March 20 Mayor Lindsay accused Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today of (moving to the right and said Mr. Humphrey could not defeat President Nixon.

title: Lord Snowdon Designs Chairmobile for the Handicapped
description: LONDONAt 42, the former Anthony ArmstrongJones, the first Earl of Snowdon, seems to have survived more than a decade of being the easiest target in Britain's Royal Family.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Ebinger Baking Company of 2290 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, one of the largest manufacturers and distributors of quality breads and cakes in the metropolitan area, applied in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday for an arrangement with creditors under, Chapter XI of the Bankrutcy Act.

title: Bridge: Tom and Granovetter Gain Share of Title on Appeal
description: CINCINNATI, March 20Two New York area experts gained a share of the open pair championship at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in the early hours of this morning.

title: Elderly Grope With Legal Knots
description: Julia Kallay was having trouble with her landlord, so the week before lastafter two months of sending in her rent check and having it returned as insufficient'she and a, fellow tenant went to a lawyer.

title: Country Music Draws LongHaired Fans
description: DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex., March 19A group of Dallas promoters experimented with a new kind of mass music festival this weekend on lonesome ranch near this hill country village 25 miles west Of Austin.

title: The Indian Ocean Contest: II
description: ROXBURY, Conn.  A new chapter m the history of the Indian Ocean opened long before the winding down of the Vietnam conflict, and the IndianPakistan war.

title: Let's Talk It Over, Mr. Grossberger
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Court on Aussie Team Opposing U.S. in Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, March 20 (AP)Mrs. Margaret Court, the 30yearold former Wimbledon champion who recently gave birth to her first child, was named today to the Australiah women's team that will meet the United States in July at Cleveland.

title: Dispute on Eastern Policy Threatens Brandt Tenure
description: BONN, March 20  Willy Brandt is facing the most critical challenge to his policy of regularizing West Germany's relations with Communist Europeso critical that it could conceivably cost him his job as Chancellor.

title: Premature Discard
description: The flat assertion by the Office of Economic Opportunity that performance contracting has failed as a means of improving learning in the public schools is an oddly quick and sweeping judgment after only one year's experimentation.

title: House Unit Reaches Agreement On Sharing Funds With States
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The House Ways and Means Committee reached agreement today on the nexttolast major issue in the revenuesharing bill. Committee members said that they might complete action tomorrow on the legislation, which provided a new form of Federal financial assistance to state and local governments.

title: Change in Highs and Lows
description: Beginning today, highs and lows listed in the left hand columns of the stockmarket tables will be for the year 1972, instead of 197172.

title: Advertising:
description: The headquarters of MEDCOM, which take up four floors at 866 Second Avenue, is notable for the sleek modernity of its appointments, the youth of its executives and the good looks of its women workers. But who notices?

title: REMAPPING PLANS SCORED AS BIASED
description: ALBANY, March 20Reports that the new Congressional District line for Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, would be amended by the Legislature to strengthen his votegetting power elicited cries of antiSemitism today from a lawyer running against Mr. Addabbo in the primary.

title: Penn Raises Tuition
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20The University of Pennsylvania has announced tuition fee increases of $250 for undergraduates and $300 for most graduate professional students, pushing the yearly cost of undergraduate and graduate tuition to $3,000 and $3,050, respectively. Tuition at the Wharton Graduate School was also raised by $100 to $3,300 per year.

title: Navy Studies Feed Whale
description: SAN ONOFRE, Calif., March 20 (UPI)Gigi the whale was lolling in a kelp bed off the Southern California coast today while the United States Navy watched from boats, helicopters and planes. Navy scientists were also using seashore monitors to study the yearling whale, which was released from captivity a week ago off San Diego with an electronic backpack sutured to her.

title: 2 Pistols Fetch $38,850
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, March 20 (Reuters)A pair of pistols made by Napoleon's gunsmith fetched a world record price of $38,850 tonight at Christie's auction galleries here. The richlyornamented, silver inlaid pistols were bought by an Italian at the first auction held at the London firm's West German branch. The pistols were made by Nicolas Noel Boutet, pistolmaker to Napoleon I and were put up for auction by princely German. family.

title: Chiang Is Reelected To Fifth 6Year Term
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, March 21 (UPI)The National Assembly today reelected Chiang Kaishek to a fifth sixyear term as President of Nationalist Chins. He ran Unopposed.

title: King of Table Tennis DalJoon Lee
description: Sometimes DalJoon Lee gets up before dawn when a business idea strikes him. I ask him what's the matter, and he tells me that he's thinking, and he has to get it down on paper, his wife, Linda, said yesterday. He's obsessed with security, with finding new ways to provide for his family. DJ doesn't ever want to be hungry again. Perhaps Lee's wish has been fulfilled. He returned home to Cleveland yesterday with a big trophy and a $1,000 check for his latest victoryin the men's United States table tennis championship on Sunday nightamid a rising tide of interest in the sport.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your zeal to protect the environment, as expressed in your editorial of Feb. 23 censuring the Brazilian Minister of Planning for welcoming new pulp mill, you have ignored some basic propositions.

title: ARTHUR D. NELSON
description: Arthur D. Nelson, a lighting director and audio engineer at WNEWTV and president of Lo, cal 794 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, died in Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday following a brain hemorrhage. He was 44 years old and lived at 22 Middle Drive, Plandome, L.I.

title: Things Look Better
description: WASHINGTONEconomic developments since the beginning of 1972 have strengthened our expectations that the year would be one of rising production, declining unemployment and a lower rate of inflation. In its January economic report the Council of Economic Advisers estimated that the Gross National Product would rise by about $100 billion in 1972, that the unemployment rate would decline to the neighborhood of 5 per cent by the year end, and that the yearend goal of an inflation rate not in excess of 2 to 3 per cent would be achieved. That is our forecast today.

title: Wall St. Broker Heads Urban Coalition Drive
description: The appointment of Salim L. Lewis, Wall Street broker, to head the 1972 fund campaign of the New York Urban Coalition was announced yesterday by Dr. Eugene S. Callender, president of the coalition, and its chairman, Walter N. Rothschild Jr.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was shocking to hear that Mihajlo Mihajlov was criminally sentenced in Yugoslavia for a letter in The New York Times.

title: General Mills Raises Earnings To Records for 3 and 9 Months
PRESCOTT JENNINGS
description: Prescott Jennings, a retired textile executive, died yester day in Boston. He was 74 years old and lived in Dover, N.H.

title: U.S. WOMEN SCORE IN FEDERATION CUP
Children Proof Packaging, On Furniture Polish Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)Citing 54 deaths in five years, the Food and Drug Administration today ordered children proof packaging for all furniture polishes that contain 10 per cent or more petroleum distillates.

title: Addicts a Growing Welfare Problem
description: The addicts arrived in the smoky morning at the BergenWillis Welfare Center in the South Bronx and waited through the junksick afternoon for the checks to come out.

title: Erich von dem BachZelewsky, SS Leader in Warsaw Razing
description: MUNICH, West Germany, March 20 (Reuters)Gen. Erich von dem BachZelewsky, the Nazi SS general who put down the 1944 Warsaw uprising, died March 8 of an undisclosed illness at the age of 73, it was announced today.

title: Service for Snow Monday
description: A memorial meeting for Edgar Snow, the American journalist who was.a friend of many Chinese Communist lead ers, will be held Monday at 5 P.M. in the United Nations Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza, at 44th Street. Mr. Snow died in Switzerland on Feb. 15 at the age of 66.

title: For Papua New Guinea, A Future Made in Japan
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, March 13At the busy Port Moresby international airport, the gateway to this Australian administered territory, each of the two Australianowned airlines employs bilingual Japanese hostesses to assist arriving Japanese businessmen and tourists.

title: Key Base Besieged
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 20 (AP)A major enemy attempt to capture the key Government base at Long Tieng, just south of the Plaine des Jarres, was reported under way today.

title: City Drug Statistics Grim
description: At least three people dead. UpWard of $3million property stolen. More than 100 persons arrested. These are the narcoticsrelated statistical facts of life in New York City on a given. day like yesterday, when President Nixon came here to highlight his concern about the problem of drug addiction.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GENEVA, March 20The International Metalworkers Federation called on its affiliated unions throughout the world today to refuse to perform any work on Spanish vessels for one week in support of the shipyard workers at El Ferrol.

title: Rifkin Plays Rags, Varied in Melody, By Scott Joplin
description: More than half a century after it was due, Scott Joplin is beginning to get the recognition he deserves. A complete collection of his piano rags has been published. His previously unproduced opera, Treemonisha, was put on in Atlanta this season. And Sunday night a program devoted to the piano rags of Scott Joplin was played by Joshua Rifkin at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Assembly Votes Bill to Amend Corroboration Section on Rape
description: ALBANY, March 20A that modifies the extent to which an alleged rape victim's testimony must be corroborated was passed today by the Assembly.

title: BALLET RAMBERT APPEALS TO YOUTH
description: LONDON, March 18  The season of new work being given by Ballet Rambert at the Young Vic has been designed with special purpose. Many new theaters are now being built, tike this one, with thrust stages in which the performing area has members of the audience sitting on three sides. The Rambert company, invited to appear in such theaters and eager to appeal to the young audiences they attract, realized that traditional works would look out of place and therefore prepared these special programs under the title Dance for New Dimensions.

title: Laotians Said to Rebel
description: VIENTIANE, March 20 (UPI) Informed sources reported today that about 1,000 Laotian taskforce troops trained by the Central Intelligence Agency rebelled against their commander over the weekend, charging that he had reneged on a promise to replace them within three months of their being assigned to Long Tieng.

title: REPRINT HOUSES VEX PUBLISHERS
description: They bear names evoking baronial English manors, their addresses are mail drops and their business is the reprint of literary classics in expensive library bindings, in some cases without permission of the original publishers. The book world calls such cases piracy.

title: FOOTWEAR PRICES TO RISE NEXT FALL
description: Footwear prices, will rise between $1 and $6 a pair next fall as a result of abnormally large buying of American hides by foreign countries, according to, domestic manufacturers, retailers and tanners. Speaking at a news conference yesterday at the National Shoe Fair, leaders of the four principal trade associations in the footwear industry said that prices would advance still higher unless temporary hide export quotas were imposed immediately.

title: MUNICIPAL BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: A syndicate that won $39.2million of New York State bonds last Wednesday cut the price by amounts that raised yields about 15/100 of a point, and then decided to split up what was still left, about $9, million to $10million, among the group's members this morning.

title: Nervousness in Moscow
description: Soviet Communist party chief Leonid I. Brezhnev confirmed yesterday foreign suspicions that the Kremlin far from fully satisfied with some major recent developments in the international arena. He betrayed a certain nervousness, particularly over the uncertain fate of the BonnMoscow treaty now being debated in West Germany and also over the possibility that secret agreements may have been concluded during President Nixon's visi to China.

title: ACCOUNTANTS SILENT ON SHEFFIELD'S DATA
description: Price, Waterhouse & Co., the accounting firm, has refused to express an opinion on the financial statements of the Sheffield Watch Corporation through Oct. 31, 1971, the watch company disclosed yesterday.

title: A Railroad Sells Past At Auction
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20 The Penn Central railroad opened a threeday auction here today of more than a million items of railroad memorabilia to raise some cash.

title: COURT TO REVIEW MIRANDA RULING
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Supreme Court agreed today to review the Warren Court's controversial Miranda v. Arizona decision on confessions It will be the first review of the decision since President Nixon's four nominees joined the Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since Mr. Nixon's announcement of a new China policy, I have searched your editorial page looking for an indictment of the Chinese Communists comparable to those of Thleu, Franco and the Greek colonels which have frequently appeared on that page. Then, in a Feb. 18 editorial, you briefly mentioned the Great Cultural Revolution, during the course of which hundreds of thousands of people were murdered. These acts you termed excesses.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 The Supreme Court, took the following actions today:

title: Cream of the Table Tennis Set
description: Marty Reisman one of tabletennis's longtime Stars and its most theatrical exponent, yesterday asked, for oldtimes sake, that he and Dick Miles be on the United States team that will face a Chinese team in this country next month.

title: Simon Lends Collection To Museum at Princeton
description: The Princeton University Art Museum, with a little help from the industrialist and art patron Norton Simon, is about to enter the big time.

title: Party Expels Habash
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20 (Reuters)Dr. George Habash, leader of the Marxist Popular front for the Liberation. of Palestine, has been expelled from the panArab movement that he helped found 20 years ago.

title: Panther Counsel Asks for Closed Trial
description: In a reversal of his position, the lawyer for Black Panther Mark Holder asked yesterday that the arsonmurder trial of the slightly built youth be closed to the press and public.

title: 28 Escape From Cincinnati Jail; 5 Captured in Massive Manhunt
description: CINCINNATI, March 20 (AP) Twentyeight prisoners, many of them armed with pistols and four of them women, escaped tonight from the Hamilton County Jail and Courthouse in downtown Cincinnati.

title: CITY TENNIS PERMITS ON SALE AT 5 SITES
L. I. Pact Signed On Minority Hiring In Building Trades
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 20 Representatives of Long Island labor unions, the construction industry and civil rights groups signed today an affirmative action plan for hiring minorities in the construtcion trades. It was the first such action in the suburbs in the country, according to Federal officials.

title: Hospitals Accused of Failure To Eliminate Rats and Roaches
description: A major public employes union yesterday made public Health Department reports that, according to the union, show most city hospitals to be rodentand roachinfested to the point where the health of patients and employes alike is endangered.

title: Noyes, Miss Conroy Take 2 Speed$,kate Titles Each
description: LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP)  Michele Conroy of Minneapolis and Bill Noyes of San Bernardino, Calif., captured two [races apiece yesterday in the North American indoor speedskating senior championships.

title: Humphrey Rated High By the Ripon Society
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)The Ripon Society,. an organization; of liberal Republicans, ranked the Senate voting, record of Hubert A. Humphrey today as the highest among candidates for, the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Lindsay Aides Volunteer To Work Without Salary
description: About onethird of Mayor Lindsay's national campaign staff has volunteered to work without pay, at least until after the April 4 Wisconsin primary, to ease a critical shortage of campaign funds.

title: Galella Story of Missed Photos Disputed by the Peter Duchins
description: Peter Duchin, the pianist, and his wife, Cheray, yesterday disputed testimony given last week by Ronald E. Galella, the freelance photographer, who is accused of harassing Mrs.. Aristotle Onassis.

title: I.T.T. Has No Comment
description: David H. Kerman, director of public information for I.T.T., said.last night that the company would have no immediate comment on Mr. Anderson's charges.

title: 6 Killed, 146 Hurt in Blast On Crowded Belfast Street
