description: To the Editor:

title: NIXON ASKS A RISE IN AID TO ELDERLY
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 President Nixon asked Congress today to provide an extra $100 million for nutrition programs for the elderly as part of what he called a comprehensive strategy for helping older Amencans.

title: The Screen:Concert for Bangladesh Now a Documentary
description: On Aug. 1, 1971, Ravi Shankar, along with George Harrison, Leon Russell, Billy Preston, Bob Dylan and several other notable performers of rock music gave a concert at Madison Square Garden to raise money for the suffering people of Bangladesh. The concert was very popular, and in general a critical success, and, in the language of public relations, a historic occasion. In time it was followed by a record album, which was followed by a charge of financial finagling, which was followed by a libel suit, which has been followed by much journalism, which is followed at last  almost eight months after the eventby a movie, "The Concert for Bangladesh." It opened yesterday at the DeMille.It is a very good movie as such movies go (and they often go quite badly), and friends who were at the concert tell me that it is a faithful reproduction of the original. This may not sound like much for a documentary filmed on the spot. But anyone who has seen many rock-concert movies will appreciate that in this one there are no unnecessary zooms, no lab-created light shows, almost no exploitation of the on-screen audience, no insistence that a concert of music is somehow a social revolution.Indeed, "The Concert for Bangladesh" exhibits less technical nervousness in the face of musical performance than any other remotely similar film I can think of. And because it is so little bothered with what it must do next, say, to turn song into cinema, it probably succeeds in moving with its people more closely, and surely differently, than the audience at Madison Square Garden could have done.There are vocal solos mostly by George Harrison, Leon Russell and Bob Dylan, but also by Ringo Starr and the remarkable Billy Preston, and there are sitar and sarod duets by Ravi Shankar and Ali Akbar Kahn. Saul Swimmer directed, and Dylan and Harrison apparently helped in editing the work of eight cameramenand I think they all deserve credit for the simplicity with which the film cuts between long shot and medium shot and often very tight close-ups, and leaves dramatic intensity to the music and the musicians, where it belongs.The worst thing in "The Concert for Bangladesh" is the sound, which is of course very loud, but neither rich nor full. Somebody had the notion of recording the audience (or an audience) response to each number and producing it from the rear of the theater as a kind of canned aid to enthusiasm. This has nothing to do with the spirit or the look of the film, and, given the reticence and intelligence of everything else, it functions essentially as promotional nonsense, a six-track stereophonic insult.

title: FORMER CHAPLAIN WITNESS AT TRIM
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 (AP)A former Navy chaplain testified today that he had been the object of pro vocative overtures in his counseling office from one of two Navy wives who have ac cused Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen of adultery.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CONSPIRACY. By John Flersey. 274 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: 2 Die as Scaffold Falls at 1 Astor Plaza
description: A metal scaffold used for window washing crashed down from the 54th floor to an eighth floor roof at 1 Astor Plaza yes terday, killing a window washer who had been standing on the scaffold and crushing to death a man who had been working on the roof.

title: Climb Is the Biggest Since Economic Curbs Began
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 The Government confirmed to day what housewives already knewthat soaring food costs, led by meat, raised overall consumer prices sharply in February.

title: Mrs. King Triumphs
description: RICHMOND, March 23, (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King defeated Nell Truman of Britain, 6.2, 75, today to gain the quarter finals of the $18,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: Reuss Calls for Starting World Monetary Reform
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Henry S. Reuss disclosed today the existence of a preliminary plan for re form of the world monetary system prepared by the staff of the International Monetary Fund. He urged that it be the starting point for prompt international negotiation.

title: Freund Opposes Bill on Negotiated Rates
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)The chief economist for the New York Stock Exchange said today that if the negotiated rate limit for commissions had been set at $100,000 last year a large number of brokerage firms would have been pushed to the borderline of survival.

title: COLOR TV RECORDER IS DISPLAYED BY RCA
description: The RCA Corporation demon strated yesterday at Indianap olis its latest color video tape cartridge recorder aimed at the consumer market. Spokesmen said they hoped to market the system by late 1973.

title: REGENTS DISCUSS ISSUE OF BUSING
description: ALBANY, March 23The State Board of Regents is ex pected to reaffirm its endorse ment of busing as a tool to achieve school integration de spite President Nixon's pro posed moratorium on busing and Governor Rockefeller's ac ceptance of the President's plan.

title: U.N. ECONOMISTS REPORT ON EUROPE
description: GENEVA, March 23The in dustrialization of Europe should be just about completed in the next 10 years, United Nations economic researchers predicted today.

title: Mikhail Kedrov, Soviet Director And Stanislavsky Protege, Dies
description: MOSCOW, March 23 Mik hail N. Kedrov, the actor and director who was one of the leading figures in the Soviet theater, died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: Ceausescu Visiting Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 23 (Agence FrancePress)  Presi dent Nicolae Ceausesco of Ru mania was welcomed by Presi dent Kenneth Kaunda at Lu saka's international airport to day at the start of a fiveday visit to Zambia. President Ceau sescu, the first head of state to visit Lusaka this year, was welcomed by a 21gun salute and traditional African dancers.

title: South Africa Opens New Local Council In SouthWest Area
description: KATIMA MULILO, South West Africa, March 23 (Reu ters)  South Africa officially opened a legislative council in the Caprivi Strip today under its policy of creating black homelands with partial internal selfgovernment in SouthWest Africa.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 24, 1972

title: Faulkner Again Confers With Heath on Crisis in Northern Ireland
description: LONDON, March 23Prime Minister Brian Faulkner of Northern Ireland flew back to Belfast tonight after a new at tempt to force changes in the longawaited British proposals for the troubled province.

title: SUGAR FUTURES SHOW DECLINES
description: For the second consecutive day prices of world No. 1.1 sugar futures declined the limit of  cent a pound across all contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Ex change.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTES CREDIT RATE LIMITS
description: HARTFORD, March 23The today to limit the interest that can be collected on retail credit on retail charge accounts and 15 per cent on bank charge accounts.

title: Military Exercise Begins
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., March 23 (Reuters)The first major joint services exercise to be held in the United States for seven years began today at this sprawling Army base in central Texas. The sixday exercise, called Gallant Hand, involves more than 23,000 men from the Army and Air Force, including Air National Guard and Air Force Reserve.

title: Goldberg Bids Congress Define President's Role in Giving Data
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Arthur J. Goldberg, the former Supreme Court Justice, urged Congress today to adopt a comprehensive statute to de fine the President's responsibil ity in furnishing vital informa tion to the legislature.

title: Soul Food and Good Music
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: JUVENILES COMPETE IN FIGURE SKATING
description: The first of more than 200 skaters from seven states be gan competition yesterday in the 50th Middle Atlantic figure skating championships at the Sky Rink. The meet, the oldest of its kind in the United States, will continue through Sunday afternoon.

title: Unconscious Is Syndicated To Combs for $1.8Million
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 23 (AP)Unconscious, a race horse on the comeback trail after treatment for a leg in jury, was sold today to a syndi cate headed by Leslie Combs 2d, a major thoroughbred breeder.

title: Price Skyrocket
description: Misguided as is the walkout of four top unionists from the Pay Board, their action does sharply raise the question of whether the Administration's antiinflation program is fairly balanced with respect to both wages and prices. That question is made sharper still by the official report yesterday that the consumer price index climbed onehalf of 1 per cent last monththe largest increase since before President Nixon's New Economic Policy was launched last summer.

title: Saigon Reports Increased Action
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 (AP)The South Viet namese command reported an increase today in enemy at tacks on its troops in South Vietnam and in part of neigh boring Cambodia.

title: and Pay Stability
description: Just as it is imperative that the price end of the anti inflation effort be tightened, there is need for preventing a new wage runaway in the wake of the walkout from the Pay Board of all but one of its labor members.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Chilly Offer
description: After a Florida Keys tech nique for luring fish to the hooks with a chum ball was described a few weeks ago in this column, it was only a matter of time before Sparse Grey Hackle, the world's most delightful cor respondent on things pisca torial, could be expected to respond.

description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Following is the text of a prepared statement by Presi dent Nixon on changes in the Pay Board:

description: A State Supreme Court jus tice reversed himself yesterday and reopened a murderarson trial to the public and press a day after the State Court of Appeals ruled that another jus tice erred in closing a trial last November.

title: Banks Will Get Stock
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Com pany reported yesterday a $47. 2million net loss, on a fully ac crued basis (including charges for interest, taxes and the like which are not being paid cur rently), for the first two months this year. This compared with a $66.3million deficit in the com parable period of last year.

title: Sharing the Blame
description: I am here as Police Commissioner to talk to you, the leaders of the legal profession in this city, about our court system. You will not enjoy what I am going to say, but somebody has to say it.

description: A 27yearold Bronx man em ployed at the Y.M.C.A.'s Sloane House was being questioned by the police and fire marshals last night in connection with the fire that killed four men and injured more than a score of others, at the Y Wednesday night.

description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The House Committee on Science and Aeronautical voted unanimously today to authorize $3.428billion to run the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's pro grams during the year starting July 1. The space agency had sought $3.379billion.

title: M'LAREN IN MEMO PUSHED I.T.T. SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Before he heard the company's special pleas, Assistant At torney General Richard W. Mc Laren argued most strongly to the Solicitor General that win or lose the Government should take one of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph merger cases to the Supreme Court.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, March 23Il linois reform Democrats con firmed today plans to challenge all uncommitted delegates to the party's national convention who were elected in the pri mary Tuesday and possibly some committed delegates as well.

title: Future in Textiles Considered Bright
description: HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., March 23Despite continuing problems of consumerism and ecology, leaders of America's textile industry struck an op timistic note at the opening of a meeting of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

title: 1,000 Protest at Rockefeller's Office To Save Hunter College's 2 Schools
description: About 1,000 students and parents from the Hunter Col lege High School and Ele mentary School demonstrated in front of Governor Rocke feller's office here yesterday in a second day of efforts to obtain enough money and po litical support to keep the schools from closing next June because of City University budget cuts.

title: The Opera
description: Two short comic operas, written by composers who were still in their 20's, pro vided a somewhat fluffy eve ning at the 92d Street Y.M. & Y.W.H.A. on Wednesday. Weber's Abu Hassan and Menotti's The Old Maid and the Thief were staged by the opera workshop of the Mannes College of Music, with full orchestral accompaniment un der the direction of Paul Berl.

title: Argentine Kidnapping Victim Says in Letter He Is Well
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 23 (Reuters)  Oberdan Sallustro, the Italian motor executive be ing held in a people's prison by his leftwing kidnappers, has told his wife in a letter that he is well.

title: Comedian's Son, Arrested
description: HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 (Reuters)Gary Lewis, 26 years old, musician son of the comedian Jerry Lewis, was charged today with possession of dangerous drugs after the police stopped his car. They did not name the drugs alleged ly found in the car.

title: Clothing, Rent and Taxes Add to Local Increase
description: Consumer prices in the metropolitan area spurted sharply last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.

title: North Korean Bids the U.S. Withdraw From the South
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 23  North Korea renewed its demand here today for with drawal of all American troops from South Korea and attacked them as imperialist aggres sors.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: JUNEAU. Alaska, March 23 (AP) The House rushed through a resolution today ratifying the amendment, but there was some doubt that the action had been taken legally.

title: Plebiscite in Poland
description: For all practical purposes, Polish Communist party chief Edward Gierek employed the recent parliamentary vote there as a plebiscite to demonstrate his nation's confidence in his new course. Less than a year and a half has passed since Mr. Gierek took power after his predecessor, Wladyslaw Gomulka, was discredited by the worker revolt of December 1970. Mr. Gierek evidently felt he had made enough improvements in that brief time to gamble on overwhelming approval in the parlia mentary election.

title: YANKEES TO STAY 30 YEARS IN PACT APPROVED BY CITY
description: The New York Yankees have committed themselves to re main in the Bronx for 30 years, and the city has undertaken to buy and improve Yankee Stadiumwhatever the cost under an agreement that won final city approval yesterday before the Board of Estimate.

title: FLYERS BOW, 42, TO BLACK HAWKS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (UPI)  Bobby Hull's 599th career goal started threegoal first period tonight that lifted the Chicago Black Hawks to a 42 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Pieces of a Puzzle
description: The work process has been much like fitting pieces of a puzzle together, begins the report of a task force of the state commission studying New York City's gov ernmental operations. Unfortunately, the most remark able quality of the report itself is that it, too, seems like a puzzlewith some of the pieces missing and others not fitting together any too well.

title: I.T.T. Dispute Helps Allende Politically
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 23  The socalled Chile papers purported to come from the files of the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion have proved a political windfall for President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Philadelphia Blacks To Plan and Build Center for Quakers
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23 The Religious Society of Friends announced today plans to build a $1.5million office center here with black contractors and a black labor force.

title: Advertising:
description: Hills Supermarkets, which with its agency, Martin Lan dey, Arlow Advertising, broke some very innovative advertising in New York area newspapers some four years ago, is adding tele vision to its effort on Mon day.

title: THALER CONVICTED IN SECURITIES CASE
description: Seymour R. Thaler was found guilty yesterday of dealing in stolen securities while he was a State Senator.

title: Niagara's Hero Blends Cool Hand, Cool Head
description: When a kid, from Harlem or BedfordStuyvesant sees Hempstead (LI.) High School behind the name of Al Wil liams in the Niagara basket ball brochure, he might imag ine that Williams is one of those blacks who escaped en tirely from the Northern black ghetto experience. Hempstead, after all, is in the suburbs, isn't it?

title: Cornell's Lacrosse Team Sets Back Hofstra, 5 to 3
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 23 Hofstra University's lacrosse team stayed with the nation's defending champion, Cornell University, for the first half today before a secondhalf surge by the Big Red netted three goals and a 53 victory.

title: J. Leonard Silver Weds Miss Tepper
description: Miss Lenore Doris Tepper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Tepper of Flushing, Queens, was married here yesterday to J. Leonard Silver, who is president of Hoffritz for Cut lery, Inc., and of Edwin Jay, Inc., its wholesale affiliate. Rabbi Jay Arthur Goldberg performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: Nevada Panel Rejects Plea By Hughes Gambling Setup
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 23 (AP)The Nevada State Gam ing Commission, accepting the recommendation of the State Gaming Control Board, refused today to approve top level changes in Howard Hughes's Nevada gambling empire.

title: Foley Sq. Injunction Denied
description: Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney yesterday denied an injunction sought by residents in the neighborhood to block the construction of an annex to the United States Court House at Foley Square. The residents had complained that construc tion would be harmful to the environment and was arbitrary and capicious.

title: BuildUp of Airfields by Hanoi Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23Intelligence reports are said to show that the North Vietnamese have recent ly built up airfields in the southern part of their country and have been promising the Vietcong and their own troops that they will begin using bombers over South Vietnam soon.

title: Maya Angelou's Lonely
description: An autobiography in 1970. A volume of poems in 1971. And a quarter of the way into 1972, one controversial film scriptGeorgia, Geor giaand another in the works. This has been the course of 43yearold Maya Angelou's writing career over the last three years. This success has whetted the appetite for more.

title: Detective Slain Alter L.I. Rites For Policeman Killed Saturday
description: FREEPORT, L.I., March 23 An offduty New York City de tective who came here to at tend the funeral of a patrolman slain on Saturday was shot and killed tonight, apparently by another policeman who attend ed the funeral.

title: STATE CATV UNIT URGED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, March 23The creation of a new state agency to regulate the cable television industry in New Jersey was recommended today by the leg islative commission that con ducted a yearlong study.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains; Truck Tonnage Advances
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week end ed March 18 totaled an esti mated 15.1 billion tonmiles, 3.1 per cent above the cor responding week last year. The Association of American Rail roads also reported carload ings totaled 502,425, down 1.9 per cent from the correspond ing week last year.

title: TWO MORE STATES RATIFY AMENDMENT
description: CONCORD, N. H., March 23 The New Hampshire legis lature ratified today an amend ment to the Constitution on equal rights for women. The Senate vote was 21 to 0 and the House vote 179 to 81. Ha waii's legislature yesterday was the first in the nation to ratify the amendment.

title: Novel Takes to the Stage In Gunter Grass Uptight
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 Conscience, commitment, the generation chasm, the nagging pain of doubt, inde cision and regret are all studied with gleeful and bale ful irony in Ginter Grass's play Uptight, which re ceived its American premiere last night in the Arena Stage's Kreeger Theater.

title: Frederick Eisner, 76, Dead; A Lawyer and Accountant
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 23  Frederick M. Eisner, a retired Certified Public Accountant and a lawyer, died of a heart at tack at White Plains Hospital today. He was 76 years old and lived at 16 Hotel Drive.

title: Moving On to Nowhere
description: BOSTON, Mass.In the United States of 1972, you do not need to prove a book of protest wrong in order to live as if you had not read it. All that you need to do is buy it, praise it, tell other people that it is very, very moving or that you feel extraor dinarily concerned about the issues that it raises, put it on your coffee table, tuck it into your bookshelf then get into something new.

title: Stage: Rain, a Period Piece, Returns
description: That old melodrama Rain really is a gloriously bad play. It was revived last night at the Astor Place Theater and against every single one of my better judgments, I found myself en joying it. It is an unusually awful play that time has over taken and made not just funnyit is a sad practice just to laugh at the past but also still strangely con vincing. It has become a period piece like Tarzan or Rudolf Valentino.

title: Enemy Blows Up Span of Main Bridge in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Fri day, March 24 (AP)Ter rorists blew the center span out of Pnompenh's main bridge today, killing at least three persons and wounding five.

title: Swede Gains in Badminton
description: LONDON, March 23 (Reuters) Stan Hales of Claremont, Calif., was badly beaten today in the third round of the all England badminton champion ships by Store Johnsson of Sweden, 152, 151.

title: Belgrade Fights Smallpox Dispatch of The Times, London
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Mar 23Two Belgrade hospi tals have been placed under quarantine an dthe entire popu lation of Belgrade is to be vac cinated within the next 48 hours because of an outbreak of smallpox in the Kosovo re gion 70 miles southwest of here. The epidemic was first re ported three days ago in the region, where two persons have died of the disease and 22 others have been hospitalized.

title: Boston Yields 16 Hits

The dead children were identified as Charmette Jones, a year old, and a brother, Lance, 3. Another brother, Lyle, 5, and a sister, Laurette, 4, and a neighbor's child, Albert McIntosh, who were also playing in the fiveroom apartment, escaped.

description: LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP)Jerry West hit a 15foot jump shot with, two seconds to play tonight, giving the Los Angeles Ulcers a 112110 victory over the Phoenix Suns and a tie for the National Basketball Association record for most victories in a Season68.

description: LONDON, March 24 (Reuters)The British Government's decision to assume direct rule of Northern Ireland will leave the province largely on the same constitutional footing as Scotland and Wales.

description: SUMMIT, N.J., March 24 Edwin Florence, who had been auditor of the electric department of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey for 28 years at his retirement in 1964, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital. He was in his 70's and lived at 66 Pine Grove Avenue.

title: INCREASE EXPECTED IN AUTO PRODUCTION
description: DETROIT, March 24 (AP)United States auto makers anticipate increasing auto production this week, the trade paper Automotive News reported yesterday.

title: COUNTER STOCKS SHOW ADVANCES
description: The overthecounter market did slightly better than the American Stock Exchange yesterday as most counter issues rose while the listed stocks finished somewhat lower.

title: Enemy Increases Activity in the Pnompenh Area
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 24Communist saboteurs knocked out Pnompenh's only bridge across the Tonle Sap River today in the third major attack on this area this week.

title: Wherein Young Ladies of Breeding Are Shewn a Genteel and Useful Skill
description: To walk down the long hallway to the small garden apartment in the rear of 332 East 66th Street is to be transported to a kinder and more tranquil era, a bygone time when little girls of 9 and 10, and a few years older, took it for granted that they would learn to sew. For here they are, sitting at two big tables, being taught to sew a fine seam by hand. They are also learning to knit and crochet What's more, they love it.

title: Tiny Niagara to Put Maryland to Test in Final Today
description: The folks at Madison Square Garden who have been bringing you the 35th National Invitation Tournament watt you to know that tickets are still available at the box office for today's final doubleheader which begins at 11 A.M. with the consolation game between Jacksonville and St. John's.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, March 24He is a peacemaker, a conciliator, a man who can disarm an opponent without stripping him of honor, a stalwart who can push the Conservative party's interests in Parliament and still keep his friendships with the opposition. Those, according to parliamentary colleagues, are the qualities William Whitelaw has demonstrated in his 21 months as Lord President of the Council and Leader of the House of Commons.

title: Dublin Hails Heath Move; I.R.A. Angry
description: DUBLIN, March 24  Prime Minister Heath's announcement of direct rule for Northern Ireland by London was welcomed today by the Irish Republic's Government and members of the Opposition. The reaction from the leadership of the Irish Republican Army was hostiles and bitter, however.

title: Kennedy Lauds Heath for Ulster Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (Reuters)Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other Congressional critics of British policy in Northern Ireland today praised Prime Minister Heath's decision to assert direct rule over Ulster.

title: 'Inn of Evil':Moody Japanese Film Arrives at Bijou
description: Masachi Kobayshi, the director whose dedication to the stylistically structured, mood-filled Japanese period piece has been distinctively illustrated previously in such features as "Hara-Kiri," "Kwaidan," and "Rebellion," is a good deal more moody and remote in "Inn of Evil," which opened yesterday at the Bijou. His somber saga of smugglers battling against sociological and psychological odds, as well as lawmen of the dim Nipponese past, demands a good deal of dedication by Occidental viewers unschooled in the background history the film does not indicate.A moviegoer unaware that smuggling was a surreptitious way of life long ago when foreign trade was prohibited is left with a nagging mystery. But the director's handling of his varied principals, working under the protection of a mysterious lord on their island inn sanctuary and grapping ineffectively with personal problems, is deft and incisive. And his points of view, slowly but meticulously presented, have a cumulative impact.This is, of course, slowly paced, often introspective, drama, interspersed by stabbings and swordplay. The beleaguered cast is often awash in the suds of soap opera but their serious, if postured, portrayals, as well as English subtitles, make it plain that this is not simply a vintage cops-and-robbers affair.The smugglers, their dour, but compassionate chief, his pretty, lovelorn daughter, a young man desperate to free his fiance from a brothel and a drunk lamenting the loss of his family, make for a convoluted tale. But they emerge as a varied, driven but unselfish lot who readily risk their lives in a final, bloody good deed.They are primitive but genuinely troubled types. And Mr. Kobayashi and the fine black-and-white photography that captures the essence of the gloom-filled script, largely succeed in illuminating their dark, forbidding enclave and the predicaments they only vaguely comprehend.

title: EXPLOSION INJURES 12 IN GARMENT CENTER
description: Twelve persons were injured, three of them seriously, in an explosion that spewed glass and flames through a fourthfloor furprocessing company in the garment district early yesterday morning.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Nixon warned today that he would take action to restrain food prices if they continued to rise and suggested that such action would be directed against middlemen rather than farmers.

description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., March 24 (UPI)  Gene Duffy, assistant executive director at the National Collegiate Athletic Association, died today of cancer at the University of Kansas Medical Center. He was 34 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A. B. Dick Company, Chicago, yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for a proposed offering, its first public offering, of 1.1 million shares of the common stock of the company. The shares being offered consist of 293,340 being sold by the company and 806,660 by selling shareholders. The company, founded in 1884, manufactures offset, mimeograph, duplicating and printing products. An underwriting group will be comanaged by William Blair & Co. and Kidder, Peabody & Co., Inc.

Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday that the company's loss from ordinary operations in 1971 was $284,520,523. This is on the basis of making full accruals for certain accounts, which currently are not being paid, such as interest on prebankruptcy debt, real estate taxes and certain rentals.

(AP)  Kathy Whitworth of Richardson, Tex., last year's leading moneywinner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, scored a suddendeath victory today over Beth Stone of Muskogee, Okla., in the first round of match play in the Sears women's world golf tournament.

title: ANYA SILJA HEARD IN SALOME AT MET
description: Richard Strauss admitted he had created an almost impossible role in his version of Salome. She has to appear young, yet have a big, luxuriant voice. She has to dance and, after that, sing a long monologue. Anya Silja sang the part for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night and met the qualifications for looks better than those for sound.

title: JAPAN SETS LOAN FOR WORLD BANK
description: TOKYO, March 24  The Bank of Japan has agreedto lend the World Bank the equivalent of $325million in yen in the largest single borrowing transaction in World Bank history. The largest previous borrowing was 5265million in the United States in October. 1968.

title: Encounter Near Preyveng
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 24 (AP)  The Saigon command reported today that South Vietnamese rangers and armored vehicles in eastern Cambodia had begun moving toward the beleaguered town of Preyveng, 30 miles east of Pnompenh. The Preyveng garrison has been under siege for five days.

title: S. Africa Beats U.S. Women in Tennis
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 24 (AP)South Africa upset the secondseeded United States today and joined Britain in the final round of the Federation Cup women's tennis competition. They will meet tomorrow for the wonten's equivalent of the Davis Cup.

title: Candidates' Day

title: Bridge, Once a Prime Target, Now Symbol to North Vietnam
description: THANHHOA, North Vietnam, March 14  The bridge at Hamrong, for many years a prime target of the air war, is riddled with shrapnel holes and blackened from blasts  but it apparently is still in daily use and is said to have been since the bombing began. For many North Vietnamese the failure of American planes to destroy it is symbolic of what they view as the failure of the air war in general.

title: COACHES RESENT FLA, STATE'S RISE TO N.C.A.A. FINAL

title: Buffalo Bus Stop
description: Fears about the hurtful effect of President Nixon's political game plan on busing have been dismally confirmed by the tripleplay from Nixon to Rockefeller to Buffalo. There was no question during that city's noisy Board of Education meeting this week that thepredominantly white audience had come armed with the President's moratorium on busing and Governor Rockefeller's vapid statement that he considered it under the circumstances a very constructive approach.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Justice Department branded as false today Life magazine's charges that the Nixon Administration had seriously tampered with justice in San Diego.

He thereby annulled a ruling by city officials that had removed them from the voting list.

description: LIMA, Peru, March 24The military Government decreed sweeping reform of education today. For the first time since the Spanish conquest, the Indians who make up twothirds of the country's 14 million people, will be tought in their languages as well as Spanish, which some 40 per cent of the population do not understand.

title: PENTAGON SUSPENDS USE OF SOME A7'S
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Navy and Air Force said today that they had temporarily suspended flight operations of 144 A7 close support bombers because of potential engine problems. The A7 aircraft on combat missions in Vietnam were excepted from the order, the Pentagon announcement said.

description: ALBANY, March 24Following are excerpts of a policy statement on school integration adopted today by the State Board of Regents, and of the three dissenting opinions, by Theodore M. Black, Joseph T. King and Helen B. Power:

title: Casper Takes 2Stroke Lead With 134
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 24Billy Casper outscored Jack Nicklaus today, led by two strokes after 36 holes in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open and changed his diet. With a fourunderpar 68 Casper brought his aggregate at the Lakewood Country Club course to 134 or 10 under par.

title: Unimpressed by Success
description: Supremacy and success in the haute couture never seemed to elate Cristobal Balenciaga, the son of a Spanish fisherman who became one of the world's most powerful influences in fashion.

title: Executive Changes
description: Sir William Lyons founder 50 years ago of Jaguar Cars Ltd., Coventry, England, has retired and R. W. England has been named chairman and chief executive of the company. Sir William, who was 70 years old last year, will assume the advisory post of president.

title: Union Ends Strike at Aqueduct And Racing Will Resume Today
description: The 19day strike by the Independent Association of Mutuel Employes against the New York Racing Association ended last night as the parimutuel union overwhelmingly accepted a oneyear contract guaranteeing jobs for all clerks who worked in 1971 and providing a wage increase of $3.11 a day in wages and benefits.

title: Balenciaga, Couturier, Is Dead
description: VALENCIA, Spain, March 24 Cristobal Balenciaga, widely regarded as the most influential fashion designer of the post World War II years, died of a heart attack in a hospital here. The 77yearold designer's clients had included many famous women, from movie actresses to queens.

title: Extortionist Gets 30 Months
description: A man who was convicted of trying to extort $500,000 from a Georgia carpet concern was given a 30month jail sentence yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan. The man, Gaetano Vastola, 44 years old, of 1335 86th Street, Brooklyn, was sentenced by Judge Lawrence W. Pierce, who continued bail for the alleged underworld figure and former union leader, pending appeal of the conviction last January.

title: N.Y. Phone Adds Directors
description: The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday the election of Edward J. Mortola, president of Pace College in New York City, and William L. Lindholm, vice chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as directors. Mr. Mortola succeeded John A. Coleman, who retired from the board, and Mr. Lindholm took the seat vacated by John D. deButts, who was recently named chairman and chief executive officer of A. T. & T. New York Telephone is a wholly owned subsidiary of A. T. & T.

title: New Road for Ulster
description: Prime Minister Heath has finally pulled British policy for Northern Ireland out of its dead end and pointed it to a new road that could lead to peace with justice for the tortured province. There are risks of violent Protestant backlash in Mr. Heath's actions, but he concluded that the graver longrun danger lay in a policy that had produced only violence and steady polarization of Ulster's two communities.

title: The Screen:
description: The weekend program at the uptown Film Forum includes 11 shorts from three directors working in the socalled window film or structural cinema category. Since the independent, experimental movie category can fly high, wild and anything but handsome, one of the most persuasive aspects of window watching is the format's basic uncluttered simplicity.

title: Port Notes

In China the dragon is thought of as an auspicioms rather than baleful creature, with the result that there is hardly a happier show in town.

The victories gave Brazil a 20 edge. Koch beat Humphrey Hose 63, 61, 26, 36, 64. Mandarino defeated Jorge Andrew Who had to quit play because of a twisted ankle while trailing 26, 04.

Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital received $2,090,000; Thomas Jefferson University, $3,564,000; Women's Medical College, $1,174,800, and Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine, $2,530,000.

description: YUMA, Ariz., March 24 (AP) The Oakland Athletics gave Tommy Davis, who batted 324 last season, his unconditional release today.

title: Price Changes
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company announced in Tokyo yesterday that it planned to increase prices on its products sold in this country by about 10 per cent, effective April 1. The rises will cover color and blackandwhite television receivers, radios and other electricappliances. The move had been expected since Matsushita raised freeonboard export prices byabout 17 per cent last January following the yen revaluation in December. However, officials of the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, the domestic subsidiary, said yesterday that they could offer no additional information on the pricing.

title: Porter at Sloane House Is Held Without Bail in Blaze Fatal to 4
description: A 27  year  old porter who was arrested and charged with homicide Thursday night in connection with a fatal fire at the Y.M.C.A.'s Sloane House was held without bail yesterday at his arraignment in Criminal Court in Manhattan.

title: 3 Detroit Policemen Charged in Shooting
description: DETROIT, March 24 Three Detroit policemen were charged today by the prosecutor's office with attempted murder in a shooting incident two weeks ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed today that the Federal Government provide financial aid to states and local governments to expand and revamp their voter registration programs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates' Day
description: MILWAUKEE, March 24Senator George McGovern, campaigning through rural northwest Wisconsin today, said that the Price Commission's forthcoming hearings on food costs will show that the American farmer has been one of the chief victims of the present inflation.

title: Henocide Is Rejected As Aid to Egg Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)  The Senate today voted down, 48 to 23, a bill that would have authorized the slaughter of millions of hens in an effort to drive up egg prices, which are at 40year lows.

title: SEA VIEW'S STAFF REACHES ACCORD
description: The doctors who walked off their jobs at Sea View Hospital and Home on Staten Island last week will return to duty there next week, according to a joint announcement yesterday by their representatives and the municipal hospital system.

title: Vietcong Aide Accuses U.S. of Sabotaging Talks
description: PARIS, March 24 (AP)Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the Vietcong foreign minister, accused the United States today of sabotaging the Vietnam peace talks and declared that her people will continue their just struggle if the United States refuses to negotiate.

title: Young Broker's Chinese Led to Motel Purchase
description: A fledgling realestate broker, trying out the Chinese he began learning while he was a Queens highschool student, made the original contact that led to the purchase of the Lincoln Square Motor Inn by the Chinese delegation to the United Nations.

title: Cunningham Wins A.M.C. Ad Account
description: Cunningham & Walsh, Inc., was named yesterday by the American Motors Corporation to take over its passenger car advertising from Wells; Rich, Greene, Inc.

title: NIXON SAYS PACT ON ARMS DEPENDS ON MOSCOW TRIP
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 President Nixon said today that agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union on a limitation on strategic arms would probably have to await his trip to Moscow in May for talks with Soviet leaders.

title: GOVERNOR PUSHES WOMAN FOR COURT
description: ALBANY, March 24Governor Rockefeller today called upon leaders of the Democratic party today to join with the Republicans in nominating a woman candidate for election to the State Court of Appeals next November.

title: THREE CHAMPIONS KEEP RING TITLES
description: Before a crowd of 20,129, three 1971 open champions scored victories on last night's Golden Gloves boxing program at Madison Square Garden.

title: Maybe the Answer to the Crime Rate Is This: Free Heroin Clinics
description: LINDEN, N. J.Take the profit out of heroin. Give injections of heroin by a qualified physician in a government clinic, free of charge to any addict that walks in and asks for one. Have a federally funded, cityrun neighborhood clinic staffed by a qualified physician, a registered nurse and a police officer. The heroin confiscated from the pushers and suppliers would be tested in a laboratory and marked, bagged in envelopes, and issued to clinics daily. A doctor's signature would be required.

title: Andretti Captures Pole at Sebring With Lap Record
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 24 The prancinghorse Ferrari sports cars entered by the Italian factory team qualified today for three of the first four starting positions in tomorrow's Twelve Hours of Sebring. The race, which begins at 11 A.M., is the third round of the 1972 series of 11 races on three continents for the world manufacturers championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneer 10 Course Shifted; To Go Behind Jupiter Moon
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., March 24 (AP)Scientists said they successfully completed a course correction maneuver today to send Pioneer 10 behind Io, Jupiter's orange moon.

title: Laotian Setback Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24 (AP)  Informed sources reported today that Laotian regular army unite abandoned six positions 10 and 25 miles north and cast of Luang Prabang, the royal capital, in the face of North Vietnamese mortar barrages and ground assaults.

title: Mrs. Moyer Wed to M. S. Dillon Jr.
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 24Mrs. Virginia Finlay Moyer of Bernardsville, widow of David Baxter Moyer, was married in the Princeton University Chapel here this afternoon to Milton Sands Dillon Jr., also of Bernardsville. Only members of the immediate families attended the ceremony, performed by Dean Ernest Gordon, the chaplain.

title: Merger News
description: American Brands, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Shatterproof Glass Corporation. This would be the diversified tobacco company's first move into the glass field. Robert B. Walker, chairman and chief executive officer of Amercan Brands, said the companywould acquire about 67 per cent of the capital stock of Shatterproof from the family of William B. Chase, Shatterproof's chairman, for $28 a share in cash. Shatterproof has 1,272,370 common shares outstanding. Mr. Chase said he would recommend the offer to shareholders.

title: Music: Dixon Conducts
description: Dean Dixon, the black conductor who for two decades has been active everywhere in the world but in this country, conducted the New York Philharmonic Thursday night. It was two years ago that he returned to the United States after a 21year absence.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lawyer Accused of Tax Fraud.

title: Dance: Leopardi Fragments Bows
description: BOSTON, March 24The Boston Ballet has been in existence as a fully professional dance company since 1964, but during its eight seasons it does not appear to have developed a great deal. The virtues it had in its first seasons are still quite apparent, but promise unfulfilled must after a time become promise somewhat dimmed.

title: JUDGE LOUNSBERRY OF CLAIMS COURT, 86
description: OWEGO, N. Y., March 24 (AP)Stephen M. Lounsberry, retired presiding judge of the New York Court of Claims and an upstate power in Republican politics for half a century, died Tuesday at a nursing home here. He was 86 years old.

title: MESKILL AGREES ON BUSING DELAY
description: HARTFORD, March 24Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today that he fully supported President Nixon's proposed moratorium on busing school children to establish racially balanced schools.

title: Art: Private Sensibility Marks Paintings and WaterColors by Edith Schloss
description: The paintings and watercolors of Edith Schloss, on view at the Green Mountain Gallery, 17 Ferry Street, are as much acts of the private sensibility as they are works of art. Miss Schloss is an American painter with a distinctly personal style who has been living in Italy for several years. Her paintings depict her studio at La Sena di Lerici with its stilllife objects, its bouquets of spring flowers, its glimpses of the sea. If her generally small canvases recall Klee on occasion, it has less to do with the influence of that modern master than with the fact that the artist's patchwork quilt figures as a prominent structural device In many of her paintings.

title: Farewell to Paris?
description: The United States walkout from the Paris peace talks is primarily a symbolic token of the Nixon Administration's turn from negotiations to Vietnamization as a means of ending the Indochina war.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Following is the transcript of President Nixon's news conference today as released by the White House:

title: State and City Agree on a Fund To Keep 2 Hunter Schools Open
description: Rearrangements in the state budget will avert the threatened shutdown of Hunter College's elementary and high schools, State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday.

title: More Bombings Reported
description: BELFAST, March 24 (AP)An explosion in the town of Maghera injured eight persons and wrecked two shops tonight. In Belfast, bombs damaged a bar, a service station and houses near the service station in a Protestant neighborhood, but no casualties were reported.

title: Nixon Busing Curb May Face Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 President Nixon's antibusing leglislation ran into sharp liberal opposition, including the threat of a filibuster, as Congress took up the measure today.

title: BUCKS SMOTHER KNICKS BY 13188
description: MILWAUKEE, March 24Oscar Robertson, the brains and guile of the Milwaukee Bucks offense, returned to action after missing six games tonight and led the defending National Basketball Association champions to an overwhelming 13188 triumph over the New York Knicks at Milwaukee Arena.

title: Labor Concedes Walkout Is Unlikely to Alter Phase2
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The abrupt departure of labor leaders from the Pay Board is unlikely to have any substantial impact on the Phase Two controls program, high labor union officials conceded today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HEARING ORDERED ON DETROIT BUSING
description: DETROIT, March 24  A Federal judge today ordered hearings to continue Tuesday in a school desegregation case here, although the Federal Government moved yesterday to intervene to stop any orders to bus schoolchildren.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market slipped lower yesterday in the most sluggish trading in nearly two months.

title: Background on Ulster
description: Northern Ireland, which is surrounded on two sides by the Republic of Ireland and on the other two by the Irish Sea, is a part of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The separation of the six counties that make up Northern Ireland from the rest of the island was made formal by the Government of Ireland Act of 1920, which led to independence for the South and autonomy for the North.

title: 4,022 See Royals Go
description: CINCINNATI, March 24 (AP) Nate Archibald, who scored 38 points and had 11 assists, and Sam Lacey and Tom Van Arsdale all received standing ovations when they left the court tonight as the Cincinnati Royals played their last home game in Cincinnati, beating the Baltimore Bullets, 132114.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  In switching from a Republican to a Democrat, Representative Ogden R. Reid of Westchester County has temporarily become a man without a committee.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24  It appeared today that at least five, and perhaps eight, Democrats will be on the California Presidential primary ballot June 6 to try to capture the fattest single package of national convention delegate votes in the nation. The deadline for filing qualifying petitions was today.

title: Miss Casa Is Triumph
description: RICHMOND, March 24 (UPI)  Rosemary Cassis of San Francisco, advanced to the semifinals today in the 518,000 Virginia Slims international women's tennis tournament. Miss Cassis was seeded No. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: When President Nixon made his television speech on busing, most of his audience must have believed that the Supreme Court had ordered massive busing to balance the racial makeup of public schools, and that millions of children across the country were being bused for that purpose. Those were the assumptions that seemed to underlie the President's urgency, his call for an immediate legal moratorium on busing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Increases Seen as Still Likely to Disturb U.S. Agricultural Interests
description: BRUSSELS, March 24 The compromise that ended the latest agricultural dispute within the Common Market early today calls for price increases ranging from 4 to 8 per cent and measures to encourage farmers to leave the land.

title: President Defends Kleindienst, Forecasts He'll Be Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Nixon asserted today that Acting Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst was an able, honest mart and predicted that he would be confirmed as Attorney General despite allegations of impropriety against him.

title: Antiques. Storage in 18thCentury Kas
description: If you have a problem finding furniture with sufficient storage space, you should be on the lookout for an 18thcentury DutchAmerican kas or wardrobe.

title: Lawyer's Illness Delays CourtMartial of Chaplain
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 24 (AP)  The adultery courtmartial of Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, recessed today until Monday after his lawyer became ill.

title: Reds Trade Cloninger To Cardinals for Javier
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 24 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds acquired Julian Javier for Tony Cloninger today in a trade with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: 3 Killed, 40 Hurt as Train Hits Rockland School Bus
description: CONGERS, N. Y., March 24A collision between a Nyack High School bus and a freight train here this morning killed three high school students and injured more than 40 others, eight of them critically.

title: ANGER IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 24  Militant Protestants, charging that Britain had surrendered to terrorist violence, reacted with fury today to London's takeover of Northern Ireland's government.

title: I Really Like Being a Girl
description: PITTSFORD, N. Y.Some students at the University of Michigan recently decided that both sexes could live together in the same room and select their partners by lot. The noble experiment was called off only because of excessive publicity.

title: P.B.A. Aides and City Agree on Contract
description: Negotiators for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the city have agreed on a tentative new work contract to be submitted to the association's delegate assembly next Wednesday.

title: Not ?? by Caldwell
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 24 (AP)Earl Caldwell, a New York Times reporter arrested earlier this month in a security check at the Angela Davis trial, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of possessing mari juana. A deputy sheriff making a routine search of the newsman outside the Davis courtroom March 6 found what he said was a small amount of marijuana in a film canister. Municipal Court Judge Gerald J. Kettmann scheduled a preliminary hearing for April 14.

title: ROYAL RUN IN 12TH DOWNS YANKS, 98
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 24  Rusty Torres played Buck Martinez's fly ball into center field into a 12thinning double that scored Bobby Knoop from first base and gave the Kansas City Royals a 98 victory today over the New York Yankees.

title: U.S. Bans Shipping Of Some Pesticides With Mercury Base
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency announced today an immediate ban on interstate shipment of about a dozen of the most toxic mercurybased pesticides.

title: Messiaen's Transfiguration to Be Presented Here
description: Olivier Messiaen, whose vast oratorio, La Transfiguration de Notre Seigneur Jesus Christ, will be given its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall on Easter Sunday night, is the only major composer in the world today who is active as a church musician on a regular basis.

title: Capital Sees Henry James cum Music
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  A new musical play, Washington Square, which had its world premiere this week at the Washington Theater Club, suffers from schizozophrenia. In one corner is Henry James, and in the other, Kenneth Jerome and Jerome Walman. Mr. Jerome wrote the lyrics, and Mr. Walman wrote the music. Together they take credit for the book.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The college basketball season will end today, as it always endswith U.C.L.A. winning the national championship.

title: MANY BIG BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE
description: The cost of business borrowing increased yesterday.

title: ORLAND CAMPBELL, A PORTRAIT PAINTER
description: Orland Campbell, portrait painter and art research scholar, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in the Hotel Des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street. He was 81 years old.

title: To Bear or Beget
description: The Supreme Court has given a timely boost to recent controversial but constructive proposals of the President's Commission on Population Growth.

title: Heart Study Head Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)President Nixon today named Dr. John S. Mills, head of the National Fund for Medical Education, to head a medipanel to investigate problems of heart disease. Other members will be named later, the White House said.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  The RCA Corporation expects that the liquid crystal displays on which it has been working will eventually make possible such productsas pocketsized television receivers that can be viewed in bright sunlight. The latest RCA patentin the field was granted this week to George H. Heilmeier, who is now serving the Pentagon as an assistant director of defense research and engineering. Patent 3,650,603, in which Joel E. Goldmacher is coinventor, covers a liquid crystal transparent display.

title: L.I. Court Rules Out Beach Restriction
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County yesterday struck down a 1970 ordinance of Long Beach, L. I., that had restricted the use of the city's 4.2mile beachfront to residents and their guests.

title: Surgeon Reports Test, at Curable Stage, for a Childhood Cancer
description: CLEARWATER, BEACH, Fla., March 24A Minnesota surgeon, discouraged by the lack of progress against neuroblastomaone of the deadliest cancers of childhoodsaid here today that he and his colleagues had developed a simple test that could detect the disease when most cases could be cured by surgery.

title: Canada, U.S. Win in Curling
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, March 24 (AP) Canada rallied today to beat Scotland, 107, in final roundrobin play of the world curling championships. The United States team from Grafton, N.D., beat Sweden, 106, to qualify for tomorrow's semifinals.

title: State Asking Shutdown Of 43d St. Discotheque
description: A West 43d Street teenage discotheque, the Sanctuary Club, has been accused by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of being a menace to the community and a supermarket for drugs.

title: CLEVELAND UTILITY SHOWS INCOME RISE
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The big Ohio utility placed operating revenues at $270,720,587 against $245,381,168 a year earlier. Net income rose to $41,663,332, or $3.06 a share, from the $40,732,853, or $3.02 a share, reported in1970. It was noted that in 1971 there was a new preferred dividend requirement amounting to $174,833.

title: Girl, 12, Describes Killing Of a Black Panther Here
description: A 12yearold girl testified in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday that a mart admitted her and her 13yearold friend to Black. Panther party headquarters in Corona last April 17 and held them there while a member of the Panther party, Sam Napier, was killed.

title: Berrigan Defense Calls No Witnesses And Rests Its Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 24 Defendants in the Berrigan antiwar conspiracy trial rested their case suddenly today without calling a single witness after two adverse rulings that they felt would have crippled their hopes of an affirmative defense.

title: SPITZ SETS MARK IN 200 BUTTERFLY
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 24Mark Spitz, controversial wonder boy of American swimming four years ago, has grown up.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md. March 24 (UPI)President Nixon flew by helicopter to Camp David today to spend the weekend at his retreat in the Maryland mountains. The President was accompanied by his friend C. G. Rebozo and by members of the Secret Service, military aides and other personal staff members.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Women's liberationists might read something into what's going on at Este Liiuder. Reaching, as most cosmetics houses currently are, for food to put into beauty products, the company has simultaneously produced an assortment based on milk for women and on beer for men. Both drinks, the company seems to believe, are salubrious externally as well as internally.

title: SONGS BY WILLIAMS SUNG BY WILLIAMS
description: When songwriters perform their own material, the results sometimes, can provide welcome new insight into even the most familiar tunes. But, alas, there is another side to the coin. And that is that some songwriters simply lack the platform, presence vital to the properinterpretation of their music. Paul Williams's stint at the Bitter End this week is an unhappy example of the latter.

title: FULBRIGHT PANEL SETS I.T.T. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to conduct a major inquiry into the influence of multinational corporations on United States foreign policy.

title: Bill Rates Up Sharply At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose sharply in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: NETS TURN BACK SQUIRES, 105104
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 24The New York Nets, down by 17 points in the second quarter, rallied to defeat the Virginia Squires, 105104, and pulled to within onehalf game of the Squires in their battle for second place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division.

title: Dancing Ladies, or a Feminist's Dream
description: A woman's lot is not a happy one. That was, perhaps unintentionally, the theme or, anyway, the cumulative effect of eight solos danced by as many women Thursday night in the first concert of a new series entitled Dancing ladies.

title: Canonero II Is Attempting a Comeback On a Swollen Ankle
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 25Whatever happened to Canonero II?

title: Giants Sign Jacobson, Top Nebraska Lineman
description: Larry Jacobson of the Uni versity of Nebraska, winner of the Outland Trophy as college football's top lineman of 1971, has signed a one year contract with the New York Giants, the club an nounced today.

title: Peabody Pairs Canzoni and Therese
description: BALTIMORE, March 25The Opera department of the Pea hody Conservatory of Music put on an unusual double bill last night, pairing Malipiero's Sette Canzoni and Massenet's Therese. It was an enterpris ing choice of works, and they were produced with an imag ination that overcame the limi tations of a small stage meant only for concert performances.

title: INSIDE GERMANY NEW LEBENSRAUM
description: GERSFELD, West Germany, March 9Last summer's grass es, thick and coarse, he un known on many an upland field of the Rhn region around here, mingling with the un mown grasses of previous sum mers.

title: 10 Families Still Defy Hospital Expansion
description: When Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn formalizes its expansion program, possibly within the next few months, it may have to decide what to do with 10 families that have vowed not to move out of hospitalowned apartments situated on a Park Slope street along which new med ical facilities are to be built.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Stamps
description: NOT that every month isn't important in the care of the heart, but April has been set aside by the World Health Organization for special dedi cation to the thesis that Your Heart is Your Life. It is an effort joined in by medi cal, scientific and health or ganizations throughout the world to help promote the prevention and treatment of heart and circulatory dis eases.

title: U.J.A. Drive Here Begins 1972 Effort With $31.6Million
description: The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, which opened its 1972 campaign last week, has announced that the total contributions made since it was founded 30 years ago have passed the billiondollar mark.

title: Bess Is Their Woman Now
description: IT'S rather late on a recent chill winter night. Bess Myerson, somehow resembling a giant Barbie doll (she's 5 feet 10 inches tall), bounces a small red ball (as therapy for a hand injury) against the bare par quet floor in her new and largely unfurnished Upper East Side flat and endures yet another interview, in this case about her television show.

title: The Nation
description: Two weeks ago, Najeeb E. Halaby the man picked seven years ago by aviation pioneer Juan Trippe to take over Pan American World Airways taperecorded 4 message to the air line's 36,000 employes. After review ing Pan Am's deepening financial problems and urging the employes to buckle down and work harder, he added: None of us can have real job security unless we are part, of a suc cessful and growing business.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The season is on approach it with enthusiasm.  temper it with reason Follow the rules read direction labels plan plant only what you can enjoy and care for.

title: MARCHI OPPOSED ON LANDUSE BILL
description: A bill to create a publicben efit corporation to guide the development of the city's last frontier of open land10,600 acres on South Richmondhas gotten a mixed reception at a public hearing on Staten Island.

title: Protestant Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: W. L. Emery to Wed Joy Garvin Sperry
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 25Mrs. Henry Ehlers Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joy Gar vin Sperry, to Wyman Luther Emery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donovan Emery of Westport, Conn. The future bride groom's father retired as a district manager for the Pru dential Insurance Company.

title: India Shuts Last Camp For Eastern Refugees
description: NEW DELHI, March 25 (Reuters)The last Bangla desh refugee camp in India closed today, the first anni versary of the Pakistani Army's crackdown on Ben gali separatists in what was then East Pakistan.

title: City Proposes Test of Nixon WorkRelief Projects
description: New York City has drafted a proposal to widen the state's controversial and stilldelayed welfare demonstration projects into a fullscale test of the Nixon Administration's welfare reform program.

title: Jesus People Hear Gospel Rock
description: FAIR LAWNThe Resur rection festival has a new facet these days at the long established Van Riper Ellis Memorial Baptist Church here in suburban North Jer sey.

title: Wanting to Be a rancher, She Works as a Zookeeper
description: PARAMUSWhen Bergen County's colorful Van Saun Park opened its 10acre zoo 12 years ago this May, the only females around were in pens and cages. That didn't change until Nancy Volek came on the scene.

title: Facts on Ferns For Beginners
description: THE next few weeks are the most important in the year for ferns. Although they can be transplanted at any time, there is less danger of injury and landscape disturbance when ferns are moved during the dor mant period. Hardy ferns moved as soon as the ground is frost free will be adjusted to their new surroundings by early June.

title: Friendship Pact With China Possible, Tokyo Aide Says
description: TOKYO, March 25 (UPI)  Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda said today that Japan was willing to sign a nonaggression agreement with China when relations between the two countries were normalized.

title: Art
description: ASSERTLNG with some jus tice that the apprecia tion and even patron age of contemporary art are phenomena largely among our rising middle and uppermiddle classes, the poet and critic James Schuyler once slyly noted that the esthetic needs of the very rich appear to be satisfied by beads, pelts and used furniture (its joinhs cracking like cap pistols in the hot interiors for which it was not made). Beads, pelts and used furniture: dia monds, furs and (that strange, vast category) antiques, a triad that gets odder the more thinks about it.

title: Fire in Home Kills L. I. Man
description: ROCKY POINT, L. I., March 25A 26yearold man died today in a fire of undetermined origin that badly damaged a ranch home on Aster Road. The victim's parents escaped and the grandmother of the dead man was rescued by volunteer firemen. Edward Maynes Sr., and his wife, Margaret, escaped after trying unsuccessfully to reach their son, Edward Jr.

title: JAVANESE WARNS ON FORESTATION
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25 (Reuters)The overcrowded island of Java is in danger of becoming a desert if a current forestation program falls, ac cording to the Indonesian Pub lic Works Minister, Dr. Sutami.

title: Kretchmer Shows Off City's Garbage
description: We're riding on garbage, everybody, said Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Envi ronmental Protection Admin istrator.

title: G.O.P. IN NASSAU CHOOSES A SLATE
description: LIDO BEACH, L. I., March 25 The Nassau County Republi can Committee last night named its candidates for the House of Representatives, the State Leg islature, County, Family and District Court benches and Town Council.

title: Congo Republic's Leader Demotes 20 for Coup Roles
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Re public, March 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Marten Ngouabi of the Congo Republic has reduced 20 army officers to the ranks for their parts in the abortive coup d'tat of Feb. 22.

title: S. AFRICA TAKES FIDERATION CUP
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rice, March 25 (AP)  South Africa's unheralded women's tennis team captured the Fed eratiort Cup tournament today, beating Britain, 21 in the final on a decisive deubles triumph by Pat Pretorius and Brenda Kirk.

title: Cutting Up After Hours Results in a Salary Cut
description: TURIN, Italy, March 25 (UPI) The Juventus Soccer Club has announced that it will reduce the salary of its West German player, Helmut Haller, for an undetermined time as punishment for his nightclubbing during a Euro pean Cup trip to Britain.

title: Harbor Seals Set Protection
description: ALBANY  Hunters who shoot Long Island's harbor seals are now subject to pros ecution following the signing of a new law by Governor Rockefeller last Tuesday.

title: Germans Argue Brandt's Eastern Policies
description: BONN, March 25Not since the great debates of the nine teenfifties over the question of rearmament of West Germany has the public been so emotion ally involved in a policy issue as it has become over the na tion's attempt to achieve nor mal relations with Communist Europe through treaties.

title: Israel Metal Is Booming
description: Spurred by the need to build a selfsustaining de fense establishment, Israel's metal fabrication and electronics industries are showing faster growth than others in that country, Joseph Rom of Israel's Min istry of Commerce and Indus try said recently.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bridge to be Yankee Blue

title: Recruiting Funds Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)Senator Gordon Allott, Republican of Colorado, has proposed that $198.7million more be provided in four spe cial programs to spur military programs and make it possible to end the draft.

title: Judge to Rule on Hotel Case This Week
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.A Su preme Court judge will rule here this week on a suit that will determine if a waterfront site of the Holiday Lodge Hotel in Northport could be developed in cluster housing.

title: Shredders Slowly Reducing Heaps of junked Cars
description: HOUSTON  The 1957 Plymouth rode up a conveyor belt and disappeared into a tunnel. Within 40 seconds, it had been pulverized into 5,000 bits of metal thrash ing, highspeed hammers.

title: Jewel Theft at Orly Reported
description: PARIS, March 25 (UPI)Mrs. Cecilia Lopez Pia, a wealthy Portuguese tourist, reported to the police today that her travel bag containing jewels worth $1.1million was stolen at Orly airport. The theft was de scribed by the police as the largest reported at Orly. Mrs. Lpez Pia said that the jewels included a 45carat diamond.

title: An AgriCity Is Planned on State's Largest Farm
description: BRIDGETON The Sea brook Farms, the largest in New Jersey, may become a unique type of enterprise, an agricity, a blend of indus trial, commercial, residential and agricultutal uses.

title: Television
description: IN a publicity release it's called anti television. In the official program schedules it's called Free Time. Of course, no matter how anti, the program is still on television. And, Just as there is no such thing as a free lunch, there is no such thing as free time on television. Someone, someplace, is paying.

title: Isadora Duncan Lives On in State
description: HACKENSACK  Modern dance has been considered a major American art form since Isadora Duncan kicked off her corset and shoes more than 65 years ago. But not everybody in Bergen County got Isadora's message.

title: Chess
description: THE eleventh number of the semi annual Yugoslav Chess Inform ant (covering approximately the first six months of 1971) is now available in this country, ?? it is not, for a happy change, even bigger than the last. To be exact, Number Eleven contains 622 games, compared with 841 in Number Ten.

title: Dagbury of Calartha, Pekingese, Is Selected Best at 50th Bronx K.C. Show
description: Ch. Dagbury of Calartha, a red Pekingese, who was im ported from England 13 months ago, gained his first bestin show award in America yester day at the 50th anniversary fixture of the Bronx County Kennel Club. The event, held in the giant Kingsbridge Eighth Regiment Armory, drew a rec ord 2,338 dogs.

title: The Trailer Caravan: A Mobile Society in a Portable Town
description: OUR modern mobile societyas sociologists like to call ithas an elite: a truly mobile society made up of the people who own trailers.

title: Miss Leslie Leigh Is Future Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Leslie Susan Leigh to Bryan Charles Baxenden has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Murray Stuart Leigh of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of George Bryan Bonam Bax enden of Newport Beach, Calif., and the late Mrs. Ruth Hyser Baxenden Pope.

title: Nixon Gets Authority On Foreign Air Fares
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)President Nixon has signed an act giving him fi nal approval on whether to suspend, reject or cancel air travel fares proposed by foreign airlines.

title: Hadassah: Taking Aim on Problems in U.S.
description: Hadassah, which claims to be the larg est women's organization in the United States  it has 350,000 members  planning to move in a new direction.

title: Cambodian Officer Finances RuralAid Program
description: TRAPANG TRAS, Cambodia, March 19Behind every house in this dusty hardscrabble village there is a brand new concrete pigpen inhabited by a young imported pig. Down the newly bulldozed road there is a new school, and just be yond stands a new infirmary stocked with medicine from Pnompenh.
