title: Christine Kahn Wed
description: WEST ENGLEWOOD, N. J., March 25  Miss Christine Wyant Kahn and Douglas Stokes Cook were married at noon today In Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Denny. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Kahn Jr. of Frank lin Lakes and Pompano Beach, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester W. Cook Jr. of Stuart, Fla. Mr. Kahn is pres ident of the Wyant Condi tioning Corporation in New York and Mr. Cook is presi dent of C. W. Cook and Sons Realty, Inc., Fort Lauderdale and Stuart.

title: New & Novel
description: The imponderables of wind, wave and the watery unknown make nothing so mysteriousas a mystery of the sea Hence the mythology encrusting the Flying Dutchman, the Marie Ce leste, and other aqueous enig mas. Mr. Jenkins has built a satisfactory adventure story around one of these eerie ma rine disasters. The episode he chooses is fairly recent: the disappearance in 1909 of S. S. Waratah somewhere off the coast of South Africa.

title: A Guide to GalleryHopping on the North Shore of L.I.
description: Galleryhopping on Long Island is not quite the same as a stroll down Madison Avenue. But with a car, plenty of gas, a map and a free Saturday or Sunday afternoon, the artlover or collector can make the rounds of a wide variety of art galleries.

title: Westchester Legislature Uses a Lull to Orient Its New Members
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 25 With the spotlight now turned to Congressional politics in Westchester County and the heated county issues of the last year lying dormant, the County Board of Legislators plays to a nearly empty cham ber.

title: Son for the Gerbers
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Donald A. Gerber of Brooklyn March 20 at the Sloane Hospital of the Co lumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

title: Art
description: THE subject of the Met ropolitan Museum's splendid new exhibi tion, Chinese Callig raphy, must be the most eso teric ever tackled for presen tation to the mass audience the museum must serve. And although the introductory ex planations as to what makes Chinese calligraphy some thing more than just a for eign and decorative form of writing are necessarily at an ABC level, any temptation to vulgarize this aristocratic art form as relevant has been resisted, (The appear of the exhibition at a time when everything Chinese is news is pure coincidence.)

title: Recordings
description: MOST of the best mu sic, as traditionalists never tire of point ing out to us, is written by composers who are content to bend and twist convention, not break it to bits and throw it out the win dow: Bach, Mozart, Beeth oven, Schubert, Braluns  and even late Romantics such as Mahlerwere more con cerned to widen the road they found themselves on than to crash off into entirely unmapped wildernesses. But for a few others, the genuine odd fellows and originals of music, maintraveled roads are a dusty bore. To Berlioz, Ives, Gesualdo, Satie, Mus sorgsky or Janacek (to men tion a representative few of the great eccentrics), the one worthwhile goal seems to be the discovery of new musical truths, not the refinement of old ones. Since undiscovered truths are not all that easy to come by, the quantity of great music produced by the eccentrics is of course rela tively small.

title: Outlying Housing for Blacks in Columbia, S.C. Assailed
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.In this fastgrowing metropolitan area of 322,000, the Federal Govern ment is presiding over a new kind of urban development: Blacks are being dispersed from central city slums into sub sidized housing in outlying areas.

title: C.A.B. Acts to Prevent Stranding of Tourists
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board has taken steps to as sure that never again will Americans on roundtrip char ter flights be stranded abroad.

title: It's Not Only the Plants That Grow in a Brooklyn Garden
description: We say every day is Earth Day here, said Frances Miner, curator of in struction at the Brooklyn Bo tanic Garden. You know, it's interesting to see them grow. She was speaking not of the summer haniest of corn, beets and beans, but of the 350 youngsters from, five boroughs who take part in the gardening program of fered there.

title: Outboard Mark
description: The world speed record for outboard boats is 131.051 miles per hour. The record was set by Gerry Walin, Ed monds, Wash., in an Evin rude  powered hydroplane, Starflite IV, March 16, 1966.

title: WHERE TO:
description: A fittingout program would hardly be complete without the gadgetry and other whatnottery that are useful and not so useful and make conversation pieces when things get dull on board.

title: The Borsalino Hat
description: ROME  A 200yearold Roman haberdasher, Radicon cini, or the central Via del Coro permanently keeps one of its show windows re served for Borsalino hats.

title: Uconn Coach Plays Polo to Relieve Frustrations
description: SOMERS, Conn., March 25 Until he was 38 years old, Hal Vita's total knowledge of polo was that it was played on horseback.

title: Cambodian Airport Hit
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 25 (AP)Enemy gun ners fired three 122mm rock ets into the Cambodian capi tal's international airport but caused neither damage nor cas ualties, a spokesman said.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGOThe people have spoken; the people are to be congratulated. That was Chicago Mayor Richard J. Daley early Wednesday morning, eat ing humble pie before the television cameras. For the first time in 34 years, the Cook County Democratic machine had lost a primary contestand not just one but two. Boss Daley's can didates for the Democratic nominations for governor and Cook County state's attorney had gone down to defeat.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Attending the casseroles and a suicidal baron
description: Sinister metaphysical farce has al ways been one of Muriel Spark's specialties, but readers have frequent ly disagreed about the solidity of the relationship between the dark comedy and the ideas which often hover so teasingly around it. Her latest novella, Not to Disturb, again raises this issue in an extravagant way.

title: New Cult Developing In Skiing: The Acrobatics
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March. 25There is the back scratcher, the worm, the out rigger, the bun buster and Polish wedlen. If you can do these, on skis, then you belong to a new cult rapidly achieving status in skiing. You are a hot dog and you are something special.

title: 40Devilpower Engine Tries to Eat People
description: What do you suppose started it? Was it insanity or the bite of a mealybug that made my wife, two dogs and me decide the time had come to join the out board motorboating crowd?

title: Poll Says 84% of French Term Themselves Catholic
description: PARIS, March 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  Eightyfour per cent of the French people consider themselves Catholics, according to a public opinion poll published in two publica tions, La Croix and Le Pelerin.

title: Son to Mrs. Jones Harris
description: A son was born March 17 to Mr. and Mrs. Jones Harris of New York at LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Harris is the former Miss Heidi Vanderbilt, daughter of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Mrs. Murray Vanderbilt. Her husband is the son of Ruth Gordon, the actress, and Jed Harris, the theatrical producer. The baby's father is a freelance researcher. The child, who has been named Jack Gwynne, is descended from Commo dore Cornelius Vanderbilt.

title: Molina Says Coup Failed
description: LOS ANGELES, Sunday, March 26 (Reuters)El Salva dor's Presidentelect, Col. Ar turo Armando Molina, said last night he had spoken with Pres ident Sanchez by telephone and was told that calm had been re stored throughout the country.

title: Handicapped Orphans Are in Need of Parents for Adoption
description: NEWARK  At a time when a growing number of families in the state are in dicating a desire to adopt children, the number of read ily available normal, healthy infants end older children moat soughtafter for adop tion  has sharply decreased.

title: AN ANGRY BHUTTO BARS TALKS SOON
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 25President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto tonight ruled out the possibility of his making a peacemaking trip to India soon, and angrily asserted he would not accede to Indian black mail with respect to prisoners of war.

title: BLACKS UNMOVED BY JACKSON CASE
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 25 There was little surprise ex pressed by Mississippi blacks and no strenuous reaction this week to an allwhite jury's de cision finding no official liabil ity for the violence at Jackson State College in May, 1970.

title: The Guest Word
description: For 20 years now Hugh Kenner has been publishing books. (14 of them  the latest reviewed on Page 7) and essays (hundreds) for an audience that hasn't yet been born. How else can we account for the insipid reviews, the slow sales, the indifference of his colleagues?

title: Storm Is Yet to Break on TaxRevision Proposals
description: TRENTONIt is now one month since the Governor's Tax Policy Committee recom mended a state income tax tied to a monumental refor mation of New Jersey's tax structure, but still none of the predicted political and legislative mayhem has turned up.

title: Ship to Shore: Jersey Marine Police
description: With a moist 15knot wind and 20degree temperature producing a subzero chill factor, the Hereford Inlet beach in North Wildwood, N. J., isn't the most comfort able place to be at 6:40 A.M.

title: The Country Girl An Old Champion Is Still Winner
description: CLIFFORD ODETS's The Country Girl, which has turned up in a vigorous, flashy, emo tionally satisfying revival at the Billy Rose after an earlier stint at the Kennedy Center in Washington, is built like a boxing match. Two contend ers spar with, jab at, and foul each other in an eightround bout, fighting for the survival of a seedy third party, an often drunken exstar who might just be nursed through a Broadway comeback. In the revival the shaky, florid actor is played by Jason Robards, rubbing the back of his hand across his mouth to conceal his nerves. The two people who do battle to defend and in fact define him are George Grizzard, cocky young direc tor of a show that may col lapse if its star does, and Maureen Stapleton, wife, governess, goad and weary sec ond to Mr. Robards. So much for broad outlines.

title: Portraits and Coats of Arms
description: For the floating salon that needs something more origi nal than an I'm The Cap tain plaque, fastidious boat owners are now hanging por traits of their boats done in the fascinating art form of needlepoint. And the Cap tain's coat of arms worked in needlepoint is the final word in elegance.

title: Illustrated chocolate and trumpetblowing apes
description: Sixteenthcentury Spain sired a hardy breed of young men, and in the wake of the four voyages of Columbus they came to the New World by the thousands. One of the hardiest was Juan Ortiz, curlyhaired, 17, a member of a 1527 expedition sent to explore Florida under the command of Panfilio de Narvaez. A year later, as the narrative begins, Juan's part in the explorations was cut short by Timucuan Indians who captured him by a ruse on the sands of Tampa Bay.

title: TEACHER WRITES A SONG FOR U.F.T.
description: Move over, Joe Hill. Step aside, Solidarity Forever. Make room in the pantheon of labor songs for Edward R. Mo rand's Devotion, Solidarity and HonorA Song for the U.F.T.

title: Meredith O. Moss Wed to Publisher
description: In the chapel of St. Bar tholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Meredith Octavine Moss became the bride of Edward George Tripp. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony.

title: MARGIN IS A NOSE
description: MIAMI, March 25Mr. and Mrs. John Galbreath, who had the pleasure of watching their Pittsburgh Pirates win the World Series last fall, had an other delightful day today watching their Darby Dan Farm entry of Good Counsel and His Majesty romp to vic tory in the $144,600 Widener Handicap at Hialeah.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: J. E. Errickson, Susan R Kelsey Plan to Marry
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., March 25 Miss Susan Reed Kelsey and J. Edwin Errickson plan to be married in August.

title: Lyle Stops Johnson in 3d
description: DENVER, March 25 (AP) Ron Lyle scored his 11th knock out in 13 fights tonight, putting away George (Scrap Iron) John son of Los Angeles 31 seconds into the third round of their 10round heavy weight bout.

title: The World
description: LONDONIt was 12 days ago that Prime Minister Edward Heath finally announced he was ready to meet with Prime Minister Brian Faulkner of Northern Ireland to unveil a new political plan for the violenceridden province. The meeting was set for last Wednesday. The Government's budget would be out of the way, and the two Prime Ministers could sit down and go over the whole range of proposals over which London had agonized for weeks.

title: Powell Still in Deep Coma
description: MIAMI, March 25 (UPI) Former Representative Adam Clayton Powell of Harlem re mained in a deep coma today in Jackson Memorial Hospital here Mr. Powell, who is 63 years old, has been in critical condition in the hospital's in tensivecare unit for a week.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Anne McCarthy Wed to I. A. Forbes
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25  In the chapel at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here this after noon, Miss Anne Alexander McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin A. Mc Carthy of Hillside, N. J., became the bride of Iain Alexander Forbes, who re ceived a doctorate in nuclear engineering from M.I.T. and is an assistant professor of physics at the Lowell Tech nological Institute. The Uni tarian ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Ralph N. Helversen.

title: YANKEES BEATEN BY ORIOLES, 4 TO 3
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, March 25The Baltimore Orioles pro longed a comic controversy by scoring two runs in the ninth inning to beat the New York Yankees, 43, tonight. Mark Belanger's single off Fred Beene with two out and the bases full was the deciding blow.

title: For Houk, Little Things Make Contender
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 25It is now 12 years since Ralph Houk succeeded Casey Stengel as manager of the invincible Yankees, and not quite six since he re claimed the managership from Johnny Keane of the suddenly vincible Yankees.

title: Poll Shows French Favor Britain's Market Entry
description: PARIS, March 25 (AP)  A public opinion poll showed this week that 66 per cent of French voters favor British entry into the Common Mar ket.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: College Swim Stars Disagree On Value of Shaving Down
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 25Long hair has produced its share of short tempers in college athletics, but no where is the issue more sen sitive than in swimming, where shaving down for a big meet is a psychic ritual.

title: No Consensus Found On Plan for Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L.I.More than 300 residents who overflowed the Village Hall last week to discuss a controversial plan to rezone deteriorating North Main Street agreed on only one thing: The blighted area must be rehabilitated.

title: Illustrated chocolate and trumpetblowing apes
description: For one reason or the other very few of the acknowledged masters of contemporary French painting have produced works expressly for chil dren. So Sonia Delaunay's Alpha bet, by that remarkable woman whose life and work have been in terwoven with many of the avant garde movements of the 20th cen tury, is a rare and fortuitous excep tion. And the vigor and enthusiasm expressed throughout the book make it difficult to believe that Miss De launay is now 86 years old.

title: Terry Howard Bride Of Dr. Wayne Decker
description: Miss Terry E. Howard was married yesterday morning to Dr. Wayne H. Decker at the Unitarian Church of All Souls by the Rev. Dr. Walter Don ald Kring.

title: Boston U. Cites. Red Smith
description: Red Smith of The New York Times has been selected as the 1972 recipient of Boston Uni versity's Murray Kramer Scar let Quill Award for outstand ing coverage of intercollegiate athletics. Smith will be hon ored along with other sports figures at the B. U. Varsity Club's annual Hall of Fame ban quet April 28 at the Sheraton Plaza Hotel in Boston.

title: French Priest Critical of Church Reforms Is Curbed
description: PARIS, March 25A Roman Catholic priest with a weekly radio audience estimated above five million has been ordered to halt his Sunday sermons be cause of his criticism of re forms the French church has introduced in liturgy, and in struction.

title: Letters:
description: It is understandable that Mrs. Geiger does not wel come progress in the sub urbs, [If This Is Progress in the Suburbs, No Thank You, Jan. 91 which she equates with crowding, anonymity, sidewalks, excessive and in sufficient law enforcement. Still she seems willing to earn her income in a city with all those shortcomings as long as she doesn't have to live like a city dweller.

title: Television
description: To enter his office my son and I have first to pass through a large outer office where his sizable staff is at work. The P.R. people escort us between the rows of desks to the inner sanctum. He is wait ing at the door. A glance over his shoul der takes in the room. It spells success. A long conference table, corner ban quettes, color TV monitors. The man himself is silverhaired with matching moustache. His welltailored dark suit is accented by a fashionably wide tie. He greets his callers with quiet, confi dent warmth. He notices that my son, Alexander, 4, is armed.

title: 2 Queens College Seniors Win Danforth Fellowships
description: Two Queens College seniors have won Danforth Founda tion Fellowships for study to ward their Ph. D. degrees, the foundation has announced.

title: Spring Planting
description: EVERY year I listen for spring peepers and toward the end of March, and by the middle of April I expect to see swamp maples in bloom Making the low lands blush with spring. By then the red  wing blackbirds are loud in the streamside willows and the migrant robins are strutting about our home pasture and eating the first minor hatch of insects there. And by then most real gardeners are outdoors, getting their fin gers into the soil again, renewing contact. With any weather luck at all up here in the hills we have peas planted, the first lettuce bed in, a row of carrots and one of beets, one of onion sets and maybe even a row of green beans in the ground. We may have frost as late as Memorial Day up here, but if it doesn't come we'll have very early beans. If it does, we'll replant. Some people plant peas in midMarch, but that is sheer non sense. Peas planted in March just lie there and shiver and sulk till it really warms up.

title: ITALY PESSIMISTIC ON ROLE IN MARKET
description: ROME, March 25  Advo cates of European integration here are publicly worrying about a decline in Italy's role in the Common Market.

title: Stewart Loses at Nice
description: NICE, France March 25 (Reu ters)  JanEric Lundquist of Sweden reached the final of the men's singles in the Mediter ranean international tennis tournament today when he beat Sherwood Stewart of the Unit ed States, 63, 64.

title: Rangers Stave Off Canadiens an Tie
description: MONTREAL, March 25for the crippled New York Rangers, tonight's 33 tie with Montreal was a moral victory. The 18,950 fans in the Forum gave both clubs an ovation at the end of the game, and for the Canadien fans, their gesture was pure sportsmanship.

title: Get These Men Out of The Hot Sun
description: A satirist needs subjects whose flaws, when magnified, repel us into a cyclone of strong emotions. The best satire causes us to rage at what is, to despair at its gaping dis tance from what should be. Our anguish is then dispelled by the cathartic of bitter, demonic mirthlaughter through tears, as it was called in the old timey phrase.

title: Retired Couple Keeps Guide on Course
description: ANNAPOLIS. Md.Behind the scenes at Waterway Guide, which helps yachts men make their way from Canada down the Atlantic Coast to the Keys and along the Gulf Coast to Texas and Mexico, are two young persons who thought they would retire and live a life of ease on board their 57foot trawlertype yacht, Distant Star.

title: NADER SEES SECRECY ON POLLUTION DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Ralph Nader accused the Nixon Administration today of trying to prevent House passage of tougher water pollution con trols by suppressing a report by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon's latest proposals against busing have stirred up the old argument over quality schooling for poor minority children: Can it best be achieved through integration or through com pensatory education?

title: Theater: A Troika of Russian Comedy
Why Norman And Jason Aren't Talking
description: JASON EPSTEIN and Norman Podhoretz are both in their early 40's, both Jewish, both graduates of Columbia, both editors and occasional writers, and while they were once close friends, they are now sworn enemies. They once agreed on almost everything, in lit erature and in politics; now they agree on almost nothing, and the arguments between them, in large part because of them, are re peated on every university campus in the United States, as well as in every city and town where people who are intellectuals or think of themselves as intellectualsand these days who doesn't?get together.

title: Wisconsin Six Picks Dool
description: MADISON. Wis., March 25 (AP)Tim tool, a junior from Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario was named captain today of the 197273 University of Wiscon sin ice hockey team.

title: Turk's Heads, Monkey's Fists
description: Capt. Owen Boland, with his ruddy complexion, white beard and mustache and blue cap perched on his head, looks like every sea captain. And like any experi enced sailor, the captain is an expert at knot tying.

title: Train Service to Upper Harlem. Valley Terminated
description: CHATHAM, N.Y., March 25  The last passenger train from Chatham to New York City rolled southward into oblivion this week, leaving in its track hard feelings, bitter words and a controversy about the future of transpor tation in the Upper Harlem Valley of New York State.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton, Columbia Teams to Test Their Rugby Skills in Britain
description: PRINCETON, N. J., March 18  Suceess in college ath letics frequently depends on good coaching, generous uni versity funding and Strictly, disciplined training programs. The Princeton University rug by club lacks all of these Ingredients, but still may be the best American college team competing in this sport.

title: Ruth Burgess Plans Bridal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 25Miss Ruth Webber Bur gess plans to be married here in June to Robert Sheffield Faulkner.

title: City's Duplicate Relief Claims Led to $30Million Overpayment
description: ALBANY, March 25State Controller Arthur Levitt dis closed today that New York City had received $30.7million in state welfare aid by claiming payments twice for the same cases.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Director, The Repertory Thea ter of Lincoln Center
description: TRUTH is seldom very fashionable. It's also a commodity that sells few newspapers. I run The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center and often feel like a sometimes silent, sometimes vocal guest at a completely Mad Tea Party. Frequently, it's a tossup as to who the host is. Those of us who function in the New York theatrical arena know that it takes a particular brand of insanity and brinks manship to survive. We sel dom take time to point out today's absurdities; we're too busy preparing for tomor row's. Theater may not be life or death, but we are in clined to treat it thus.

title: MISS WHITWORTH IS VICTOR IN GOLF
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 25 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, the favorite in the $85,000 Sears world golf classic, survived two rounds of match play today by defeating Louise Suggs, 5 and 4.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe spectacle of the week in Presidential politics, no question about it, was that old prac titioner of the art, Hubert Horatio Humphrey of Minnesota.

title: Foul!
description: I think back, says Paul Silas, a teammate of Connie Hawkins, to when Connie and I played  right after high school. I try and conceive what it would have been like for me, at that age, to have my college years taken away, to be scorned as a crook, to be forced to go out and face life. I couldn't have.  But he did.

title: FLORIDA DEMOCRATS ELECT 61 DELEGATES
description: MIAMI, March 25 (AP)  Congressional district caucuses elected 61 of Florida's 81 dele gates to the Democratic Na tional Convention today, and with the selection process about half completed only one black had been designated.

title: Thai Drive Snares Few Red Guerrillas
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22Results of the first large scale operation of the Thai armed forces against a Commu nist insurgent base areawith large doses of American military training, machinery, weapons, advice and prodding  reflect and repeat many of the same problems that have plagued the United States and its other allies in Indochina for nearly a decade.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Everyone thought it was a shame that Mabel Vernon couldn't be there. A veteran of the fight for women's suffrage in the United States, one of the last sur vivors of the group of women who were arrested and jailed in 1917 for refus ing to stop demonstrating for suffrage in front of the White House, Miss Vernon was sick last Thursday. She missed the Senate vote marking final Congressional approval of the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of March 2 critical of the Pentagon for backing away from an earlier decision to testify at the Price Board hearings on A.T.&T. insinuates as a reason political weight of the nation's largest corporation.

title: The Inland Sea
description: The inland sea of the title is an almost landLocked, lakelike body of waters surrounded by three of the main islands of Japan  Honshu, Shikoko and Kyushu. It's a lovely, back wards area dotted with little and large islands, all of which, as Donald Richie points out, look hospitable to the casta way. This is Richie's account of a journey (actually several journeys, but it reads as one) into the beautiful country of water. Richie's mission was to find an older, more natural Ja pan unconcerned with Gross Na tional Product. He is a sensitive, warmly comic observer of places and people. Charming photographs by Yoichi Midori kawa.

title: Hawks Tie Bruins, 55, on Boby Hull's 600th Career Goal
Gretchen Fraser Casts Vote for Pros
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 25 (AP)The woman who won America's first Olympic ski medals nearly a quartercentury ago says the Olympic Games should not bar professional ath letes.

title: Seoul Hotel Fire Kills 4
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 25Four persons were killed and five others injured this morning when fire swept a seven story downtown hotel here.

title: TV Commentary Role Goes to Elgin Baylor
description: Elgin Baylor, the former, Los Angeles Laker star, will handle the color commentary for the telecast of the first Pizza Hut Basketball Classic from the Las Vegas Conven tion Center April 15. Charlie Jones will call the playby play in the game between East and West college all star squads.

title: It's Getting Tougher to Lie
description: The problems of securities regulation may be, as Louis Loss, Harvard law professor and the authority in this spe cialty, wrote, as old as the cupidity of sellers and the gullibility of buyers, but things seem to be changing. It's getting tougher for busi nessmen not to tell the truth.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt is now clear beyond doubt, from the Presidential election campaign apart from other evidence, that the matter of tax reform or loophole closing has in no way died away as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1969.

title: Anxiety Pervades Northlreland Town
description: DUNGANNON, Northern Ireland, March 25I'm glad to see normality here this morning. I didn't know what to expect. I thought there might be more troubles.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.,  Although some of us may tend to forget it, a lot of advertising is being created outside New York, Chicago and Detroit. And some of the people who are making it were here for the annual meeting of the American As sociation of Advertising Agencies.

title: Newark News Plans Resumption of Publication
description: NEWARK, March 25  The Evening News of Newark, shut down for 10 months by a strike and other labor problems, is now scheduled to resume pub lication by or before mid April, according to Bruce Mair, president.

title: the traveler's world
description: SAN DIEGOIt may be expecting too much from a nation barely recovering from the Howard Hughes autobiography hoax farce to hope it would not lose sight of the few truly established facts in the Re publican National ConventionSan Diego shenanigans. While waiting for some Solomon to come to final judgment on whether the White House did or did not tell the boys in the Justice Department's back room to be nice to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, it is not really fair to disparage the G.O.P. convention by association or to denigrate the legitimate efforts of San Diego to lift itself up by its Republican bootstraps into a major convention city with a generous assist by its friend and neighbor, Richard M. Nixon of San Clemnente, Calif.

title: Chinese Team Set to Leave
description: TOKYO, March 25 (AP) The first Communist Chinese sports delegation to visit the United States, a table tennis team, will leave Peking Tues day, Japan's Kyodo News Serv ice reported from the Chinesecapital today. The Chinese Table Tennis Association said the delegation of about 20 players and officials would visit Canada first and arrive in the United States around April 10.

title: U.S.C.Indiana Feud Flares in Swimming
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 25 A smoldering eightmonth controversy that may carry serious implications for United States men's swimming hopes at the Munich Olympics sur faced on the final day of the National Collegiate champion ships tonight and overshad owed three American records and Indiana's fifth successive team title.

title: Richard M. Daley Weds Mrs. Corbett
description: PITTSBURGH, March 25 Mrs. Margaret Ann Corbett, of suburban Mount Lebanon and Chicago, was married today to Richard M. Daley, Chicago lawyer, and the son of Mayor and Mrs. Richard J. Daley of Chicago.

title: Sex
description: The attitude of the Church toward sex has seldom been helpful, writes Michael J. Tay lor, S. J., in presenting this volume of essays. He might just as well have said that of most recent books about sex. But theSeattle University the ologian has compiled 13 ar ticles by various authors that contribute more light than heat.

title: Cutty Sark Classroom In London Sea School
description: LONDON  A novice can build his own boat and be come qualified to sail her on the high seas  all at the cost of a pittance  in one of the most unusual series of seamanship courses offered in the world.

title: Raena Endick Fiancee
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 25Mr. and Mrs. Murray Endick have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Raena Sue Endick, to Alan I. Korenman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Koren man of Staten Island. Miss Endick, a senior at the State University of New York at Albany, will do graduate work at Columbia University this fall. Her fianc expects to graduate from the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy in June.

title: New & Novel
description: The Grand Defiance is the log of an ingenious escape from a German fortress during World War II. Alain de Forge, who plans the grand deception, is a French general in whom re side the outstanding talents of de Gaulle, Houdini and Job.

title: Amendment on Equal Rights Now Approved by 6 States
description: Six states have now ratified an amendment to the United States Constitution that would guarantee equal rights to women.

title: Updating the Dogwoods
description: THE name dogwood originates from the practice of using an extract from the bark of the hary Euro pean shrub Corms sanguinea to wash mangy dogs. Horticulturally speak ing it contributes little except for put ting forth a valiant effort of recogni tion in the autumn. Its red foliage, dark reddish winter twigs and Oman black fruit are marvels. Actually the competi tion remains fierce among the shrubby dogwoods but C. sanguinea, while not unnerving to have around, is today gen erally considered unmarketable.

title: Costa del Sol: A Weekend Of Looking
description: MARBELLA, Spain  James Wright, a 49yearold U. S. Government employe, came to the Costa del Sol to look for a vacation home. He and his wife, who own eight houses, had heard that real estate herrii was a bonanza investment. One evening he was strolling outside his hotel with a real estate salesman who was trotting out the usual argu ments: the cost of living in Spain was low, taxes were negligible, the climate was great and there were excellent opportunities for an owner to rent an apartment or house. But Wright wasn't entirely convinced.

title: Books: Basics in Commodity Trading
description: ECONOMICS OF FUTURES TRADING. By Thomas A. Hi eronymus. 338 pages. Com modity Research Bureau, Inc. $12.95.

title: DEMOCRATS SMEAR NATION, AGNEW SAYS
description: SUMTERVILLE, Fla., March 25 (Reuters)  Vice President Agnew said today that Demo cratic Presidential hopefuls were smearing the country.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Horse Show News
description: The St. Clement's Horse Show, which annually signals the start of the major out door season in the Northeast, has added a day this year and will be held May 47 at the Saratoga Race Track in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: MELLING IS VICTOR IN PRO BOWLING
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 25 (AP)Don Helling, a lefthand er from St. Louis, won two games today to capture first prize money of $10,000 in the $70,000 Andy Granatelli Bowl ing Classic.

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Impresario Serves Up Opera for $1 on L.I.
description: One dollar will get you a a familysize tube of tooth paste. Or a 32ounce bottle of mouthwash. Or a 14 ounce can of disinfectant spray. But it also will get you into a fullscale presenta tion of a Verdi, Puccini or Bizet opera.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The chairmen of two Demo cratic party reform commis sions have proposed a radical reorganization of the party that goes beyond anything here tofore attempted in American politics.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Under the rug with My Lai went truth, duty, honor, morality
description: No single event of the Vietnam war has come more to symbolize the cat astrophic consequences of the Ameri Jean involvement than the My Lai massacre. Despite claims by mili tary and political leaders that it was only an isolated aberration by a handful of misfit troops, millions around the world have come to see it as only the largest and most pub licized of countless atrocities that have marked the war.

title: Board Issues an Interim Plan To Restore the American Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 25A United StatesCanadian board set up two years ago to study ways of restoring the crumbling American Falls here recommended in an interim report yesterday a $34million plan to shut off and shore up the falls and to remove piles of fallen boulders from its base.

title: Pregnant or Not, French Are Trying to Look It
description: PARIS (AP)Even if they're not pregnant, many Parisiennes are pretend ing to have a bulge in front these days. It's all because of the spring clothes showing up in the boutiques.

title: Karr Plays Offbeat Contrabass As a Guest of Chamber Society
description: Gary Karr, the contrabass virtuoso, was the prinicpal guest of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Tully Hall on Friday night, and his presence dictated an off beat program.

title: LifeSaver: A Courtesy Inspection
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I.Ted Darnowski has a debt of grat itude to pay to the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary. So this week, as an opera tions officer, he will help launch the Auxiliary's free annual courtesy examinations of pleasure boats on Long Is land waters.

description: Associated Press

title: Mrs. Kisg Gains Final
description: RICHMOND, March 25 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., ousted the two topseeded players today to move into the final of the Virginia Slims in ternational tennis tournament.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 25The list of home run champions in the American League has been filled with men of dis tinction. Among the many notables have been such as Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig. Jimmy Foxx, Hank Greenberg, Joe DiMag glo, Ted Williams, Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris and Bill Melton. Just a Minute, please. Who in the world is Bill Melton?

title: Training Sessions Give 3 R's to School Boards
description: PRINCETONConventions and conferences often give members of an organization the chance to escape the rou tine for a brief period of relaxation under the pretense of business.

title: L.I. 12th Graders to Get College Credit
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 25  A program to let qualified high school seniors take their first year of college education while in high school was announced this week by C. W. Post Col lege and Chaminade High School.

title: FORDHAM SCORES IN DEERING CUP
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., March 25 Well aware that though spring was only five days oldbut that it had ar rivedFordham University got an early jump on the crew rac ing season today by playing host to the third annual Deer ing Cup regatta.

title: Hunts Point Development Plan Offered
description: Community Board 2 pro posed a series of measures to the City Planning Commission last week that it said would alleviate a critical problem of industrial sites crowding out the residential sites In the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

title: A bold underground novel of the split Russian soul
description: For two centuries now, under czars and commissars, Russia has given us the most brutal autocracy and brilliant literature. During the last 20 years its best writing has come from poets, novelists and es sayists who cannot publish in their own country but whose work, in de fiance of the bureaucratic fist, finds its way into the West.

title: One Man Gripes About Perfection
description: IHAVE a complaint against the airlines. I have flown more than 250,000 miles in my 20 years as a journalist, yet I do not have one horrendous experi ence to relate. This puts me at a great disadvantage at cocktail parties when the conversation turns to air travel.

description: One of the complaints of Congres sional doves is that the executive branch often carries on its operations abroad in a manner that is not made fully known to the public. Last week there were two disclosures that seemed to illustrate this concern:

description: The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday began an investigation of Friday's collision between a school bus and frieght train in Congers, N. Y., in which three high school students were killed and more than 40 injured.

title: WELFARE OUTLAYS OF $4,1BILLION SET A RECORD IN STATE
description: ALBANY, March 25 The cost of providing welfare and Medicaid assistance for more than 1.7 million people through out the state was a record $4.1 billion in 1971, an increase of $876million over 1970, the Department of Social Services announced today.

title: State Protection Sought for Playful Harbor seals
description: TRENTONNew York act ed last week to protect its harbor seals, but in New Jersey the animals are un protected  and occasionally wounded and killed without penalty.

title: Two Supermarket Chains in the Capital Join Drive on Meat Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 The two largest supermarket chains in this metropolitan area have begun advising con sumers to combat the high price of fresh meat by using other protein sources.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As former members of the faculty of the University of Rhodesia, we wish to express our support for Africans rejecting, the, settlement proposals con tained in the HomeSmith agreement.

title: CLEANING WOMAN, 33, IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: The body of a 33yearold cleaning woman who had been stabbed, strangled and robbed was found yesterday morning in Jackson Heights, Queens.

description: Public lockers in Penn Sta tion.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Emma Lathen is a writer of the urbane school, out of Rich ard Lockrldge and (in a curious kind of way) Dorothy Sayers. Her bankerdetective John Put nam Thatcher of Sloan Guaran ty, never raises his voice, ob serves events with amused de tachment, and seldom becomesemotionally involved with the cases he is called upon to solve. Lathen's dialogue is bright, ob servant and just this side of cutesy.

title: CESARE RETURNS WITH CITY OPERA
description: Handel's Giulio Cesare, one of the City Opera's major hits since its revival in 1966, returned to the State Theater Friday night under the direc tion of Julius Rudel, its mu sical values intact, the ultra stylized production by Tito Capobianco in some need of repairs.

description: Drawing by John ??

title: U.S. Welcomes Assumption of Ulster Rule by London
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)The State Department welcomed today the British Government's decision to as sume direct rule in Northern Ireland, saying It hoped this would secure peace with jus tice in the spirit of compro mise.

title: If You Are Maimed by a Criminal, You Can Be Compensated (Maybe)
description: FRIDAY had been a good day for Jack Harris. His wife, Nelle, who had been sick for several weeks, was out of the hospital; his four children were excited about Christmas, a week away, and the car trunk was full of presents for them from fellow employes at North shore Hospital, where he worked as a kitchen helper. Everyone seemed happy and expectant. All in all, A very good day.

title: Enemy Still Trying to Seize Defenses at Key Laos Base
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. March 25 North Vietnamese forces, in heavy shelling beginning last Saturday and followed by a se ries of ground attacks have driven Laotian troops off four of the nine positions on the ridge overlooking the mountain base at Long Tieng.

title: POLLUTION GALLED CALIFORNIA PERIL
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 25Californians have been warned by their own State Environmental Quality Study Council that the state is losing the battle against pollution on all fronts.

title: POLL FINDS SURGE IN MARIJUANA USE
description: The Gallup Poll has found that the percentage of adults in the United States 18 and older who have tried marijuana has nearly tripled over the last two and a half years.

title: 50 Filipino Refugees Die
description: MANILA, March 25 (AP) The Manila Times reported to day that at least 50 persons, mostly children, have died from hunger and disease in a Moslem refugee camp on the island of Mindanao. A dispatch from Co tabato city said that the mayor had reported that 10,000 refu gees in his municipality were suffering from an acute short age of food and medicine.

title: Photography
description: THE differences in the work of Thomas Bar row and that of Charles Gatewood both presently on view at the Light Gallery, 1018 Mad ison Avenueboil down to a distinction between the lit erary and vernacular modes in photography.

title: Finally, a Rock Movie That Stars the Music
description: HOW long does it take for inventiveness to become clich? For the bright, clear flash of a new way of looking at things to blur into a mass of indiscriminate, meaning less color?

title: 6 STATES GET DELAY ON CLEANAIR RULES
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The Environmental Pro tection Agency has given six states an 18month extension of the deadline for submitting plans to meet secondary na tionwide cleanair standards.

title: Miss Spaulding Becomes Bride
description: HINGHAM, Mass., March 25In the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist here this afternoon Miss Martha Ann Spaulding, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Spaulding, was mar ried to Charles Fontaine. Mar tin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fon taine Martin of Darien, Conn. The Rev. John Gallop per formed the ceremony.

title: The Nation
description: Representative Nicholas J. Begich, Democrat of Alaska, had a complaint: We're tired of always having East erners say, Because we made a mess of our backyard, we want to make sure your backyard isn't messed up.

title: Solution For Wisteria
description: THE wisteria has long been a favorite with home gardeners, for its regal racemes of pealike flowers in lavender, pink and white.

title: Mimi Stone Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Chauncey Ives of New York and Bromley S. Stone of New York and Lo cust Valley, L. I., of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Mary CliffJones Stone, to David Elliott White, son of Mrs. Elliott White of Darien, Conn., and Frederick Kingi bury White of New York. The wedding is planned for June.

title: From Marlboro, Six Chamber Players
description: The program was entitled Music from the Marlboro Fes tival, and of course it fea tured young and veteran musicians who come to nestle every summer in Vermont under the wide wings of Ru dolf Serkin. Milne Barrett, pianist; Annie Kavafian, vio linist; Nancy Cirillo, violist, and Timothy Eddy, cellist, were the pretty little chicks. Isidore Cohen, violinist, and Julius Levine, bassist, were the veterans.

title: George Sargent Plans to Wed Miss Cynthia Browne in June
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Britton Browne Jr. of Wash ington and Watch Hill, R. I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Browne, to George Paull Terrence Sargent, son of Mrs. Randall Hagner Jr. of Washington and the late Christopher Smith Sargent. The wedding is planned for June here.

title: Brazil Clinches Match
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 (UPI)Brazil clinched a first round victory in South Ameri can Davis Cup play today by winning a doubles match against Venezuela.

title: Mrs. Knauer's Comments
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI)President Nixon's con sumer affairs adviser, Mrs. Vir ginia H. Knauer, urged shoppers to buy more meat substitutes and less precooked, frozen or other processed foods until grocery prices leveled off.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn 1916 Gen. Smed ley Butler of the United States Marines led his troops ashore in the Dominican Republicto make that country safe, as he put it, for the bogs of the Na tional City Bank. The little Caribbean nation had defaulted on loan payments and other obligations, and the United States had decided to Intervene mili tarily to restore order.

title: Karen Hauck To Be Bride
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., March 25Miss Karen Marie Hauck and William Charles Frank, 1970 graduates of Washington College in Ches tertown, Md., plan to be mar ried late next month in Ho bart, Tasmania, where the fu ture bridegroom is engaged in commercial fishing.

title: Barbara A. Perina Prospective Bride
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 25Dr. and Mrs. Anson Perina have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Penne, to Dixon Mac Donald Merkt, son of Adolph Julius Merkt of New York, Guilford, Conn., and Nan tucket, Mass., and the late Mrs. Virginia Harris Merkt.

title: Hunterdon County Residents Question Suburban Development
description: FLEMINGTON  A couple of weeks ago, people jam packed the 1,000seat high school auditorium here for a performance of the ainfield Symphony. Last Sunday, only 150 people drifted in to hear Paul Davidoff, a leading advocate of opening up the suburbs to solve innercity housing and job problems.

title: THE ARTIFICIAL TWINNING SPECTER
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: About Motor Sports
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 25 Today's Twelve Hours of Sebring was the annual last race on Sebring's World War II airport. With all the extensions wangled in the last few years from international safety inspec tors, insurers and the air port authority, this 21yearold airport lay out has played more farewells than Sarah Bern hardt and has had more revivalsthan Phoenix. But the con sensus this weekend was that today's race was indeed the last one at the airport. Few will lament its passing.

title: HOW TO:
description: Ladies who own and skipper their boats have the same fittingout prob lems as their male counterparts. Most are systematic, have thought through their project and have set up a work time schedule to get boats ready for the water.

title: Coins
description: THE first Ancient, Medie val and Foreign Inter national Coln Conven tion will be held here May 12 and 13, it was an nounced last week by Edward P. Hartmann, managing di rector of Numismatics Com munications, of this city. The show will be held in the War wick Hotel, Sixth Avenue and 54th Street. There will be no admission charge either day and visiting hours will be from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

title: Education
description: Reading tests in elementary schools are intended to serve sev eral purposes. They let school sys tems, principals and teachers eval uate the success of instruction. They provide a comparative yard stick for the effectiveness of schools within a system, classes within a school, children within a class. They are a diagnostic tool to help children improve their per formances.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  Hey, look who's on television! an Argentine store clerk said excitedly, and a crowd gathered around the set to see. The attraction was Juan Domingo Pern, the exiled former populist dic tator, on a filmed shopping trip to a Supermarket in Madrid, where he has been living for nearly ten years. Sev eral million television viewers watched Mr. Pern pick out vege tables, instruct a butcher on cutting his beefsteaks, and get a friendly pat on his sagging cheek from his third wife, Isabel, a former cabaret dancer.

title: FLA. STATE LOSES
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 There may come a day when the University of California, Los Angeles is no longer the National Collegiate basketball champion. But that time seem ed far off today after the Bruins defeated Florida State, 8176, to give U.C.L.A. its sixth consecutive national title and eighth in the last nine seasons.

title: Mrs. Schwarz Has Child
description: A daughter was born last Wednesday to Mr. and Mrs. Allan Schwarz of New York at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, Queens. Mrs. Schwarz, the former Gail Cahn, is a speech therapist in the city school system. Her husband is a realestate broker with Wil liam A. White. The child has been named Jeanne Suzann.

title: IN THE NATION
description: George Wallace has been elected to no major office but that of Governor of Alabama, and in all of his cele brated battles with the Federal Gov ernment he has been defeated. But those who dwelt upon that fact, Mr. Wallace once said, simply did not understand the uses of defiance.

title: LEGISLATORS PICK ART FOR THE MAIL
description: ALBANY, March 25Separate but equal muses are at work on the huge South Mall state office project as the legislative branch moves into its new mar bled home conceived by the chief executive and noted arts patron, Governor Rockefeller.

title: Longshoremen Reach Accord in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP)A Federal mediator an nounced a tentative agree ment today that would end a nineday strike of dock work ers at the Port of Philadel phia.

title: Practice Makes Perfect
description: THE perfect garden would allow each family member the outdoor pleasures without wearying and unpleasant maintenance. Most gardens will end up as a compromise.

title: MushroomLike District Is Just Roncallo's Dish

title: Medicine
description: When you get one of these lib erated women in bed, one male col lege student complained, you damn well better perform the way they want, or that'll be the end of the re lationship.

title: MICHIGAN INDIANS RUN A NEWSPAPER
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., March 25A newspaper designed to get the Indian to reexamine his roleproduced by Indians for Indiansshows signs of flour ishing after eight months of publication.

title: Mary G. Connorton, a Teacher, Is Bride of Daniel P. FitzGerald
description: Miss Mary Grace Connor ton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John V. Connorton of New York, was married here yes terday afternoon to Daniel P. FitzGerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Francis FitzGerald of White Plains.

title: Knicks Win, 9883, Set Crowd Record
description: The Knicks ended their Na tional Basketball Association regular home schedule last night before a capacity crowd that established a pro basket ball season attendance record and, to mark the occasion, handed the Cleveland Cavaliers a 9883 trimming at Madison Square Garden.

title: Los Angeles Survey Finds Most Blacks Like the Police
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UPI)A majority of blacks here like the police and want more police patrols in their neighborhoods, a Police De partment survey has con cluded.

title: Law
description: The Warren Court's ruling in the case of Miranda V. Arizona has never been one of President Nixon's favorites. The decision, handed down in 1966, held that unless suspects are advised of their rights prior to interrogation by police, no confessions or statements they make can be used in court. Time and again, Mr. Nixon has charged that it unduly favored the criminal forces in society and has urged that it, be overturned.

title: Counselor Is Teaching A Subject He Practices
description: MONTCLAIRYou have to be a parttime psycholo gist, project a fatherimage and exhibit enough empathy to be rated a friend, Frank Brunette of Ridgewood tells his classes in student coun seling at Montclait State College.

title: Washington and Other Memories
description: The recollections of a mem ber of the British upper classes who served as London Times correspondent in postWorld War I Washington, then shifted to the British Foreign Office. He rubbed elbows with most of the U. S. political figures between the wars; obviously was intelligent and charming; kept a diary and has a good memory. Now crowding 90, he has written an agreeable book that will be of interest to readers old enough to remem ber it all and to historians of the period, who may find in it occasional footnote aside.

title: Military Revolt in El Salvador Reported Crushed
description: SAN SALVADOR, Sunday, March 26  Rebel military forces attemped to overthrow the Government of E1 Salvador yesterday, but President Fidel Sancehz Hernandez said in a radiotelevision broadcast they had been crushed.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: SICCO L. MANSHOLT became the fourth president the Common Market Executive Commission. Dr. Mansholt, a farmer, assumed his duties during the bloc's continuing dispute over agricultural policies Britain cut taxes by $3.14billion to spur economic recovery before joining the E.E.C. Foreign investment by U.S. companies, although planned to be a record $15.2billion in 1972, is beginning to slow, the Commerce Department reported.

title: Bronx Man Killed Fixing Flat
description: A Bronx man was struck and killed by a car early yes terday morning while he was fixing a flat tire on his car on the 207th Street Bridge con necting Manhattan and the Bronx. He was identified as Eugene Turner, 25 years old. The police would not reveal his address. The driver of the other car was identified as James O'Connor, 50, of 454 Quincy Avenue, the Bronx. He was charged with vehicular homicide and driving under the influence of intoxicants.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The New York Post editorial page editor's account, written with his wife and daughter, of his son Michael's long day's journey into night. Michael died at 26 from an overdose of barbiturates. Prior to that he had had a history of mental illness stretching back nine years, during which he had seen eight psychiatrists and been hospitalized in five insti tutions. The grieving parents haven't found an answer to the tragedy. The young man bounced from doctor to doctor him an errant pinball; none seemed to agree on his trouble; each new treatment started afresh, as if nothing had gone before. The book is not so much an indictment of psychiatry as baffled (and courageous)

title: MARKET WEIGHING BREZHNEV SPEECH
description: PARIS, March 25The Com mon Market's foreign affairs specialists say that a major speech by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, indicates that a corner may have been turned in the Market's relations with the So viet Union and Eastern Europe.

title: Soviet to Seek Soil. From Back of Moon
description: MOSCOW, March 25One of the next goals of Soviet lunar exploration is the return of the first soil samples from the far side of the moon.

title: News of Dogs
description: Leonard B. Brumby Jr. has been elected senior vice president and Normsn J. Furber a vice president of the American Kennel Club by the board of directors.

title: Andretti  Ickx, in Ferrari, Win at Sebring
description: SEBRING, Fla., March 25 Mario Andretti of the United States and Jacky Ickx of Bel gium won the Twelve Hours of Sebring tonight in a rela tively easy onetwo finish for the Ferrari factory. The runner up was driven by Ronnie Peter son of Sweden and Tim Schenken of Australia.

title: A Priority Fulfilled: Turner's Ocean Title
description: Ted Turner, sailing's inde fatigable maninmotion from the landlocked port of At lanta, was back in action again this winter on the Southern Ocean Racing Con ference following his capture of the first world oceanrac ing championship.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A Memorial for Winchell Set at The Lambs April 7
description: A memorial service for Wal ter Winchell will be held at The Lambs, the theatrical club at 130 West 44th Street, on Friday, April 7, at 2 P.M. The day would have been the 75th birthday of the newspaper col umnist and commentator.

title: Something Special
description: Camping is a vacation that provides fun for any child. But it is something specialfor a crippled youngster. In addition to outdoor fun, he has an op portunity to develop self reliance, learn new skills and share in groupactivities with those who have similar handicaps.

title: I.T.T. Tax Ruling Linked To Complex Maneuvering
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation en gaged in complicated maneu vering to gain a favorable tax ruling necessary to accomplish its controversial 1970 merger with the Hartford Fire Insur ance Company.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Margiotta Calls the Shots in Nassau
description: ALBANYIn the cave of the winds, watch out for the quiet ones.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 Hubert H. Humphrey broke off his campaigning in Wisconsin this week to search for con vention delegates and money in Oklahoma, Nebraska, California and Pennsylvania.

title: Pope Opens Library Exhibition Of Vatican's Biblical Treasures
description: ROME, March 25Pope Paul VI opened today an exhibi tion of Biblical manuscripts and early printed editions of the Bible that put some of the rarest treasures of the Vatican Library on display.

title: The Economy
description: WASHINGTONGeorge finally did it. Until last week, President Nixon's economic stabilization program, what ever its virtues or failures, had been sailing on smooth political waters. No effective voice among the Democratic Presidential candidates had been lifted in opposition to the President's policies for curing the country's economic ills.

title: Young Democratic Activist Believes in the System
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Margaret Callahan, a 19 yearold sophomore at Molloy College, is the first teenage zone leader elected in the country and she says she really believes in the Amer ican democratic process.

title: It's Dawn for Platform Tennis
description: PRINCETON  One of the nicest things about paddle tennis is watching the dawn come up, said Mrs. Sheila Leyton, of Princeton, last week, as she and her husband, Eric Leyton, fin ished a game at the Princeton Community Platform Tennis courts.

title: Miss Janice A. Walsh Will Marry on May 6
description: John M. Walsh, a vice pres ident of the New York Tele phone Company, and Mrs. Walsh of New York and Man toloking, N. J., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janice Ann Walsh, to Joseph Patrick Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Kelly of East Greenbush, N. Y. The wed ding is planned for May 6 at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: COOP CURBS ASKED BY TENANT GROUPS
description: Tenants' groups that packed a public hearing yesterday on a bill that would make it more difficult to change an apart ment building with rental units into a cooperative bitterly crit icized politicians for allegedly dragging their feet on the measure while giving it lip service.

title: Meadowlands Projects Opposed by a Coalition
description: ENGLEWOOD  They've been called idealists, hot eyed critics and un realistic. Nevertheless, the Save the Meadowlands Coali tion is gathering strength to become strong enough to buck the proposed sports complex and industrialresi dential development of New Jersey's 20,000acre Meadow lands.

title: Under water
description: I began John Lilly's fourth book, The Center of the Cyclone, with a feeling of excitement. Here was a 56yearold man with impeccable sci entific credentialsa physician and psychoanalyst, with training in neuro physiology, biophysics and electron ics  who was devoting himself to exploring a variety of states of consciousness that are generally re garded as beyond the scientific pale.

title: End of Rocket Project Produces Space Age Ghost Town
description: JACKASS FLATS, Nev., March 18 The carcass of the Fed eral nuclear rocket program a $1.4billion effort lasting 15 years  that has just expired sprawls across the desert here below the summit of Skull Mountain near Death Valley.

description: The World

title: Plan to Use Herbicide at Park Touches Off Dispute in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 25 A herbicide employed in Viet name to kill thick vegetation that could shelter an enemy force may be used in Baxter State Park in northern Maine.

title: WHAT TO:
description: Whoever said There's nothing new under the sun forgot about the in genuity of marineaccessory manufac turers. If there is a chance or a place for a new product, they will come up with it and if there already is such a product, they will improve it.
