description: Winter's Dream

title: SHOP TALK
description: MORRISTOWN  There should be more places like Morristown. Where else will you find the ugly board fences of Urban Renewal turned into an outdoor art show? And, a few blocks away, a handsome county courthouse, built in 1827 in the GrecoRoman style?

title: L.I. Supermarket Paid $500 in Fines On Sanitary Code
description: A Levittown, L. I., super market paid the highest fine levied last month by the New York State Department of Agri culture and Markets for un sanitary conditions, the depart ment has reported.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: PARAMUS  If bigname bands are making a come back in the Metropolitan areaand the fact that Rose land, the New York City ballroom that was a home for name bands in the '20s, '30s and '40s, is now booking name bands regularly for the first time in more than 20 years suggests that some thing is happeningthen Leo Pinkus has to be one of the most perceptive entrepre neurs in the area.

title: Needle Infections Rise in Drug Abuse
description: The spreading epidemic of drug abuse in the country has brought with it an increase in infectious diseases caused by the use of contaminated needles and syringes among persons who inject themselves with heroin, amphetamines and many other drugs.

title: Democratic Caucuses in Maine Give Big Majorities to Mashie
description: PORTLAND, Me., March 25 There is no more doubt that Senator Edmund S. Muskie, the Polish tailor's son from central Maine, will carry this state's Democratic delegation than there is doubt that the tide will rise and fall tomorrow on the rocky shores of Casco Bay.

title: Black Lawyers to Fight Racial Injustice
description: To some 60 black lawyers and law students gathered in an upstairs ballroom at the Staler Hilton, the time had come to be a little less lawyer like at, least in the tradtional sense of the National Bar As sociation.

title: NOW Says Democrats Pick Beauty Over Brain
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 25 (AP)The Democratic party is using a sexist appioach in hiring hostesses for cits na tional convention here this summer, a women's libera tion group contends.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Daniel Hcchter, one of France's largest readytowear manufacturers, has opened a showroom on Seventh Ave nue for the direct sale of his product to American retailers.

title: Mental Health Clinic
description: The Mental Health Clinic of Flushing Hospital has re ceived a $40,000 matching funds grant from the New York City Department of Mental Health Services, en abling the clinic to expand its services to children in the Flushing  Whitestone  Beech hurst  Melba  College Point area.

title: U.S. HEROIN DRIVE SET IN 33 CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP)The Justice Department has picked 33 cities in which teams of Federal, state and lo cal Jaw enforcement officials will concentrate efforts to stop the flow of heroin on the na tion's streets.

title: BADILLO OPPOSES CON ED EXPANSION
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo urged the Army Corps of Engineers yesterday to deny a permit for the proposed ex pansion of Consolidated Edi son's generating plant in As toria, Queens.

title: New Orleans, Hoping to Outdo Houston, Putting Up Ultimate StadiumSuperdome
description: We've got to stop the peo ple in ?? from going to that damned domed sta dlum in Houston, said Hor ace L. Hayden, who is doing more than his share to re vive his home town, New Or leans.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: One reason lobsters are so expensive is that it takes eight years at sea, from Cape Cod northward for them to grow to one pound.

title: There was time for visions and revisions
description: The problem of the relationship between great poetry and the beliefs of the man who wrote it is sometimes dismissed as insoluble or unimpor tant, and sometimes fanatically ex aggerated. The severance between poetry and all belief which I. A. Rich ards found in The Waste Land (though Eliot did not) can be per suasively argued; the triviality or even wickedness of poetry that reflects be liefs inconsistent with one's own has often been proclaimed. Few of us have the intellectual purity implied by the first position or the fanaticism of the second. We put the question out of our minds. But some of the great early moderns force it on us because of their passion for systems of belief which offer drastic solutions to the world's problems. Eliot's was a Christian answer. NonChristian ad mirers of the poetry may find com fort in his own formulapoetry can tell you what it feels like to believe certain things without requiring you to believe them toobut this may not be enough if you accept certain implications of the prose: that your lack of Christian belief, especially if you replace it with belief in some thing else, is evidence of barbarism or heresy, or at best hollow indif ferentism.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Seaver Pitches Solidly in Mets' 74 Triumph, Allowing 3 Hits in 6 Innings
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25  Tom Seaver pitched six solid innings of threehit ball today as the New York Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 74, but the Mets had big trouble back in the barn with Danny Frisella, their No. 1 righthanded relief pitcher.

title: Elizabeth Stolba Plans June Bridal
description: CROMWELL, Conn., March 25Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stolba have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Stolba, to George Bliss Reese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Livingston Mesier Reese of New Hamburg, N. Y., and Hewlett, L. I.

title: A Vast Industrial Park Is Growing in Meadowlands
description: SECAUCUSWhat is billed as the largest industrial park in New Jersey is rising dra matically in the Meadow lands, directly across the Hudson River from Midtown Manhattan.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Conservative Groups Mount Campaign Against Chavez Union
description: KEENE, Calif., March 25 Less than two years after it Won landmark contracts in the California grape industry, the United Farm Workers is under fierce attack, and its leaders are fighting for survival.

title: Houseguests Who Refuse to Say Goodby
description: NOT too long ago, a colonel at Fort Monroe, Va., out late one eve ning, saw what he later de scribed as a large dark form in the murky waters of the tidal moat surrounding the military base. The colo nel followed the formlarger than a dog but not as big as the Loch Ness monsterand watched it move back and forth across the moat until it disap peared under a postern bridge. This is only the most recent event in a 150year history of reports of things moving around in the moat and in houses on the grounds of the walled fort, an active U.S. Army post. The colonel's  and other officers'sightings occasioned humorous references in the post news paper. But with the recent publication of The Ghosts of Fort Monroe, a book describing all the spectral shenanigans in the area, the subject of local apparitions has evoked considerable curiosity.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Leave Firm Impression
description: We not Russians, the visitors kept saying, we Georgians.

title: Music
description: IT was late in the afternoon, and Karl Boehm was back in his Cen tral Park West hotel room. He had spent the day rehearsing Acts I and III of Verdi's Otello at the Metropoli tan Opera, and it had been the first time the staging and musical elements had been put together, always a diffi cult business. The 77yearold conductor sounded as if he had a cold. He ad mitted that he did. I woke up this morning feeling very tired. The weather here is so changeable. But after I had been conducting the rehearsal for 15 minutes, I was back in my element and I felt fine. That is always the way with me. If I couldn't conduct, I don't think I would want to live any more.

title: Federal Agents Seize Cuban Festival Films Here
description: Less than an hour before the first New York Festival of Cuban Films was to go into its second day at the Olympia The ater yesterday afternoon, Fed eral agents carrying a search warrant confiscated films and propaganda material. The ac tion forced, the cancellation of six programs scheduled for yes terday and today.

title: State Art Grants: Less Money for More Groups
description: In its second year of ma jor public aid to the arts, the state gave less money to more groups$13million to 810 arts organizations, com pared with $18million to 600 groups in the previous year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Among the gods of twilight, George Blanda of the Oakland Raiders has been revered as the toughest of the old athletes. But he is a place kicker and a substitute quarterback. He wears a helmet with a protective face bar. And his season in volves only 14, games. Not that George Blanda is to be scorned. Soon to be 44 years old, he is a snarling competitor. Butthe toughest of the old ath letes Just might be Lorne (Gump) Worsley, soon to be 43, a pudgy goaltender who has signed a new twoyear contract with the Minnesota North Stars through the 1974 Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Police in Japan Find Bodies of 2 From Radical Group
description: TOKYO, March 25 (UPI) The police dug up today the bodies of two former members of a radical Japanese youth group dedicated to overthrow ing the Government.

title: DISEASED CATTLE HELD BEEF SOURCE
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 25A researcher who has found a highly successful treatment for a common can cer of beef cattle said here to day that in his studies he had discovered that some diseased cattle were passing inspection and reaching the American market place.

title: TWOACT TRIANGLE ON LONDON BOARDS
description: LONDON, March 25  In Notes on a Love Affair at the Globe Theater, Frank Mar cus attempts the hazardous act of dramatic striptease: a play that Invites us to prowl around the workroom and inspect the tricks of playwriting and then to marvel: at the creation of something out of nothing.

title: Who is Bob Miller
description: I want to put the America's Cup out of its misery. I want to kill it. It's a terrible series, the heavyweight cham pionship of yachting. Once someone has won it, it will be all over. Its just a big waste of money.

title: Movies
description: ACTOR Alan Arkin, who turned movie director last year with Jules Feiffer's Little Mur ders, is about to take that turn again, this time with a film version of Kurt Von negut Jr.'s first novel, Player Piano. Arkin and Vonnegut will join producers Edward Pressman and Burtt Harris on the independent project, which should get under way this summer, And, says Har ris, not only will Arkin di rect but he has also written the script.

title: MUSKIE CENSURES NIXON IN MADISON
description: MILWAUKEE, March 25 Senator Edmund S. Muskie returned to the Wisconsin Democratic Presidential primary campaign today and sharply attacked President Nixon's en vironmental policies.

title: Tommy Jacobs Finds a Home After 13 Years on Golf Tour
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif. For 13 years, Tommy Jacobs played the professional golf tour. He won four tournaments, earned $227,000, almost be came United States Open champion in 1964 and Masters champion in 1966 and, toward the end, got tired of the rat race.

title: John William Ryan, 73, Of Construction Company
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 26John William Ryan, president and founder of the John W. Ryan Construction Company, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 166 Wilmot Road.

title: Queen Elizabeth Home After Long Trip Abroad
description: LONDON, March 26 (UPI) Queen Elizabeth II arrived home tonight from a nearly sevenweek tour abroad. Her jet landed at cold, windy Heathrow airport.

title: Roosevelt and Stalin: A Revelation
description: HOUSTONImportant new evidence has come to light regarding the begin nings of the cold war and how Presi dent Roosevelt felt about the Soviet Union and its ambitions just before his death in April, 1945.

title: Rangers Lose, 50
description: On a night in which the Rangers were denied first place for the 30th consecutive year, many Minnesota North Stars pummeled a fan who had cursed them and had leaped on one of the players after Minne sota defeated the New Yorkers, 50, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lanigan Stars as Riverdale Keeps Speed Skate Title
description: The Riverdale Speed Skating Club, paced by Billy Lanigan, scored 78 points and won its fifth consecutive title before 1,308 fans at the ninth annual Middle Atlantic meet at the Riverdale Arena yesterday.

title: Marcia Kastenbaum Wed
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., March 26Miss Marcia Dale Kasten baum and Evan Michael Kress were married this af ternoon at the Tanuny Brook Country Club by Rabbi Solo mon Rothstein. The parents of, the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kastenbaum of Fort Lee and Mr. and Mrs. David Kress of the Bronx.

title: Saigon's Troops Report Killing 106 of Foe in Clashes Near Hue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 26 (UPI)The South Vietnamese reported killing 106 ?? troops today in three clashes near the old imperial city of Hue.

title: Mrs. Marcos Ends Tour
description: MANILA, March 26 (Reuters) The wife of President Ferdi nand E. Marcos returned today after a 22day trip that in eluded a visit to Moscow.

title: WILLIAM NKOMO, AFRICAN LEADER
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 26 (AP)  Dr. William Nkomo, first black president of the South African Institute of Race Relations and a prominent African leader, spokesman, ed ucator and ctitic of apartheid and the South African govern ment, died here today of a heart attack.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Blockstein Bride Of R. M. Schwarzbart
description: Miss Sandra Rae Block stein was married here at noon yesterday to Robert Morton Schwarzbart, son of Hugo Schwarzbart of New York and the late Mrs. Schwarzbart. Rabbi Jacob Goldberg performed the cere mony at the Essex House. The bride's parents are Mrs. Morris Blockstein of Pitts burgh and the late Mr. Block stein.

title: LAKERS WIN 69TH FOR N.B.A. RECORD
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 The Los Angeles Lakers set a National Basketball Association season record of 69 victories by defeating the Seattle Super Sonics, 12498, tonight in the final game of the regular sea son.

title: Yugoslavia Spurring Action To Bar Smallpox Outbreak
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26 (AP)A largescale program of vaccination against smallpox was carried out today in Belgrad and other Yugoslav cities.

title: JUMP TITLE WON BY DADDY'S BABY
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., March 26Dr. George West's Daddy's Baby captured one class and fi nished fourth in another to win the Open Jumper championship today at the concluding session of the twoday The Hill Horse Show.

title: Odasz Victor in Tennis
description: Bobby Odasz, unseeded led the way into the quarterfinals of the first New York City open indoor tennis tournament yes terday with a 60, 63 victory over Randall King at the Wall Street Racquet Club. Among the seeded players Peter Doer ner and Rod Brent gained the third round, Bob Barker was upset by Don Brousseau, 62, 6.3, and Ray Garrido bowed to Ray Wilson, 64, 67, 64. Gary Reiner edged Kevin Graham, 75. 64.

title: Tragic Negligence
description: Routine precautions could have prevented the tragedy last week that killed three high school students and critically injured many more when a freight train tore through a Rockland County school bus.

title: A. B. C. to Show 2 Divorce Films With Burtons Exchanging Leads
description: Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton will star next season in two madefortelevision 90 minute motion, pictures to be shown by the American Broad casting Company. It will be the first time the Burton have ap peared together in movies made especially for this medium.

title: DISSIDENTS IMPERIL VEGA PLANT ACCORD
description: WARREN, Ohio, March 26 (AP)The 22day strike against the General Motors Corpora tion's Lordstown complex end ed today with ratification of new contract by United Auto mobile Workers. Local 112; but about half of the plant's 600 skilled tradesmen said that they, would refuse to work.

title: Stealing Home Plate
description: Michael Burke, president of the New York Yankees, has let it be known that his team's decision to stay in New York was, in a sense, a declaration of faith in the city and its future. He said so after accepting what amounts to a blank check, signed by the city's taxpayers, with the amount to be filled in later by the Yankees.

title: DACCA TAKES OVER MAIN INDUSTRIES
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 26The Government of Ban gladesh, formerly East Pakistan, tonight announced the nation alization of the new nation's major industries in a move that mostly affected bigbusiness families from West Pakistan, who used to dominate industry here.

description: NEW ORLEANS. March 26 Gary Player of South Africa made it two in a row for foreign golf professionals on the tour today when he won the Greater New Orleans open by one stroke.

title: Advertising:
description: Almost the very first thing Cunningham & Walsh did Friday after American Mo tors informed them that they'd been given the pas senger car account, was to run a drawing for a brand new Gremlin. That's how happy management was.

title: Black Hawk's Win, 40
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (UPI) Tony Esposito, the Black Hawks' goalie, posted his ninth shutout today and the Hull brothers, Bobby and Dennis, each scored once as Chicago defeated the St. Louis Blues, 40.

title: Underground Gasoline Lake Poses Threat in Jersey
description: SEWAREN, N. J., March 26  From a well in the yard beside her asbestos shingled home here, Mrs. Fred Klopsch can draw gaso line pure enough to run her power lawn mower.

title: Hamilton Warren, Founder Of Prep School in Arizona
description: SEDONA, Ariz., March 26 Hamilton Warren, founder of the Verde Valley School, a non profit, multiracial college prep aratory school here, died at his home today. He was 68 years old.

title: Brian's Song Wins a Peabody Award

title: N.A.S.D. DISCIPLINES BROKERAGE HOUSES
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers announced yesterday that it had taken dis ciplinary action against 10 firms and 18 individuals. The associton charged that they had violated its rules of fair practice. Four of the firms and nine individuals were from New York.

title: South African Crash Kills 8
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, March 26 (UPI)Two light aircraft collided today about 26 relies southeast of Pretoria, police officials said, and at least eight persons were killed. One of the planes was prepar ing to land at a private air strip near Hartbeeepoortthun when it struck the other, which was taking off. Both burst into Barns.

Mean while, a survey of the first 340 elected delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion showed that the party's reform rules were falling short of their goals in regard to representation for women, youth and minorities. Other political news, Page 24.

title: Envoy to Australia Defends Investment By U.S. Companies
description: CANBERRA, Australia, March 26Walter I. Rice, the United States Ambassador to Aus tralia, has come out strongly in defense of American in vestors here. They are currently under intensive fire by politi cians, conservationists and economic nationalists.

title: HOGAN CRITICIZES MEDIA ON IRVINGS
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. and Manhattan District Attorney Frimk S. Hogan accused the media yesterday of misleading the public by presenting spec ulation as fact in news ac counts of the investigation of the purported Howard Hughes autobiography.

title: SOVIET PLANNING LANDING ON MARS
description: MOSCOW, March 26In the next few years, perhaps in late 1973, the Soviet Union hopes to land a robot lifedetection laboratory an Mars.

description: BOSTON, March 26 (UPI) John Havlicek scored 27 points and led the Boston Celtics to a 133120 victory today over the Detroit Pistons in the last reg ularseason game. The Celtics will meet the Atlanta Hawks in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Sports of The Times
description: Tracey Souter Barrett, alias Richard Oliver Barrett, alias Dick Oliver, also known as Kewpie Barrett, was a cheerful and crafty gentleman out of Montoursville, Pa., where Loyalsock Creek joins the West Branch of the Sus quehanna near Williamsport. Though he looked like a bartender, Dick Barrett threw baseballs for a living more than 20 years, and he had an armament of pitches as varied and confusing as his names.

title: Bridge: Precision Team Ousts Aces In Semifinals at Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, March 26 The Precision Team, consist ing of six young experts from the New York area, ousted the world champion Aces early today from the Vander bilt Cup competition in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. This afternoon, the victors began play in the final against a lesserknown foursome led by Paul Swan son of Morgantown, W. Va.

title: To Gather Material, It Took Patience and a Ruse
description: The plan for publication of Dr. Albert Einstein's papers, assembled through years of search, negotiationand, to some degree, a diplomatic ruserep resents one of the more ambitious pub lishing ventures of the century.

title: Frogs Fight in Malaysia
description: PENANG, Malaysia, March 26 (AP)  Two species of frogs battled for five hours today, an event that local residents believe portends a coming dis aster but that zoologists say is a fight for breeding grounds. About 70 reportedly died in the battle.

title: Labor Eager for '72 Fight On Food Price Increases
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 One of the most bitter political struggles of the 1972 campaign will be fought out on the un likeliest of battlegrounds: the neighborhood supermarket.

title: ROYALS DEFEATED BY YANKEES, 20
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26  Mel Stottlemyre and Sparky Lyle faced on 27 batters today as they pitched a onehit 20 victory over the Kansas City Royals and helped the New York Yankees sharpen their pitching staff for the ap proaching season.

title: Charles H. Singer Dead at 69; Radio and Electronics Pioneer
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  Charles H. Singer, one of Amer ica's pioneers in radio and electronic communications, died today of cancer at Sibley Hos pital. He was 69 years old.

title: I.R.S., for IncomeTax Cheats, Has Many Unhappy Returns
description: On a morning in Decem ber, 1961, a man walked into a bank in midtown Manhat tan and cashed a check for $10,000.

title: Royals Triumph, 135122
description: CLEVELAND, March 26  Nate Archibald scored 45 points and John Mengelt 28 as the Cincinnati Royals beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 135 122, tonight. It was the last game for the Royals as repre sentatives of Cincinnati. Theywill play in Kansas City next season.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI, March 26 (AP)A 38yearold black woman who was chosen as a Democratic National Convention delegate for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that she would turn down the post. Her husband said she feared repris als from the black community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Installs 4 Street Lights After 8 Months of Complaints
description: After eight months of prod ding, an East Side community board, with some help from Bellevue Hospital, has suc ceeded in shedding new light on the neighborhood  and on the city bureaucracy.

title: Haiphong Took a Beating but Supplies Keep Flowing
description: HAIPHONG, North Vietnam, March 12North Vietnam plans to expand its harbor facilities here at least 50 per cent in the next year.

title: 2 Chilean Rightists Charged With Violations of Security
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 26 (Reuters)A Santiago judge today formally charged the president and secretary general of an extreme rightwing or ganization called Patna y Libertad (Country and Free dom) with having violated Chile's internal state security.

title: Catholic Among 3 Ministers Named for Ulster by Heath
description: LONDON, March 26Prime Minister Heath today named a Roman Catholic among three ministers to serve in the new Northern Ireland office, which becomes effective this Thurs day.

title: The Einstein Papers: Childhood Showed a Gift for the Abstract
description: When a boy was born in Ulm, Germany, on March 14, 1879, his head was so large and angular that his mother feared her child was de formed until she was reas sured by her doctor that it would grow normally. The baby was given the name Albert Einstein.

title: 2 Youths Shot in Bronx As Rival Gangs Battle
description: Two young members of a Bronx youth gang were shot and seriously wounded last night when members of a rival gang invaded their meeting place in the cellar of a tene ment in the Morrisania section, the police reported.

title: TERRELLZUG TEAM CAPTURES U.S. TITLE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 26 The second  seeded team of Larry Terrell and Jim Zug of Philadelphia won the national squash racquets doubles champ ionship today at the Minneapo lis club, defeating topseeded Peter Martin and Colin Adair of Montreal, 515, 11.15, 1512, 1510, 159.

title: Man in the News
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land. March 26He speaks in a solemn monotone, rarely raising his voice. At packed rallies he steps to the rostrum and almost hypnotically, wills the crowd into silence. His voice is even and emotion less; his words are electric.

title: Reserve Is Facing Possible Dilemma On Interest Rates
description: Shortterm interest rates dis played signs late last week of renewed upward pressure, a de velopment that credit analysts believe would pose a major dil emma for the Federal Reserve.

title: Pat Rice Wins Riding Trophy, Qualifies for National Finals
description: BAYPORT, L. I., March 26 Pat Rice of Huntington, L. I., won the Maclay Trophy at the Equitation Lodge horse show today and qualified for the na tional finals at the National Horse Show in New York in the fall.

title: Standstill Is Found In '71 Membership Of Churches in U.S.
description: Church membership in the United States has leveled off to a standstill, according to the editor of the 1972 Yearbook of American Churches.

title: Bright Golden Haze Honors Rodgers
description: The Broadway theater paid an affectionate tribute last night to one of its musical geniuses, Richard Rodgers, at a slightly advanced celebration of his 70th birthday.

title: Condors Subdue Squires
description: PITTSBURGH, March 26 (AP)  The Pittsburgh Condors, playing possibly their last game in this city, nipped the Vir ginia Squires, 131130, tonight on a jump shot by Dave Lattin with 19 seconds left.

title: U.C.L.A. ROLES ON; SO DOES TURMOIL
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26  The aftermath of the 34th Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso elation basketball tournament promises to be considerably less routine than the competition, which led, inevitably, to an other championship for the Uni versity of California, Los An geles.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 26 (AP)  The Indiana. Pacers broke away from the tenacious Dallas Chaparrals in the final period today for a 9888 vic tory.

title: Dublin Parties Meet Amid Peace Hope
description: DUBLIN, March 26On this Palm Sunday, a day of bril liant sunshine interrupted by gusts of rain, the Irish Repub lic appeared uplifted by a surge of hope for peace, tinged by fear that something would occur to destroy it.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, March 26Nearly 51 years ago, when King George V opened the new pro vincial parliament in Northern Ireland, he appealed to all Irishmen to pause, to stretch out the hand of forbearance and conciliation, to forgive and forget.

title: Program for Elderly Here Threatened by Budget Cut
description: It keeps me out of the rock ing chair, keeps my spirits go ing, said Mrs. Oppie L. Emer son, a brighteyed 72yearold worker for Path, a service pro gram for the elderly.

title: Treasury Considers Sale Of Some of Nation's Gold
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The United States Treasury has considered in recent months what would be a dramatic move selling some of the Govern ment's remaining $9.7billion gold stock on the free market.

title: TV: Last of Mohicans
description: The recent Elizabeth R series, featuring a virtuosic per formance by Glenda Jackson as England's Virgin Queen, proved to be a popular success for pub lic television's Masterpiece The ater, assembled in Boston from British Broadcasting Corpora tion dramatic serials. Accord ing to one rating service, Eliza beth at times was, in the New York area, on a shade behind a mass appeal series on one of the commercial networks.

title: An Aide Says That Senate Panel Did Not Give Memo to the I.T.T
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A spokesman for the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that the controversial memo randum that generated the committee's investigation of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's contri bution to the Republican Na tional Convention had not been given by the committee to the company.

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS BUS DID NOT STOP
description: Robert R. Meehan, the Rock land County District Attorney, said yesterday that the school bus that was in a collision With a freight train Friday did not stop, as required by state jaw, before crossing the tracks.

title: Sabres, Penguins Tie, 22
description: BUFFALO, March 26 (AP) Rene Robert scored with 13 sec onds remaining in the game to give the Buffalo Sabres a 22 tie with the Pittsburgh Pen guins tonight.

title: TWO MET ROOKIES STOP DODGERS, 91
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26The New York Mets kept rolling along despite their springtime injuries today, win ning their fifth straight game with a 91 pounding of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET AIR EXPERTS ARE VISITING HANOI
description: HONG KONG, Monday, March 27A toplevel Soviet military delegation of special lets in air defense has arrived in Hanoi.

title: COMMUNISTS BACK MAKARIOS IN CRISIS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 26  In the present crisis between Cyprus and Greece, as in all the previous crises that have faced this uneasy island, Presi dent Makarios, the conserva tive primate of the Orthodox Church, has no stancher sup porter than the Communist party.

title: Lubavitch Rabbi Marks His 70th Year With Call for Kindness
description: Menachem Mende Schneer son, the Lubavitch rabbi, reached the Biblical age of 70 yesterday, but he has been living in the age of the Bible every one of those years.

title: In Harrison, Hotel Issue Splits Town
description: HARRISON, N.Y., March 26 This Westchester town, no stranger to bitter zoning fights, is wrestling now with an application from Marriott Hotels, Inc., to build a 500 room hotel.

title: OUTLOOK IS BLEAK FOR 8 TB CLINICS
description: Federal refusal to renew a $764,000 grant for tuberculosis control here after June 30 pos es a severe threat to eight chest clinics in municipal hos pitals, Health Services Admin istrator Gordon Chase declared yesterday.

title: Open Courtroom
description: The state's highest court has delivered a needed re minder to judges at all levels that they cannot trample on the constitutional right of free press through arbi trary prohibitions issued in the name of protecting the constitutional right of defendants to fair trial.

title: MACKELL FAVORS NEW SEARCH LAW
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell suggested yesterday that Federal legisla tion be passed that would create avenues of redress for victims of illegal police searches while permitting the wider use of incriminating evi dence in the prosecution of criminals.

title: Meany Walkout Is Justified
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters)  Two Democratic Presidential hopefuls denounced the Administration's antiinfla tion program today.

title: Pope Conducts Palm Rite At Opening of Holy Week
description: Holy Week, marking the seven eventful days in Chris tendom that culminate in East er, began yesterday with Palm Sunday services in Roman Catholic and Protestant church es across the world.

title: Miss Cullen's Putt on 18th Hole Takes Sears Golf by a Stroke
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 26 (AP)Betsy Cullen's 18th hole birdie gave the blonde Oklahoman a 72 and firstprize money in the Sears $85,000 Women's World golf classic to day, her first victory in eight years on the tour.

title: Israel to Discipline Officers In Bedouins' Displacement
description: TEL AVIV, March 26The Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, told the Cabinet in Jerusalem today that senior army officers and a civilian official had overstepped their authority during the evacua tion of Bedouins from an area in the occupied Sinai Peninsula that had been fenced as a security measures. He said dis ciplinary measures are to be taken against the officers.

title: Dance:Graham Revivals
description: It is about 18 months since the Martha Graham Dance Company last appeared in New York, although it has, since then, toured extensively in other parts of the country. It had been hoped that the company would give a New York season, but this has not proved possible, although in the fall of this year it is ex pected that the troupe will tour the eastern United States and return to Broad way for a subsequent season.

title: Britain's Economy Stagnant Despite Tax Cuts
description: LONDON, March 26 if laymen can fudge the serious ness of an illness by the size of the dose of medicine pre scribed by the doctor, then the British people now know that their economy is in a very bad way.

title: Sales in Used Sector Show 31% Gain
description: Machinetool orders in Feb ruary soared 20 per cent over the January level, the National Machine Tool Builders Associa tion reported over the week end. At the same time the Machinery Dealers National As sociation said that February sales of used machine tools were the best in 26 months, rising 31 per cent above the January level and 32.4 per cent above February, 1971.

title: SHOP TALK
description: That giant bowl being of fered in the new catalogue of the Kenton Collection is more than a fish tankit's a coffee table, a conversation piece and a terrarium (when you tire of the fish) all in one. Called the Aqua Dome, the 40inchdiameter table has a glass top, an acrylic bowl and a chromed steel base. Twenty fresh or saltwater fish, it's said, will thrive in side in the 40 gallons of water that the bowl can hold  or about a dozen small plants will grow as in a rain forest the price, when used as a text arium, is $200; as a fish bowl it's $14 more (for the standard aquarium air pump and undergravel fil ter). Neither price includes the fish or the plants. And the freight is extra too, shipped from Texas. (About $19 to New York.)

title: Study Says Relief Mothers Move Here
description: More than threefourths76 per centof the city's 250,000 welfare mothers last year had been born outside New York State, Assemblyman Andrew Stein reported yesterday in making public the newest study by his consultant on welfare problems, Nicholas Kisburg.

title: Swiss Killed by Flagpole
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, March 26 (Reuters)One person was killed and five seriously in jured today when a flagpole crashed down on a soccer grand stand.

title: In the Chilean Lake Country, Political Crosscurrents Are Aswirl
description: PANGUIPULLI, Chile  The record player spun and the young couples, who had pushed aside the tables in the hotel dining room, danced to a syn copated song that said: In creasing production helps make the revolution.

title: U.S. Six Crushes Japan
description: BUCHAREST, March 26 (Reuters)  The United Sbates hockey team held a slender lead tonight in the overall rat ings of the Group B world championships after notching a 145 victory over Japan. The Americans have amassed four points after two victories and lead East Germany on goal av erage.

title: The Chiang Myth
description: The election of Chiang Kaishek to a fifth sixyear term as President of the Nationalist Government on Taiwan seeks to perpetuate a longfading myth that has been effectively demolished by President Nixon's rapprochement with Peking.

title: City Seeking Legislation Against GetRichQuick Chain Distribution Schemes
description: City Consumer Affairs Com missioner Bess Myerson and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz have proposed new legislation outlawing chain dis tributor schemes.

title: I. R. A. IN ULSTER APPEARS TO EASE TERRORIST PLANS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26The Irish Republi can Army, sharply divided over the tactics it should use in Northern Ireland, is evidently scaling down terrorist activi ties as a result of Britain's take over of the province.

title: Olga A. Cuttita Married Here
description: Miss Olga Ann Cuttita daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony Ctittita of New York and Henryville, Pa., was married here yester day afternoon to Lawrence Philip Ibsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ibsen of the Bronx.

title: Operation PUSH Opens Office; 5,000 Mark the Event at Picnic
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson opened the New York regional office of his new black eco nomic and political develop ment organization  People United to Save Humanity or Operation PUSH  yesterday with a festive soul picnic at the National Guard Armory at 142d Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Britain and Malta Agree On Price for Use of Bases
description: LONDON, March 26Britain and Malta signed an agreement here today for the continued use by the British of military bases on the Mediterranean island.

title: French Sportswear Producer Says U.S. Market Is a Jungle
description: PARIS, March 26It is a jungle, the American market brutal, capricious, unusually difficult, says Maurice Bider mann, a French sportswear manufacturer.

title: 100 Jainists Here Observe Patron's 2,500th Year
description: The 2,500th anniversary of the birth of Lord Mahavira, great hero, spiritual leader and patron saint of Jainism, an ancient Indian religion that predates Buddhism, was ob served yesterday by more than 100 of the prophet's followers.

title: At a Mesta Party: Politics and Prophecy
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The big quesion is whether Perle Mesta's party last night at the Shoreham Hotel was prophetic. She entertained for Dwight D. Eisenhower when he was a general, and for Harry S. Truman and Lyndon B. Johnson when they were Vice Presidents. Now she gave a big bash for a hand some Washington neighbor and longtime friend, John B. Connally, and his pretty wife Nellie.

title: Flyers on Top, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (AP)Goals by Simon Nolet and Bob Kelly in the first period sparked the Philadelphia Flyers to a 41 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: Theater: Whitsuntide
description: What could have gotten into Cora? ask the startled parishioners at St. Thom as's ontheGreen Episcopal Church in Westwood, Conn. Cora has just disrupted serv ices by standing up, closing her eyes and warbling, Shamanananana. She is not, as some might think, drunk, crazy or spaced out on LSD. She is a victim of glossolalia.

title: Safe Driver Plan Offered
description: The Eimpire Mutual Insur ance Group has announced that it has received approval from the New York State Insurance Department to introduce a re vised Safe Driver Plan. It is available only to holders of family policies in New York State.

title: Randolph Conducts a Bach Passion
description: The St. Cecilia Chorus, led by David Randolph, presented a performance of Bach's St. John Passion at Carnegie Hall Saturday night assisted by an orchestra and six vocal soloists. The singers were Karen Alt man, soprano; Virginia Brobyn, contralto; James Schwabacher, tenor (Evangelist); Melvin Brown, tenor (arias); William Metcalf, bass (Jesus); and Richard Clark, bass (Pilate, Peter and the bass arias).

title: They're Learning To Speak Italian And Cook It Too
description: The Hebrew and Spanish students dance, the Greek classes drink ouzo and kick their heels like the chorus of Zorba. The Chinese students cook won ton soup on a hot plate right in class, and the French make mayon naise, because the instructor is shocked at the American depravity of using the bot tled kind. The German stu dents have written and will perform an operetta called Die Strumpfandopperette (The Operetta of the Gar ter), with a mystery plot involving strangling by gar ter. A student who can't sing supplies the sound effects for thunder.

title: Bullets Halt Braves
description: BALTIMORE, March 26 (UPI) Archie Clark scored 13 of his 29 points in the decisive third quarter as the Baltimore Bullets snapped a fourgame losing streak by downing the Buffalo Braves, 119101, tonight in the regularseason finale for both teams.

title: Midtown Jeweler Robbed
description: A jeweler was robbed yester day morning of $150,000 in precious bracelets by a man who had followed him into his office building at 33 West 46th Street, he told the police. He said the man placed an unknown object against his back, accompanied him to his sixth floor office and forced him to open the jewelry vault. The jeweler, Elizer Low, 26 years old, was found, gagged and bound, two hours later by his father, Wolf.

title: NETS CONQUERED BYDENYER, 10891
description: DENVER, March 26 (AP) The Denver Rockets defeated the New York Nets, 10891, to day, hurting the Nets' hopes for a secondplace finish in the American Basketball Associa tion's Eastern Division.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Twenty years ago in Washington, D.C., Negroes could not sit down with white people at a drugstore lunch counter. In seventeen states and the District of Columbia black children were legally barred front going to the same public schools as white children. In a third of the country blacks had to ride in the back of streetcars and could not go into a good hotel or restaurant.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH AN CLINCH FIRST
description: BOSTON, March 26 (UPI) Mike Walton scored two goals tonight as the Boston Bruins posted a 54 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and clinched first place in the Na tional Hockey League East Divi sion.

title: Miss Sutherland Teams With Di Giuseppe
description: Under ordinary circum stances, Joan Sutherland (a very tall soprano) and Enrico Di Giuseppe (a very short ten or) would make a faintly ridic ulous pair of operatic lovers. But since the Met's Fille du Regiment production thrives on vaudeville sight gags of this sort, Mr. Di Giuseppe's diminu tive Tonio, his first with the company at Saturday's matinee, fit in perfectly  especially when Miss Sutherland looked down at her admirer and gave him a pat on the head before he, completely disappeared in her arms.

title: Wall Street Can Be a Gal's Best Friend
description: Is the securities business any place for a woman? Put that question to Mrs. Julia Montgomery Walsh and you get this reply rushing at you with expresstrain speed:

title: Legislature Due to Act on Budget and Amendments This Week
description: Final approval of the $7.87 billion state budget and action on the Federal women's rights amendment and the state leg alized gambling amendment are expected this week before the Legislature begins an 11day recess.

title: AMEX STRUCTURE SET FOR CHANGES
description: Proposals for an extensive reorganization of the governing structure of the American Stock Exchange were an nounced over the weekend.

title: Skaters Strike Happy Medium Here
description: With a skatesacrossthe sea, handholding finale to the Walt Disney song It's A Small World After All, most of the world's finest figure skaters presented a 2hour exhibition at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Vasyliunases Join For a Bavicchi Deut
description: Izidorius and Vytenis Vasliu nas, a fatherand son violin/ piano duo from Boston, per formed at Carnegie Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon. Aside from Mozart's Sonata, K. 306, the program offered two itemsof interest: the world premiere of John Bavicchi's Sonata No. 4 on Lithuanian themes and Wolf Ferrari's Sonata in G minor.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY HAWKS,120106
description: ATLANTA, March 26The Knicks finally concluded the regular National Basketball As sociation schedule  almost gratefully. Turning in their third ragged effort in eight days, the New Yorkers bowed, 120106, to a strong second half effort by the Atlanta Hawks today at Alexander Me morial Coliseum.

title: MISS COURSON DUO WINS SKATE DANCE
description: Two members of the host club took time out from their official duties yesterday to win the veterans' dance event as the 50th Middle Atlantic figure skating championships ended.

title: LOBBYIST SUFFERS A HART SEIZURE; QUESTIONING ENDS
description: DENVER, March 26A Sen ate subcommittee's hospital room interrogation of Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the ailing Washing ton lobbyist for the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, came to an abrupt end this afternoon after Mrs. Beard clutched her chest and moaned with heart pains.

title: Okefenokee Alligators Are Staging Comeback
description: ATLANTA, March 26 (AP) The alligator population in the vast Okefenokee Swamp of South Georgia is staging a comeback because of tough conservation laws enacted in recent years. Fears that the large reptile might vanish are lessening.

title: Sally R. Weisberg, Teacher, Is Bride
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 26 Miss Sally Ruth Weisberg, a 1969 graduate of Cernell University, was married here this afternoon to Paul Leo Goldberg, who graduated from Cornell in 1968. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel by Rabbi Max Gelb, assisted by Cantor Willam Wilff.

title: Bundy Asserts Ford Fund Must Hold Down Budget
description: McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Fundation, said yester day that the fundation needed to continue its policy of bud getary austerity for the im mediate future.

title: 76ers Bow to Warriors, 116 115, And Ramsay, the Coach, Resigns
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (AP)  Jack Ramsay, coach of the Philadelphia 76ers, resigned today, immediately after his team lost its final regularsea son National Basketball Associ ation game to the Golden State Warriors, 116115.

title: Miss Frankenfelder Wed to S. R. Bleier
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.,March 28In Temple BethEl of Northern Westchester here today, Miss Marjo Tech Frankenfelder, daughter of Mrs. Richard Frankenfelder bf Mamaroneck and the late Mr. Frankenfelder, was mar ried to Steven Randolph Bleier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bleier of Chappaqua. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

title: 60 KILLINGS LAID TO SOUTH YEMEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 The Yemeni Embassy charged in a statement made public here today that the authorities in Southern Yemen were respon sible for the machinegun slay ing a few days ago of 60 men, women and children during a wedding ceremony at the vil lage of Wazieh, near the south western border between the two countries.

title: Helen S. Kan Wed To. Eric Rosenberg
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 26Miss Helen Sue Kass and Eric M. Rosenberg were married here this afternoon at the Scarsdale Synagogue by Rabbi David Greenberg. The bride it the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. WaHex Kate. Mr. and Mrs. Fred L. Rosen berg are the parents of the bridegroom.

title: CITY PLANS TO CURB WELFARE CHEATS
description: The city's Department of Social Services, hoping to vir tually eliminate the fraudulent duplication of cases, is working to develop a computerized clientinformation bank to bring together data on all its nearly 1.3million welfare re cipients.

title: RICHARD DAVIS, 59, DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Richard Haliock Davis, a career diplomat, died of the heart attack yesterday evening while on an inspection tour of United States diplomatic missions in the Car ibbean, He was 59 years old.

title: A Plastic Is Molded Into RealisticLooking Spare Facial Parts
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 26A plastic of the type used in making upholstered fur niture is being molded into real isticlooking spare facial parts for persons deformed by cancer surgery, injury or birth defects, an Alabama dentist reported here.

title: Highly Militarized Moscow Police Focus on the Causes of Crime
description: MOSCOW, March 26  The Moscow militia, as the police force is known here, is a more highly militarized organization than its New York counterpart, with a great deal of saluting and standing at attention.

title: Boyd Will Aid Nixon Drive As He Opposes Pike on L.I.
description: BLUE POINT, L. I., March 26 4Between now and July, Jo seph H. Boyd Jr. will be doing double dutycampaigning for Congress against one of the state's most tenacious Demo cratic incumbents, and running the Nixon campaign in the State's suburbs at the behest of his current boss, Governor Rockefeller.

title: MRS. E.A. SAMPIERRE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 26Mrs. Ann Feldman Sam pierre, wife of Edward A. Sam pierre, president of the Sam pierre Chemical Corporation of New York, died yesterday at the age of 48. She lived at 6 Wildwood Circle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Protestants to Stage Strike Today
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26The rightwing Unionist Vanguard Movement went ahead today with plans for a work stoppage tomorrow and Tuesday to show Protes tant anger over the dissolution of the Ulster parliament.

title: 2 CHOSEN TO DIRECT JOURNALISM COURSE
description: Columbla University's Gradu ate School of Journalism an nounced yesterday the appoint ment of Earl Caldwell of The New York tithes and Robert C. Maynard of The Washington Post as codirectors of its Sum mer Program in Journalism for Members of Minority Groupe.

title: A Man and His Husky Rescued From Hudson
description: A sevenandahalfmonth old Siberian husky slipped into the icy waters and swift currents of the Hudson River yesterday afternoon and both she and her master nearly drowned.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A lioto and 2 Codefendants Win Civil Case Over Sharing of Fees
description: VANCOUVER, Wash., March 26 (AP)A Superior Court jury returned verdicts today in favor of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco and two former Washington state officials who had been accused of unlawfully sharing $2.3million in legal fees.

title: Mrs. King Wins From Mrs. Gunter In Final, 63, 64
description: RICHMOND, March 26 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., won the $18,000 Virginia Slims international tennis tournament today with a 63, 64 victory over Mrs. Nan cy Richey Gunter of San An gelo, Tex.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Julius Tantleff, the owner of the Black Angus restau rant in the San Carlo Hotel, told the police yesterday that burglars had stolen jewelry and furs worth $100,000 from his penthouse apartment in the hotel at 150 East 50th Street.

title: Battles Reported in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 26 (UPI)  Military spokes men reported heavy fighting to day south and west of Pnom penh. There were said to be battles at Kompong Trach on Routo 2, abut 75 miles south of here, and at Peang Lovea, about 30 miles to the west.

title: Senators Laughing Before Mrs. Beard's Attack
description: DENVER, March 26  Mrs. Dita Davis Beard, the salty Washington lobbyist, set Sen ators laughing this afternoon only minutes before her ailing heart brought on another col lapse and ended hearings here.

title: Mrs. Snow Visiting Peking
description: HONG KONG, Monday, March 27 (Reuters)  Lois Wheeler Snow, widow of the American writer, Edgar Snow, arrived in Peking yesterday for a visit, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

title: Turning Justice Around
description: Troubling questions still surround the debate over the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation; a pivotal mystery is what caused Assistant Attorney General Richard McLaren to change his mind about taking the case to the Supreme Court for a test of the permissible scope of conglomerate mergers. He had eagerly sought such a test. Yet he chose to accept instead an arrangement permitting the giant conglomer ate to hold on to the billiondollar Hartford Fire Insur ance Company.

title: MAX ROSENBAUM
description: Max Rosenbaum, cofounder and treasurer of the S. E. Ni chols Company, a discount de partment store chain of 23 stores from the Atlantic Sea board to the Midwest, died Fri day in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L. I.

title: Teresa Lioy Married
description: Miss Teresa Elaine Lioy, daughter of Dr. Anthony D. Lioy, a physician, and Mrs. Lioy of Palisade, N. 3., was married here yesterday after noon to Clark Woods Faulk ner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Faulkner of Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. James Cleary performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride is an alumna of Sweet Briar Col lege. Her husband, a gradu ate of Culver Military Acad emy and Washington and Lee University, is working for a master's degree in busi ness administration at the University of Nebraska.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BacallaoBrown Triumph
description: Dr. Pedro Bacallao, of the Princeton Club, and Bailey Brown, of the Bronxville Field Club, won the Lone Star Club's invitation squash racquets dou bles tourney yesterday. The topseeded pair defeated Roland Oddie, of the New York Ath letic Club, and Torn Jones, of the Racquet and Tennis Club, 159, 1514, 1814, in the final.

title: Israeli Military Instructors Almost Gone From Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 26 (Reuters)The departure of Israeli paratroop and army in structors from Uganda was al most complete tonight as Pres ident Idi Amin's deadline for their expulsion drew near.

title: 2 Women and 2 Children Die In a Trailer Fire in Jersey
description: FRANKLINVILLE, N.J., March 26 (UPI)Two women and two children perished in an early morning fire that swept their trailer today in this Gloucester County community.

title: KING LEAVES AMMAN TO VISIT WASHINGTON
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 26 (Reuters)  King Hussein left Amman today for Washington to explain his recently an nounced plan for a federal king dom on the East and West Banks of the Jordan River. His talks with United States of ficials are also expected to cover economic aid.

title: Halaby, in Farewell to Pan Am, Complains of Regulatory Policy
description: In a farewell message to the 36,000 employes of Pan Ameri can World Airways, Najeeb E. Halaby has said his greatest regret was what he called the failure of Federal regulators to restore PanAm's proper oppor tunity to compete in the world.

title: CHINA SAYS SOVIET FLIRTS WITH TAIPEI
description: HONG KONG, March 26  Peking said today that Mos cow was stepping up flirtation and collusion with the Chinese Nationalist Government in Tai pei and voiced the suspicion that the Soviet Union was tak ing a hand in attempting to create two Chinas.

title: 1933: F.D.R's Diplomatic Initiative
description: WASHINGTONIn the comment on President Nixon's discussions with spokesmen for the People's Republic of China, with the objective of seek ing the normalization of relations be tween the two countries, little if any note has been made of similar nego tiations by an earlier American Presi dent with the other Communist super power, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The reason for the omis sion may be that in 1933 the U.S.S.R. sent its negotiator to Washington, and in 1972 the President did the traveling.

title: 2 Held Near Pittsburgh In Killing of 2 Policemen
description: PITTSBURGH, March 26 (UPI) The police in suburban Penn Hills filed murder charges to day against two suspects, just released on bail from an armed robbery charge, in the fatal shooting of two policemen in a shopping center.

title: THAI INSURGENTS SEEN INCREASING
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22The number of armed in surgents in Thailand has grown 15 to 20 per cent ever the last year and a half, according to Thai military officials and Western diplomats.

title: Advertising:
description: There's a new ad agency at 909 Third Avenue and unlike Benton & Bowles and Need ham, Harper & Steers, in the same building, it is a one product shop created for the short haul.

title: B'nai Brith Moves to Save Hillel Programs at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. March 26David M. Blumberg, president of B'nai B'rith, an nounced today that his organ ization had provided funds to avert a threatened shutdown of its Hillel Foundation building at Rutgers University.

title: MAX DEUTCHMAN
description: Max Deutchman, a manu facturer of women's dresses in Yonkers from 1915 to 1955, died Saturday in the Brandy wine Nursing Home, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. His age was 85.

title: Virginia Psychologist Treats Stutterers by ComputerAssisted Therapy, but Some Experts Voice Doubt
description: ROANOKE, Va., March 26 for half her life, since she was 17 years old, Sue Wolff had been seeking a treatment for a problem that had bothered her for as long as she could remember  her stuttering.

title: WATER IN QUEENS SCORED ON TASTE
description: The quality of ground water supplied by a private concern to 18,000 customers in Wood haven and surrounding sections of Queens has deteriorated so much that housewives cannot make a decent cup of coffee, restaurants cannot set out dish ware free of waterstains and a glass of tap water is a gag ging experience.

title: Steel Makers Await Word on Quota
description: PITTSBURGH, March 26 Domestic steel producers were waiting last week for word of a new import quota.

title: NEW MINIMUM TAX NETS $117MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 The major reform of the 1969 Tax Reform Act cost some 18,000 wealthy individuals a total of nearly $117million in additional taxes last year, but the tax that they paid under the reform provision averaged only 4 per cent.

title: Antiwar Protests Begun by Backers Of the Harrisburg 7
description: HARRISBURG, March 26  Some 600 supporters of the Harrisburg Seven, many with faces painted in the macabre hues of death, began today a week of antiwar protests.

title: Opera:Zeffirelli's Otello
description: In most ways, the new production of Verdi's Otel lo at the Metropolitan Opera has been turned over to Franco Zeffirelli, who was both set designer and direc tor. The production was un veiled Saturday night.

title: Paris's Pliant Voice Blends With Wife's At New Room of Jazz
description: Jackie Paris, who was sing ing and playing guitar on 52d Street in the bebop days of the late 1940's, has since built a polished and skillful per forming style on the talents that he was showing then. With his wife, Anne Marie Moss, who once was the vocalist in Maynard Ferguson's band, Mr. Paris is making his first ap pearance in New York in many years as the opening attraction in a new jazz oriented room, Baron Steakhouse, 1 East 48th Street.

title: Miss Bonnie Strack Is Bride Of Claude Kress Williams Jr.
description: BOSTON, March 26Tte Gordan Chapel of the Old South Church, Congregation al, was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Bonnie Louise Strock, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Edward Strock of New ton Center at Vineyard Haven, to Claude Kress Wil liams Jr. He is a son of Mr. Williams of Houston and Mrs. Alexander Harvey 2d of Baltimore and a greatgrand nephew of Samuel H. Kress, founder of. S. H. Kress & Co., the variety store chain.

title: BOB ALLISON WINS IN ATLANTA 500
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 26 Bobby Allison won the Atlanta 500 today in a sizzling stretch drive that carried him from third place to the checkered flag in the last five laps. He beat A. 3. Foyt's Mercury by a scant 16hundreths of a second, about five car lengths. Bobby Isaac finished third in a Dodge, a few yards behind Allison.

title: Radio Free Europe Is Target Of Criticism Again in Poland
description: WARSAW, March 26 The Polish press today renewed its attacks on Radio Free Europe after a bill passed by the United States Congress last week provided funds to keep the station in operation at least until June 30.

title: Citizens Budget Group Chooses New Director
description: Dr. David Bernstein, a 56 yearold expert on govern ment and urban affairs, was named yesterday as execu tive director of the Citizens Budget Cominission, with which he has been associated since 1948.

title: Delta Village Basks in New Prosperity
description: LONGTHANH, South Viet nam, March 10Nguyen Van Tien has a new tractor. Mrs. Mai Thi Hue, down at the rice mill, and her neighbors across the canal have new television gets.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 26 (AP)Artis Gilmore slammed in a dunk shot with seven sec onds left to give the Kentucky Colonels a 105104 triumph over the Floridians tonight.

title: GUERRILLAS EXTEND ARGENTINE DEADLINE
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 26 (Reuters)  Marxist urban guerrillas holding an Italian businessman, Oberman Sallus tro, extended today by 36 hours their deadline for his execu tion, originally set for today.

title: Dance: Paul Taylor Company in Queens
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Com pany, which has not performed in Manhattan since Feb., 1971, except for a recent lecture demonstration at Town Hall, presented two New York pre mieres Saturday night at the Queensborough Community Col lege Theater.

title: STOKOWSKI SERVES 3STAR BILL OF FARE
description: A typical Leopold Stokowski concert often has a rather cu linary flavor, and at yesterday afternoon's program by the American Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall the master chef served up a representative, if variable, threecourse menu.

title: Personal Finance
description: By an overwhelming vote of 29 to 7, the Connecticut Senate late last week ap proved a new credit law that restricts retail stores to charging no more than 12 per cent, or 1 per cent a month, on their revolving charge accounts. Many have been charging 18 per cent, or 1 per cent a month.

title: Chess: Kavalek Leads Record Field In Northeastern U. Tourney
description: The Northeastern Univer sity Spectacular, held in Bos ton in January; attracted 116 playersa record for Boston. Four other events held in the city over the same weekend attracted a total of 138 play ers.

title: Philippine Tribe Said to Live in Caves
description: MANILA, March 26 (AP)  Anthropologists reported today that the Tasadays, a Stone Age people discovered last year in the southern Philippine rain forest, make their homes in caves, a fact not previously known about them.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 26 The Democratic party's new reform rules are failing in im portant respects to produce the desired results, a survey of the first 340 delegates elected to the Democratic National Con vention indicate.

title: Volpe Disputed on Use of Montana Environmental Report in Clearing Aid to Big Sky Road
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe has approved major Federal financing for a $1.2million road into the pri vately developed Big Sky golf and ski resort 40 miles south of Bozeman, Mont.

title: Rupp, 70, Plans to Run For Congress Seat, if...
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 26 (AP)Kentucky's basket ball coach, Adolph Rupp, said today that he would run for Congress if he is not al lowed to continue coaching past the university's manda tory retirement age.

title: Rockets Stop Blazers
description: HOUSTON, March 28 (AP)  Elvin Hayes celebrated his night by scoring 30 points and leading the Houston Rock ets to a 131109 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers, in what might have been Tex Win ter's last game as the Rockets' coach.

title: 102 Vie for 10 National Book Awards
description: Judges for the National Book Awards have chosen 102 leading nominees for the 10 prizes that are assum ing an importance for the book industry comparable to that held by the leading Oscar award winners for the movie world.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Japanese Cup Victors
description: HONG KONG, March 26 (UPI) Japan today completed a 50 sweep of the Davis Cup Eastern Section A by beating Hong Kong in the final two singles matches. Jun Kuki beat Ling Fong, 6.0, 6.1, 62, and Jun Kamiwazumi beat. Charles Chang, 62, 63, 60.

title: STANDARD POODLE GAINS TOP AWARD
description: TETERBORO, N. J., March 26 A magnificent white standard poodle, Ch. Alekai All of Stone bridge, owned by Mrs. Janet R. Abrahams of Meriden, Conn., was chosen best at the 29th allbreed show of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey in a field of 1,000 dogs today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 26 Senator Vance Hartke of In diana withdrew today from the race for the Democratic Presi dential nomination and warmly endorsed Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, one of his rivals on the April 4 Wisconsin pri mary ballot.

title: DOLE SCORES LABOR; O'BRIEN SEES FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, March 26, (Reuters)Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican party chairman today attacked last week's walkout by labor from the Pay Board by saying that President Nixon's antiin flation program would not be sacrificed to the egos of a new outdated union leaders.

title: College Students These Days Don't Throw Money Around
description: A while back, runny a par ent, anxiously awaiting a lengthy, communication from a son ?? daughter away at college, was not infrequently disappointed when the let ter arrived and the contents could be boiled down to two words: Send money.

title: Capitol Investigation Finds Substantial Evidence of Mismanagement in the Lockheed C5A. Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 A preliminary report by the General Accounting Office finds that there is evidence to support charges of mismanage ment in the C5A cargo plane program.

title: Mekong River Traffic Halted
description: PNOMPENH, March 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  Traf fic on the Mekong River be tween South Vietnam and Cambodia has been halted, a military Spokesman said here today. Pnompenh is heavily de pendent, on river traffic, espe cially for fuel and munitions.

title: 100 DIE AS REVOLT FAILS IN SALVADOR
description: SAN SALVADOR, March 26 President Fidel Sanchez Her nndez of El Salvador said to day that more than 100 soldiers and civilians had been killed in an unsuccessful uprising against the Government yester day.

title: Proxmire Asks Decontrol On Importing Canadian Oil
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)  Senator Williiam Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today urged immediate decon trol of oil imports from Canada.

title: 3 Bombs Disrupt Milan Rally
description: MILAN, Italy March 26 (AP) Three bombs exploded today inside and outside a local thea ter during an election rally at tended by 3,000 neoFascists. The police said no one was in jured. The rally ocntinued.

title: Power to the People
description: No one can accuse former Tammany Hall boss Edward N. Costikyan of having mud on his shoes or hayseed in his hair. He is city slicker through and through. His hair is thinning and black and what's left of it is combed across a baldish crown. He wears ex pensive suits and derby hats, or did wear hats until recently, and other wise exudes the confidence of the Big City Pol.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: GREENFIELD, Iowa, March 26  Roger Blobaum was right. The long knives started flashing and slashing at last night's district convention.

title: PAUL SAMUEL SANDERS
description: OXFORD, England, March 26 (AP)  Paul Samuel Sanders, associate professor of English at the University of Massa chusetts in Amherst, died yes terday in Oxford Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Wooden's Future: Bright as Past
description: I could talk about that man all night, said Walt Hazzard, who plays in the back court for the Buffalo Braves of the Na tional Basketball Association.

title: Lobbyist on Senators: That Bunch of Bums
description: Mrs. Dita D. Beard, in an interview with Time maga zine last week, referred to the members of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee who questioned her yesterday as that bunch of little bums.

title: Excerpts From I.T.T. Aide's Statement
description: DENVER, March 26 (UPI) Following are excerpts from Mrs. Dita D. Beard's pre pared statement to a Senate Judiciary subcommittee to day:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 27 (UPI)  Kentucky apparently became today the first state to certify a PresidentialVice Presidential ticket when it placed the names of Gov. George C. Wallace and T. Cole man Andrews, Virginia attor ney, on its November ballot.

title: DE LA TORRE SHOWS GUITAR SENSITIVITY
description: Rey de la Torre began his guitar recital Sunday night at Tully Hall with some delicate Renaissance dances and two charming scores by the early 19thcentury Spaniard Fernan do Sor After that, however, the Cubanborn virtuoso jumped to the 20th century, brightening the sound and enlarging his tonal palette with rarely played folklore pieces.

title: Health Group Sues U.S. to Drop Seals That Approve Meat
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)  The American Public Health Association sued the Government today to force the dropping of U.S. Inspected for Wholesomeness seal on fresh meat and the substitution or warnings that the meat might contain disease germs.

title: Bridge: Young Precision Team Takes Vanderbilt on Strong Finish
description: CINCINNATI, March 27 The young Precision Team of New York experts captured the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship hem in the early hours of this moan ing, and established a strong claim to be considered one of the great teams in Ameri can bridge history.

title: U.S. LABOR LEADERS RETURN FROM HANOI
description: Three American labor lead ers returned last night from a visit to North Vietnam and said that they had what they felt was something worth while to report to Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, and possibly to the President.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 28, 1972

title: Boy Steals Father's Car And Kills Man in Queens
description: A 14yearold Queens boy stole his father's car yesterday afternoon and killed one man and sightly injured two other persons when he lost control of it, according to the Police.

title: Armed Forces Decrease
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI)The armed forces now are at their smallest size since North Korean troops crossed the 38th parallel in 1950, the Pentagon said today. The Pen tagon's monthly report showed there were 2,425,051 men and women in uniform Feb. 29.

title: Madison Square Officer is Named Head of Athena
description: Alvin Cooperman a vice president, and director of the Madison Square Garden Cor poration, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Athena Com munications Corporation, a sub sidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc.

title: BACH PASSION IS LED BY ABRAHAM KAPLAN
description: Beth's St. Matthew Phan unfolded smoothly enough as sung by the Collegiate Chorale under Abraham Kaptain's direc tion Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, but the performance ely intermittently rose above, a gen eral level of solid respectability.

title: Connecticut Police Back Warren Court After Law Study
description: NEW HAVEN, March 27 Most of the more than 70 Connecticut state and local policemen who have recently studied Supreme Court deci sions at the University of New Haven emerged from the criminallaw course with a wholehearted acceptance of the High Court's rulings af fecting police work.

title: Kentucky Retires Rapp After 42Year Career
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 27 (AP)Adolph Rupp's 42 year basketball coaching ca reer at Kentucky ended to night with an announcement by the school's athletics board of his retirement.

title: JEWS ESTABLISH STUDIES ON GOALS
description: The establishment of an in stitute composed of prominent Jewish academicians to draft longrange goals for Jewish or ganizations and to undertake research in problems affecting Jews in this country and abroad was established, yesterday.

title: Census Unit Predicts A Vote of 85 Million
description: WASINGTON, March 27 (AP)The Census Bureau es timated today that 85 million Americans would vote for President in November.

title: U.S. BondRating Rules Urged
description: A member of the House In terstate and Foreign Commerce Committee said yesterday that Congress was considering legis lation to set standards for rat ing state and city bonds.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RETREAT It's a warm, woodpaneled restaurant and bar that seems to cater to local clientele and it's called Bradley's, 70 University Place, at 11th Street (2286440).

title: MUSKIE DISCLOSES CAMPAIGN DONORS
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine disclosed today a list of 13,982 contributors who do nated $2,027,840 to his Demo cratic Presidential campaign in a 15month period that ended last Jan. 31.

title: BRECHT CARRAR STAGED IN CHILE
description: TEMUCO, ChileA perform ance of Bertolt Brecht's The Rifles of Mother Carrar, a play with a revolutionary mes sage, recently inaugurated a new theater at the Chilean North American Cultural Cen ter here.

title: Narcotics Detective Commits Suicide, Reportedly After an Inquiry by Seymour
description: A detective specializing in major narcotics cases commited suicide yesterday, high police officials said, after being inter rogated by the office of the United. States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: State Unit Named to Study AidtoChildren Program
description: ALBANY, March 27Gov ernor Rockefeller today moved to halt the growth in the num ber of families receiving. Aid to Dependent Children by appoint ing a 14member task force to explore the problem of obtain ing support from hteir absent fathers for children now on public assistance.

title: N. C. A. A. Expands Basketball Tourney
description: The National Collegiate Ath letic Association will expand its championship basketball tournament to 28 teams in 1974. The additional three teams will come from new con ference champions, still unde cided, which will receive auto matic bids. To make room for the new teams, firstround byes will be limited to one team in each of the four regions.

title: Cougars Drafted Riker
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 29 (UPI)The Carolina Cougars disclosed today that Tom Riker of South Carolina and Dennis Wuycik of North Carolina were their top choices in the Ameri can Basketball Association draft early this month.

title: Soviet Pledges Aid to Hanoi
description: TOKYO, March 27 (AP) Marshal Pavel F. Batitsky, So viet deputy defense minister, met with the North Vietnamese defense minister, Vo Nguyen Giap, in Hanoi today and pledged continued military sup port for the Vietnam war, the official Vietnam News Agency reported.

title: CurtissWright Hag Profit
description: The CurtissWright Corpora tion had a turnaround in 1971 with a net profit of $1,477,716, or 18 vents a share, after extraordinary charges in con trast to the net loss of $4,638, 000 incurred in 1970, the com pany reported yesterday.

title: Rare Opportunity
description: The House of Representatives will decide, perhaps today, whether to support or to undermine the Senate's unanimous and unequivocal move to clean up this coun try's waters. A Senate bill aims to eliminate all dis charge of pollutants by 1985. It would give the Federal Government enough authority, through a veto power over discharge permits issued by the states, to assure uniformity and thus to prevent industries film shopping around for indulgent regulations. And it would allow any citizen to sue polluters, and even the authorities themselves, where standards are not enforced.

title: Tests Hint Protein Is Vital to Cancers
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 27A Harvard surgeon said today that his research team had demonstrated in animal and test tube experi ments that the growth of most cancerous tumors was depend ent on a protein substance without which the tumors re verted to a dormant, harmless state.

title: They Use a Rink, a Puck and an Alarm Clock
description: Forget basketball. Forget stickball, handball, oneold cat and ringaroundrosy. The new city game is hockey, and if that brings to mind roller skates, skinned knees and homemade pucks, you haven't been paying atten tion during the most remark able development in children's athletics and family together ness since Little League base ball captivated a generation of suburban fathers.

title: EXTENSIVE STRIKE BY PROTESTANTS DISRUPTS ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 27  Demonstrations, work stoppages and a wide dis ruption of industry hit North ern Ireland today as Protestants began a twoday general strike to protest Britain's takeover of the local government.

title: PLAYOFF OPENERS HINGE ON INJURIES
description: The National Basketball As sociation's second seasonalso known as the playoffs  gets under way tonight with the defending champion Milwaukee Bucks and recordsetting Los Angeles Lakers both opening at home.

title: TV Fairness Doctrine Hearings Open
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 The television Fairness Doc trine was debated today as the Federal Communications Commission opened a week of hearings on it. The controver sial policy, formulated in 1949 and since amplified by F.C.C. decisions and court ruling's, holds that broadcasters have an obligation to present con flicting views on controversial issues.

title: Market Place
description: It was a frank but notfor attribution exchange of views at lunch and it was highly relevant for the small in vestor, to say nothing of his more affluent contemporary.

title: Mel Allen to Be Honored
description: SALISBURY, N. C., March 27 Mel Allen, the former broad caster for the New York Yan kees, will be inducted into the National Sportswriters and Sportscasters Hall of Fame here tomorrow night: Allen will be the ninth member. The others are John Kieran, Grantland Rice, Damon Runyon, Ring Lardner, J. G. Taylor Spink, Ted Busing, Graham McNamee and Clem McCarthy.

title: Garner, Sullivan Cited as Haggerty Award Whiners
description: Richie Garner of Manhat tan College and Tom Sulli van of Fordham were hon ored yesterday as cowin ners of the Haggerty Award at the 39th annual awards luncheon of the Metropolitan Writers Association at the Penn Plaza Club in Madison Square Garden. They were the first players to share the honor as the outstanding college basketball players in the metropolitan area since the award began in 1941.

title: Britain Bans Skins Of Three Animals
description: LONDON, March 27Imports into Britain of tiger, snow leopard and clonded leopard skins will be banned from midnight tonight, in a Move by the Government to protect these endangered species. Announcing the banin the House of Commons, Anthony Grant, parliamen tary undersecretary of state for trade, said that imports of furs, skin rugs and cov erlets obtained from the three animals would be prohibited.

title: I.R.A. Truce Reports Denied
description: DUBLIN, March 27  The headquarters of the Irish Re publican Army here angrily de nied today as false and ma licious a report that its Lon donderry brigade had declared a fourweek truce. It said the authors of the report would be severely punished.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: It was more than 30 years ago, when I was a teenager, that I Brit saw ducks being baited in a salt pond on Martha's Vineyard Island.
