description: The National Maritime Union said yesterday that a prelimi nary tally showed that its deep sea members had voted to ap prove a new contract by 3,187 to 126, with 35 abstentions.

title: 6 Killed by Terrorist Bomb in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH. Cambodia, March 28 (UPI)  A bomb be lieved placed by a saboteur ex ploded in Pnompenh today, killing six persons, and the Cambodian Government warned residents to arm themselves and dig trenches in preparation for a possible enemy attack on the city.

title: The Enduring Miracle
description: JERUSALEMThe mood, in Jeru salem this Easter weak is remarkably calm. The Palm Sunday pilgrimage wandered over the stony hills of this lovely city in brilliant sunshine, and even the Israeli politicians, who pay little attention to the church bells and singing pilgrims, seem to have ac quired a new serenity.

title: 69 Rule Curbing CourtMartial Is Made Effective Retroactively
description: In a decision that could clear the records of thousands of for mer servicemen, the United States Court of Appeals here decided yesterday to give retro active effect to a 1969 ruling by the Supreme Court that sub stantially limited the right of the armed forces to hold courtsmartial.

title: Turkish Premier Bars Ransom For Three Kidnapped Britons
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 28 Nihat Erim, the Turkish Pre mier, said today his Govern ment would not yield to the de mands of the kidnappers of three British radar technicians.

title: L.I. HOMICIDE CHIEF SEEKS RETIREMENT
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 28 Detective Sgt. Matthew Bonora, the 44yearold chief of the Nassau County Police Depart ment's homicide squad, has ap plied for retirement after 22 years on the force.

title: Matzoh Gifts Destroyed After Soviet Rejection
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)  The United States Postal Service has destroyed 8,000 pounds of matzoh originally mailed to the Russian Embassy for dis tribution to Jews in the Soviet Union. Senator Har rison A. Williams Jr. said today.

title: General Tire Reports Profit Gains Despite a Decline in Sales
Jews Lease Area in Nassau To Ease Observance of Laws
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 28 Hempstead Town today sym bolically leased a square mile of West Hempstead to an Or thodox Jewish congregation to enable the congregants to more easily observe Jewish laws.

title: Their Affection For the Solitude Of Block Island
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I.Can you imagine working hard all your adult life and then, instead of settling down comfortably among the palm trees, you retire to an island where:

title: Vatican Assails 33 Theologians For Criticism of Its Leadership
description: ROME, March 28The Vati can said today that 33 Roman Catholic theologians in Europe and North America had serious ly offended the church by charging in an appeal last week that it was suffering from a crisis of leadership and con fidence.

title: John DeMain of NET Opera Wins a Julius Rudel Prize
description: John DeMain, associate con ductor of the NET Opera Thea ter, has ben selected as the second recipient of the Julius Rudel Award, to work with the New York City Opera. The award was established three years ago by Lawrence E. Deutsch and Lloyd Rigler, bothof Los Angeles, to help young conductors learn about the musical and artistic direction of an opera company by working with Mr. Rudel, who is general director of the New York City Apera. Christopher Keene was the first winner.

title: The Day Is Won or Lost In Instant at the Wheel
description: About Motor Sports

title: Colonels Defeat Condors
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 28 (AP)  The Kentucky Colonels, playing the final quarter with out Artis Gilmore, Dan Issel and Louis Dampier, held off a Pitts burgh Condor rally to score a 134132 victory to night.

title: 570 Hurt in Train Crash
description: FUNABASHI, Japan, March 28 (Reuters)At least 570 people were hurt, nine seriously, when a crowded commuter train rammed into the rear of an other train today, during the rush hour.

title: U.S. Aides Won't Comment
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 United States officials declined to comment today on reports that Libya and Jordan had provided Pakistan with Ameri canbuilt aircraft during her re cent war with India.

title: Court Backs Legal Fees Paid By TV Station to Challengers
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled to day that a television station could pay the fees and ex penses of lawyers who had originally challenged its li cense renewal, but who had then withdrawn the challenge when the station agreed to im prove its programing.

title: NETS TOP PACERS IN FINALE, 92 TO 86
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., March 28  The New York Nets saved their finest defensive effort for their regularseason finale to night and beat the Indiana Pacers, 9286, at the Nassau Coliseum. It was the lowest score of the season by Indiana, the secondplace finisher in the Western Division of the Ameri can Basketball Association.

title: B52's Strike at Enemy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 28 (AP)  American B52's flew seven missions over the northern and central parts of South Vietnam today in what the United States command described as a continuing cam paign to break up any attempt ed enemy offensive. A mission is flown by one to three planes.

title: ALBATROSS OWNERS DROP STAN DANCER
description: YONKERS, March 28Own ers of Abatross, the 4yearold pacer who was the 1971 Har ness horse of the year, have voted 73 to replace Stanley Dancer as the standard bred's trainerdriver. Last season Al batross won 25 of 28 races and earned $558,009.

title: RICHEY ADVANCES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG. South Africa. March 28 (Reuters) Topseeded Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., met an unex pectedly strong challenge from South Africa's Derek Schroder in the second round of the South African open tennis championship enroute to a 62, 62, 76 victory.

title: Maryland Legislature Gets Bill for Multisport Complex
description: ANNAPOLIS, March 28 (AP) Gov. Marvin Mandel sent to the Maryland legislature today a bill creating a state authority to build a multisports complex in Baltimore for the city's four professional teams.

title: A 'Forgotten Ballet by Milhaud to Have Its Premiere
description: GENEVAYou see, Dar ius Milhaud said with a smile of triumphant patience. A score can lie forgotten in a drawer for years, but one day it will jump out again.

title: Westchester Tries a Little Bit of Kindliness
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 28  Kindness, if not exactly bursting out all over West Chester County, is at least flowing gently here and there during this officially pro claimed Kindness Week in Westchester.

title: E.B.C. TRADE SURPLUS REACHES $1.5BILLION
description: BRUSSELS, March 28 (Rout ers)The Common Market had a trade surplus of $1.5billion in 1971, compared with a defi cit of $436million in 1970, ac cording to official figures re leased by the E.E.C. Executive Commission today.

title: A Woman Leader in Brooklyn To Challenge Celler in Primary
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, a 30yearold Brooklyn district reader announced yesterday that she would oppose Representative Emanuel Celler for the Democratic Congressional nomination in the June 20 primary.

title: Chairman Is Named by Indian Head
description: Richard J. Powers, formerly vice chairman of Indian Head, Inc., was elected chairman and chief executive of the 19year old conglomerate company yes terday.

title: RANGERS SEEKING TO CLINCH SECOND
description: Rod Gilbert took time out from his hospital stay yesterday to skate with the Rangers, then returned to Lenox Hill to re main in traction until doctors determine when he can play again.

title: Passover Celebration Starts This Evening
description: The weeklong celebration of Passover begins at sun down today.

title: WEALTH INSTITUTES SUED BY FEMINISTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)A coalition of women's organizations filed today a suit charging that the National In stitutes of Health practiced arbitrary and invidious dis crimination against women.

title: Einstein Urged Physicists Help Bar Arms Race
description: In December, 1944, in the midst of World War II and only seven months before the first atomic explosion, Albert Einstein proposed that the world's lead ing physicistsincluding two Russians be mobilized to prevent a postwar weapons race.

title: Penn Central Men Bitter as Deadline on Crews Nears
description: AVON, Ind.  Bob Moore, who has been helping to push freight froth here to Missouri for 20 years, stared at the newly posted notice on the bul letin board in the Penn Central crew shanty, shouted a curse, and added:

title: Rinaldo Has Everything a Baroque Opera Needs
description: On the honor roll of Handel's Greatest Hits, Rinaldo would definitely rate as a Golden Oldie. The opera's premiere performance on Feb. 24, 1711, brought the baroque composer his first London success and set a style that ruled English music for nearly 20 years. Many a casual student of Han del history has often wondered, therefore, just how good an opera Rinaldo is.

title: COUGARS DEFEAT SQUIRES BY 127121
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 28 (AP)Wendell Ladner scored on a jump shot with 46 seconds left to break a tie and the Car olina Cougars went on to beat the Virginia Squires, 127121, in an American Basketball As sociation game tonight.

title: Market Place: Portfolio Advice Stirs Questions
description: The ad appeared under a box number in a major news paper. It must have been rather appealing to some brokerage firms. It read something like this:

title: Chinese U.N. Delegation Shifts to Motel It Bought
description: The Chinese delegation to the United Nations yesterday moved their living and work ing headquarters to the former Lincoln Square Motor Inn, at 155 West 66th Street, from the Roosevelt Hotel, where it had had its quarters since Dec. 8.

title: ROMNEY PROMISES A FIGHT FOR CITIES
description: DETROIT, March 28  George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, said today that his de partment was not abandoning the central cities.

title: Floridians Clinch 4th
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 28 (AP)Warren Jabali scored 30 points tonight as the Florid ians whipped the Memphis Pros 118107, to clinch a spot in the A.B.A. playoffs.

title: Candidates' Day
description: FOND DU LAC, Wes., March 28Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the Federal Government should set up a network of national labora tories to conduct research into problems of environment.

title: Westchester Republicans Set to Designate Vergari to Oppose Reid
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 28 Stung by Representative Ogden R. Reid's defection to the Dem ocratic party a week ago, the Westchester County Republi can organization has decided to designate District Attorney Carl A. Vergari to run against him in the 24th Congressional District in November.

title: Books of The Times
description: NOT TO DISTURB. By Muriel Spark. 121 pages. Viking. $5.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: OREGON, Wis., March 28 Senator Edmund S. Muskie pro posed today that the Federal Government give the states $7.2billion to help them provide every elementary and second ary school pupil  including those in private and parochial classrooms  with the same quality of instruction.

title: Wary Senate Unit Queries Navy On New Outlays for F14 Fighter
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Navy disclosed today that it was planning to pay the Grumman Aerospce Corporation an additional $40million to compensate it for the loss of a test model of the F14 air craft and the subsequent slip page in production of the new carriers fighter plane.

title: For Democrats, Gloves Are Off
description: News Analysis

title: Good Malta Pact
description: Everyone concerned  meaning the United States and the other NATO allies, as well as the two signatories  will gain from the agreement finally concluded for con tinued British use of military facilities on Malta. Prime Minister Mintoff showed himself to be a Lough negotiator but one flexible enough to scale down his unrealistic earlier demands and settle for an annual payment nearly three times the sum Malta has been receiving.

title: Fordham, N.Y.U. Nines Will Play at Stadium
description: Fordham and New York University will meet in a baseball game at Yankee Sta dium May 19, officials of the schools and the Yankees an nounced yesterday.

title: Lakers Beat Bulls, 9580, for 10 Lead
description: LOS ANGELES, March 28 (UPI)After a sluggish first half, Los Angeles scored 15 straight points in a 4minute span of the third period tonight and the Lakers went on to beat the injurytroubled Chicago Bulls, 9580, in the first game of the National Basketball Asso ciation's Western Conference playoff semifinals.

title: Albany at MidSession
description: This has been a preelection session of the State Legis lature at which many of the major decisions had already been made before the curtain opened and the callto order gavel was sounded. Approval of Governor Rock efeller's proposed $7.9billion, holdtheline budget by both houses yesterday was foreshadowed by the tough tax decisions reached in last year's special session.

title: Public Services Crippled By Walkout in Quebec
description: QUEBEC, March 28 (Reuters) The Quebec provincial gov ernment was hit by the largest strike in the province's history today when many of the 210, 000 public service employes staged a 24hour walkout for higher wages.

title: City Council Votes to Prohibit Sabbath Elections
description: A bill prohibiting local com munity electiens such as in an tipoverty graups or school boards on Friday aftir sun down and on Saturday or Sun day was passed yesterday by the City Council.

title: METS BOW IN 10TH ON ROOKIE'S BALK
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 28 Brent Strom, a rookie left hander getting his last inspec tion before tomorrow's squad cuts, twice dissipated leads in the final two innings, which enabled the Detroit Tigers to edge the Mets, 54 in the 10th today. The loss snapped the Mets sixgame winning streak.

title: Dr. Hans Simons of New School Dies
description: Dr. Hans Simons, president of the New School for Social Research from 1950 to 1960, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 85 Landscape Avenue, Yonkers, after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Warriors Rally to Down Bucks In N.B.A. Playoff Game,117406
description: MILWAUKEE, March 28 (AP) The Golden State Warriors, down 13 points in the second quarter, rallied behind Jeff Mul lins and Jim Barnett for a 117 106 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight and a 10 lead in their fourofsevengame Na tional Basketball Association Western Conference playoff.

title: Advertising:
description: A wellprepared and ques tioning stockholder from Chicago contributed yester day to the longest annual meeting of The New Yorker Magazine in recent history.

title: Conglomerate Mergers
description: Economic Analysis

title: Prices of Silver Futures Show Advances for Day
description: Prices of silver future closed about 4/10 cent to 5/10 cent off the day's highs of 1.60 cents to 1.70 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday. Commission houses provided good buying support throughout the trading session, aided by chartist buy ing.

title: New Under Secretary at the U.N.
description: Man in the News

title: Air Cargo Security Plan Skims by Hurdle in House
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 A New YorkNew Jersey com pact giving the Waterfront Commission of New York Har bor power to take over the cargo security fucntions at the metropolitan airports narrowly cleared a major hurdle today. A House subcommittee for warded the measure on to its parent Judiciary Committee, but without a favorable rec ommendation.

title: Bus Accident in Jersey
description: MONTVILLE, N. J., March 28 (AP)A school bus on the way to Montville High School lost its back wheels while rounding a curve today, causing minor injuries to four of the 44 stu dents on board.

title: The FastTrial Rule Alone Is Not Enough, Fuld Says
description: New York State's chief judge said yesterday that the imple mentation of the speedytrial rule, which is to go into effect May 1 unless blocked by the Legislature, would not solve the problems plaguing the state court system.

title: Advertising:
description: Edward A. McCabe, a vice president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, rode to glory last night alternating between the back of a Perdue chicken and the driver's seat of a Volvo.

title: MINGUS AND BAND UNLEASH TALENTS
description: While the Thad JonesMel Lewis band is touring the Soviet Union for the State Department, its Monday night gigs at the Village Vanguard have been taken over by Charles Mingus and a 20piece band. Mr. Mingus recently gave a surprisingly bland concert at Philharmonic Hall with an ex panded version of this band but things have changed now that he is back in a club.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Robert S. McNamara, the guiding force behind Reading Is Fundamental, a national program to put free books in the hands of chil dren who seldom before had a chance to own a book of their selection, triumphantly announced a foundation grant of $1.15million.

title: SUFFOLK AIRPORT IS FACING CHANGES
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 28 The Suffolk County Execu tive, John V. N. Klein, told the County Legislature today that Suffolk County Airport in West hampton Beach had lost more than $1million in the last 18 months through mismanage ment and inefficiency and would lost about $700,000 more this year.

title: ALBANY APPROVES BUDGET FOR STATE CURBING SPENDING
description: ALBANY, March 28A $7.87 billion state budget that is ex ceptional for holding spending near the current year's level was approved by the Legisla ture today as Democrats helped the Republicans provide the margins of passage.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 28 A poll indicated today that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was running a close fourth in the Wisconsin Demo cratic Presidential primary on April 4.

title: CHARLES STOPPED BY NAPES IN 7TH
description: LONDON, March 28  Jose Napoles didn't need his smelling salts after all.

title: Questions to Professor Indicate U.S. Still Hunts Clues in Pentagon Papers Case
description: BOSTON, March 28A study of dozens of questions put to a Harvard professor before a grand jury yesterday indicates that the Federal Government is still groping for clues about how Daniel Ellsberg distributed the Pentagon papers to the news media.

title: PENSION TAX BASE IS LIKELY TO SOAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Congress appears to be moving toward another radical increase in the wage base on which So cial Security taxes are paid.

title: The Jesus Freaks and Jesus
description: SAUSALITO, Calif.A few days ago I gave a ride to a rather pleasant hippie couple who seemed to have no particular destination. I asked, What trip are you on? He said, Like spiritual trip? I said, Yes. He said, We're on the Jesus trip. Whose Jesus? I asked, Billy Graham's or mine? Well, it's all sort of the same, isn't it?

title: Dynalectron Says Process Cuts Sulphur in Fuel Oil
description: The Dynalectron Corpora tion said yesterday that it had developed a process that makes it economically feasible to pro cess heavy fuel oils and meet strict low sulphur air pollution codes.

title: Boston U. Protest Pressed
description: BOSTON, March 28 (AP)  Between 7,500 and 2,000 Boston University students voted to day to demand the ouster of the school's president and dean of students and called a gen eral student strike for April 5. This was in reaction on an inci dent yesterday when 33 persons were arrested at a sitin on campus property protesting the presence of military recruiters.

title: Patrolman's Bail Reduced
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 28 William McQuillan, a New York City patrolman who has been charged with murder in the shooting of a New York City detective, Ronald Chocko, was released on $15,000 bail today after a preparole report on his background was re ceived by a Nassau County Court judge. He had been held in jail on bail of $250,000 in connection with the slaying, which occurred at Freeport.

title: Candidates' Day
description: LA CROSSE, Wis., March 28 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama moved his campaign for the Presidency into the western reaches of Wisconsin today and assured those who questioned has past racial poli cies that he had never wronged the Negro.

title: GEORGE J. MORRISEY, FINANCIAL EDITOR, 62
description: George J. Morrisey, editor of The Commercial and Financial Chronicle and The OTC Mar ket Chronicle, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park. He was 62 years old and lived at 10920 71st Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Murphy Orders Police to Weigh In And Diet If Obese
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yester day that he was establishing a compulsory weightloss pro gram for fat policemen.

title: Beame Study Asserts Chaos Marks Hospital Agency Fiscal Procedures
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame charged the New York City Health and Hospitals Cor poration yesterday with cha otic fiscal procedures and grossly inadequate manage ment techniques, citing as an example a $171million book keeping discrepancy.

title: Chaparrals Beat Stars, 9895
description: DALLAS, March 28 (AP) Rich Jones and George John son led a fourth  quarter spree that provided a cushion to hold off a late rally as the Dallas Chaparrals posted a 9895 victory over the Utah Stars tonight.

title: New Life at the U.N.
description: The appointment of Representative F. Bradford Morse of Massachusetts to be an Under Secretary General of the United Nations arouses mixed feelings. As topranking American in the U.N. Secretariat, Mr. Morse will be replac ing the late Ralph J. Bunche, though his duties will not be identical with Mr. Bunche's. Many at Turtle Bay and elsewhere will regret that President Nixon did not desig nate an experienced diplomat for the post.

title: LIMITS ARE POSTED ON DIRT IN FOODS
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The Food and Drug Admin isration made public today for the first time a master list of food contamination limits that puts ceilings on such things as rodent hairs in peanut butter and from fly eggs in tomato juice.

title: FUNDS AND BANKS SUE MODEX CORP.
description: Two mutual funds managed by the Dreyfus Corporation teamed up with two major banks yesterday to charge the Alodex Corporation, a South haven, Miss., real estate con cern, its accountants and its investment banker with fraud in connection with a 1971 stock offering.

title: 400 IN BANGLADESH KILLED BY SMALLPOX
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 28 (Reuters)A smallpox epi demic is raging in parts of Ban gladesh, and officials report that at least 225 people have died in one district alone.

title: BERKELEY FAVORS LEGAL MARIJUANA
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 28 The Berkeley City Council endorsed tonight a proposed state constitutional amendment to decriminalize the use of marijuana.

title: City Officials Generally Happy With State's Budget
description: City officials were generally happy with the state budget approved in Albany yesterday, but they warned that the next step in the budgeting process in which the city hopes for $850million more in state aid would be the most crucial.

title: Fire Halts Subway Lines
description: A twoalarm fire in an amusement center at 1217 Surf Avenue near Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island yesterday af ternoon caused an 80minute shutdown of power at the Still well Avenue station of the city transit system. From 3:30 to 4:50 P.M. the trains on the QJ route were turned around at the Brighton Beach station and on the F route the turn around was made at the Kings Highway station.

title: Laaadies and Gentlemen the Circus!
description: Cynics and sourheads, avoid Madison Square Gar den like the plague through May 29. The circus is back. But ladies and gentlemen, children of all agesthat's the booming starter  don't miss it. The 102d goround of Ringling Brothers and Bar num & Bailey is grand show.

title: School Board Appointment Raises Issue of Conflict
description: A 42yearold city high school teacher was appointed yesterday by Borough President Robert T. Connor of Richmond to replace Dr. Mary E. Meade as a member of the central Board of Education.

title: WINGS TOP BRUINS AND STAY IN RACE
description: DETROIT, March 28 (AP) The Detroit Red Wings scored four goals in the third period tonight to preserve its National Hockey League playoff hopes with a 63 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: KILLING BY POLICE SCORED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) An independent study group said today that Chicago police men killed more persons over an eightmonth period than did the police in any of the four other largest cities in the na tion. The group charged that the city had a triggerhappy society of policemen.The Chicago Law Enforce ment Study Group, a joint proj ect of Northwestern University Center for Urban Affairs and 12 community organizations, cited a survey taken July, 1970, to March, 1971, that reported the ratio of police killings in Chi cago was more than three times higher than in New York, Los Angeles and Detroit and almost 1 times higher than in Phila delphia.

title: 4 Die in Nashville Air Crash
description: NASHVILLE, March 28 (UPI) A private plane approaching Nashville Metropolitan Airport crashed and burned today near a fogshrouded suburban shop ping center, killing all four persons aboard.

title: DOW OFF BY 2.71; FOOD CHAINS FALL
description: Supermarket stocks took another drop yesterday amid signs that the Nixon Adminis tration plans to keep a closer, eye on grocery pricing policies in an effort to hold down spi raling food costs.

title: HOUSE TURNS BACK MOVES TO STIFFEN CLEANWATER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 The House decisively rejected today every attempt by envi ronmentalists to correct what they regard as weaknesses in the water pollution control bill written by the Public Works Committee.

title: STUDY INDICATES BUS DID NOT FAIL
description: A Federal investigator study ing the collision between a freight train and a school bus near Nyack last Fri day said yesterday that prelimi nary findings gave no indica tion of mechanical failure of the bus at this point in time.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 28if George C. Wallace is wooing Wisconsinites with the Grand Ole Political Opry, John V. Lindsay is superstarring in Naked City.

title: Convict Is Killed, 2 Are Captured in Jailbreak Attempt at San Jose
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 28 One prisoner was killed and two others who were holding two hostages wore captured to day, ending an attempt to escape from the county jail here.

title: Some of Einstein's Reflections, Aphorisms and Observations
description: (From a letter dated April 16, 1954, to S. Flesch of Vienna):

title: Exhibition of Modern Sculpture Stirs Bitter Controversy in Staid Nuremberg
description: NUREMBERG, West Ger many  Nuremberg, famed for its old buildings and its artists of old, has acquired 30 modern sculptures and in the process stirred up a bitter, sometimes violent controversy.

title: Ralston Beaten by Russell
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., March 28 (AP)Richard Russell of Ja maica pulled an upset today in the Caribe Hilton invitation tennis tournament by defeating Dennis Ralston, the United States Davis Cup coach and captain, 57, 75, 63.

title: EXPERTS FOR I.T.T. ARE UNAVAILABLE
description: Two experts hired by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to in spect a disputed memorandum that linked the settlement of three antitrust suits against the company to promised financial support of the Republican party's 1972 national conven tion remained unavailable for comment yesterday for the fourth day.

title: Meany Tells Price Panel Phase 2 Failed America
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., told the Price Commission today that its price controls were a failure because the Nixon Administration was not providing the tools to en force them.

title: Detroit Faces Area School Plan; CityOnly Integration Rejected
description: DETROIT, March 28A Fed eral judge said today that he was dutybound to order some type of metropolitanarea plan to desegregate Detroit's largely black schools. Such a plan could mean largescale busing.

title: MRS. ADAMS BATCHELLER
description: Mrs. Ruth Brady Scott Batch eller, widow of Adams Batchel ler, who was a partner in the brokerage firm of Dominick & Dominick at his death in 1951, died yesterday in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 62 years old and lived at 15 East 69th Street and Windmill Farm, Long Lane, Far Hills, N. J.

title: Union Carbide Linde Unit Realigns Schedule of Prices
Distributors Back TextileCare Label
description: Labeling to provide instruc tions on care of textile products was endorsed yesterday by the Textile Distributors Association. It represents mills and con verters that distribute the great bulk of fabrics used in apparel and home furnishings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Transport Control Seen
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 A Federal Power Commission presiding examiner ruled today that the agency had no jurisdic tion over a company seeking to build a plant to make synthetic gas from naphtha but that it did have authority over the trans portation and sale of the syn thetic product after it was mixed with natural gas.

title: Saigon Given U.S. Base
description: PHANRANG, South Vietnam, March 28 (AP)The United States Air Force deactivated its 315th Tactical Airlift Wing today and turned over to South Vietnam its Phanrang air base, built on the central coast six years ago at a cost of $60 million.

title: Soviet, at Geneva, Offers Pact to Bar Chemical Arms
description: GENEVA, March 28The Soviet Union presented to the Geneva disarmament confer ence today a draft convention calling on all nations to agree never in any circumstances to develop, produce, stockpile or otherwise acquire or retain chemical means of warfare.

title: Badminton Champion Is Indonesia's Hero
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27His lanky body glistens with sweat, but it is his opponent who is doing most of the work. He looks lazy at times, moving list lessly before a crowd that know he's in control and ap plauds the few points his op ponent gets mostly out of sympathy.

title: Pentagon Proposes $30Million Bonus To Gain Reservists
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)The Pentagon asked Con gress today for $30million in bonuses for reservists effective Saturday, and $200million more next year to try to at tract enough doctors and men with other special skills into a voluntary military force.

title: 10 TO 40 YEARS GIVER IN HOLDUPS
description: Prison sentences ranging up to 40 years were imposed by a Federal judge here yesterday on four men taking part in some or all of a series of armed robberies in North Carolina and New York.

title: INTEREST RATES ON BONDS EDGE UP
description: Credit Markets

title: Hanoi Bids U.S. Return To Paris Peace Talks
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, March 29 (Reuters)  North Vietnam has called on the United States to return to the Paris peace conference on Vietnam, suspended in definitely by President Nixon, according to the official North Vietnamese press agency.

title: Pros Sign 71 Jacksonville Sophomore
description: MEMPHIS, March 28 (UPI) The Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Associa tion, fighting for survival, clipped into the college ranks today and signed David Brent of Jacksonville University, a 7footlinch sophomore.

title: 4 Seized in Queens Bank Holdup In Shootout With Police Cordon
description: Two policemen assigned to a special roving squad guarding banks in Queens thwarted a holdup of a bank in the Jack son Heights section in which robbers tried to bargain their way out by using hostages. Four suspects were seized and a fifth was believed to have escaped.

title: Executive Changes
description: Cresap, McCormick & Paget, Inc., management consultants, has named Joseph P. Merriam as ex ecutive vice president.

title: Trade Gap Widens
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 Both exports and imports de clined in February with resump tion of the West Coast dock strike, and the trade deficit widened to the second largest for a month on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Patchwork Budget
description: News Analysis

title: I.T.T. Scandal
description: It now appears that I.T.T. lobbyist Dita Beard, who collapsed with a heart seizure while being questioned in a Denver hospital by Senate Judiciary Committee members, will not be able to testify again for six months or more.

title: Jersey Allows Girls to Try Out For High School Varsity Teams
description: TRENTON, March 28Girls will be allowed to try out for varsity high school sports  at least for the coming year under a pilot program ap proved today by the New Jer sey State Interscholastic Athlet ic Association.

title: AMEX PRESENTS IDEAS ON FUTURE
description: The American Stock Ex change is engaged in a Series of presentations to securitiesin dustry leaders in order to show them its ideas about the stock market of the future.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  Kurt Waldheirn, the U.N.'s Austrian Secre tary General, has an eminently prac tical view of the United Nations and his own role. Aware of its imperfec tions, he is convinced the time has come for the organization to improve its administrative and financial effi ciency. As for the major problem politicalthe U.N. does what its mem bers permit it to do, no more, no less.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An underwriting group man aged by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., offered yesterday 400,000 shares of the Ferro Corporation common stock at $33.50 per share, the price at which the stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. According to the announcement, uses for the proceeds will include invest ment in new plant and equip ment for the manufacture of fiber glass in Nashville.

title: Health Care Act Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)  Representative Al Ull man, Democrat of Oregon, sub mitted a bill today under which the Federal Government would share in the cost of health in surance for all Americans. His proposal, called the National Health Services Act, would create nonprofit health care corporations set up and regu lated by state health commis sions and operated on the local level by hospitals, dentists, doctors and other health pro fessionals. The plan would be financed by a combination of payroll taxes and general rev enues.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Deeparmhole dresses to go under deeparmhole coats are starting to show up and Jerry Silverman is delighted. The manufacturer, who spe cializes in wearable clothes, says they remind him of Balenciaga, whose clothes were always wearable.

title: Nastase Easy Victor
description: MONTE CARLO, March 28 (UPI)llie Nastase of Rumania advanced in the $20,000 Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today with an easy 64, 61 victory over Nikki Spear of Yugoslavia. Nastase won the tournament last year.

title: Corporate Change Planned
description: Western Union International, Inc., said yesterday it would become a subsidiary of a new company, WUI, to be incor porated in Delaware. The change requires approval by sharehold ers and governmental authori ties.

title: RIGHTS AIDE TERMS BUSING BAN RACISM
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)A civil rights lobbyist, Clarence Mitchell, said today that when President Nixon pro posed a moratorium on forced school busing he placed him self on the side of those who have stood in school doorways to bar black children.

title: JAKARTA DRILLING CAMBODIAN GROUP
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 27Indonesia is training 60 Cambodian soldiers in com mando techniques for the Lon Nol Government, military sources in Jakarta have dis closed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Monetary Reform Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 A group of former high Gov ernment officials and private economists said today it was urgent that negotiations for world monetary reform be started at the earliest possible time.

title: Legislature Votes Election Reform; 5 Panels Would Replace City Board
description: ALBANY, March 28The Legislature today passed two bills that would revamp the election process in New York City.

title: Fraser Wins, 97, 98
description: HONG KONG, March 28 (AP) Neale Fraser, captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, de feated Takeshi Koura of Japan, 97, 98, and Geoff Masters of Australia downed Jun Kuki of Japan, 64, 98, as the Hong Kong tennis championships started today.

title: DONIE BUSH DIES; LED BE TEAMS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 28 (AP)Donie Bush, who batted ahead of Ty Cobb, the Detroit Tigers legendary center field er, for 13 years and later man aged four major league ball clubs, died today at the age of 83.

title: Pakistan Said to Have Got U.S.Built Jets From Arabs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 28Military sources disclosed today that the air forces of Libya and Jordan had provided Americanbuilt combat aircraft to Pakistan during her war with India and that some of these planes were still in Pakistani service.

title: Hanoi Says It Won't Press South Politically
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, March 17In a series of interviews, North Vietnamese officials have taken pains to say they want to reassure the United States that North Vietnam has no in tention of pressing a political or ideological claim on the South if President Nguyen Van Thieu is ousted.

title: City Says Cut of 1,067 Jobs Is Due May 1 in Fund Crisis
description: The Lindsay administration announced plans yesterday to lay off 1,067 employes May 1 in probation, health, housing and airpollution programs as a result of state budget cuts ap proved Tuesday in Albany.

title: TEMPLE EMANUEL MARKS PASSOVER
description: Passover began at sundown yesterday, and Temple Emanuel celebrated with a Seder last night. Why is this night dif ferent from all other nights? Russell Coyne asked the cele brants, and the Rev. Nathan A. Perilman answered:

title: State Legislature Gets 2 Bills To Aid Housing and Hospitals
description: ALBANY, March 29  Two bills that would authorize the state Housing Finance Agency to issue an additional $1.5bil lion in bonds and notes to finance mortgage loans for limitedincome housing and for hospital and nursinghome facilities were submitted today to the Legislature on the Gov ernor's behalf.

title: G.M. Sets a Joint Venture With a Korean Auto Maker
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 29The General Motors Cor poration agreed today with the Shinjin Motor Company of Seoul to start a $48million,5050 joint venture to produce automobiles in South Korea for both domesticsales and ex ports.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Donald Blessing Rice, named today as president of the Rand Corporation, is known throughout the Federal bu reaucracy as a very good listener and an unusually objective arbiter of highly competitive claims on the Government's tax dollar.

title: STUDENTS PICKET HARRISBURG TRIAL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29About 175 young men and women, most of them semi narians, surrounded the Fed eral Building with a chain today to protest the Vietnam war and expressed support for the Harrisburg Seven defend ants on trial within.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN.
description: APPLETON, Wis., March 29 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama disclosed today cam paign contributions that cov ered the last three years and totaled less than $1million.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: BERNARD A. BROWN
description: Bernard A. Brown, founder and president of the United Buying Service Corporation, a consumer cooperative buying organization, died of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday. He was 65 years old and lived on West 58th Street and in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands.

title: DELTA AIR PLANNING CHANGE IN ITS FLEET
description: Delta Air Lines announced yesterday it had signed a pur chase agreement to buy 14 Boeing 727's from the Boeing Company at a cost of about $100million.

title: Market Place: Speculative Era Brewing Anew
description: It's hard to believe after the stock market blood bath of 1969 and 1970, but it ap pears that wealthy investors are beginning to seek super performance once again.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS BOMB PLOT FIGURE
description: SEATTLE, March 29 (AP) A Federal grand jury has in dicted Leslie Bacon, the anti war activist, on charges of com mitting perjury before a grand jury last year when she denied being inside the United States Capitol hours before a bomb exploded in a men's room.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN.
description: MILWAUKEE, March 29 Senator George McGovern re ported today that his Presiden tial campaign raised more than $240,000 from 2,984 contribu tors in February and early March, most of it before his un expectedly strong secondplace showing in the New Hampshire primary March 7.

title: Personal Finance: Students' Defaults
description: Have you ever borrowed money under the studentloan program and then allowed the loan to go into default?

title: State Contends L.I.R.R Gangs Are Idle a Quarter of Their Time
description: ALBANY, March 29  Long Island Rail Road work gangs were found more idle than in the past, wasting more than a quarter of their time, accord ing to clandestine observations made by state auditors.

title: Skiing Areas Soon To Get the Willies Over the Jimmies
description: News of skiing

title: Bausch & Lomb Is Sued On Earnings Disclosures
description: Bausch & Lomb, Inc., re ported yesterday that five law suits have been brought against the company, charging that it violated Federal securities laws by failing to make prompt, pub lic disclosure of an estimate of firstquarter earnings.

title: Political Soup Kitchens
description: Manhattan Assemblyman Franz Leichter was not pre cisely right when he labeled a boondoggling bill expand ing membership on New York, City's Board of Elections as one creating a soup kitchen for retired politicians. The bill establishes not one but five soup kitchens. They loom as sanctuaries in which financial sustenance can be found for the faithful who, for reasons of age or other wise, no longer can stand the heat of the hustings.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Starts Campaign in State
description: Representative Shirley A. Chisholm, opening her New York State primary campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday, an nounced the names of 32 dele gatecandidates and then took to the streets for a bit of mid town and uptown sidewalk campaigning.

title: Miss Davis Tells of Buying Guns but Denies Plot Role
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 29 Angela Davis, in an emotional declaration of her innocence, said today that she had pur chased some guns but vigorous ly denied that she had given them to a group that tried to free George Jackson from prison.

title: Antitrust Ruling Set
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company violated antitrust law when it centered the spark plug business and took over the Autolite name, the Su preme Court ruled today by 7 to 0.

title: Indian Bus Plunge Toll Big
description: COCHIN, India, March 29, (Reuters)  A bus plunged into the backwaters leading to the Arabian Sea today and about 40 persons were believed to have drowned. Twelve persons sur vived.

title: Heath's Plan for Ulster May Work
description: LONDONThe Northern Ireland Provincial Parliament is dead, But prospective mourners should not weep over the body as though once, in life and health, it was one of the hallowed institutions of Western democracy. The Stormont Governmentand the Constitution from which it sprang was founded on prejudice and sus tained by bigotry. Its passing is a merciful relief.

title: Notes on People
description: There's a litle oil on the roiled waters stretching be tween the House of Repre sentatives and the People's Republic of China. Secretary of State William P. Rogers has informed House Speaker Carl Albert that House Dem ocratic Leader Hale Boggs and Republican Leader Ger ald R. Ford have been invited to visit the Mainland. Some weeks back, Mr. Albert made clear that he felt the lower house had been slighted when President Nixon brought back word from Peking that the Chinese had extended invitations to Senate Leaders Mike Mansfield and Hugh Scott.

title: Alabama Appoints First Three Blacks As State Troopers
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 29The Alabama Department of Public Safety, which was ordered by a Federal court in February to recruit more Negroes, announced today that the state's first three black state troopers had been hired.

title: A Teacher Who Started Out By Opening Her Own School
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Nine years ago, when her older son was 2, Margaret Skutch scoured Stamford looking for a nursery school for him. She didn't find one she liked until a friend told her about a Montessori school an hour's drive away.

title: TV: It's the Time for RerunsWith a Difference
description: It's rerun time again on the commercial networks. Except for the few new series that began earlier this year, the schedule for the next few months will be heavy with episodes already broadcast in the last year or so. If you managed to miss them the first time around, you're not safe yet.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 29 Democratic candidates in the April 4 Presidential primary are frantically hopscotching around Wisconsin these days in pursuit of an electorate whose voting vagaries are as unpredictable as the early spring weather.

title: Airline Ruled Guilty of Bias
description: Northwest Orient Airlines has been found guilty of dis criminating against a black automotive mechanic by false ly charging, him with poor work and dismissing him in October, 1969, from his job at Kennedy International Airport, the City Commission on Human Rights announced yesterday. It ordered the airline to pay the man, Oswald Collins, 41 years old, a total of $1,284 in pay he would have received before finding a new job and $500 for mental anguish and hu miliation.

title: CHARLES A. WIGHT, 73, MINERAL FIRM AIDE
description: NIANTIC, Conn., March 29 Charles A. Wight, a former senior executive of the Freeport Minerals Company, died today in Lawrence Memorial Hospital, New London, after a brief ill ness. He was 73 years old and lived on Old Black Point Road.

title: WQXR Not for Sale; Times Will Continue To Operate Station
description: WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, will not be sold, the board of directors of The New York Times Com pany announced yesterday. The board said it had decided to take the AM and FM outlets off the market and to continue to operate them.

title: Report on Jets Circulates
description: SAIGON, March 29 (UPI) Military sources said today that new unconfirmed intelligence reports indicated that North Vietnam was planning to use Sovietbuilt jets for the first time in the fighting in South Vietnam. The sources added, however, that United States officers were highly skeptical of the reports, which originated with South Vietnamese offi cials.

title: Militant Ulster Protestants Confer on Future Protests
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 29Militant Protestants, buoyed by a twoday general strike that paralyzed Northern Ireland, met secretly today to plan further protests against Britain's takeover of the prov ince.

title: U.S. Riders Leave for European PreOlympic Drills
description: The United States Eques trian Team's threediy squad Jack LeGoff, the coach, four riders and 12 horses left Kennedy Airport on a chartered KLM airliner yes terday for five months of preOlympic competition and training in Europe.

title: Presidential TV News Parleys Ruled Subject to Equal Time
description: WASHINGTON, March 29A littleknown and neverused de cision by the Federal Commu nications Commission would require radio and television networks, if asked, to grant equal time to candidates oppos ing President Nixon if he held any broadcast news conferences between now and the Nov. 7 election.

title: NASSAU DETECTIVE ASKS CAHN OUSTER
description: MINEOLA, March 29  The commanding officer of the Nas sau County Police Department's homicide squad called today for the resignation of District Attorney William Cahn, whom he accused of bringing undue pressure against appointed of ficials of the department through the power of his of fice.

title: P.B.A. Delegates Reject Proposed Pact
description: Police union delegates yes terday overwhelmingly rejected a new contract proposal that would have raised annual pay and benefits to $16,894 and also would have provided for a re vision of patrolmen's work schedules.

title: Colleges, High Schools Drop Most 1Shot Fouls
description: College and high school basketball teams will no longer take one foul shot after each of the first six common fouls charged to an opponent during a half. Starting next season, the team that is fouled will, instead, put the ball in play from the point out of bounds nearest to the point of the foul after those early infractions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday that the new Environmental Control Board had been so successful in speeding compli ance with the Air Pollution Control Code that he was Installing to extend the board's jurisdiction to other areas, such as littering.

title: Controls Failing, Mills Says
description: BOSTON, March 29 (AP) Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said to day that the Administration's economic controls were not succeeding and that he was just about ready to say we must go back to some sort of price freeze across the board.

title: Advertising:
description: The recent criticisms of the press by two important advertising agency executives probably upset a lot of people.

title: Men Are Cutting Their Hair Again
description: Are all those lion manes, Beetle locks and footwide Afros going to wind up on the barber shop floor? There are signs that men's hair is going short again. The new hair cuts are a far cry from the skinhead, bootcamp look, but those painstakinglygrown curls are coming off the collar. Recently, male models who paraded the new conservative tailoring looked positively kempt again. And so do a number of avantgardists, who are tired of looking like everybody else.

title: Vidal's Play Due April 17
description: An Evening With Richard Nixon, the new play by Gore Vidal, has been booked to open at the Shubert Theater during the week of April 24 after a series of previews starting April 17. Edwin Sherin is di recting.

title: Francis B. Sayre Dies at 86; ExCommissioner to Philippines
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Francis B. Sayre, law professor, diplomat and prominent Episco pal layman, died today at his home. He was 86 years old.

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Orders Inquiry Into Leak
description: TOKYO, March 29 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Takeo Fu kuda ordered an investigation today into leaks of official documents.

title: Drysdale Is Upset By Dent in 3 Sets In Macon Tourney
description: MACON, Ga., March 29 (UPI)  Phil Dent of Australia upset secondseeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 36, 63, 76, to night in the second round of the fifth annual Macon interna tional tennis tournament.

title: Peking Assails U.S. Stand In Suspending Paris Talks
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, March 30 (Reuters)China ac cused the United States today of arbitrarily suspending the Paris peace talks and urged the Nixon Administration to re sume talks with the Vietnamese Communists in a serious man ner.

title: It Even Includes Maternity Benefits
description: Sports of The Times

title: Hanoi Says New Talks Are Up to U.S.
description: PARIS, March 29  North Vietnam said today that it was waiting for the United States to take the initiative in resum ing the stalled peace talks here.

title: YANKS WILL CARRY ONLY 2 CATCHERS
description: MIAMI, March 29The New York Yankees will probably carry only two catchers, Thurman Munson and John Ellis, on their roster when the season begins, and the reason ing behind the decision offers some insight into the kind of problems baseball managers really think about.

title: With Economy in Ruins, Bangladesh Faces Food Crisis
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29As a column of horsecarts carrying bagged rice plods along a dirt track on the edge of Faridpur, ragged children scramble in the dust for a few kernels that have escaped from a hole in a bag.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that its directors have authorized the sale of 2 million new com mon shares. Stockholders will be offered the right to subscribe to one new share for each 10 shares held. Terms of the offer ing will be set later. There are currently 20,185,132 shares outstanding.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN.
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., March 29 The South Carolina Demo cratic party, a free  wheeling mixture of old party regulars, Negroes and reform  minded college students, elected tonight 32 uncommitted delegates to the Democratic National Con vention.

title: Lord Rank, Film Magnate, Is Dead at 83
description: LONDON, March 29Lord Rank, founder of the Rank Or ganization, which financed many of the bestknown British film productions and also op erated an extensive chain of theaters in which to show them, died today in a hospital in Winchester. He was 83 years old.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET AMONG 60 NAMED IN HOUSING FRAUD
description: Dun & Bradstreet, nine other corporations and 40 individuals, including an officer of thecred itrating concern and the No. 3 man in the Hempstead, L. I., insuring office of the Federal Housing Administration, were named in Federal indictments yesterday in an alleged multi milliondollar housing fraud scheme.

title: ACCOUNTANTS GET REPORT ON RULES
description: A special study group of the accounting profession released yesterday a long report propos ing changes in how accounting standards are set and who sets them.

title: Leslie Nelson Jennings, 81, Poet and Editor, Is Dead
description: Leslie Nelson Jennings, poet and former coeditor with the, late Harold Vinal of the poetry magazine Voices, died Monday in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he was spending the winter. He was 81 years old and lived at the Hotel Winslow, Madison Avenue at 55th Street.

title: Medical Plan in Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 29Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he was sending med ical and dental units of the New Jersey Natibnal Guard into the state prison here in re sponse to inmate demands for improved care.

title: SCAM UPSETS YONKERS CHOICES
description: YONKERS, March 29On paper, tonight's $25,000 final of the Hopeful Pacing Series figured to be a twohorse race, though nine standardbreds went postward at Yonkers Raceway.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It's not a puton. Bouncing Bertha's Banana Blanket real ly is the name of the com pany. And the owners, Rich ard Kennedy and his wife, Barbara, who are in their late twenties, look like walking advertisements for the clothes for men and women they've been making at 706 Avenue of the Americas for the last two years.

title: Oklahoma House Rejects Equal Rights Amendment
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 29 (UPI)The Oklahoma House rejected Tuesday a proposal to ratify the women's equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES POTATOTRADE BAN
description: A House Agriculture subcom mittee, overriding its chairman, voted yesterday, 6 to 2, to ban potatofutures trading in all commodity markets in this country.

title: SEBASTIAN OFFERS PLEASANT MELODIES
description: John Sebastian was at Phil harmonic Hall Tuesday and Wednesday night, wearing his familiar tiedyes, smiling his nonstop smile and exuding good vibes in all directions.

title: Bank Group Automates Money Transfers Here
description: The New York Clearing House Association, whose 11 member banks include six of the 10 largest banks in the country, has quietly introduced a new electronic money trans fer system that portends major changes in the operation of the nation's money market.

title: Bangladesh Will Try 1,100 Pakistanis
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 29The Bangladesh Govern ment plans to try 1,100 Paki stani military prisoners for war crimes and expects to begin the trials by the end of the year, official Bengali sources disclosed today.

title: HSIEH FUCIIIII, 74, CHINESE LEADER
description: PEKING, March 29 (Reuters) The death, of Hsieh Fuchip, former Chinese Minister of Se curity and a member of the Politburo, was announced here today.

title: Seymour Assails P.B.A. Attack on the Knapp Panel
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. accused the Patrolmen's Benevolent As sociation yesterday of working against the interest of both the people and the policemen of New York in its attempts to discredit the Knapp Commis sion.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: ALMA NORTH WINS HIALEAH HANDICAP
description: MIAMI, March 29 (AP)Alma North led from gate to wire today to win the $64,600 Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah Park. Her margin in the 1 mile race for fillies and mares was a length and a half.

title: 100 in Congress Ask Division of H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The first major attempt to break up the Department of Health, Education and. Welfare started today with almost 100 Congressmen backing a reor ganization plan that the Nixon Administration strongly op poses.

title: Nixon Aide Asks Wide Debate On Desirability of U.S. Growth
description: LOS ANGELES, March 29 President Nixon's top environ mental adviser, Russell E. Train, called today for a national de bate on the desirability of growth.

title: Chaplain Says He Spurned Woman and She Got Angry
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 29 (AP)A woman who has accused him of adultery offered him free love and became angry and hostile when he spurned her offer, Comdr. An drew F. Jensen, a Navy chap lain, testified at his court martial today.

title: West Germans 20 Victors
description: BUDAPEST, March 29 (UPI) West Germany beat Hungary, 20, today in a tuneup soccer match for the European Na tion Cup tournament.

title: Senate Extends Controls On CommunistBloc Sales
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters)The Senate today passed a bill temporarily ex tending to Aug. 1 the present system of controls on exports to Communist countries while Congress works out a new system.

title: Adm. Louis E Denfeld,ExChief Of Naval Operations, Dies at 80
description: WESTBORO, Mass., March 29 Adm. Louis E. Denfeld, who was Chief of Naval Operations from 1947 to 1949, died last evening at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELFAST, March 29 (UPI) A British Army major in the bomb disposal squad was killed tonight when a bomb in a parked car exploded. The offi cer was the 292d person killed since violence broke out 31 months ago in Northern Ireland.

title: CONTEMPT CHARGED IN WAR PAPERS CASE
description: BOSTON, March 29Samuel L. Popldn, an assistant profes sor of government at Harvard, was held in contempt today by a Federal District judge for re fusing to answer nine ques tions before a grand Jury in vestigating the release and dis tribution of the Pentagon papers.

title: LEAFS 4 IN FIRST DOWN BRUINS, 41
description: TORONTO, March 29 (UPI) Four firstperiod goals enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to beat Boston, 41, tonight and snap the unbroken string of the Bruins' goalie, Gerry Cheev ers, at 32 games.

title: U.S. Plane Downed By Missile in Laos; Crew of 14 Missing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, March 30  North Vietnamese antiaircraft missiles shot down an Air Force AC130 gunship over the Ho CM Minh Trail in southern Laos early yesterday morning, and the 14 crewmen of the fourengine plane were declared missing to day by the United States com mand.

title: John K. Starkweather Dies at 81; ExGovernor of Stock Exchange
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 29John K. Starkweather, a governor of the New York Stock Exchange from 1940 to 1944 and Mayor of Scarsdale from 1942 to 1945, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 23 Autenrieth Road.

title: In Siberia, From Bratsk to Novosibirsk, U.S. Rock Groups Are Big, Nixon Isn't
description: BRATSK, U.S.S.R., March 23Across the vast ex panses of Siberia, the pros pect of President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union this spring stirs little excitement. People are more interested in knowing about American cars, books, rock groups and fashions.

title: HAL ROACH JR. DIES; RAN FATHER'S STUDIO
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 29 (UPI)Hal E. Roach Jr., a former movie and tele vision fillm producer, died in a hospital early today from complications of pneumonia. He was 53 years old.

title: PRIESTS DEFECTIONS REPORTED BY VATICAN
description: ROME, March 29The Vati can said today that 13,450 Roman Catholic priests aban doned their vocations from 1964 through 1969.

title: Harlem 4 Due to Be Released Tomorrow as Bail Is Reduced to $5,000 Each
description: The four youths known as the Harlem 4 will be re leased from jail on $5,000 bond each, probably tomorrow morn ing.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 29, 1972

title: Orantes Wins in 3 Sets
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, March 29 (UPI)Rain washed out play today on the third day of the South African open tennis championships af ter only three of more than 70 scheduled matches were completed.

title: Prisoner Is Found Hanged in His Cell On Rikers Island
description: A 23yearold inmate under psychiatric observation on Ri ker's Island hanged himself last night with a noose fashioned from strips of his trousers, the Department of Corrections re ported.

title: Executive Changes
description: Martin H. Rod has been elected senior vice presidentoperations of James Talcott Factors, the factoring division of James Talcott, Inc., the finan cial organization.

title: N.B.C. Plans 5 New TV Series for the Fall
description: Crime and adventure series will make up the major part of the new programing the Na tional Broadcasting Company will present next season, a first look yesterday at its fall scheduled disclosed.

title: Tests Set for Pill That May Reduce Breast Cancer
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 29Researchers in Bos ton are planning a clinical test of a new kind of oral contra ceptive based on a form of the female hormone estrogen that some scientists believe may lower the risk of getting breast cancer.

title: 5 HOUSE LIBERALS BACK BUSING CURB
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Five white liberal members of the House of Representatives from the Detroit area signed today a petition to force a House vote on a constitutional amendment prohibiting busing.

title: Levitt to Bar Payment For $16,000 M.T.A. Ads
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that he would refuse to approve the use of state funds to pay for more than $16,000 worth of newspaper advertising placed this week by the Metropoli tan Transportation Authority.

title: Soviet Sees No Threat to Environment In Increasing Output Under Its System
description: MOSCOW, March 29  A current of thought worrying its way through the West, the idea that economic growth has eco logical limits that may be reached in the next few gen erations, has not yet reached the public in the Soviet Union.

title: Stage: Gusto Is the Word for The Beggar's Opera
description: Gusto  simple gusto as raw as Hogarth, as lecherous as Boswell, as malicious as Popehas taken over the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn, where at the Academy of Music it is offer ing a positively euphoric and joyous production of The Beggar's Opera.

title: STATE UNIT MOVES TO LIMIT PENSIONS
description: ALBANY, March 29A state commission called tin the Legis lature, today to exclude future employes from the liberal benefit provisions of the Legis lativeExectitive Planthe most envied in the state re tirement, system.

title: KISSINGER TO VISIT JAPAN NEXT MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national se curity, will fly to Tokyo on April 15 for three days of in formal discussions with Jap anese leaders, the White House announced tonight.

title: The Screen:Breezy James Coburn in 'Carey Treatment'
description: Blake Edwards's "The Carey Treatment," which opened here yesterday, is an absurdly entertaining movie about a medical pathologist named Peter Carey (James Coburn), the sort of rugged, left-wing individualist who makes $45,-000 a year, spends a good deal of it on a set decorator's dream of a Boston duplex, drives a station wagon a block long and affects the kind of slash-pocket, casual clothes worn mostly by male models for Esquire as they horse around, without damaging the creases.At one point in the film, which pretends to be concerned with his hunt for the person who performed a fatal abortion on the hospital administrator's daughter, Peter is described as a dissident professor who, like disloyal soldiers and renegade priests, is bent on destroying the Establishment. However, I don't think we have to take this too seriously,, for "The Carey Treatment," like so many respectable private-eye movies, is sustained almost entirely by irrelevancies.Because Mr. Edwards ("Gunn," "A Shot in the Dark") and, apparently, his script writer, James P. Bonner, have a good deal of humor, these irrelevancies become the movie's purpose, or, at least, the reason for seeing it if you don't quite feel up to, say, "The Sorrow and the Pity."Almost every red herring that Peter pursues, and every blind alley in which he finds himself trapped, has its comic point, if only a line like the one spoken by a blackmailing photographer the moment Peter is about to beat him up. "Please," he whines, "I just had a hernia operation."Under these circumstances it's probably not surprising that the film's most irrelevant character, someone who has absolutely nothing to do with anything, is also most endearingthe hospital's dietitian played by Jennifer O'Neill, who is possibly the most beautiful woman in American movies this week. She never does get fully worked into the plot except as the girl with whom Peter sleeps, more or less because when he first meets her she smells so good. ("It's the vanilla," she explains. "I spilled it down the inside of my dress trying to give some taste to the egg pudding.")Under these circumstances, too, it probably makes no difference that Coburn is one of those actors whomnever for a minutedo you mistake as anything but an actor having a rather breezy time of it, even when he gets run down by an automobile in a telephone booth and survives with the loss of only his spleen, an organ that is, according to 'The Carey Treatment," cheerfully expendable.Just about everyone in the film seems to be having a certain amount of fun, including Elizabeth Alien, as the hospital administrator's self-described shanty-Irish wife ("I belong to the club now"): Pat Hingle, as a detective captain; Alex Drier, as a society doctor and leading suspect, and James Hong, the doctor originally charged with the fatal abortion, principally, it seems, because he is Chinese.Mr. Edwards, I understand, was so distressed with the way Metro treated his movie that he once tried to have his name taken off it. Why, I can't imagine, unless it was the producer, or some other Metro flunky who forced him to use a few more Boston locations than were absolutely necessary, and to cast all the men in such a way that leads one to suspect they all have their hair done at the same salon.Otherwise "The Carey Treatment" looks to be exactly what might have been intended by a talented director with reasonably venal ambitions to amuse a great many people.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The primary in Wisconsin, where Mayor Lindsay has been drawing good crowds, is less than a week away. It is not surprising, therefore, that the Mayor has not yet heeded the advice of Meade Esposito, the Brooklyn Demo cratic leader, to drop out of the Presi dential race and straighten out New York City. Hope springs eternal, and Mr. Lindsay knows that a spectacular showing for him next Tuesday would repair his political fortunes and re plenish his campaign bankroll.

title: Mrs. Cook Is a Main Contender For Appeals, Court Nomination
description: Assemblyman Constance E. Cook, a liberal Republican from Ithaca, emerged yesterday as a leading contender for the Re publican and possibly the Lib eral nomination for the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: HARRY CRAMER
description: Harry Cramer, group vice president of Texfi Industries, Inc., died yesterday in his New York apartment. He was 43 years old and lived also in Greensboro, N. C.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Backs Application For TransAtlantic Cable
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Reuters)The Federal Com munications Commission ap proved today the joint applica tion of four companies to lay a new type of transAtlantic cable for operation by 1976.

title: Velasquez Big A Triple Includes Bold and Bright
description: On past performances, Rok eby Stable's Bold and Bright appeared overmatched in the sixfurlong sixth race at Aque duct yesterday.

title: Events Leading to TrainBus Collision Reenacted
description: VALLEY COTTAGE, N. Y., March 29Federal investiga tors restaged today some of the events that led last Fri day to the collision of a Penn Central freight train and a school bus in this Rockland County community near Nyack. Four high school students died and more than 40 were injured as a result of the crash.

title: Pollution Lobby
description: To the accompaniment of more lobbying activity than has been seen on Capitol Hill in a long while, the House of Representatives has turned down key amendments that would have made its water pollution control bill comparable in strength to one passed unanimously last fall by the Senate. The pressure brought to bear against the amendments by industry was heavy but expected; pressure by the Administration to the same end was heavy and indefensible. Not least was the influence of the House's own Public Works Committee, which had brought in the diluted bill.

title: Wood, Field and Stream.
description: Denmark will phase out its highseas fishery for the en dangered Atlantic salmon by 1976, according to Richard A. Buck, chairman of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency, who re ceived word of the Danish United States agreement from the State Department.

title: Trevino Is Now Thinking For Approach to Masters
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., March 29It was a stupid decision, Lee Trevino said to day about his voluntary two year options from the Masters golf tournament, Here to com pete in the $200,000 Greater Greensboro open that starts tomorrow, Trevino is looking ahead to the Masters, which begins in Augusta, Ga., a week from tomorrow.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: March 30, 1972

title: Southern Pacific to Press For Its Rock Island Deal
description: The Southern Pacific Com pany will continue to press for approval from the Inter state Commerce Commission to purchase the Southern lines of the Chicago, Rock Island & Pa cific Railroad Company, Ben jamin F. Biaggini, president of the Southern Pacific, said in an interview here yesterday.

title: PAN AM CONFIRMS ACORD ON CREDIT
description: Pan American World Airways confirmed yesterday that it had reached an agreement for the revolving credit arrangement for. $270million with 38 banks at an interest rate  per cent above the prime lending rate, currently at 45 per cent. The loan which wasp due on Saturday, is therefore extended for one year.

title: Taiwan's Canadian Trade
description: TAIPET, Taiwan, March 29 (Reuters)Taiwan's exports to Canadareached $80.7million in 1971, trade officials reported today. Imports totaled $11mil lion. The officials said Taiwan was now Canada's second larg est supplier in Asia after Japan.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHO ARE THE MAJOR AMERICAN WRIT ERS? A Study of the Changing Literary Canon. By Jay B. Hubbell. 344 pages. Duke University. $11.75.

title: Penguins Best Seals, 54
description: PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP)  The Pittsburgh Penguins, trailing twice by three goals, rallied in the final period to de feat the California Seals, 54, tonight and keep in contention for a berth in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: News of Dogs
description: When Ch. Jenmist Dougal, a Sealyham, was named best of 2,736 dogs at the Harris burg (Pa.) show, it was the 10th time the little white ter rier had taken the honors at an allbreed fixture. But Mrs. Henry Sutliff Jr., his owner, has yet to see Dougal gain the top award. This time I thought she would see us., said Al Ayers, who handles the Sealy. She and her hus band were at the show earlier, when Dougal won the national specialty. They left to attend the club's meeting and dinner and nev er returned.

title: Day in Court Will Cast D. & B. in New Role
description: Several hours after the news yesterday that a Federal grand jury had issued indictments charging housing fraud viola tions against 50 defendants, in cluding Dun & Bradstreet, there were only a few pockets of shock in the headquartersof the 131yearold company at 99 Church Street. A public relations executive referred in quiries on the suit to the com pany's general counsel, who hewed to a brief, official state ment denying all. A vice presi dent, told of the suit, said he was surprised to hear of it, while another said he had heard of it and was also surprised.

title: Boy Dies, Brother Is Hurt, In Blaze in Far Rockaway
description: A 5monthold boy was killed and his 6yearold broth er was seriously injured yester day afternoon in a fire that broke out in their apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, while their mother was at a hospital having two other children treated for lead poisoning.

title: Construction Orders Lag On Decline in Utility Work
description: A decline in electric utility projects in February brought the total value of nationwide construction contracts awarded in that month to their lowest level in three months, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw Hill Information Systems Com pany reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Sues Aircraft Makers, Alleging Curb on Research
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Justice Department today charged every major American manufacturer of aircraft with engaging in an illegal agree ment to suppress competition in the research and develop ment of aircraft and patentable components of aircraft.

title: Nixon's Responsibility
description: Every President has to be mindful of his responsibili ties as leader of his party. Until the financing of national politics is placed on a more rational, disciplined basis, one of those responsibilities inevitably includes the raising of campaign funds.

title: SQUIRES TOP PROS TO CLINCH SECOND
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 29 (AP) The Virginia Squires captured second place in the American Basketball Associa tion's Eastern Division tonight, taking a final regular  season game from the Memphis Pros, 12399.

title: CYE MARTIN, ACTOR AND HABERDASHER
description: Cye Martin, a Broadway haberdasher who doubled as an actor, died Tuesday evening at the age of 56. He lived at 100 West 57th Street and his shop was at 1657 Broadway, at 51st Street.

title: ARGENTINE LEFTISTS SAY ITALIAN IS ALIVE
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 29 (UPI) The kidnappers of a Fiat executive, Oberdan Sallustro, indicated today he was still alive despite expiration of the deadline for payment of ransom for his release.

title: Fulbright Urges Ban on U.S.I.A. Film
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chair man of the Senate Foreign Re lations Committee, asked the Justice Department today to re strain forthwith the use of a United States Information Agency film on Senator James L. Buckley's monthly television program to be shown starting this weekend on 12 stations in New York State.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAlGN.
description: MILWAUKEE, March 29A Midwest storm covered the campaign trail in Wisconsin with up to a foot of snow today, disrupting candidates' schedules and wiping out pre cious hours of stumping in this final week of the Presidential primary competition here.

title: WILKINS'S REMARK IN AFRICA ATTACKED
description: Two organizations have taken sharp issue with a statement made in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Monday by Roy Wil kins, the civil rights spokes man, that the condition of black workers in South Africa could worsen if American business in terests moved out.

title: City Seeks a Way to Save Harlem Enclave
description: A choice, surviving frag ment of the city's diminishing store of architectural treas urethe houses of Striver's Row in Harlem will be given a thorough inspection in the next three months with a view toward historic preservation.

title: MIGNON DUNN SINGS ROLE OF HERODIAS
description: We have it on the word of opera historians that Strauss's Salome once could send shiv ers of horrified delight up an audience's spine with its mix ture of necrophilia, dissonance, sex and ultraviolence, A.D. 30 style. In our franker time, it is difficult to suppress yawns at its supposedly sensational moments, and the current Met ropoilitan Opera production compounds the problem by be ing both terribly explicit and terribly tame, always a poor formula.

title: Chicago Track to Revive Its Arlington Handicap
description: CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)  Arlington Park will renew its Arlington Handicap this year, and make it a $100,000added event.

title: CELTICS RESUME PLAYOFFS HABIT
description: BOSTON, March 29 (AP) The Boston Celtics returned to the National Basketball Assad ation playoffs they once ruled with a 126108 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: The Screen: 'Cool Breeze':Heist Planned to Fund Black People's Bank
description: From M-G-M, the company that gave you "Gone With the Wind," there now comes "Cool Breeze," a mostly black remake of "The Asphalt Jungle"also given you by M-G-M. Actually, the quality of blackness is somewhat strained, embracing as it does much of the cast, and most of the attitudes, and virtually all the ad campaign but none of the major technical credits, including Gene Corman as producer and Barry Pollack, who directed and wrote the screenplay.I assume by now that most moviegoers have seen "The Asphalt Jungle" and remember the story of the brilliantly planned jewel theft that gradually, inexorably comes undone through the character quirks and frailties of the men who execute it. In "Cool Breeze" the story remains roughly the same, set this time in Los Angeles though the motives have been made pseudo-altruistic (to fund a black-people's bank) and the conclusion has been made defiantly inconclusive, leaving the underworld mastermind, Sidney Lord Jones (Thalmus Rasulala), wholly in possession of his icy millions in diamonds and his warm taste for sexy young girls."Cool Breeze" has rather a lot to say about sexy young girls, and about sex generally (much of it fairly brutal), and about whatever matters of practical philosophy happen to pass through the minds of its characters.
