For an action movie it is curiously short on action (the actual heist seems a perfunctory afterthought) and long on characterand it clearly intends more to reflect on a quality of life than to develop the consequences of any specific course of conduct.I don't mean that it's a reflective movie. Rather, it is a movie in which everybody bellyaches or shows off or talks about what it means to be what he is. Everyone plays a role, which is nothing new, but everyone also knows he is playing a role, and so "Cool Breeze" tends to function as a kind of serious genre parodynot unlikely for a black man's movie in a white man's world.But "Cool Breeze" really has nowhere to take its observations, since it is neither militant nor pacifist, but only, sporadically, ironic. And the film seems at each moment to be diminished below its potential even when it attempts strong bravado. Pollack directs some sequences very well, but he seems unsure of what matters dramatically and what doesn't, and he is unevenly served by his cast. The cast is only good in its sadness, and especially with Raymond St Jacques as Mercer, the high-powered fence (the Louis Calhern role in "The Asphalt Jungle") who loses everything except an understanding that the best use of the substance of life is to support a style.

title: Jury to Deliberate Today In Case of 3 U.M.W. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)The trial of W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, went to a Federal District Court jury late today, but deliberation was postponed until tomorrow.

title: U.S. Offers a Grant to Public Library
description: The deficitplagued research libraries of the New York Pub lic Library will receive up to $500,000 in Federal fundsif the same amount can be raised from contributions between now and June 30.

title: Top Players Gain Easily In Easter Bowl Tennis
description: Jack Gorsuch, John Powell and Michael Grant, the top seeded players in the boys' 16 yearold division, advanced easily in, the first round of the Easter Bowl tennis tournament at the Stadium Tennis Center, the Bronx, yesterday.

title: For 20th Precinct, a Break With Past
description: At noon yesterday the si ren at the West 68th Street police station sounded its last mournful blast and minutes later the green wooded doors of the 80year old building with its grimy redbrick fa cade and its black iron car riage lamps  were officially closed.

title: Humanities Goal: Broader Audience
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The National Endowment for the Humanities, which has re ceived scant public attention compared with its sister agency, the National Endow ment for the Arts, which deals with such glamorous matters as theater, opera, film, orches tras and museums, is setting its sights on Middle America.

title: Protecting Diplomats
description: On the morning after a Soviet diplomat was showered with blood by a young Jewish Defense League militant at a Washington reception recently, Ambassador George Bush went before a Congressional committee to plead for legislation making it a Federal crime to harass orattack foreign diplomats in this country. Some such action is imperative.

title: Booby Trap Kills 2 G.I.'s
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March29 (AP)Two Ameri can soldiers were killed and four wounded in a boobytrap explosion today as they pa trolled a Jungle area 31 miles east of Saigon.

title: HERBERT B. KATCHER
description: Herbert B. Katcher, president of UMM Corporation, a finan cial credit subsidiary of United Merchants & Manufacturers, Inc., a diversified textile con glomerate, died apparently of a heart attack yesterday in a Manhattan restaurant. He was 50 years old and lived at 50 Central Park West.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Dismisses Nader Appeal Against I.T.T.Hartford Merger
description: HARTFORD, March 29 An appeal by Ralph Nader to up set the merger of the Interna tional Telephone and Tele graph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Com pany was dismissed in Superior Court here today.

title: Hussein Urges Joint Rule For an Open Jerusalem
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 King Hussein of Jordan pro posed today that, as part of a final peace agreement, his coun try and Israel should share the administration of Jerusalem as a unified, open citya meet ing place for the three great religions of the world.

title: MEAT PRICE DROP IN A FEW WEEKS SEEN BY CONNALLY
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, after meeting with the heads of 12 major super market chains, predicted today that meat prices would decline over the next few weeks.

title: 2 Sites Considered
description: ALBANY, March 29  The state's Commissioner of Cor rectional Services said today that a controversial maximum program, maximum security prison would be created out of an existing prison facility in the state and that the first inmates would be moved into it about May 1.

title: West Berliners Go East as Wall Opens
description: BERLIN, March 29For the first time in six years, the Ber lin wall was opened today to allow West Berliners holiday visits in the East.

title: Senators to Vote Next Week on Ending I.T.T. Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 With Republican Senators com plaining of dilatory tactics and Democrats warning of a white wash, the Senate Judiciary Committee today scheduled a vote for Thursday of next week on Republican demands for an end to the hearings concern ing the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Recapitalization Is Deferred By Great Western United
description: Directors of the Great West ern United Corporation an nounced last night in Denver that they had deferred in definitely a previously an nounced recapitalization plan in which the company's $1.88 cumulative preferred stock would be reclassified as 1.5 shares of common stock each.

title: POSTAL SERVICE TO FREEZE HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Postmaster General E. T. Klas sen outlined today plans to im prove the reputation and per formance of the financially and professionally troubled Postal Service, including a 90day freeze on hiring.

title: Rangers Tie Wings, 22
description: The capacity crowd of 17,250 fans exploded in wild cheers last night when Vic Hadfield scored twice within 49 seconds to give the New York Rangers a 22 tie with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Gar den.

title: KING HUSSEIN AVOIDS COMMENT ON F104'S
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 King Hussein of Jordan avoided direct comment today on a re port in The New York Times that his country and Libya had provided Americanbuilt combat aircraft to Pakistan during her war with India last year.

title: Exchange Extends Holiday
description: The New York Cocoa and Sugar Exchange will extend, its closing in observance of Easter to include next Monday as well as Good Friday. This will Con form with the traditional Easter Monday closing of the London Sugar Exchange.

title: Longshoremen Vote 5 to 1 For New Philadelphia Pact
description: International Longshoremen's Association locals in Philadel phia approved a new labor contract by a vote of better than 5 to 1 yesterday and ended a strike that had kept the port closed since March 14.

title: The Lurking Danger of Naderism
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Over 500 law students gathered recently to hear Ralph Nader (class of 58) on a cold, wet, snowy Saturday night. Nader's message was a political one. He spoke of lawyers throwing out corrupt gov ernments, of individual sacrifice and of commitment to the public interest. But he was not speaking of power to the people. His vision was very different and very disturbing for sev eral reasons.

title: Vaccination Required
description: Travelers to Yugoslavia, Iran and Iraq must have a valid vaccination certificate for smallpox when they return, city health authorities advised yes terday.

title: Vote Recount Asked
description: CONCORD, N. H., March 29 (AP)Two national convention delegate candidates who were pledged to Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, and lost to supporters of Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, in the New Hampshire Democratic primary have re quested recounts. They are J. Joseph Granduaison of Nashua, Senator McGovern's New Eng land campaign coordinator, and Martha Copithorne of Gilford.

title: Ulster: Signs of Spring?
description: It is too early to be optimistic about Northern Ireland but there are encouraging developments in the aftermath of the suspension of the Stormont Government. Even William Craig, leader of the extremist Ulster Vanguard, has implored the Protestant majority to confine its actions to boycotts, strikes and civil disobedience, rather than engage in violence.

title: Police Change Designation
description: The Police Department an nounced yesterday that in the future it would refer to Puerto Ricans and Spanish  speaking peoples as Hispanic. The de partment will no longer use the term Puerto Rican when refer ring to people of Spanish origin.

title: Hawks Tie on Savard's. Goal
description: CHICAGO, March 29 (UPI) Serge Savard lifted a 15foot shot over the Chicago goalie; Gerry Desjardin, for his first goal of the season with only 39 seconds left to play tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 5.5 tie with the Black Hawks;

title: Reserves Decline 2.3% in Crude Oil, Institute Reports
description: Proved recoverable reserves of crude oil fell 2.3 per cent in 1971, the American Petro leum Institute, the oil industry's major trade association, report ed yesterday.

title: Howard Accepts $120,000, Same Salary as Last Year
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 29 (UPI)Frank How ard, who balked at taking a salary cut, has agreed to play for the. Texas Rangers for the same $120,000 salary he re ceived last season.

title: P.S.C. GRANTS CON ED A $42.6MILLION RISE
description: ALBANY, March 29  The Public Service Commission to day granted the Consolidated Edison Company an increase in its electric rates to obtain an estimated total of $42.6million in additional revenues.

title: Campaign Notes
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 John B. Connally, the Secretary of the Treasury, has emphasized to anyone who will listen or cares to ask that he has no plans to switch to the Republican party. But Republican offi cials say that he has alreadyagreed to under take an increas ingly active role in the campaign to reelect the President.

title: SEIZURE OF I. T. T. PROPOSED IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29  The confiscation of the properties in Chile of the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Company was proposed today by one of the minor par ties of the governing Popular Unity coalition.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Sincemore than 70 per cent of last year's 27,000 al coholrelated traffic deaths were caused by problem drinkers, the Government is going after them in a public service ad campaign un veiled yesterday in Wash ington.

title: Credit Markets
description: Short  term interest rates came under renewed upward pressure yesterday, partly re flecting technical factors, while bond prices showed only nar row changes. Among the key money  market rates that climbed were those on com mercial paper, certificates of deposit and the level at whichthe Federal Re serve extends tem porary credit to dealers in Govern ment securities. Another group ofbanks around the country, in cluding Chicago's largest, the Continental Illinois, raised their prime lending rates to 5 per cent from 4 per cent.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Creditors Make Offer
description: PARIS, March 29Sixteen creditor nations in effect re jected today a proposal by the Chilean Government of Dr. Sal vador Allende Gossens for a consolidation of debts. They made a counteroffer, however, that seemed as favorable as that granted the previous Chilean Government.

title: Clark Calls Case Against Berrigan Outrageous
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 29 Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged today that the Government had raised an outrageously false case against the Rev. Philip F. Ber rigan and six other antiwar ac tivists accused of a bombing kidnapping conspiracy.

title: The Talk of Camden, Ala.
description: CAMDEN, Ala., March 24 Every so often, as the morn ing plodded along, the soft voiced black woman would leave the table at tue front of the secondgrade class room and walk over to the line of dusty windows.

title: BOARD APPOINTEE TO QUIT TEACHING
description: James F. Regan, the new Staten Island appointee to the Board of Education, said yes terday that he would resign as a city teacher to avoid any possible conflict of interest.

title: MRS. EMILE DU PONT
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 29 (UPI)Mrs. Margaret Dick du Pont, the wife of Emile du Pont, a director of the dupont Ckrporation, died yesterday while vacationing at Chub Cay in the Bahamas, it was an nounced here today. She was 69 years old.

title: House Approves Water Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  After voting overwhelmingly to restrict the right of citizens to file environmental suits, the House passed its version of a water pollution control bill today 378 to 14.

title: and Jackson's Too
description: The Republicans are not alone in preferring secrecy to disclosure. Some Democrats in Congress are busily rais ing funds for their reelection campaigns before the April 7 deadline. On the national level, the most conspicuous offender is Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington. Unlike Senators Muskie, Humphrey and McGovern and Mayor Lindsay, he has steadfastly refused to reveal the money sources for his wellfinanced Presidential effort.

title: Hoak on Steelers Staff
description: PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) The Pittsburgh Steelers hired their former running back, Dick Hoak, as offensive backfield coach today.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthe counter market took beatings yesterday as both lists dropped sharply in quiet trading.

title: 2 BOMB EXPLOSIONS REPORTED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 29 (AP)A bomb esti mated at up to 150 pounds of gelignite exploded in downtown Belfast tonight, blowing out windows for hundreds of yards and demolishing the truck in which it was placed. There were no reports of injuries.

title: In French Culinary Art: The Beginnings of a Subtle Revolution
description: COLLONGESAUMONTD OR, France, March 29if you read the French restaurant guides for 1972, haute cuisine is in trouble. The venerable Guide Michelin, out earlier this month, gave stars to eight fewer restaurants than it did last year and Maxim's dropped one rooster in the ratings of the less renowned Guide Kleber.

title: ALTIMETER PRICE CALLED TOO HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Altimeters for about 300 Navy planes, bought last fall from a single manufacturer without competitive bidding, cost $1,700 apiece. Almost identical instru ments, bought recently for about the same number of Air Force planes after competitive bidding by six manufacturers, cost $565 apiece.

title: BOLIVIA IS OUSTING 119 SOVIET AIDES
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 29 The Bolivian Government has ordered 119 members of the Soviet Embassy staff to leave the country within seven days, Foreign Minister Mario Gutir rez said tonight.

title: BRANCH TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF GOODRICH
description: Branch Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday an agree ment in principle with B. F. Goodrich Company for the pur chase of all the outstanding stock of Motor Freight Corpo ration, a subsidiary of the rub ber company, for an undis closed amount of cash.

title: Bridge: Same Contract Plays 2 Ways, Depending on Who Is Declarer
description: Playing a game contract from opposite sides of the table made a difference of two tricks on the diagramed deal from the Vanderbilt, semifinal last Saturday be tween the defending Aces and the Precision team that won the title.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN.
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 29 (UPI)Norman F. Jones, a black political col umnist for several Florida newspapers, was named to day chairman of a national black citizens committee for Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Reynolds Metal Proposes Uranium Mill Consortium
description: The Reynolds Metal Company said at Richmond, Va., yesterday that it had filed a proposal with the Atomic Energy Commission to organize a consortium of companies that would build, own and operate a gaseous diffusion plant to enrich uranium fuel for nuclearpower generating plants.

title: Joseph PaulBoncour Is Dead; ExPremier of France Was 98
description: PARIS, March 29 Joseph PaulBoncour, a former French Premier and longtime Foreign Minister, died here last night at the age of 98.

title: Suit Contends Sex Was a Condition For Keeping Job
description: A suit, believed to be the first of its kind, was filed yes terday in Federal Court in Newark by a young woman charging that a corporation ex ecutive attempted to make having sexual relations with him a condition of her con tinued employment and thus discriminated against her on the basis of her sex.

title: Boston Marathon Adds A Division for Women
description: BOSTON, March 29 (AP) Women will be allowed to compete officially in the Bos ton Marathon for the first time this year but in a special division of their own, the Boston Athletic Association announced today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Frank Shakespeare, the director of the United States Information Agency, is at odds with William Shakespeare, the playwright, and the issuemarvelous to sayis the value of a name.

title: U.S. Announces It Will Sell 36 Phantom Jets to Greece
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 Charles W. Bray 3d, State De partment spokesman, said to day that the United States had signed an agreement with Greece providing for the sale of two squadrons of F4 Phan tom jets. A Phantom squadron normally comprises 18 aircraft.

title: West Bank Elects Five Leaders Who Favor an Independent State
description: NABLUS, Israeli  Occupied Jordan, March 29 (AP)Arab voters in the first elections held in Israelioccupied terri tory have chosen five new lead ers more or less opposed to King Hussein of Jordan and committed to an independent Palestine state, election results showed today.

title: Police Start Vertical Patrols to Combat Indoor Crime
description: Concerned that intensified pa trols have driven muggers off the streets and into apartment, buildings, the police of several Manhattan precincts have be gun conducting vertical pa trols inside the buildings.

title: STOCKS DECLINE 4TH DAY IN A ROW
description: The stock market, buffeted by adverse reports from Wash ington and by the pressures of mutual  fund portfolio dress ing, suffered yesterday its fourth decline in a row.

title: Chess: Olafsson Finishes Strong To Take Reykjavik Tourney
description: The fifth international Reykjavik tourament, a 16 man round robin, ended in a victory for Fridrick Olafsson of Iceland with 11 points, with the scoring on the Sonneborn Berger system.

title: GROUP DISCOUNTS U.S. TRADE DEFICIT
description: PARIS, March 29Monetary authorities from 10 industrial western nations, reaffirming their determination to defend the Dec. 18 currency realign ment, established today that only four countries have had to absorb unwanted dollars since the December accord and that dollars had begun flowing back to the United States.

title: Mets Send Williams, Foli and Hahn to Tidewater Farm
Topco Loses Decision
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)  The Supreme Court today held, in a 6to1 de cision, that the Topco cooperative associa tion of about 25 small supermarket chains operating in 33 states violates Federal anti trust law.

title: Earthquake Hits Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, March 29 (UPI)  An earthquake strong enough to knock dishes from shelves and crack chimneys shook southeastern Missouri and sections of surrounding states today.

title: WARPOWER CURBS DEBATED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Marcia 29 The Senate began debate to day on a bill that its sponsors contend is necessary to check the warmaking powers of the presidency. The Administration has protested that the measure is unconstitutional and unwise.

title: Of Politics and Primaries
description: To the Editor:

title: CenturyOld Firehouse Shut in Midtown Amid Charges That Area Will Suffer
description: The old red firehouse at 48th Street and Eighth Ave nue closed its doors for good yesterday as disgruntled fire men in Ladder Company 4 grumbled over their reloca tion to Engine Company 23.

title: Injunction Blocks Albatross Removal From Dancer Rein
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP)  Two minority stock holders in the syndicate that owns the pacer Albatross have obtained an injunction pre venting removal of the horse from the stable of Stanley Dancer at Liberty Bell Park.

title: S.E.C. Announces the Members Of 3 Industry Advisory Panels
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today ?? names of members of three industry advisory committees that will help the commission develop the rules for imple Mentation of its proposed Changes in the structure of the securities markets.

title: Mattel Reports Operating Loss; Other Earnings Figures Issued
TESTIMONY BEGINS IN THE DAVIS CASE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 30 The state's first witness in the murder trial of Angela Davis said today that her testimony may have been influenced by the prosecutor.

title: Bountiful Portions At East Side Deli
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and ddbor (four triangles to none).

title: MRS. RUTH Z. KAUTH, LED VACATION FUND
description: TUCKAHOE, N.Y., March 30 Mrs. Ruth Zirkle Kauth, founder of the Girls Vacation Fund, died Monday of muscular dys trophy at her home here. She was 73 years old.

title: State Agrees to a 4% Raise In 1 Year Pact With Union
description: ALBANY, March 30The state and the Civil Service Employes Association reached a tentative agreement today that would give most state workers a 4 per cent increase in their salary rate, but no ac tual cash raises for the next 12 months.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Fell to 114.9 During Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 114.9 from 115.0 last week.

title: The Screen: Two Rare Gestures of Showmanship
description: It would be pleasant to praise the films of Robert Nelson, if only because they openly invite praise and ag gressively associate them selves with the most obvious signs and symbols of enter tainment. Of course, they aren't entertainment; they are altogether more serious and they mean to be some thing much deeper.

title: CUSTOMS INSPECTOR AT KENNEDY SEIZED
description: A customs inspector assigned to Kennedy International Air port for the last six years was arrested yesterday in a continu ing investigation of an alleged $20million marijuana smug gling ring at the airport.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHUB CAY, the Bahamas On the final day of the Crown Colony Club's recent hisandhers billfish tourna ment, Edwin J. Gould of New York City boated a 549pound Atlantic blue marlin on 30 pound test line. If certified by the International Game Fish Association, his fish will supplant the existing record in that line classification.

title: HENRY SWEET JONES
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31 (AP)Henry Sweet Jones, one of two remaining members of the French Army's Olite Lafayette Escadrille flying squadron in World War I, died today. He was 79 years old.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partmentstore sales at $784 million, up 15 per cent from the yearearlier $684million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $8,107,000,000, up 8 per cent from $7,506,000,000.

title: For Handful of Americans, Vietnam Is Almost Home
description: SAIGON,South Vietnam, March 30 They sell cars to G.I.'s in the PX and hunt for Vietcong in the jungle. They live in airconditioned bungalows called Palm Springs and marry willowy Viet namese. They are the handful of Ameri cans, out of two million soldiers and 50,000 civilians, who have stayed on, year after year, as people back home have become discouraged and disillu sioned with the war in Vietnam.

title: Fund Rule Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission published today a proposed rule that would pre vent the adjournment of meet ings of mutual fund sharehold ers, when a legal quorum was present, without votes on pend ing issues.

title: Segment of Oil Pipeline Into Siberia Is Finished
description: MOSCOW, March 30  The Soviet Union announced today the completion of a strategic 500mile oil pipeline that will ultimately extend from the west Siberian fields across Si beria to the Pacific.

title: Soviet Arms Aid $5Billion, Cairo Says
description: CAIRO,March 30A con ference held in Cairo recently by Russians and Arabs to dis cuss their differences, griev ances and points of agreement led to a disclosure that Soviet military assistance to Egypt had reached a total of about $5billion, with a current rate of $5million a day.

title: PRESIDENT TO BAR TWO RAIL STRIKES
description: The White House announced yesterday that President Nixon would sign an Executive order blocking for at least 60 days two strikes threatened tonight against the nation's railroads.

title: A $ Gap Divides Sexes in Golf
description: Lee Trevino is one of the male golfers that Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge has not seen play, but she has heard enough about the popular, peppery Chicano to recite some of his quotes.

title: Catholic Priest's Ad in Playboy: Gets 600 Inquiries on Seminary
description: The Roman Catholic priest who bought a fullpage adver tisement in Playboy magazine last January to stimulate re cruitment for the Order of the Most Holy Trinity (Trinitarians) has come up with an ecclesiast ical bonanza.

title: Market Place
description: You remember National Student Marketing, that youthcult company that was going to set the world on fire by selling the college student everything from fraternity pins to foosballa table soo cer game popular in Europe.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 30 (AP)Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., gained the quarterfinals of the Caribe Hilton tournament today by defeating Wendy Gilchrist of Sydney, Australia, 62, 60.

title: I.T.T. Favors for Congressmen Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Mrs. Susan Lichtman, Mrs. Dita D. Beard's former secretary, said in an interview here to day that the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion regularly did favors for members of Congress and that she herself handled a request from Senator Vance Hartke last summer for use of one of the company's jet planes.

title: Polish Cardinal Complains Over Police Raid on a Chapel
description: WARSAW, March 30 The Roman Catholic Church in Po land accused the police today of raiding a chapel in a village on the outskirts of Warsaw and forcibly removing its taber nacle.

title: Nader Says He'll Appeal Suit Against I.T.T. Merger
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., March 30 (AP)Ralph Nader says he will carry to the Connecticut Su preme Court his suit against the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: Clifton P. Walker, Chief Officer Of Hornblower & Weeks, Dead
description: Clifton P. Walker, managing partner and chief executive of ficer of Hornblower & Weeks Hemphill  Noyes, investment bankers, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

title: FARM PRICES OFF AFTERS 5 MONTHS OF STEADY RISES
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Agriculture Department announced today a decline in its index of farm prices after five consecutive months of in creases.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The merger of the 85,000member United Teachers of New York State and the 105,000mentber New York State Teachers Association is expected to be announced at a news conference at 2 P.M. tomorrow in the Ameridana.

title: Nonwhite Wins in S. Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, March 30. (UPI)France's unseeded nonwhite tennis star, Wanero N'Godrella, provided the first upset in the men's singles today when he elimi nated 15thseeded Dick Crealy of Australia in straight sets in the second round of the South African open championships, the first multiracial tennis tournament in this country.

title: U.N. and U.S. Deny Aid to Bangladesh Is Being Impeded
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30United States and United Nations sources today announced their satisfaction with the efforts being made to relieve war and faminen in Ban gladesh although the progress seems slow.

title: The Poodles Try to Show Some Class
description: PALM BEACH, Fla."Palm Beach is not particularly a rhinestone town, Ceil Day said. She was explaining why there are so few rhinestone collars in her Poodle Paradise, a shop dedicated to keeping rich people's pets looking like rich people's pets.

title: Baseball on the Brink of Player Strike
description: TEMPE, Ariz., March 30 (UPI) Marvin Miller, executive direc tor of the Major League Base ball Players Association, said today on the eve of a critical Note on whether to call a strike against the game, it's all up to the players now.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A syndicate of underwriters headed by Birr, Wilson & Co. yesterday announced the initial public offering of 214,130 com mon shares of the Sigmaform Corporation of Menlo Park, Calif., at $9 a share. Part of the offering's proceeds will be used to establish a plant for Sigmaform in Germany. The company manufactures plastic tubing and molded shapes for use in electrical cables.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A grand jury has refused to indict Bayard Rustin, a longtime civil rights activist; for carrying an illegal sword cane.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RISE IN CORN LEVY CRITICIZED BY BUTZ
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Secretary of Agricul ture Earl L. Butz today criticiz ed the European Common Mar ket for having raised import levies on United States corn by 11 per cent last week.

title: Lindsay Vetoes a Curb On His Capital Spending
description: Mayor Lindsay has vetoed as unwire and unworkable a restriction on his spending of $200million in lumpsum ac counts in the capital budget.

title: JOB UNIT WIDENS WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Equal Employment Oppor tunity Commission has strength ened its regulations on job dis crimination against women and has broadened the rules to in clude for the first time em ployer policies on pregnancy and childbirth.

title: Help for the Library
description: The thousands of readers and researchersNew York ers and nonNew Yorkers alikewho use the New York Public Library daily are well aware of the damaging impact the Library's financial difficulties are having on its operation, and on the availability of its rich resources to the public. Now a gleam of hope has appeared in the announcement by the National Endowment for the Hu manities, acting with President Nixon's approval, that it plans to provide $500,000 in Federal funds by June 30 to help meet operating costs of the great research divisions of the Library.

title: $40,000 Stolen in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, March 30 (AP) Three armed men escaped with about $40,000 in cash today after the robbery of an armored car crew member inside Lu theran Hospital, the police said. The hospital said the money was to be used by the St. Louis Pay Truck Company, which operates a check cashing booth there to cash the pay checks of hospital employes.

title: TURKISH LEFTISTS SLAY 3 HOSTAGES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, March 30 The police stormed a house in a mountain village today and killed 10 leftist terrorists af ter the terrorists had murdered three foreign hostages, the Gov ernment reported.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30  Alabama's state highway director has abruptly resigned amid reports that top state of ficeholders have been under pressure to make personal con tributions to the Presidential campaign of Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Soviet Threatens Boycott of Environmental Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30  The Soviet Union closed the door today on its participation in the planned Stockholm conference on glob al environmental problems arid then cautiously reopened the door a crack.

title: Pear Fritters Suggested for Dessert
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe. Stuffed flank steak Broccoli Hash brown potatoes Tossed green salad Fresh pear fritters

title: White House Aide Quits
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The White House an nounced today the resignation of Carol Harford as assistant for cultural affairs, She will become deputy director of the Wolf Trap Foundation for the Performing Arts in Virginia.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 30 (AP)Disorderly conduct con victions of 13 persons, includ ing Murray Kempton, the poli tical commentator, arising from demonstrations in Chi cago at the 1968 Democratic National Convention, were up held today by the Illinois Su preme Court.

title: Romney Opens LastDitch Drive To Obtain Aid for Central Cities
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 30After three years of mostly unsuccessful attempts to per suade the White House to do more for the troubled central cities, George Romney began a lastditch effort today to get some action.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Common Cause announced to day details of its plans for a national program to monitor political campaign contribu tions.

title: Faulkner's Parting Call: Integration With Britain
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 30  On his last day as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Brian Faulkner made an unexpected plea today for complete integration of Northern Ireland into the Unit ed Kingdom.

title: Morton Cautions Nation as Use of Energy Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, said today that the United States con sumed 69,010trillion British thermal units of energy last year, 2.3 per cent more than in the previous year and more than ever before in history.

title: J.C. Snead, faros, Barber Pace Golf
Shift of MIG's to India in War Reported
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Western diplomatic sources reported today that the Soviet Union transferred some, of its jet warplanes from Egypt to India last December to replace Indian Air Force losses during the IndianPakistani war.

title: Students Testify About Collision With Train That Killed 4 on Bus
description: POMONA, N. Y., March 30 Survivors of the trainschool bus collision in nearby Valley Cottage a week ago, along with members of the train crew and a 10yearold boy who saw the crash from his bedroom window, recalled the accident in vivid detail here today at a Medical Examiner's inquest.

title: Optimism of Consumers on Business Outlook Is a Bit Brighter
description: Consumers throughout the country are more optimistic about business conditions now but they are not showing any increased willingness to buy, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Lima Court Rejects Appeal By Publisher Told to Resign
description: LIMA, Peru, March 30 (AP) A Peruvian appeals court has turned down an appeal against an order forcing the publisher Pedro G. Beltran to resign as director and sell his stock in the Lima newspaper La Prensa.

title: Where Do Bunnies Come From?
description: YAPHANK, L. I., March 30 Ages and ages ago, some believe, the dawn goddess Eostre changed a bird into a rabbit in AngloSaxon Eng land and gave life to the Easter Bunny.

title: G & S Grand Duke Proves Full of Entrancing Songs
description: If Mozart lovers are curious about Ludo Silla and Ver dians about Oberto, those who like Gilbert and Sullivan are just as fascinated by the rarely performed works of that great Victorian duo. Wednesday night there was a chance to see The Grand Duke at the Hunter. College Playhouse. This last of the G & S collaborations was pre sented by the Blue Hill Troupe, which had given the work its New York premiere 35 years ago. It had had only one local production since then, by the American Savoy ards in 1961.

title: Brewery Expansion Voted
description: The AnheuserBusch, Inc., di rectors have approved the expansion of the company's Jacksonville, Fla., brewery. This will double the annual shipping capacity of this plant to more than 4 million barrels annually.

title: Bucks Triumph, Even Series, 11
description: MILWAUKEE, March 30 (AP)Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 25 points tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 11893 victory over the Golden State Warriors. The triumph squared their National Bas ketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoff series at 11.

title: BIG BOARD LOWERING VARIABLEFEE BASIS
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that its governing board had approved amendments authorizing mem bers and member firms to un fix the sales charges on the por tion of all transactions above $300,000 in value.

title: Sydenham Hospital Gets First Community Board
description: A community board was for mally installed yesterday at Sydenham Hospital by Dr. Jo seph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. It is the first such board at a general municipal hospital here.

title: SERIOUS U.S. CRIME INCREASED 6% IN '71
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Serious crime in the United States rose by 6, per cent in 1971, the smallest increase in six years, the Justice Depart ment announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBERT J. BONNIE SR.
description: Albert J. Bonnie Sr., retired president of the moving and storage concern of his name at 3213 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, died Monday in Fort Lauder dale, Fla., where he lived. His age was 70. He founded the Bonnie Boys Club in Brooklyn, which promotes sandlot and Little League baseball games.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: March 30, 1972 THE PRESIDENT

title: Ali and Foster in Tokyo Bout to Be Shown re Tonight
description: TOKYO, March 30 (AP) Muhammad Ali and Mac Fos ter will meet in Japan's first heavyweight fight on Saturday.

title: RALLY BY FLYERS DOWNS SABRES, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP)The philadelphia Flyers rallied for three goals in the third period tonight to defeat the Buffalo Sabres, 31, and gain sole possession of fourth place in the West Division of the national Hockey League.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Following are the delegate vote totals of the Democratic Presidential candidates as compiled by The New York Times:

title: Soviet, Told to Oust 119, Puts Bolivia Staff at 40
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 30 (UPI)The Soviet Ambassador in La Paz today denied any wrongdoing on the part of his embassy and said it had only 40 attaches in Bolivia and not the 119 the Government had asked be withdrawn.

title: FIVE INDICTED HERE IN STOCKSALE CASE
description: A Federal grand jury yester day indicted five individuals and a brokerage cooncern for allegedly defrauding stock pur chasers by using a false and misleading offering circular in the sale of stock.

title: New Jerusalem Digs Yield Dramatic Finds
description: JERUSALEM, March 30 A desolate courtyard where Israeli and Arab soldiers faced each other for 19 tense years is yielding dramatic archeo logical evidence of the Jeru salem of the time of Jesus.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Knicks, Bullets to Begin Familiar ScenePlayoffs
description: BALTIMORE, March 30  For the New York Knicks, the National Basketball Association playoffs would not be authen tic without a rugged series against the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Williams Looking To Play's Opening
description: Tennessee Williams's new play Small Craft Warnings opens Easter Sunday at the Off Broadway Truck and and Warehouse Theater. The date is an accident of sched uling. It's in embarrassing taste to open then, Mr. Wil liams said this week, sitting in his hotel suite.. To attract critics to the Bowery on East er Sunday evening  some body is bound to make a crack about the Resurrec tion. They'll say the Resurrec tion didn't come off. He laughed heartily.

title: Greek Official Warns Makarios to Yield
description: ATHENS, March 30An au thoritative Government source said today that unless President Makarios bowed to Greek de mands, Greece would proceed toward a solution of the Cyprus problem without consulting the Cypriote Government.

title: EXCON EDISON AIDE WINS PENSION SUIT
description: Gerald R. Hadden, a retired Consolidated Edison Company vice president who was linked to the scandal involving James L. Marcus, former city water commissioner, and Carmine G. De Sapio, won a State Supreme Court suit here yesterday grant ing him a life pension from the utility of $743.71 a month.

title: Mayor Tells Murphy to Report On Change in Police Schedules
description: Mayor Lindsay directed Po lice Commission Patrick V. Murphy yesterday to report to him promptly on workschedule changes that must be made even in the absence of a new contract with the Patrolmon's Benevolent Association.

title: JACQUES CHORON, A PHILOSOPHER, 68
description: Dr. Jacques Choron, a phi losopher and an author who studied death and selfdestruc tive phenomena, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 21 West 86th Street.

title: Ottawa Greets Chinese Team Warmly
description: OTTAWA, March 30 Canada's capital extended a warm official welcome this afternoon to a party of 28 Chinese, including 13 of the country's tabletennis cham pions.

title: RUSSIAN EXPLAINS VENUS 8 MISSION
description: MOSCOW, March 30A So viet space official disclosed to day that the primary mission of Venus 8, an unmanned space craft launched earlier this week, was to determine the chemistry of the surface of Venus.

title: RONAN WON'T SEEK TO HEAD PORT UNIT
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, yes terday withdrew his name from consideration for the post of executive director of the Port of New York Authority.

title: TRADING LIVELIER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market yesterday ended the week on an upbeat as both lists advanced in steppedup trading.

title: Credit Markets
description: Most interest rates continued to creep higher yesterday in a quiet session dominated by hol iday and endofquarter influ ences. A scattering of money rate increases was recorded in bankers acceptances, commer cial paper and certificates of deposit, but some of these rep resented catchup moves of in stitutions that did not raise rates earlier. The Irving Trust Company, which was the first bank to raise its prime lending rate to 5 per cent in the current upward trendit moved last Friday said yesterday that it would retain that level for the week beginning Monday. Some other banks, including the Philadel phia National, went to 5 per cent yesterday.

title: JOSEPHINE U. HERRICK
description: Josephine Ursula Herrick, a professional photographer who in 1941 began a program of rehabilitation through photog raphy for wounded veterans, died at Roosevelt Hospital on Monday after a long illness. She was in her sixties and lived at 28 East 73d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Both sides in the fiveweekold Transport of New Jersey bus strike agreed to resume negotiations at 10 A.M. today after Gov. William T. Cahill called company officials and union representatives to his office In Trenton yesterday.

title: 9 BASES NEAR DMZ HEAVILY ATTACKED BY NORTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 31North Viet namese gunners poured up to 4,000 rounds of their heaviest artillery, rockets and mortars into South Vietnamese bases and towns along the demilitar ized zone yesterday in the big gest attack since the sieges of Conthien and Khesanh more than four years ago.

title: Feb. 3 Increases In Telephone Rates Win U.S. Approval
description: A $160million increase in New York Telephone Company rates that has been in effect since Feb. 3 was approved by the Price Commission yester day.

title: Bankers Quietly Experimenting With Loans for Poor
description: Bankers in 24 states have been quietly experimenting with highrisk loans to the poor, a leading American banker dis closed here yesterday.

title: STILWELL OUSTS OKKER BY 63, 76
description: MACON, Ga., March 30 (AP) Graham Stilwell of England defeated No. 1seeded Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 63, 7.6, today to gain a semifinal spot in the $25,000 Macon ten nis tournament.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANTHONY TROLLOPE. By James PopeHen nessy. Illustrated. 400 pages. Little, Brown. $10.

title: DUNFIELD TAKES A.A.U. DIVE FINAL
description: DALLAS, March 30 (AP)  Don Dunfield, who was runner up seven times previously, cap tured the men's onemeter title for the first time today in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving champion ships.

title: BusTrain Crash Kills 10
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 30 (Reuters)Ten people were killed and 27 seriously injured today when a freight train smashed into a school bus and dragged it 150 feet. Seven of the dead were children.

title: Jazz Improvisation By Stevie Wonder Delights Bitter End
description: You say you've been wonder ing whatever happened to the excitement and the vitality of jaia improvisation? You say you'd like to hear some inventive musicians playing with raw enthusiasm? Okay. Go to the Bitter End some night before Tuesday and listen to Stevie Wonder and his superb band.

title: VACCINE REGULATION IS ASSAILED AS LAX
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)  Congressional investi gators say 32 ineffective vac cines were allowed to remain on the market for at least 10 years while drug regulators ex changed memorandums about the problem.

title: PORTER LEAVES PARIS TO CONSULT IN U.S.
description: PARIS, March 30 (AP)Wil liam J. Porter, head of the United States delegation to the Vietnam peace talks here, left for Washington today for con sultations.

title: Black Visions Delayed
description: Black Visions, the program of four oneacters that was to have opened last night at the Public Theater Annex, will have its premiere on Tuesday. Gloria Foster and Beverly Todd play the leading roles.

title: Campanellain Hospital; Condition Held Serious
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., March 30 (UPI)Roy Campanella, the former Brooklyn Dodger catcher whose career was cut short by an automobile acci dent in 1958, was listed in serious condition late tonight at Grasslands Hospital here. The nature of his ailment was not disclosed.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIZARD IN THE CUP. By Peter Dickinson. 196 pages. Harper & Row. $5.95.

title: Education's Own Voice
description: When the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare was created in 1953, its opponents questioned the need of a cabinet position for areas which they basically considered none of the Federal Government's business. Today, there is no longer any doubt that Washington is, and ought to be, deeply concerned with the nation's health, education and welfare. The question is rather how to make the Federal Government's involvement more effective.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS LEAD A REBOUND
description: A technical rally led by glamour issues and some sooth ing monetary comments from Europe combined to send stock prices briskly higher yesterday.

title: U.S. Preparing to Topple Roadside Billboards
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 30After a seven year struggle with the net tion's billboard industry, the Federal Government says that it is ready to begin an all out assault on sign pollu tion along America's main highways.

title: COSMOS SIGN TWO, ADD ETHNIC FLAVOR
description: In an effort to attract ethnic group fans, the New York Cos mos of the North American Soccer League announced yes terday the signing of two star players on the international sceneCinesinho of Lanerossi Vicenza of Italy and Helenio Herrera Jr. of Real Madrid of Spain.

title: CITY BAR WEIGHING AN INQUIRY INTO WAR
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is considering the feasibility of conductinz an inquiry into what it has described as com pelling evidence that serious breaches of the law of war have been committed by all parties in the Indochina war.

title: Miss Margaret ScottDuff Is Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Mar garet Abercromby ScottDuff of New York to Hans William Kertess, a general partner in Salomon Brothers, invest ment bankers, took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Walter McNeely, an Episco palian, perfomed the cere mony at the home of Thomas Schippers, the conductor, and Mrs. Schippers.

title: News of Skiing
description: Dozens of ski areas will be open this weekend as many devotees of the snow running sport take their last big fling at winter. And though bases probably will be substantial at many upper New England resorts in the weekends that follow, lift ticket business will plummet.

title: John Graham Adds Variety to the Viola In Tully Hall Recital
description: If John Graham's recital a Tully Hall on Wednesday night had done nothing else it would have shown what a tough time a violist has in try ing to devise a program featur ing his instrument in works composed for it. The viola is still in search of a literature of its own.

title: CHILE'S CONGRESS SETS C.I.A. INQUIRY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 30 The Chilean Congress has de cided to investigate past activi ties of the United States Cen tral Intelligence Agency and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation report edly aimed at keeping President Salvador Allende Gossens from taking office in 1970.

title: MUSEUM CANCELS CUBAN FILM SHOW
description: The Museum of Modern Art called off yesterday its sched uled showing of six Cuban films that are among 23 the Treasury Department has been trying to seize since last week as alleged smuggled contraband.

title: Studies Discount Cancer Link To Presence of Diseased Cats
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., March 30 A series of studies, including an investigation of 32,000 families with pet cats, has turned up absolutely no evidence of a link between can cer in the animals and leuke mia in man.

title: Merger News
description: Directors of the Clorox Com pany and MartinBrower Cor poration yesterday approved the terms under which Clorox will acquire MartinBrower. An agreement in principle was an nounced by the two concerns on March 6.

title: New Curbs on Housing Fraud Cited
description: An official of the Federal Housing and Urban Develop ment Department said yester day that new procedures adopt ed during the last year would prevent recurrence of the kind of graft and illegal practices alleged in indictments an nounced Wednesday against 10 companies and 40 persons.

title: Assembly Redistrict Plan In Connecticut Invalidated
description: HARTFORD, March 30A Federal Court here today de clared unconstitutional Connecticut's controversial plan for reapportioning the General Assembly. The ruling stunned the state's legislative and po litical leaders.

title: Suburban Housewives Striving to Become the New Woman
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  I don't know if it's really possible to be free and married, says a Fairfield County house wife. I think of marriage as an op pressive institution.

title: Bacallao Duo Wins Final
description: Dr. Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club and Bailey Brown of the Bronxville Field Club won the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's limited Class A doubles final yesterday at the City Athletic Club, defeating Stan Nelson and James Prigoff of the host club, 1511, 158, 1815.

title: MONETARY BASE GAINS SHARPLY
description: The Federal Reserve System pumped $1.3billion into the money market this week in an apparent attempt to slow the recent sharp rise in shortterm money rates, the central bank's weekly statement showed yes terday.

title: Three Met Pitchers Set Back Reds 41
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30The Mets concluded six weeks of spring training tonight by downing the Cincin nati Reds, 41, behind the pitch ing of Buzz Capra, Jon Matlack and Tug McGraw.

title: Stage: Funny Thing Happens Again
description: Everyone ought to have a favorite Broadway musical. Personally my favorite for 10 years has been A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum. Last night at the LuntFontanne Theater A Funny Thing happened once again, and I fell in love with it as desperately as ever. This is the funniest, bawdiest and most enchanting Broad way musical that Plautus, with a little help from Stephen Sondheim, Burt Shovelove and Larry Gelbert, ever wrote. Pseudolus rides again.

title: The Price of Irish Unity
description: Not for the first time in the Ulster agony the Catholic Primate of all Ireland has made a timely contribution to sanity and peaceful advance. Cardinal Conway says he would not shed a single tear if the Irish Republic's Constitution were amended to eliminate the special status of the Catholic Church and to provide for legal divorce as it now obtains in Northern Ireland.

title: Sales of Retail Chains Up 11% Last Month Easter Buying Helped
AIR WAR CASUALTIES SAID TO STIR WORRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The Nixon Administration is re ported to be seriously concerned over the increased casualty rate in the air war in Indochina.

title: Berrigan Plot Case Is Sent to the Jury
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 30 The conspiracy case of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six other antiwar activists went to the jury this afternoon after a charge by Federal District Judge R. Dixon Herman that was denounced by defense at torneys as a summation for conviction.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., March 30 (UPI)The body of Walter Starr Jr., a 7yearold boy whose disappear ance March 4 triggered a search in dense woodlands, has been found in Greenwood Lake.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OnceBlighted Area Is Thriving
description: DETROIT, March 30 You see these plans, the sketchesit's a fever, was the way Sal Ciaramitaro, a fruit and vegetable man, ex plained what has happened.

title: FORD BUYS SHARES FROM FOUNDATION
description: DETROIT, March 30 (AP) Ford Motor Company announced today it had completed the pur chase of 483,750 shares of its own Class A stock from the Ford Foundation for approxi mately $35.5million.

title: Red Cross Volunteer Drivers Make Life Simpler for Handicapped
description: Rudolph Bauer's most mem orable day since he retired as a television technical di rector was given him by a 13yearold girl so badly crippled with cerebral palsy that she had to receive school instruction at.home in her wheel chair.

title: P. J. PICCIRILLI, 80, EXPERSONNEL AIDE
description: P. J. Piccirilli, a Navy aviator in World War I and a former personnel director of the Unit ed States Industrial Chemical Company, now a division of National Distillers and Chem ical Corporation, died Saturday in a nursing home in Green wich, Conn. He was 80 years old and a former resident of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: TRAVELERS TO FILE REPORTS ON FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Treasury announced today its final regulations under the 1970 law aimed at curbing the abuse of secret foreign bank accounts by organized and white collar criminals.

title: Reutemann Wins Grand Prix
description: SAO PAULO, March 30 (UPI) Carlos Reutemann of Argen tina won the Brazilian Grand Prix Formula I auto race at the Inter Lagos race, tack today by upsetting Brazil's Emerson Fit tipaldi. Reutemann overtook Fittipaldi in the 32d lap when the Brazilian favorite was forced to drop out of the race when his Lotus 72D developed trouble in its rear suspension system. Sweden's Ronnie Peter son finished second.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice upheld the sanctity of a burial ground and barred a 71yearold man from selling a part of a cemetery plot that has been in his family for more than 100 years.

title: Two Robbers Kill Man Trying to Help Mother
description: A 29yearold Harlem man was shot and killed last night in the hallway of the apartment building where he lived when he tried to stop two men from robbing his mother, the police reported.

title: Selective Strike Planned
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The chief negotiator for the Sheet Metal Workers Union, J. W. O'Brien, said today that he did not plan to call a walk out by any of his members until after the Easter holiday, and even then would strike only one selected railroad.

title: LONDON
description: LONDONBritish officials have a way of questioning whatever world political trends happen to be fashion able at the moment, so they are watching the Soviet Union's new reasonable diplomacy with detached skepticism.

title: Johnson of Republic National To Be Security National Chief
description: Rex D. Johnson has been named president, director and chief administrative officer of the Security National Bank, Patrick J. Clifford, chairman and chief executive, announced following yesterday's board meeting.

title: Fireworks Plant Blast Kills 3 in Massachusetts
description: BRIDGEWATER, Mass., March 30 (AP)A fireworks factory exploded today kill ing et least three persons and injuring 11.

title: WinnDixie Freezes Prices
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 30 (UPI)WinnDixie Stores announced today that there would be no increase in reg ular shelf prices on all meat and grocery items in April in its 871 stores throughout the Southeast.

title: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCU, DRINK DEWAWS. William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies. Imported by Palmer & Lord Ltd., Syosset. N. Y.Advt.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.American uni versity students seem more relaxed and tolerant today than two or three years ago, less tense, less hysterical and less given to violent protest against governmental policies with which they disagree or against intel lectuals associated with such policies. Both the amount of protestation and the novelty of its expression on cam puses have lessened and this produces an atmosphere of relative detente.

title: NASSAU POLICE AIDE IS RELIEVED OF DUTY
description: MINEOLA, March 30The commanding officer of the Nas sau County Police Depart ment's homicide squad was replaced today, a day after ho accused District Attorney Wilt Ham Cahn of pressuring police men and called for his resig nation.

title: The Release of Vietnam
description: WORCESTER, Mass.Almost a cen tury ago, Frederick Jackson Turner wrote that the westward expansion of America was destined to go on until a physical barrier must finally obstruct its progress. Only now, when our young brothers and sons return from Asia without their limbs, with their spines twisted and broken, do we feel the full weight of the closing of the frontier.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Senators Everett B. Jor dan, Democrat of North Caro lina; Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, and Marlow W. Cook, Republican of Kentucky, were appointed today as the Senate members of a joint Congressional committee that will make plans for the 1973 Presidential inauguration.

title: Yanks Defeat Expos, 40, On Peterson's TwoHitter
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30 Fritz Peterson pitched a twohit shutout to night, the first complete game by a Yankee hurler this spring, and defeated the Montreal Ex pos, 40. The Expos had al ready won an afternoon game in West Palm Beach, 51, from the Atlanta Braves, but used different players in the night game, although the squad was not split into A and B units.

title: WESTGATE IS NAMED IN $300MILLION SUIT
description: SAN DIEGO, March 30 (AP) The Westgate California Cor poration and its president, C. Arnholt Smith, are accused of violating the Securities Ex change Act of 1934 in a $300 million damage suit filed in Federal District Court by a 20 share stockholder.

title: ExGov. Nunn Is in Race For Senator in Kentucky
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 30 Former Gov. Louie B. Nunn strode into the state capitol 28 minutes before the midnight deadline and filed last night to run for Senator in the Repub lican primary. Minutes later, John Y. Brown Jr., the fried chicken millionaire, who had been considering entering the Democratic primary, drove away from the premises with out filing.

title: Anxiety Growing at Stevenson High Over Gangs and Violence at School
description: Conditions at the Bronx's newest high school, Adlai E. Stevenson, which is plagued by gangs and troubled by violence, are causing growing anxiety among students, parents and community officials.

title: Markets Close Today
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges and the over thecounter market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday, along with re gional exchanges. Commodity markets will also be closed. Most overseas markets are also planning to close for the holi day. Banks here will remain open.

title: LILCO Is Granted A 23% Rate Rise; Totals $5.6Million
description: ALBANY, March 30  The Public Service Commission to day authorized the Long Island Lighting Company to impose an average electricity rate in crease of 2.3 per cent on 800,000 customers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Studying Protocol Problems And Other Issues of Soviet Trip
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The giant United States Gov ernment machine is slowly gear ing itself for President Nixon's trip to Moscow in May.

title: 21 Noble Splash Gives Mallano First Winner
description: With John Mallano riding to victory for the first time in his career, Mrs. Lafayette E. Thomas's Noble Splash took the fecture race at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Ronan Letter to Port Unit
description: Following is the text of a letter by Dr. William J. Ro nan, chairman of the Metro politan Transit Authority, to W. Paul Stillman, chairman of the selection committee of the Port of New York Author ity, withdrawing his name from consideration for the post of executive director of the Port Authority:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 30 (AP)Representative Wilbur D. Mills filed today as a Demo cratic candidate for reelection to an 18th term. Mr. Mills, 63 years old, who has no an nounced opponent, did not file in person but had his papers delivered to the Secretary of State's office. Mr. Mills is also a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President. He is permitted to seek both offices under recent state law.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Rep. Goldwater Weds Miss Gherman
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., March 30Fortyeight hours before their wedding today, Representative Barry M. Goldwater Jr., Republican of California, and Susan Lee Gherman changed churches in order to be married to the strains of their favorite con temporary music.

title: The Stage
description: Pinocchio is back. No, not the brilliant, animated Disney movie but a lifesized, musical puppet version, of all things, that works surpris ingly well. Youngsters and their parents last night at the Felt Forum, where the show will run through April 9, seemed to have a fine time. So did we.

title: JOHN M. VALLEAU
description: TEANECK, N. J., March 30 John M. Valleau, who retired in 1964 as a partner in Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, New York Stock Eicchangei house, died of a heart attack yesterday while visiting his daughter, Mrs. Janice Winkle man, in Pittsburgh. He was 77 years old and lived at 5281 Standish Road.

title: Bases Heavily Shelled
description: SAIGON,South Vietnam, March 30Communist gunners and ground troops staged a se ries of heavy, apparently co ordinated attacks on eight South Vietnamese fire support bases along the demilitarized zone today, and the fighting re portedly continued into the night.

title: Subcontractor Denounces Indian Point APlant Work
description: A subcontractor who has built a key part of Consolidated Edison's new nuclear power plant at Indian Point, N. Y., has asked the Atomic Energy Com mission to withhold the licens ing of the reactor because of inadequate, incomplete and questionable design of parts of the reactor that pose a se rious problem of plant safety.

title: Advertising:
description: David A. Schwartz' bag is package testing. Or is it his package that is bag testing? Well, whichever it is he uses a tachistoscope to do it.

title: Paintings Stolen in Paris
description: PARIS, March 30Five im pressionist paintings and a Calder mobile were stolen from an art gallery in downtown Paris in broad daylight yester day. The value of the works, which are insured, has been estimated at at least $600,000. The thieves made off with their loot at lunchtime.

title: ASHTON M. TENNEY
description: RYE, N. Y., March 30 Ashton Melville Tenney, a re tired textile engineer who had worked for the Eastman Kodak Company for many years, died yesterday in the United Hos pital, Port Chester. He was 83 years old and lived at 332 For est Avenue.

title: Final Arguments Set Today In Chaplain's CourtMartial
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 30 (AP)Testimony ended to day in the courtmartial of Comdr. Andrew F. Jensen, a Navy chaplain, on a charge of misconduct by adultery. The case is expected to go to the jury tomorrow.

title: MERCHANDISE COSTS HIGHER IN FEBRUARY
description: Prices advertised by depart ment, specialty and general merchandise stores averaged 2.6 per cent higher in February than in the same month a year before, according to the Adver tising Bureau, a division of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: Retarded Man Missing Here
description: A distraught father appealed yesterday for help in locating his severely retarded son, miss ing since Tuesday night when the son went to the circus at Madison Square Garden with a group from the Suffolk State School. The missing man is Raymond de la Bastide Jr., 28 years old. His father, who lives at 2569 Ocean Avenue, Bell more, L. I., said his son suffers from congenital heart disease. He can answer to his name, but not speak otherwise. He was described as 5 feet 9 inches tall, 150 pounds, light coin plexioned, with light broorn hair and blue eyes.

title: Bridge: Yonkers Players Gain Share Of Swiss Team Championship
description: Although the Vanderbilt Cup, with 64 teams com peting, was the prestige event in the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in Cincinnati last week, it was numerically overshadowed by the Swiss teams, which attracted 224 teams for two days of play.

title: Rome to Drop RushHour Fares; Plans to Bar Autos from Center
description: ROME, March 30Rome's City Hall announced today that bus and streetcar fares would be permanently abolished dur ing rush hours.

title: NIXON AIDES SEEK LESS WITHHOLDING OF TAX FOR MANY
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 At least 40 million families and individuals are having too much Federal income tax withheld this year, and the question of what to do about the problem has started an intense dispute within the Nixon Administra tion.

title: Senator Buckley, Backs L.I. Man
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 30Senator James L. Buckley today made his first endorse ment of a local candidate since he was elected to office in 1970. He backed a Conserva tive incumbent Assemblyman, Charles Jerabek.

title: C.A.B. APPROVES RISE IN I.A.T.A. AIR FARES
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a series of international airline agree ments providing for fare in creases ranging from onehalf of 1 per cent to 10 per cent.

title: Lindsay and Jackson Pressing For Wisconsin Crossover Votes
description: MILWAUKEE, March 30 Several Democratic contenders in Wisconsin's crowded Presi dential primary Tuesday, their strength within the party frag mented by their sheer numbers, stepped up today their efforts to stimulate and then capture a big Republican crossover vote.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: KIEL, Wis.There are 12 candidates on the Democratic ballot in Tuesday's Wisconsin Presidential primary, but only three seem to excite Kiel, a city of 2,858 in the dairy country northwest of She boygan ("home of world champion cheddar cheese, says a sign outside town).

title: Executive Changes
description: The Marine Midland BankNew York has electedRichard R. Linkas senior vice president and controller and Edgar J. Roberts Jr. as senior vice president in charge of the Far East region of the International banking department.

title: Adirondack Challenge
description: The Horizon Corporation, an Arizona land sales com pany, is reported to be buying an extensive privately owned tract in the Adirondack Park with the intention of subdividing it into lots of oneandahalf and two acres. The intention is to provide some 30,000 people with the luxury of second homescomplete with access roads, golf courses and skiing facilitiesin an undis guised assault on a primeval area of forest and wetland. As though this were not enough, of an affront to the greatest wilderness east of the Mississippi, the corpora tion hopes to make two or three artificial lakes by damming up the scenic Grass River.

title: Gabriel Heatter,Radio Newsman,Dies
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 30Gabriel Heatter, the radio commentator whose unfailingly optimistic news broadcasts brought World War II into the American living room, died here early today of pneumonia. lie was 82 years old.

title: POLICE IDENTIFY 2 SLAIN IN JERSEY
description: HOLMDEL TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 30A man who was found shot to death with a girl in a gully here last Monday was identified today as one who had a criminal record on Long Island.

title: The Extraterrestrial Imperative
description: DOWNEY, Calif.Man's nature is attuned to an infinite, indestructible world. Earth has ceased to be such a world, and therein lies the great crisis of our time.

title: RIRIEWOODBURY IN DANCE DEBUT
description: Healthy variety and good, craftsmanship rather than or iginality marked the New York debut of the RirieWoodbury Dance Company from Salt Lake City Wednesday night at the LouisNikolais Dance Theater Lab, 344 West 36th Street.

title: West German City Widens Quarantine To Fight Smallpox
description: HANOVER, West Germany, March 30 (Reuters) Health authorities here today quar antined 193 more people known to have been in contact with a Yugoslav migrant worker suffering from smallpox, raising the total isolated to nearly 450.

title: Rail TonMileage Gains
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic last week totaled an estimated 15.2 billion ton miles, up 1.9 per cent from a year before. Carloadings for the week totaled 504,613, down 2.3 per cent.

title: RACKET WITNESS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: The owner of one of the most lucrative restaurantnight clubs in Queens, a key witness in an investigation of organ ized crime in that borough, was shot to death early yester day morning within 15 feet of where more than a dozen per sons were in motel rooms.

title: Puerto Rico Judge Allows Rock Fete but Bars Drugs
description: SAN JUAN. P. R., March 30 (AP)  A judge reversed him self today and gave the go ahead for an Easter weekend rock music festival.

title: STOKES TO DECLINE TO BE A DELEGATE
description: Former Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland, recently signed by the National Broadcasting Company as coanchorman of WNBCTV's 6 P.M. newscasts, said yesterday that in view of his contract he would not serve as a delegate to the Demo cratic Convention if elected.

title: Wilkins Denies Defending Plants in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, March 30Roy Wilkins, executive director of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People, today challenged interpretations placed by news agencies on his recent remarks about Unit ed States business involvement in South Africa.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Moved by some strange compulsion to revisit the scene, Bob Short returned to Washington the other day to tell 400 listeners in the National Press Club why he took their baseball team to Texas. They paid $4 each to hear him, which is a measure of inflation; six months ago, $3.50 would have enabled them to watch Frank Howard swing a bat.

title: LAKERS SET BACK BULLS BY 131124
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers rallied in the final four minutes and scored 10 straight points to beat the Chicago Bulls, 131. 124, tonight and take a 20 lead in their Western Conference semifinal playoff series.

title: Advertising:
description: Soft Drink Industry, a trade magazine, is going to extend its coverage to beer, bottled water and noncar bonated beverages, and it will increase its controlled circulation from 9,587 to 11, 129. It will also change its name.

title: Bolstering Papadopoulos
description: One week after Colonel Papadopoulos appointed him self Regent of Greece in addition to his jobs as Premier, Foreign Minister and Defense Minister, the United States agreed to sell him 36 Phantom jet fighterbombers. Thus did Washington once again act in a way bound to help shore up the Athens dictatorship at a time when it was obviously undergoing some strain.

title: ExNewburger Partner Fined by the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had censured and levied a $25,000 fine against a former managing partner of Newburg er, Loeb & Co. and had barred him from having any associa tion with any clearing member firm without prior approval from the exchange.

title: A Theater on Broadway Sold to Harkness Ballet
description: A new dance theater will be opened next fall in the Lin coln Center area to house the Harkness Ballet and other performing groups.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, March 30 (UPI) Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minne sota, announced today the Cabi net he would name if he were elected President. It contains two women, two blacks and one SpanishAmerican.

title: Notes on People
description: Bernard Malamnd, William Styron, and John Updike have been appointed honor ary consultants in American letters at the Library of Con gress for the next three years. L. Quincy Mumford, Librarian of Congress, said the three writers will advise on acquisitions of literary works, with particular em phasis on manuscripts and foreign books in the field of belles lettres. They'll also be called on to recommend projects for bibliographic work, and to recommend critics and scholars to carry out such projects.

title: U. S. Taking Precautions
description: ATLANTA, MaMrch 30 (UPI) The National Center for Disease Control said today that strict foreign quarantine meas ures are being taken to avoid a spread of smallpox from Yugoslavia into the United States.

title: 42 Years of Heavenly Dining End For Patriarch of the Cloud Club
description: Daniel K. Ludwig, the pub licityshy shipbuilder, sent his regrets and warm regards in a handdelivered letter. James Foley, former vice chairman of Texaco, sent a telegram. Rob ert C. Hills, former president of Freeport Sulphur, and Joel Hunter, once president of Cru cible Steel, wrote from retire ment in New Orleans and Del ray.

title: Jersey Doctor Defies Stae By Performing Abortions
description: NEWARK, March 30  A prominent Bergen County phy sician disclosed here today that he had performed two abor tions this morning at his Engle wood Cliffs office, in defiance of a directive by the. State Attorney General that such abortions were still a criminal act in New Jersey.

title: Stanley F. Rose Weds gmily Ciner in Peru
description: Miss Emily Carol Ciner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Ciner of Scars dale, N. Y., was married March 23 to Stanley Frazer Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley DeLurey Rose of Falls Church, Va. The civil ceremony was performed in the Miraflores City Hall in Lima, Peru, where the bride groom is a lawyer with the corporate advisory depart ment of Price Waterhouse Peat & Co.

title: President's War Powers
description: Senator Javits is indulging in Nixonian hyperbole when he asserts that his War Powers Act, currently before the Senate, is one of the most important pieces of legisla tion in the national security field that has come before the Senate in this century. The act merely attempts to spell out powers which Congress has always enjoyed under the Constitution but which successive Congresses, especially in recent years, have allowed dangerously to erode. Unless Congress acts more responsibly than it did, for example, in 1964 when the Tonkin Gulf Resolution was hastily adopted without serious challenge, the War Powers Act is not likely to prove effective in checking the arbitrary extension of Presidential authority in the warmaking field.

title: Leaders in Senate Oppose Diverting WarPowers Bill.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 Senator John Stennis, Chairman of the Armed Services Commit tee, and Senator Mike Mans field, the majority leader, to day opposed moves to divert to the Senate Judiciary Commit tee a bill defining the Presi dent's warmaking powers. Such a diversion is favored by the Nixon Administration.

title: TRADING ERRATIC IN MEAT FUTURES
description: Trading in meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Ex change yesterday was described by a Chicago commodity broker as nervous. He said there was no doubt that trading was affected by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally's re cent meeting with heads of major supermarket chains in an effort to stabilize rising mea prices at the consumer level.

title: Port Notes
description: Although seafaring has traditionally ranked high among the nation's most dangerous jobs, the number of illnesses and injuries re ported aboard oceangoing American flag ships in 1971 dropped to the lowest level in at least 20 years. At the same time, the number of seamen's jobs available dropped to the lowest level since 1937, when the Marine Index Bureau first began keeping records on injury rates for the industry.
